title: The 10 Hottest Semiconductor Startups Of 2023
summary: CRN highlights the 10 hottest semiconductor startups of 2023, showcasing companies that are challenging established players in AI computing, addressing memory and data transfer bottlenecks, and innovating in cloud-native processors and telecom. These startups have achieved significant milestones this year, including major funding rounds, product launches, and growing customer and partner momentum, positioning them for success in a rapidly evolving industry. The article details each company's offerings and recent achievements.

title: Astera Labs IPO, an overview
summary: Astera Labs, founded in 2017, specializes in connectivity solutions for data-centric systems, particularly for cloud and AI infrastructure. The company is preparing for an IPO in 2024, with Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase & Co. as lead underwriters. Astera Labs' competitive advantage lies in its innovative products for accelerated computing and its strategic use of cloud environments for product design, distinguishing it from competitors like Credo, Trenton Systems, and Magma.

title: Qorvo to sell Chinese assembly, test factories to Luxshare ...
summary: Qorvo Inc. has agreed to sell its assembly and test facilities in Beijing and Dezhou, China, to Luxshare Precision Industry Co. Ltd. The deal includes Luxshare acquiring the facilities' assets, operations, and workforce, while Qorvo will continue to be supplied through a long-term agreement. This move allows Qorvo to streamline its manufacturing network while Luxshare expands its role in the electronics manufacturing services sector, particularly within the Apple supply chain.

title: Are the Chips Down for First Trust Nasdaq Semiconductor ETF?
summary: The First Trust Nasdaq Semiconductor ETF (FTXL) has seen a significant 52.7% rise year-to-date, fueled by strong performances from top holdings like Intel and Qualcomm. Despite a challenging period for chipmakers, the global chip sector is forecasted to grow by 13.1% in 2024, though some analysts and investors express concerns about the sector being overheated. Intel's new Core Ultra processors and substantial investments in R&D and manufacturing are seen as positive drivers for the industry.

title: The Best Artificial Intelligence ETFs of 2023
summary: The article highlights the top-performing Artificial Intelligence (AI) ETFs of 2023, with returns as high as 71%. It details five specific AI ETFs, including thematic funds that invest in companies benefiting from AI growth and AI-powered funds that use AI to select stocks, identifying key holdings and year-to-date performance for each.

title: CACI International (CACI) Secures $64M U.S. Air Force Contract
summary: CACI International (CACI) has secured a five-year task order valued at up to $64 million from the U.S. Air Force to provide life cycle hardware and systems engineering support for the Distributed Common Ground System (DCGS). This contract aims to enhance agile and effective quick reaction capabilities for ground stations and improve intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance operations. This win is part of a continuous flow of significant contracts for CACI from various government agencies, bolstering its reputation as a key defense contractor.

title: Lisa Su’s net worth: How she saved AMD & built her wealth
summary: This article details Lisa Su's background, her impact as CEO of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), and how she built her net worth. It covers her engineering career, her strategies to diversify AMD's product portfolio and financial recovery, and her compensation, highlighting that her wealth primarily comes from AMD stock holdings. The article also touches upon AMD's stock performance under her leadership and her status relative to being a billionaire.

title: AMD releases new chips to power faster AI training
summary: AMD announced the availability of its new MI300 chips, including the Instinct MI300X accelerator and Instinct M1300A APU, designed to power demanding AI training and large language models. The company also unveiled the Ryzen 8040 mobile processors, which will bring enhanced AI capabilities to laptops in 2024. These releases position AMD to compete more directly with Nvidia in the booming AI chip market.

title: Meta Platforms, IBM create industrywide AI alliance to share technology
summary: Meta Platforms and IBM are leading an industry-wide AI Alliance of over 40 companies and organizations to promote open-source artificial intelligence development. The coalition aims to share technology, reduce risks, and focus on responsible AI development, including safety and security tools. This initiative seeks to increase open-source AI models and foster collaboration with academic researchers.

title: NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) Morgan Stanley Raises Target Forecast
summary: Morgan Stanley has increased its 12-month target price for NVIDIA Corporation (NVDA) from $235.00 to $250.00, while re-iterating an "Overweight" rating. This upgrade indicates strong confidence in NVIDIA's fundamentals, driven by AI and data-center demand, despite market concerns about U.S.–China export restrictions and competitive pressures. The target hike acts as a counterweight to bearish sentiment, suggesting the recent stock pullback may be overdone relative to NVIDIA’s long-term earnings potential.

title: Amkor to build $2 billion semiconductor testing plant in Peoria. 2,000 jobs promised
summary: Amkor Technology Inc. plans to build a $2 billion advanced semiconductor packaging and testing facility in Peoria, Arizona, creating approximately 2,000 jobs. The plant will partner with TSMC, testing chips produced for Apple Inc., and is expected to begin production within two to three years. This investment is seen as a significant step in bolstering the U.S. semiconductor supply chain and is supported by the CHIPS and Science Act.

title: Amkor Announces U.S. Advanced Packaging and Test Facility In Peoria
summary: Amkor Technology, Inc. announced a $2 billion investment to build an advanced packaging and test facility in Peoria, Arizona, creating 2,000 new jobs. This facility will be the largest outsourced advanced packaging facility in the US, bolstering America's national security and semiconductor supply chain. Apple will be the first and largest customer, and Amkor has applied for CHIPS funding to support the project.

title: Diamond Sleet supply chain compromise distributes a modified CyberLink installer
summary: Microsoft Threat Intelligence has uncovered a supply chain attack by the North Korea-based threat actor Diamond Sleet (formerly ZINC). This attack involves a modified CyberLink application installer that includes malicious code and has impacted over 100 devices globally. Microsoft has taken steps to protect customers, including notifying CyberLink and adding the malicious certificate to its disallowed list, while also providing detection and mitigation guidance.

title: AES in talks to sell major coal-fired power plant in Vietnam: sources
summary: US energy firm AES Corp. is reportedly in discussions to sell its majority stake in Vietnam's 1.2 gigawatt Mong Duong 2 coal-fired power plant to Czech energy firm Sev.en Global Investments as part of its global strategy to divest coal assets by 2025. South Korea's Posco International, the second-largest shareholder, is also considering selling its 30% stake. The potential sale aligns with Vietnam's goal to end coal power generation by 2050, and AES itself plans to build an LNG terminal and gas-fired power plant in the country.

title: China's Zeekr reveals wider loss in US IPO paperwork, Geely shares fall
summary: China's Zeekr Intelligent revealed wider losses for the first half of the year as it made its US IPO paperwork public, intending to use the funds to expand its product line. Shares in its parent company, Geely, fell on the news. Zeekr reported a net loss of 3.87 billion Chinese yuan ($531.34 million) for the six months ended June 30, though net revenue more than doubled.

title: After Earnings, Is AMD Stock a Buy, a Sell, or Fairly Valued?
summary: Morningstar assesses AMD's stock post-Q3 earnings, evaluating its fair value, economic moat, and future prospects, particularly in the AI accelerator market. The company's target of over $2 billion in AI accelerator revenue for 2024 positions it as a significant player. While fair value is estimated at $125 per share, high uncertainty exists due to competition from Nvidia and potential shifts in the x86 architecture dominance.

title: Investing in Semiconductor ETFs & Stocks
summary: This article explores investing in semiconductor ETFs and stocks, detailing the sector's evolution, market dynamics, and future outlook, especially concerning AI. It highlights semiconductors' crucial role in modern technology, the economic powerhouse of the industry, and the benefits of investing via ETFs for diversification and accessibility. The piece also discusses factors influencing the sector, including geopolitical efforts to secure supply chains and the profound impact of AI on semiconductor demand and innovation.

title: On-device AI chips: New battleground for chipmakers
summary: Global chipmakers like Samsung Electronics, Qualcomm, Intel, and AMD are intensifying their focus on on-device AI chips for smartphones, laptops, and PCs, recognizing its potential for customized services, lower costs, and enhanced privacy compared to generative AI. This shift is expected to drive significant growth in AI-enabled consumer electronics and contribute to rising memory chip prices. Both on-device AI and generative AI are seen as complementary, with companies like Samsung planning to integrate both into future smart devices.
source: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition
source_domain: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition

title: SolarWinds hack explained: Everything you need to know
summary: The SolarWinds hack, identified as one of the largest cybersecurity breaches, involved malicious code injected into its Orion IT monitoring software, affecting thousands of organizations including the U.S. government. Suspected Russian nation-state hackers, referred to as Nobelium, gained widespread access, leading to significant investigations and legal actions against SolarWinds. The incident highlighted critical vulnerabilities in supply chain security and spurred new cybersecurity initiatives and regulations, such as the mandating of Software Bill of Materials (SBOMs).

title: Analysts Offer Insights on Technology Companies: Confluent (CFLT), Western Digital (WDC) and Intel (INTC)
summary: This article summarizes recent analyst ratings for several technology companies: Confluent (CFLT), Western Digital (WDC), and Intel (INTC). J.P. Morgan maintained a Buy rating on Confluent, Rosenblatt Securities reiterated a Buy on Western Digital, and Morgan Stanley held a Hold rating on Intel. The article details price targets, analyst success rates, and consensus ratings for each company.

title: Nvidia to take on Intel, Qualcomm with Arm-based processors for PC; availability pegged for 2025
summary: Nvidia is developing Arm-based processors for personal computers, aiming to compete with Intel and Qualcomm, with availability expected as soon as 2025. This move intensifies competition in the PC chip market, especially as AMD is also reportedly working on Arm-based processors for PCs. The initiative follows Apple's successful transition to in-house Arm-based chips, boosting Mac sales, and poses a significant challenge to Intel's dominant position.

title: Oracle spends more than $100 million on Ampere chips
summary: Oracle Corp has agreed to prepay $104.1 million for processor chips from startup Ampere Computing and also invested $400 million in Ampere in its fiscal 2023. This investment and chip purchases are intended to give Oracle's cloud services a competitive edge against rivals like Amazon.com and Google, which develop their own server chips. Ampere designs custom server chips based on Arm technology, competing with Intel and Advanced Micro Devices.

title: Cisco to buy cybersecurity firm Splunk for $28 billion
summary: Cisco Systems agreed to acquire cybersecurity firm Splunk for approximately $28 billion, marking its largest-ever deal aimed at bolstering its software business and leveraging the AI boom. This acquisition is expected to reduce Cisco's reliance on its networking equipment business and accelerate revenue growth and gross margin expansion. Despite potential antitrust scrutiny, both companies anticipate the deal, valued at $157 per share for Splunk, to close by the end of the third quarter of 2024.

title: Goldman Sachs Physical Gold ETF ETF Price, Holdings, & News (CBOE:AAAU)
summary: The Goldman Sachs Physical Gold ETF (AAAU) tracks the LBMA Gold Price index, investing in physical gold bars held in Perth, Australia. It offers investors exposure to gold spot prices, with shares redeemable for gold coins and small bars. AAAU was launched on July 26, 2018, and has seen its shares increase by 65.1% this year, trading at $42.82.

title: How Applied Materials and Intel are helping chipmakers buy clean power
summary: Applied Materials and Intel are co-sponsoring the Catalyze program, run by Schneider Electric, to accelerate access to renewable energy for semiconductor supply chain companies. The program aims to help chipmakers decouple their growth from environmental impact by making it easier for their suppliers to purchase clean power through aggregated power purchase agreements. This initiative seeks to educate suppliers and provide a platform for smaller entities to participate in the renewable energy market, ultimately reducing Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions across the industry.

title: Mobileye completes follow on offering
summary: Mobileye Global Inc. announced the pricing of a previously announced underwritten secondary public offering of 38,500,000 shares of its Class A common stock by Intel Overseas Funding Corporation at $42.00 per share, totaling US$1.6 billion. The offering is expected to close on June 12, 2023, with RBC Capital acting as joint bookrunner. The selling stockholder also granted underwriters a 30-day option for an additional 5,775,000 shares.

title: GlobalFoundries opens $4 billion Singapore expansion fab to meet 'demand for essential semiconductor chips'
summary: GlobalFoundries has opened a $4 billion fabrication plant in Singapore to meet the increasing global demand for essential semiconductor chips, particularly for automotive, AI, and industrial sectors. This expansion will significantly boost the company's manufacturing capacity and create approximately 1,000 new jobs in Singapore. Despite current weakness in consumer-related demand, GlobalFoundries CEO Thomas Caulfield anticipates a doubling of the industry over the next decade due to new applications and AI's impact.

title: SOXQ ETF: Huawei's Latest Phone And Implication For Semis Stocks
summary: Huawei has launched the Mate 60, a new 5G smartphone, signaling its recovery from past sanctions and strengthening China's semiconductor industry. This development poses competitive risks for holdings within the Invesco PHLX Semiconductor ETF (SOXQ). Given these implications for the semiconductor market, the author maintains a "Hold" position on SOXQ.

title: 10 Best Semiconductor ETFs
summary: This article identifies and discusses the 10 best semiconductor ETFs based on 5-year share price performance, providing insight into the semiconductor market's recent performance and future outlook. It highlights key companies within these ETFs and analyst perspectives on the industry's recovery and growth drivers such as AI and automotive demand.

title: Intel’s Terminated $5.4B Tower Acquisition: 5 Big Things To Know
summary: Intel terminated its $5.4 billion acquisition of Tower Semiconductor due to regulatory approval issues, a setback for CEO Pat Gelsinger's IDM 2.0 strategy and Intel Foundry Services. The deal's failure, possibly due to U.S.-China geopolitical tensions, resulted in a $353 million termination fee. Despite this, Intel remains committed to its foundry business, aiming to become the second-largest global external foundry by 2030, though Tower's capacity and customer base would have provided a significant boost.

title: Supermicro Announces High Volume Production of E3.S All-Flash Storage Portfolio with New CXL Memory Expansion Offerings
summary: Supermicro is commencing high-volume production of its E3.S all-flash storage portfolio, which includes new CXL memory expansion offerings. These solutions support PCIe Gen5 drives and CXL memory modules to meet the demands of large AI Training and HPC clusters. The company's Petascale systems are a new class of storage servers designed for high-throughput, low-latency storage, available with Intel Xeon Scalable or AMD EPYC processors.

title: Mobile chip giant Qualcomm shares slide amid worst smartphone slump in years
summary: Qualcomm shares fell after the company gave a tepid sales forecast for the current quarter, indicating continued weak demand for mobile devices, especially in China which accounts for over 60% of its sales. The company plans further job cuts, having already recorded US$285 million in restructuring charges, as it takes a conservative view of the market amidst an industry downturn. This performance underperformed a broader chip industry rally, raising concerns about the smartphone market's recovery.

title: AMD stock rises 3% after earnings beat, CEO predicts ‘multiple winners’ in AI race
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) shares rose 2.7% after hours following an earnings beat, with its CEO predicting "multiple winners" in the AI race. The company's PC sales slightly exceeded estimates, while data-center sales were just under projections. This performance follows Intel Corp.'s recent report of a data-center beat and strong PC sales.

title: AMD earnings preview: Is the company ceding ground to Intel?
summary: This article previews AMD's upcoming earnings report, questioning whether the company is losing market share to Intel. Historically, Intel's struggles have benefited AMD, but Intel's recent performance suggests a potential shift. Wall Street will be looking for confirmation of this trend in AMD's latest quarterly results.

title: U.S. chipmaker AMD to invest $400 million in India by 2028
summary: U.S. chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices (AMD.O) announced a significant investment of $400 million in India over the next five years, including the establishment of its largest design center in Bengaluru, creating 3,000 new engineering jobs. This move aligns with India's efforts to become a chipmaking hub, attracting other major players like Applied Materials and Micron with its incentive programs. AMD's expansion underscores the country's growing importance in the global semiconductor industry.

title: Odisha is all set to be a Global IT & Semiconductor hotspot, here’s how
summary: Odisha is poised to become a global IT and Semiconductor hotspot, attracting significant investment intentions from major IT and Semiconductor MNCs. A delegation from the Government of Odisha met with top Silicon Valley industry leaders, resulting in commitments for an HDI-PCB manufacturing facility worth approximately Rs. 4,360 crore (~530 million USD) and Offshore Development Centers from Integreon and iOPEX. The state also plans collaborations for 5G, Industry 4.0, and semiconductor design education, aiming to create numerous employment opportunities.

title: Arizona State University, Applied Materials partner to create $270M Materials-to-Fab Center
summary: Arizona State University and Applied Materials, Inc. are partnering to create a $270 million Materials-to-Fab Center at ASU Research Park in Tempe. This facility will provide hands-on learning and research opportunities on leading-edge semiconductor equipment, bridging the gap between academic research and prototyping. The initiative aims to accelerate discovery, develop next-generation processes, and strengthen the semiconductor workforce in Arizona and the U.S.

title: Aehr Reports Record Revenue and Profit for Fiscal 2023 and Guides for Over 50% Increase in Revenue for Fiscal 2024 on Strength from Semiconductor Wafer Level Test and Burn-in Demand
summary: Aehr Test Systems announced record financial results for fiscal 2023, with net sales reaching $65.0 million and GAAP net income of $14.6 million, driven by demand for semiconductor wafer level test and burn-in products. The company also provided strong guidance for fiscal 2024, projecting revenue of at least $100 million, a 50% increase, and GAAP net income of at least $28 million, reflecting over 90% growth. This growth is attributed to increased adoption of their FOX systems and WaferPak Contactors for silicon carbide in electric vehicles, as well as new opportunities in silicon photonics and gallium nitride markets.

title: Under pressure, but thriving: What makes Druck pivot pioneers?
summary: Druck, a pressure sensing device manufacturer, has successfully navigated recent market uncertainties by pivoting into new industries like semiconductors and electric vehicles, adapting from its traditional aviation focus. The company has invested in automation, tackled supply chain disruptions, and is committed to talent development and achieving net-zero emissions, demonstrating resilience and strategic growth in challenging times.

title: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. – More market share gains expected
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) is expected to gain further market share in the data center CPU market and capitalize on opportunities to expand its presence in the data center GPU market due to increased generative AI adoption. The company's margins are projected to grow post-acquisition of Xilinx and Pensando, driven by increasing revenue contributions from its Data Centre and Embedded segments. Phillip Securities Research initiates coverage with an Accumulate recommendation and a target price of US$125.00, anticipating marginal revenue growth in FY23e and re-acceleration in FY24e.

title: China, chips & US dispute: Wolfspeed, Triad-based Qorvo paying the price
summary: Wolfspeed CEO Gregg Lowe is navigating renewed challenges with China regarding semiconductor exports, reminiscent of issues in 2019. This comes as China bans exports of key materials like gallium and germanium, which are crucial for Wolfspeed and Qorvo's chip production. The ban, effective August 1st, has already impacted the stock prices of both companies and is a major point of discussion during Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's visit to Beijing.

title: Netherlands-based ASML Holding Remains the Central Player in the Global Chip Supply Chain
summary: ASML Holding, a Netherlands-based company, is the sole provider of crucial photolithography systems and extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography machines essential for manufacturing computer chips, making it a central player in the global chip supply chain. The company faces significant challenges and opportunities amidst ongoing "Chip Wars" and export controls, particularly regarding its sales to the Chinese market. ASML is considering creating China-specific versions of its lithography tools to comply with export regulations while maintaining market access, highlighting the complex geopolitical landscape influencing semiconductor manufacturing.

title: Stock of the week - Advanced Micro Devices (29.06.2023)
summary: This article discusses the potential impact of new US chip export restrictions to China on Advanced Micro Devices (AMD). While such restrictions negatively affected semiconductor stocks, AMD's exposure may be limited as China's share of its revenue has significantly decreased. The article also compares AMD's stock performance to Nvidia and Intel, noting Nvidia's stronger recovery from the 2022 sell-off.

title: Chipmaker Micron beats on demand from booming AI, easing glut
summary: Micron Technology exceeded third-quarter revenue estimates driven by high demand for its memory chips in the rapidly expanding artificial intelligence sector and an easing supply glut in traditional markets. The company's shares rose over 2% after reporting stronger-than-expected earnings and anticipating improved pricing trends. Despite ongoing U.S.-China tech tensions impacting its presence in the Chinese market, Micron expressed confidence in the memory industry's recovery.

title: Artificial Intelligence Opens a Generational Opportunity for Chipmakers
summary: The article discusses how the expansion of AI applications, especially large language models, is creating a "generational opportunity" for chipmakers. It highlights the projected growth of AI chip spending to nearly $165 billion by the end of the decade, primarily benefiting GPU-based chip providers like Nvidia, and notes that the demand for specialized AI hardware is leading to significant investments, partnerships, and a potential "long capital investment cycle" for the semiconductor industry. The article also examines how this shift will impact traditional CPU providers and accelerate the replacement of legacy computing infrastructure with AI-first hardware.

title: Applied Materials: 2023 TIME100 Most Influential Companies | TIME
summary: Applied Materials, the largest maker of machines that produce semiconductors, was recognized in TIME's 2023 TIME100 Most Influential Companies list. The company announced plans to invest up to $4 billion to build the EPIC Center in Silicon Valley, an R&D campus aimed at rebuilding U.S. influence in chipmaking. This facility will provide advanced tools and space for university researchers and chipmakers like Intel and Samsung, potentially housing $25 billion of research in its first decade with anticipated federal CHIPS Act funding.

title: AMD's AI chip challenge to Nvidia remains uphill fight with no big customers named
summary: AMD unveiled new details about its MI300X artificial intelligence chip, designed to challenge Nvidia's market dominance, but did not announce any major customers for the product. While the chip offers significant memory capacity aimed at cost reduction for AI services, the lack of customer commitments disappointed Wall Street, causing AMD's stock to fall. Analysts noted that Nvidia's strong market position is reinforced by its software ecosystem, which AMD is attempting to counter with its Rocm platform.

title: AMD launches new Instinct MI300X AI chip to take on Nvidia’s GPUs
summary: AMD has launched its new Instinct MI300X AI accelerator chip, designed to compete with Nvidia's GPUs in the generative AI market. The company also introduced its Infinity Architecture Platform, powered by eight MI300X chips, and its ROCm software ecosystem. Despite these announcements, AMD's stock fell due to a lack of major customer endorsements for the new chips and details on pricing.

title: AMD launches new data-center AI chips, software to go up against Nvidia and Intel
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) unveiled new data-center AI chips and software, including the Instinct MI300X accelerator and MI300A, to compete with Nvidia Corp. and Intel Corp. Despite these announcements at its Data Center & AI Technology Premiere event, AMD's stock declined, finishing down 3.6%. The new products are specifically aimed at handling generative-AI workloads.

title: Applied Materials Announces $4 Billion Investment In EPIC Center For R&D Collaboration
summary: Applied Materials is investing $4 billion into its new Equipment and Process Innovation and Commercialization (EPIC) Center, a collaborative R&D project designed to accelerate semiconductor production techniques. This initiative aims to reduce the time from foundational research to mass commercialization by 30% through overlapping R&D phases and fostering direct collaboration between universities, equipment makers, and chip companies. The EPIC Center will strengthen Applied Materials' position in the industry, benefit chip makers with faster product roadmaps, and provide invaluable learning opportunities for university students.

title: Here’s how Applied Materials manages supply chain and semiconductor research
summary: Applied Materials plans to invest US$4 billion over seven years into a collaborative R&D facility in Silicon Valley, the Equipment and Process Innovation and Commercialization (EPIC) Center, to accelerate semiconductor technology development. The company emphasizes the critical role of R&D and collaboration in the semiconductor industry and discusses global supply chain changes and its investment strategy in the US and Singapore. Applied Materials also outlines its Singapore 2030 plan, focusing on manufacturing capacity expansion, deepening R&D, strengthening partnerships, and talent development, with Singapore serving as its sole Center of Excellence for advanced packaging.

title: Applied Materials' Big Bet: A ‘Unique’ $4B Chip R&D Center
summary: Applied Materials is investing up to $4 billion to build the "EPIC Center," a 180,000-square-foot semiconductor R&D facility in Silicon Valley. This unique center will bring together chipmakers, academics, and ecosystem partners to accelerate manufacturing innovation, reduce costs, and shorten product development timelines, especially crucial in the complex 'angstrom era' of chipmaking. The investment's final size is contingent on subsidies from the U.S. government’s CHIPS and Science Act.

title: Applied Materials plans to build US$4bn R&D center
summary: Applied Materials plans to invest up to US$4 billion to construct a new Research and Development (R&D) center in Silicon Valley, aiming to accelerate semiconductor manufacturing innovation. This "EPIC Center" would be the largest R&D facility in the semiconductor industry and is envisioned to speed up the transition of academic research to factory production, while also potentially leveraging funding from the US CHIPS and Science Act. The project seeks to address technical challenges and attract talent crucial for the industry's growth.

title: Applied Materials plans $4B Silicon Valley chip research facility
summary: Applied Materials plans to build a $4 billion chip research facility in Sunnyvale, California, part of a larger potential investment of up to $25 billion over 10 years, contingent on support from the CHIPS Act. This facility is expected to create 1,500 construction jobs and aims to accelerate semiconductor technology and manufacturing equipment research and development. The project signifies the CHIPS Act's success in attracting significant private investment back to the U.S. semiconductor industry.

title: Applied Materials to invest $4 bln in Silicon Valley chip research center
summary: Applied Materials announced plans to invest up to $4 billion in a new chip research center in Silicon Valley, aiming to accelerate semiconductor manufacturing advances. The facility, scheduled to open in 2026, will create up to 2,000 engineering jobs and host extensive research work in collaboration with universities and chipmakers. This investment aligns with the U.S. government's efforts to boost domestic semiconductor manufacturing through the CHIPS and Science Act.

title: Applied Materials Launches Multibillion-Dollar R&D Platform in Silicon Valley to Accelerate Semiconductor Innovation
summary: Applied Materials, Inc. announced a multibillion-dollar investment to build the Equipment and Process Innovation and Commercialization (EPIC) Center in Silicon Valley. This facility will be the world’s largest and most advanced for collaborative semiconductor process technology and manufacturing equipment R&D, aiming to accelerate innovation and reduce the time to commercialization for new technologies. The center will provide dedicated space for chipmakers and university researchers, fostering collaboration and addressing critical industry challenges like talent shortages and R&D costs.

title: Applied Materials plans $4B Silicon Valley R&D facility
summary: Applied Materials announced plans to invest up to $4 billion in a new Silicon Valley research and development facility. This "EPIC Center" will focus on advancing semiconductor manufacturing and is expected to house over $25 billion in research work within its first decade. The investment is contingent on receiving funding from the CHIPS and Science Act, aiming to accelerate the industry's ability to bring new technologies to market.

title: Supermicro Launches Industry's First NVIDIA HGX H100 8 and 4-GPU H100 Servers with Liquid Cooling -- Reduces Data Center Power Costs by Up to 40%
summary: Supermicro has launched the industry's first NVIDIA HGX H100 8 and 4-GPU servers featuring liquid cooling, designed to significantly reduce data center power costs by up to 40%. These new rack-scale solutions accelerate deployment and increase performance for AI and HPC workloads, while also lowering operating expenses and improving Power Usage Effectiveness (PUE) by up to 86% in direct cooling costs. The systems offer up to 30x performance improvement over previous generations for large transformer models and boast advanced features like PCIe 5.0 and NVIDA H100 SXM5 Tensor Core GPUs.

title: Implications and Updates From China’s National People’s Conference
summary: China's annual "Two Sessions" parliamentary meeting revealed strategic policies for economic growth, trade, and technology, targeting a 5% GDP growth in 2023 driven by domestic consumption. The conference highlighted key implications for sectors like EVs, clean energy, cloud computing, biotechnology, and semiconductors, emphasizing self-reliance and technological innovation. Government restructuring and increased focus on digital infrastructure and R&D are expected to significantly impact various industries and investment themes in China.

title: Beating the S&P 500 at Its Own Game
summary: This article examines the performance of equally weighted S&P 500 indexes compared to traditional cap-weighted indexes. While an early attempt by Dean Witter Reynolds in the 1980s failed due to high expenses and poor timing, the equally weighted strategy has significantly outgained the conventional index since 1998, primarily driven by its exposure to smaller companies rather than value stocks. The author concludes that equally weighted portfolios have merit despite their initial tarnished reputation.

title: Growing chip supply helps Baxter slash backlog
summary: Baxter International significantly reduced its backlog for Front Line Care products by half in Q1, thanks to an improved supply of electromechanical components, including semiconductor chips. This improved availability has allowed the healthcare company to reduce spot purchasing, lower costs, and enhance operational predictability, though an elevated backlog still remains which the company aims to address throughout the year. Despite facing continued pressure from rising supply chain costs from suppliers, Baxter expresses cautious optimism about turning the corner on component supply.

title: Cisco Business Model
summary: This article details Cisco's business model, which has evolved from primarily selling networking hardware to offering high-technology services and software. It covers the company's financial performance, revenue streams from hardware sales, licensing, and services, and strategic initiatives like acquisitions. The article also provides a SWOT analysis, outlines key competitors, and discusses Cisco's customer segments and value propositions.

title: Amkor Technology seeks to open Vietnam factory in fourth quarter
summary: U.S.-based Amkor Technology Inc. expects its mega facility in Bac Ninh, Vietnam, to begin first-phase manufacturing in the fourth quarter of this year. This factory, covering 1.9 million square feet, will be among Amkor's largest globally and represents a $1.6 billion investment until 2035. The move highlights Vietnam's growing importance as a manufacturing and R&D hub for major foreign electronics manufacturers.

title: according to the complaint.
summary: This article is a very short piece, simply stating "according to the complaint." and reporting that it was authored by Noah Zuss. It appears to be an internal reference or a placeholder snippet within a larger news reporting system, likely pertaining to a legal complaint.

title: GlobalFoundries sues IBM, says trade secrets were unlawfully given to Japan's Rapidus
summary: GlobalFoundries has filed a lawsuit against IBM, alleging that IBM unlawfully shared confidential intellectual property and trade secrets with Japan's Rapidus and Intel Corp. GlobalFoundries claims IBM is unjustly receiving substantial licensing income from these disclosures and is also seeking to halt IBM's recruitment of its engineers. IBM denies the allegations, calling the lawsuit "meritless."

title: Tower Semiconductor Announces First Quarter 2023 Earnings Release Date
summary: Tower Semiconductor (TSEM) announced that it will release its first-quarter 2023 earnings on May 15, 2023. The company will not provide guidance for Q2 2023 or hold an earnings conference call due to its ongoing transaction with Intel. Tower Semiconductor is a leading foundry in analog semiconductor solutions for various high-growth markets.

title: Artificial Intelligence in China: Implications and Opportunities
summary: The rapid adoption of generative AI platforms like ChatGPT has highlighted China's strong position to benefit from the AI trend. Driven by massive data, a skilled workforce, supportive government policies, and an advanced manufacturing base, Chinese companies like Baidu, ByteDance, Alibaba, and Tencent are poised to become leaders in generative AI. The article details the foundational strengths of China's AI ecosystem and the potential beneficiaries within its tech and semiconductor industries.

title: Applied Materials stock rises on new chip-making system that helps lower costs
summary: Applied Materials Inc. shares rose after the company unveiled a new chip-making system designed to lower manufacturing costs for semiconductors. The system, called Centura Sculpta, promises to save fabs like TSMC and Intel $50 per wafer. This innovation led to a notable outperformance of Applied Materials stock compared to its peers and the broader semiconductor market.

title: Applied Materials’ Innovative Pattern-Shaping Technology
summary: Applied Materials has unveiled its new Centura® Sculpta® patterning system, a breakthrough technology designed to reduce the cost, complexity, and environmental impact of advanced chip manufacturing. This system offers an alternative to EUV double patterning by allowing chipmakers to elongate shapes in a single EUV pattern, thereby increasing pattern density and eliminating issues associated with double patterning. The Sculpta system is expected to provide significant capital and manufacturing cost savings, along with environmental benefits like reduced energy, CO2 emissions, and water consumption per wafer.

title: Cisco works with Mercedes-Benz to create mobile office
summary: Cisco is partnering with Mercedes-Benz to integrate its Webex conferencing tools directly into the dashboards of the 2024 E-Class vehicles, transforming cars into mobile offices. While driving, users are limited to audio, but when parked, they can access all Webex features including video meetings, content sharing, and automatic transcription. This move allows Cisco to expand its collaboration tools into new markets, following a boost in video-conferencing platforms during the pandemic.

title: Qualcomm Introduces the World's First 5G NR-Light Modem-RF System to Fuel a New Wave of 5G Devices
summary: Qualcomm Technologies has announced the Snapdragon X35 5G Modem-RF System, the world’s first 5G NR-Light modem-RF system, designed to bridge the gap between high-speed mobile broadband and low-bandwidth IoT devices. This new system aims to expand 5G to new use cases like smartwatches, XR glasses, and industrial IoT by offering smaller, more cost-efficient devices with longer battery life. Customer sampling is expected in the first half of 2023, with commercial devices launching by the first half of 2024.

title: Data Center Sales Drive AMD's Q4 Resurgence
summary: AMD reported better-than-expected Q4 results, driven by strong data center sales which helped offset declining demand for PC chips. The company forecasts first-quarter revenue of up to $5.6 billion and expects its data center business to continue growing, allowing it to gain market share against rivals like Intel despite an overall chip glut.

title: Why AMD is faring much better than Intel in the same tough economy
summary: AMD is showing a much brighter short-term outlook compared to Intel, despite both operating in a difficult chip market. While Intel faces widespread declines, AMD's data center business is experiencing growth, aided by new chip introductions and its acquisition of Xilinx. Both companies are affected by a slumping PC market, but AMD expects to gain market share in that segment and grow its data center revenue at Intel's expense this year.

title: AMD CEO promises to keep taking data-center from Intel even as cloud demand pauses following 'strong' 2022
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su has pledged to continue gaining data-center market share from Intel, despite an anticipated pause in cloud demand after a robust 2022. Following Intel's worst year since the dot-com bust, AMD's stock rose as its Q1 2023 sales forecast of over $5 billion reassured Wall Street. This positive outlook comes as AMD's data-center sales grew, even with initial light demand from cloud customers.

title: AMD earnings: What to expect
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. is reporting earnings on Tuesday, facing lowered expectations from Wall Street following Intel's recent quarterly report. Analysts anticipate AMD will issue a weak 2023 forecast, similar to Intel's, due to inventory clearance impacting gross margins and a contracting data-center market. Despite this, AMD has little room for error after its own weak outlook last quarter.

title: Contract manufacturer Celestica is cutting dozens of jobs in Silicon Valley
summary: Contract manufacturer Celestica is cutting jobs in both Fremont and San Jose, joining other tech companies like Intel and Synopsys in reducing staff in Silicon Valley. This move comes amidst a trend of job cuts in the region.

title: AMD earnings face even more scrutiny after ‘astonishingly bad’ Intel outlook
summary: AMD's upcoming earnings report is under increased scrutiny following Intel's "astonishingly bad" outlook, particularly regarding inventory and data-center issues. CEO Lisa Su had previously expressed confidence that AMD would end 2022 in a stronger position, and the market will now evaluate that claim in light of rival Intel's struggles. AMD is scheduled to report its results after market close on Tuesday.

title: ASML beats earnings forecasts, sees 2023 growth amid China worries
summary: ASML Holding NV exceeded fourth-quarter earnings forecasts and projects over 25% sales growth in 2023, despite potential new U.S. export restrictions affecting its sales to China. The company's order backlog reached a record 40 billion euros, indicating strong demand from major semiconductor manufacturers. CEO Peter Wennink noted that economic conditions are expected to improve towards the end of the year, with China's economy recovering, maintaining high demand for ASML's equipment.

title: AMD can keep eating Intel’s lunch, Barclays says as stock surges
summary: Barclays upgraded AMD's stock to overweight from equal weight, leading to a more than 6% surge in AMD shares. Analyst Blayne Curtis believes AMD's Genoa and Bergamo platforms will enable further market-share gains against Intel. The upgrade also suggests AMD could benefit from Meta reaccelerating its spending.

title: CES 2023: AMD, Nvidia, auto applications get the hype, but analysts say this one chip maker ruled
summary: At CES 2023, while companies like Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and Nvidia Corp. received significant attention, analysts suggest that a lower-profile chip maker is better positioned post-convention. Morgan Stanley analyst Joseph Moore noted ongoing caution regarding overall chip demand, particularly due to softness in China, but highlighted autos as a strong theme at the event.

title: 'This is our Intel' — Mayor Matt Miller on Charles River's $212 million expansion project
summary: Ashland City Council approved a 75% property tax reduction for Charles River Laboratories, enabling a $212 million expansion that will add 200,000 square feet to its facility and create at least 500 new jobs. Mayor Matt Miller likened the project to "Ashland's Intel," emphasizing its economic importance and the company's commitment to the city. The expansion is expected to boost payroll by $24 million and reinforce Ashland County's biggest employer.

title: Intel Hires HP’s Christoph Schell As Chief Commercial Officer
summary: Intel has appointed HP's Christoph Schell as its new Chief Commercial Officer, overseeing the company’s Sales, Marketing and Communications Group, which includes the Intel Partner Alliance program. Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger emphasized that Schell's role is crucial to Intel's comeback plan, which involves expanding into new markets and achieving significant revenue growth. Schell, who previously served 25 years at HP, will join Intel's executive leadership team and is tasked with driving innovative sales and marketing approaches globally.

title: Astera Labs CEO: ‘We Could Be The Broadcom’ Of CXL Solutions
summary: Astera Labs, a chip connectivity firm, has experienced continuous growth despite a soft global economy, driven by early investments in cloud and emerging connectivity technology like CXL. CEO Jitendra Mohan envisions the company becoming "the Broadcom" of CXL solutions, aiming for a $10 billion total addressable market. The company attributes its success to its innovation, execution, and ability to anticipate market needs, enabling it to thrive as a private entity in a volatile semiconductor industry.

title: Astera Labs Enters Pre-Production Phase of Leo Memory Connectivity Platform for CXL-Attached Memory Expansion and Pooling
summary: Astera Labs announced its Leo Memory Connectivity Platform, supporting CXL 1.1 and 2.0, has entered pre-production sampling for customers and partners. This platform aims to solve memory bottlenecks and enable secure, reliable, and high-performance memory expansion and pooling for cloud servers. The announcement highlights successful interoperability testing and addresses the growing demand for memory in AI and ML applications.

title: Sales of computer graphics cards slump to lowest level in two decades
summary: Sales of computer graphics cards hit a 20-year low in Q3 2022 due to a global economic slowdown and the impact of the Ethereum merge on cryptocurrency mining. Major chipmakers like AMD and Nvidia experienced significant declines in discrete desktop GPU shipments, with AMD particularly hard hit. Despite the slump, new high-end GPU launches and Intel's entry into the market (grabbing a 4% share) offer potential for future sales boosts.

title: Micron Technology Sees Chip Recovery by the End of 2023
summary: Micron Technology Inc. stock has fallen significantly in 2022 due to weak demand for DRAM chips and an oversupply in the market. Despite a challenging fiscal Q1 2023 with missed earnings and lowered guidance, Micron expects improving customer inventories to lead to increased revenue in the fiscal second half of 2023. Analysts have revised their ratings and price targets, with some maintaining overweight or buy ratings despite the current downturn.

title: Kyndryl Receives Recognitions from ISG and Gartner® for Managed Network Services
summary: Kyndryl announced it has received recognitions from leading analyst firms ISG and Gartner for its managed network services, just one year after becoming an independent company. The company achieved leadership standing in the 2022 ISG Provider Lens™ Network Software Defined Solutions and Services Report for the U.S. and was recognized as a Niche Player in Gartner's Magic Quadrant for Managed Network Services. These recognitions underscore Kyndryl's growth strategy, advanced delivery, and strategic alliances in the network and edge computing space.

title: Mobileye among best Wall Street flotations of 2022
summary: Mobileye Global Inc. led Wall Street's largest flotations in 2022 by valuation, with a market cap reaching $27.1 billion after its October IPO, providing a 61% return. Acquired by Intel for $15 billion, Mobileye successfully went public at nearly $17 billion. The company's performance, alongside other larger but less valuable IPOs, stood out in a year that saw the lowest number of flotations in three decades.

title: Intel Asks Delaware Court to Dismiss $4 Billion VLSI Patent Suit
summary: Intel Corp. has requested the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware to dismiss a $4.1 billion patent lawsuit brought by VLSI Technology, citing VLSI's failure to disclose its full ownership structure as required. Intel argues that VLSI's opaque ownership, controlled by investment funds managed by a SoftBank subsidiary, is characteristic of hedge fund-driven patent litigation. The case highlights ongoing disputes between Intel and VLSI, including previous multi-billion dollar judgments against Intel, and concerns surrounding disclosure requirements set by U.S. District Judge Colm Connolly.

title: Mavenir expands presence in Brazil boosted by 5G technology
summary: U.S.-based company Mavenir is expanding its presence in Brazil, leveraging the deployment of 5G technology by phone carriers. The company, a systems integrator competing with giants like Ericsson and Nokia, has secured Telefónica’s Vivo as a client and is negotiating with other major carriers and regional providers. Mavenir has significantly increased its capital to finance product development and growth, with plans to potentially assemble open RAN radios in Brazil.

title: New business to bring more jobs to Plainview
summary: A new joint venture called DSM Semichem LLC. is set to begin construction on a facility in Plainview, Texas, in January, which will produce electronic sulfuric acid (ELSA) and create new jobs. This development is a result of Samsung's investment in a Texas facility and its need for local resources. The Plainview location will be the first U.S. facility for Dongjin Semichem Co., Ltd., and its operations are anticipated to begin after January 1, with full operation planned by the end of 2024.

title: Emerging memories move to replace embedded NOR flash
summary: Emerging memories like ReRAM, MRAM, and FRAM are poised to replace embedded NOR flash, driven by its limitations below 28-nm process technology and the need for low-power, high-reliability solutions in demanding applications. Major foundries like Samsung, TSMC, and GlobalFoundries are shipping production parts with ReRAM or MRAM, while companies like Infineon, Weebit Nano, and Everspin Technologies are advancing their respective technologies for automotive, industrial, aerospace, and data center applications, addressing challenges in density, scalability, and integration.

title: Exxon Mobil gives employees massive pay raises
summary: Exxon Mobil is significantly raising employee salaries by an average of 9% and granting restricted stock options to 14,000 employees globally, marking its largest salary increase in 15 years. This comes amidst record-breaking profits for the oil giant in 2022. The article contrasts Exxon's good fortune with mass layoffs occurring in the tech, housing, and financial sectors at companies like Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, PepsiCo, Intel, and BuzzFeed.

title: When will it open? How can you find jobs? 5 things to know about Phoenix's TSMC semiconductor plant
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) marked a significant milestone with a "tool-in" ceremony at its new Phoenix semiconductor fab, announcing a second factory and attracting President Joe Biden's visit. This massive $40 billion investment will create 4,500 direct TSMC jobs and tens of thousands more in construction and supporting industries, boosting metro Phoenix's economy. The fabs will produce advanced 4-nanometer and 3-nanometer chips, generating substantial annual revenue and tax contributions, while also prioritizing sustainability with advanced water reclamation and solar energy.

title: Is the Market Still Undervalued After the Recent Rally?
summary: The US stock market, though having rallied, remains undervalued by 10% as of November 30, 2022, according to Morningstar's equity coverage. This article suggests that while some turbulence is expected, there are opportunities in communication and cyclical sectors, and even certain tech and wide-moat stocks like Tesla, which have become undervalued. The author anticipates sluggish GDP in early 2023 but an acceleration in the second half, with inflation moderating.

title: Wi-Fi NOW Awards: List of finalists announced! Read who made it to the final round here.
summary: Wi-Fi NOW has announced the finalists for its annual awards across various categories, including Affordable Connectivity, Best Wi-Fi IoT Product, Enterprise Wi-Fi Solution, and more. The winners will be revealed at the Wi-Fi NOW Awards Gala on Monday, December 12. This year saw nearly double the number of entrants compared to the previous year, indicating increased competition and value for the awards.

title: Lockheed Martin and Intel Demonstrate 5G Capabilities For Military Aircraft Use
summary: Lockheed Martin, in partnership with Intel Corp., successfully demonstrated 5G capabilities for military aircraft use, integrating military tactical radios into Lockheed Martin’s 5G.MIL Hybrid Base Station. This achievement paves the way for 2023 flight testing of crewed and uncrewed aircraft for distributed teaming as part of Project Carrera. The collaboration aims to bridge commercial 5G stacks with military datalinks to enhance resilient communication solutions for the Department of Defense.

title: As Intel begins layoffs, no clear indication of effects in Rio Rancho
summary: Intel has begun layoffs, but a spokesperson for the company's New Mexico operations provided no specific details regarding the impact on its Rio Rancho facility. This comes after Intel's CEO and CFO announced expected workforce reductions during their third-quarter earnings call.

title: Lam Research completes acquisition of semiconductor equipment distributor
summary: Lam Research (NASDAQ:LRCX) announced it completed the acquisition of SEMSYSCO GmbH, a semiconductor equipment provider. This acquisition enhances Lam's capabilities in advanced packaging and chiplet-based solutions, broadening its offerings with cleaning and plating capabilities for heterogeneous integration. The deal also includes a new research and development facility in Austria, expanding Lam's global development network.

title: Ciena Deepens Foray Into Access with Two Acquisitions
summary: Ciena Corp. is expanding its broadband access portfolio with two key acquisitions: Tibit Communications and Benu Networks. Tibit, acquired for approximately $210 million, specializes in pluggable optical line terminals for PONs, while Benu Networks, purchased for an undisclosed sum, offers a cloud-native platform for edge functions including virtual Broadband Network Gateways. These acquisitions aim to strengthen Ciena's presence in the lucrative broadband access market, which is a growing segment of its overall sales.

title: Intel Elects Barbara G. Novick to Board of Directors
summary: Intel Corporation announced the election of Barbara G. Novick, co-founder and senior advisor at BlackRock Inc., to its board of directors, effective December 1, 2022. Novick will serve as an independent director and join the board’s Audit & Finance and Compensation committees, bringing extensive expertise in investment, finance, and unlocking stockholder value to assist Intel's transformation. Her background includes co-founding BlackRock in 1988 and leading its Global Government Relations and Public Policy Group.

title: Chipmaker Astera Labs Nabs $150M, Hits $3.1B Valuation
summary: Astera Labs, a Santa Clara-based chipmaker, secured a $150 million Series D funding round led by Fidelity Management and Research, pushing its valuation to nearly $3.2 billion. The company provides data and memory connectivity solutions for major chipmakers and plans to use the new capital to expand product lines, grow its workforce, and establish new research and design centers in Canada. This funding highlights continued investment in the semiconductor industry despite a general slowdown in unicorn creation.

title: Astera Labs Accelerates Company Growth with Series-D Funding and Expanded Board of Directors
summary: Astera Labs announced significant company growth, including closing a $150M Series-D funding round led by Fidelity Management & Research, which raised its valuation to $3.15B. The company also expanded its Board of Directors with Dr. Alexis Black Bjorlin of Meta and Michael Hurlston of Synaptics, and grew its product portfolio with the Leo Memory Connectivity Platform for CXL™. These milestones, alongside global expansion with new R&D centers in Canada, position Astera Labs for continued leadership in connectivity solutions for intelligent systems.

title: Astera Labs raises $150M to boost connectivity for intelligent systems
summary: Astera Labs has successfully closed a $150 million Series D funding round, bringing its valuation to $3.15 billion. The semiconductor design firm specializes in connectivity solutions for intelligent systems, critical for emerging AI and machine learning workloads in data centers. The company also announced an expanded board of directors and a new product, the Leo CXL Memory Connectivity Platform, to enhance application performance.

title: Intel hit with $949 mln U.S. verdict in VLSI computer chip patent trial
summary: A federal jury in Texas ordered Intel Corp to pay VLSI Technology LLC $948.8 million for infringing a VLSI patent related to computer chips. Intel plans to appeal the verdict, which follows a previous $2.2 billion verdict against the company in a separate patent trial. VLSI, a patent-holding company affiliated with Fortress Investment Group, argued that Intel's Cascade Lake and Skylake microprocessors violated its patent for improvements to data processing.

title: Lam Research Acquires SEMSYSCO to Advance Chip Packaging
summary: Lam Research has acquired SEMSYSCO GmbH, a global provider of wet processing semiconductor equipment, to enhance its capabilities in advanced chip packaging. This acquisition broadens Lam's offerings to include cleaning and plating for heterogeneous integration, particularly for fan-out panel-level packaging, which is crucial for high-performance computing and AI applications. The deal also brings SEMSYSCO's R&D facility in Austria, expanding Lam's global development network.

title: Cisco to open its first EU chip design center in Barcelona
summary: Cisco Systems announced it will establish its first EU chip design center in Barcelona, Spain, aiming to bolster Europe's semiconductor ecosystem. This initiative aligns with Spain's €12 billion PERTE program and the EU's strategy to reduce dependence on chip production in China. The investment's specific amount was not disclosed, but the project is expected to consolidate Barcelona as a technological hub.

title: Intel loses bid to revive antitrust case against patent foe Fortress
summary: A U.S. appeals court upheld the dismissal of Intel Corp's antitrust lawsuit against Fortress Investment Group LLC, finding insufficient evidence that Fortress's patent aggregation practices had anticompetitive effects. Intel had accused Fortress of stockpiling patents to threaten tech companies, but the court said Intel failed to show it paid higher royalties or was prevented from making products. This decision follows a nearly $2.2 billion patent verdict against Intel in favor of a Fortress-affiliated entity.

title: HP says it will bring jobs back to Corvallis from overseas if it gets CHIPS Act money
summary: HP Inc. announced plans to bring manufacturing jobs back to Corvallis, Oregon, if it secures funding from the CHIPS Act. This move would reverse years of downsizing in Oregon operations and consolidate development, prototyping, and manufacturing. The company sees the $52 billion federal allocation as an opportunity to reinvigorate its significant research and development site in Corvallis, which specializes in MEMS and Microfluidics.

title: BDA advises onsemi on sale of Niigata foundry to Mercuria, Sangyo Sosei, Fukuoka Capital
summary: BDA Partners advised onsemi on the sale of its Niigata wafer manufacturing facility in Japan to investment vehicles managed by Mercuria Holdings Co Ltd, Sangyo Sosei Advisory Inc, and Fukuoka Capital Partners Co Ltd. This transaction will create Japan's first independent specialty semiconductor foundry. The sale is expected to close upon regulatory approvals and fulfillment of closing conditions.

title: Crypto firm Iris Energy close to defaulting on debts
summary: Crypto firm Iris Energy is nearing default on hardware debts for three special purpose vehicles (SPVs) as their generated cash is insufficient to meet repayment requirements. While data centers remain unaffected, the company is in discussions with its lender. This situation highlights broader challenges in the crypto industry, with other firms like Core Scientific and Compute North also facing financial distress.

title: Micron Ships World's Most Advanced DRAM Technology With 1-Beta Node
summary: Micron Technology has announced it is shipping qualification samples of its 1β (1-beta) DRAM technology to select smartphone manufacturers and chipset partners, achieving mass production readiness for the world's most advanced DRAM technology node. This LPDDR5X mobile memory delivers top speeds of 8.5 gigabits per second, with significant gains in power efficiency (15% improvement) and bit density (over 35% improvement) at 16Gb per die capacity. The 1β node is poised to support highly responsive applications from mobile to data centers and intelligent vehicles, stemming from Micron's pioneering R&D and nanomanufacturing capabilities.

title: Residents suing town of Hudson, Intel over redevelopment plans
summary: Residents of Hudson, Massachusetts, have filed a lawsuit against the town and Intel Corp. in Massachusetts Land Court. The suit challenges a proposal to redevelop Intel's former property into a 1.2 million-square-foot warehouse, arguing that such a development is not allowed by town bylaws for "by right" construction. The plaintiffs, including residents of nearby housing complexes and a children's center, contend that the proposed use is commercial and not industrial, and therefore does not meet zoning requirements.

title: Intel names compliance chief
summary: Intel Corporation has promoted Carol Tate to vice president and chief compliance officer (CCO), as announced by April Miller Boise, Intel's executive vice president and chief legal officer. Tate had been acting CCO since January and has a strong background in ethics and compliance roles at various companies. This promotion highlights Intel's focus on strengthening its ethics and compliance culture under new leadership.

title: Intel's Mobileye unit valued at $22 bln as shares cruise higher
summary: Mobileye Global Inc., Intel's self-driving technology unit, debuted strongly on the U.S. stock market, reaching a valuation of $21.8 billion despite earlier IPO target reductions. The company's chief communications officer highlighted the importance of gaining a public platform and product visibility, especially for its SuperVision product, amid a challenging year for U.S. IPOs. Mobileye, which was previously listed before its acquisition by Intel in 2017, competes in the fiercely competitive assisted driving market, projecting deployment in 270 million cars by 2030.

title: Mobileye pops more than 37% in market debut after spinning out of Intel
summary: Mobileye, Intel's self-driving car technology company, saw its shares surge over 37% in its stock market debut after spinning out of Intel. The IPO, which valued Mobileye at around $17 billion, raised $861 million, with Intel planning to use some proceeds to build chip factories. This market debut provides a notable tech IPO in a slow year, despite Mobileye's valuation being below Intel's initial expectations.

title: Intel unit Mobileye prices IPO above range to raise $861 mln
summary: Mobileye Global Inc (MBLY.O), the self-driving unit of Intel Corp (INTC.O), successfully priced its IPO above its target range, raising $861 million. The IPO valued Mobileye at $16.7 billion, significantly lower than Intel's initial $50 billion hope, amid one of the worst years for U.S. IPOs on record due to market volatility. Despite the challenging market, Mobileye proceeded with the offering, with Intel retaining a majority stake.

title: Intel To Carve-Out Mobileye On October 26
summary: Intel is proceeding with the carve-out of its Mobileye division through an IPO on October 26, 2022, with shares trading under the symbol "MBLY". The IPO is priced at $21.00 per share, above the initial range, and Intel will maintain a significant majority stake after the offering, making Mobileye a controlled company. This article provides valuation analysis for both Intel and Mobileye, reiterating a 'Hold' rating for Intel given current market conditions and strategic challenges.

title: Chipmaker UMC cuts capex in readiness for prolonged downturn
summary: Taiwanese chipmaker United Microelectronics Corp (UMC) has announced a significant cut in its planned 2022 capital expenditure by almost a fifth, citing weakening consumer demand and a prolonged market downturn. The company expects headwinds in the fourth quarter and sees no immediate signs of recovery, particularly in smartphone and PC demand. Despite the cuts, UMC affirmed that expansion projects in Singapore and Tainan are proceeding to meet long-term supply commitments.

title: Mobileye IPO: 5 things to know about the Intel autonomous-driving spinoff
summary: Intel's autonomous-driving spinoff Mobileye Global Inc. has returned to the public markets through an IPO, pricing shares at $21, above the targeted range. While Intel initially hoped for a valuation as high as $50 billion, Mobileye's market capitalization is now close to its original acquisition price of $15.3 billion at roughly $16.7 billion due to a struggling IPO market. Mobileye, a pioneer in automated-driving technology, is focusing on a larger market while facing increasing competition.

title: China’s Biren GPUs Can’t Be Made at TSMC Due To US Regulations & Competition With NVIDIA
summary: Birentech, a Chinese chip startup, is reportedly barred from manufacturing its Biren GPUs at TSMC due to US regulations aimed at restricting China's access to advanced AI and datacenter chips. This decision is influenced by the Biren BR100's potential to outperform NVIDIA's A100 chips, which are already banned for the Chinese market, and could severely impact Birentech's manufacturing plans.

title: Intel plans to cut thousands of jobs hit by PC slowdown - Bloomberg News
summary: Intel Corp is reportedly planning a significant reduction in its workforce, potentially numbering in the thousands, due to a downturn in the personal computer market. This move comes after the company cut its annual sales and profit forecasts in July, stemming from missed second-quarter estimates and reduced consumer spending on PCs. Some divisions, such as sales and marketing, could see cuts affecting about 20% of staff, with an announcement expected as early as this month.

title: Intel CEO Pushes to Further Separate Chip-Design, Production Arms
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger is planning to further separate the company's chip-design and chip-making factory operations. This new structure is intended to allow Intel's factories to function as contract chip-making operations, serving both Intel engineers and external chip companies equally, as part of a broader effort to revamp the company and increase returns.

title: Intel plans ‘thousands’ of job cuts, Bloomberg reports, as PC sales slide
summary: Intel is reportedly planning to cut thousands of jobs, particularly within its sales and marketing divisions, due to a significant decline in PC sales and revenue forecasts. The company's stock has lost nearly half its value this year, exacerbating financial challenges even as Intel commits billions to expand manufacturing. The layoffs would mark a significant reversal for Intel, which previously experienced worker shortages.

title: Can Any Emerging Memory Technology Topple DRAM and NAND Flash?
summary: This article explores the challenges emerging memory technologies face in unseating DRAM and NAND Flash, prompted by Intel's exit from the Optane business. It delves into the history and current state of ferroelectric RAM (FeRAM), resistive RAM (RRAM), phase-change memory (PCM), and magnetic RAM (MRAM), discussing their breakthroughs and limitations. The author questions whether any of these contenders can achieve the "Holy Grail" of storage-class memory.

title: Micron would change Syracuse area for decades to come. Are we up to the challenge?
summary: Micron Technology's plan to build a $100 billion semiconductor fabrication campus near Syracuse promises thousands of high-paying tech jobs and significant regional growth. However, a major challenge lies in developing a skilled workforce to fill these specialized positions, requiring a concerted effort from educational institutions. The expansion also necessitates planning for infrastructure, housing, and social services to support the anticipated population influx and economic changes in the area.

title: Intel Hits Key Milestone in Quantum Chip Production Research
summary: Intel Labs and Components Research organizations have achieved the industry's highest reported yield and uniformity to date of silicon spin qubit devices, developed at Intel's transistor R&D facility. This milestone uses Intel’s second-generation silicon spin test chip and demonstrates success across an entire 300-millimeter silicon wafer with a 95% yield rate, marking a crucial step toward scaling quantum chips for commercialization. The research shows fabricating quantum chips on Intel’s established transistor process nodes is a sound strategy for the future of quantum computing.

title: Microchip Technology contemplates major factory expansion in Gresham
summary: Microchip Technology is considering a significant expansion of its Gresham factory, Fab 4, which could bring substantial new investment and hundreds of jobs to Oregon. This potential expansion comes amidst a nationwide boom in chip manufacturing and federal incentives, positioning Oregon to remain competitive in the semiconductor industry. The move is crucial for the state, as it seeks to attract high-wage jobs and capitalize on federal funding for semiconductor research and manufacturing.

title: The Chips That Make Taiwan the Center of the World
summary: This article examines Taiwan's critical role in the global semiconductor industry, particularly through TSMC, and the geopolitical risks associated with its dependence on the island amid rising U.S.-China tensions. It explores the potential catastrophic economic consequences for the world if military action or political pressure disrupts Taiwan's chip manufacturing capabilities. The author argues that while Taiwan's chip industry provides a "silicon shield," it also makes the island a crucial target in any conflict.

title: Micron to invest up to $100 billion to build chip factory in upstate New York
summary: Micron announced plans to invest up to $100 billion over two decades to construct a large semiconductor factory in upstate New York, spurred by the U.S. government's CHIPS and Science Act. This facility, planned for Clay, New York, is expected to create nearly 50,000 jobs and will receive significant incentives from both state and federal sources. The move aims to boost domestic chip production and strengthen the U.S. technology leadership.

title: Who is Micron? How the tech giant grew into world’s 4th-largest semiconductor maker
summary: Micron Technology Inc., the world's fourth-largest semiconductor maker, is poised to invest $100 billion in a new fabrication plant in Clay, New York, creating up to 9,000 jobs. The article details Micron's humble beginnings in a dentist's basement, its unique early investors including McDonald's and a potato farmer, and its subsequent growth into a Fortune 500 company. It also highlights the company's commitment to further expansion with a new $15 billion fab plant in Boise, Idaho.

title: Micron picks Syracuse suburb for huge computer chip plant that would bring up to 9,000 jobs
summary: Micron Technology plans to invest up to $100 billion to build a massive computer chip manufacturing complex in Clay, a Syracuse suburb, which is slated to be the largest single private investment in New York history. This project is expected to create 9,000 direct jobs and an additional 40,000 supply-chain and construction jobs over the next 20 years, significantly boosting the region's economy and establishing Central New York as a major semiconductor manufacturing hub. The decision comes after an intense effort by state, local, and federal officials, backed by over $6 billion in state and local incentives and the federal Chips and Science Act.

title: Japan to give Micron Tech up to $320 million to boost Hiroshima chip output
summary: Japan announced a subsidy of up to 46.5 billion yen ($320 million) for Micron Technology Inc. to boost advanced memory chip production at its Hiroshima plant. This move aligns with growing cooperation between Tokyo and Washington in chip manufacturing and comes as Micron trims capital investments elsewhere due to falling demand. The subsidy is part of Japan's broader strategy to bolster domestic chip production and foster technological collaboration.

title: Intel Innovation 2022 Unveils New CPUs, Expanded Dev Cloud
summary: Intel Innovation 2022 introduced the new 13th generation Intel Core processors, the Intel Geti computer vision platform, and an expanded Intel Developer Cloud. These advancements highlight Intel's progress in enterprise-focused technology, offering improved performance, AI model creation capabilities, and early access to future hardware for developers. The event reinforced Intel's commitment to innovation in computing.

title: Intel Accelerates Developer Innovation with Open, Software-First Approach
summary: Intel announced its continued commitment to an open, software-first approach to accelerate developer innovation, showcasing new tools and services at Intel Innovation 2022. The company introduced new offerings in AI, security, and quantum computing, emphasized the importance of the open oneAPI ecosystem, and detailed partnerships with companies like Red Hat and Leidos to foster widespread innovation and address industry challenges.

title: Intel Launches 13th Gen Intel Core Processor Family Alongside New Intel Unison Solution
summary: Intel has launched its 13th Gen Intel Core processor family, including the i9-13900K, touted as the world's fastest desktop processor. The new lineup offers significant performance improvements for gaming and content creation, alongside the introduction of the Intel Unison software solution for seamless multi-device connectivity. These products aim to enhance PC experiences by combining high performance with platform compatibility and innovative software.

title: Intel Unveils New Chips and Software as It Chases a Comeback (INTC)
summary: Intel Corp. introduced new personal-computer processors, graphics semiconductors, and software as part of its strategy to regain its position in the chip industry. The new lineup includes Core desktop processors for high-performance users and a graphics chip named Ponte Vecchio for data centers, aimed at challenging Nvidia. These announcements were made at Intel's Innovate event, showcasing their efforts towards a comeback.

title: Uncover Big Opportunities in Smaller Companies
summary: With small- and mid-cap stock valuations at 20-year lows relative to large caps, investors may find a compelling opportunity in SMID-cap companies. Historically, SMID caps have demonstrated outperformance over large caps, and the current valuation discount, coupled with a larger universe of under-covered stocks, presents a potential for long-term growth. A focused strategy, rather than broad-market exposure, is recommended to identify suitable companies in this segment.

title: Supermicro Delivers Second-Generation NVIDIA® OVX™ Computing System for 3D Collaboration, Metaverse, and Digital Twin Simulation, Powered by the New NVIDIA L40 GPU
summary: Supermicro announced the release of its second-generation NVIDIA OVX computing system, powered by the new NVIDIA L40 GPU, designed for 3D collaboration, metaverse, and digital twin simulation. These new servers aim to provide the necessary graphics, AI, and network performance for building and operating immersive 3D virtual worlds at data center scale. The systems will support up to eight NVIDIA L40 GPUs, ConnectX-7 SmartNICs, and current/future CPU processors from Intel and AMD.

title: Intel Announces AI Global Impact Festival Grand Prize Winners
summary: Intel announced the global grand prize winners of its AI Global Impact Festival, recognizing six student groups and three teachers for their impactful AI projects and best practices in AI skilling. The festival, which received over 1,000 entries from 25 countries, aims to democratize AI and encourage next-generation technologists to use AI for social good. This initiative is part of Intel's commitment to expand digital readiness to 30 million people in 30,000 institutions in 30 countries by 2030.

title: Cloud optimization co Zesty raises $75m
summary: Israeli cloud optimization company Zesty has raised $75 million in a Series B funding round co-led by B Capital and Sapphire Ventures, bringing its total funding to $116 million. The company's automated system dynamically adjusts cloud configurations to ensure stability and optimize performance rather than solely focusing on cost reduction. Zesty has doubled its annual recurring revenue since early 2022 and employs 120 people, serving over 300 customers with most revenue from North America.

title: Supermicro Announces 8U H100 HGX Server
summary: Supermicro has announced its new 8U Universal GPU Server, incorporating eight NVIDIA H100 Tensor Core GPUs, designed for large-scale AI training, NVIDIA Omniverse, and Metaverse applications. This server increases AI performance with improved thermal density, enabling lower power consumption and operation at higher data center temperatures, while supporting both current and next-generation CPUs and GPUs. The company is expanding its leading GPU server lineup with this addition, offering flexibility with front and rear I/O, AC or DC power support, and liquid cooling options.

title: MaxLinear 'AnyWAN' chips target FTTP, DOCSIS and FWA
summary: MaxLinear has introduced a new family of AnyWAN broadband gateway chipsets designed to support multiple access networks and software platforms, including FTTP, DOCSIS, and FWA.
