These chips aim to simplify operations for device manufacturers and operators, while also helping to alleviate supply chain constraints. The AnyWAN family comprises three products, with volume production expected in Q4 2022, and MaxLinear is also working on DOCSIS 4.0 integration for future roadmap developments.

title: Micron breaks ground on $15 billion U.S. chip plant, says more to come soon
summary: Micron Technology is breaking ground on a new $15 billion chip plant in Boise, Idaho, and plans to announce another U.S. plant soon. These new factories will significantly increase Micron's U.S. DRAM production to 40% of its global volume, up from 10%. This investment aligns with the U.S. Chips and Science Act to boost domestic semiconductor manufacturing.

title: Editorial: Responsibly Harnessing the Power of AI
summary: This editorial by Lama Nachman, Intel Fellow, discusses Intel's commitment to the responsible development and deployment of artificial intelligence. It highlights how Intel leverages AI to mitigate risks, drive positive change, and details their approach through a Responsible AI Advisory Council, focus on diversity and inclusion, and stringent privacy and security measures. The article emphasizes collaboration and continuous effort to ensure ethical AI solutions across industries.

title: What to know about Ohio's Intel Silicon Heartland factory project
summary: Intel is investing over $20 billion to build two new semiconductor manufacturing factories in Ohio, dubbed the "Silicon Heartland," aiming to boost domestic chip production. The project, located on nearly 1,000 acres in Licking County, is expected to create 3,000 Intel jobs, 7,000 construction jobs, and tens of thousands of long-term jobs, with production slated to begin in 2025. Significant road improvements and an additional $100 million in educational partnerships are also part of this massive development.

title: From a basement to a $15 billion investment. This timeline shows how Micron got here
summary: Micron Technology announced a $15 billion investment in its Southeast Boise campus, marking the largest private investment in Idaho history. The expansion is expected to create over 17,000 American jobs. This article provides a timeline of Micron's history, from its founding in a Boise basement in 1978 to its latest major investment in 2022.

title: Intel Names Shlomit Weiss Senior Vice President and General Manager of Design Engineering
summary: Intel Corporation announced that Shlomit Weiss has been appointed Senior Vice President and General Manager of the Design Engineering Group, replacing Sunil Shenoy who will retire at year-end. Weiss, with over 30 years of experience, will lead the company's design, development, validation, and manufacturing support of IPs and SoCs, reporting directly to CEO Pat Gelsinger. This change is part of Intel's IDM 2.0 strategy to drive product leadership and engineering excellence.

title: Spot.io founders raise $28M for secret cyber startup two years after $450M exit
summary: The founders of Spot.io, which was sold to NetApp for $450 million two years ago, have launched a new cybersecurity company called Upwind. The startup has already secured $28 million in Seed funding from prominent VCs like Greylock, Cyberstarts, and Leaders VC, despite currently operating in stealth mode. The founders, including former Spot CEO Amiram Shachar, are re-teaming for this new venture after their successful exit.

title: Intel and Brookfield partner up to finance new chipmaking facilities
summary: Intel and Brookfield have partnered to finance new chipmaking facilities, with Brookfield helping to fund new Intel facilities in Chandler, Ariz. This collaboration aims to support the expansion of Intel's manufacturing capabilities.

title: Investors are Scooping up Residential Properties Near Central Ohio’s Future Intel Site
summary: Real estate demand is booming near Intel's future $20 billion development in Central Ohio, three years before its operational date. Investors, including those from the West Coast, are actively buying residential properties to rent out, anticipating future scarcity and higher values. The rapid growth highlights challenges such as limited available housing, high land costs, and the need for significant infrastructure development to support new homes and attracted businesses.

title: Arm sues Qualcomm, aiming to unwind Qualcomm's $1.4 bln Nuvia purchase
summary: Arm Ltd. has sued Qualcomm Inc. and its recently acquired chip design firm Nuvia Inc. for breach of license agreements and trademark infringement, seeking to unwind Qualcomm's $1.4 billion Nuvia purchase. Arm is requesting an injunction that would compel Qualcomm to destroy designs developed under Nuvia’s license agreements with Arm, alleging its approval was needed before the transfer to Qualcomm. This lawsuit signifies a major rift between two key technology partners, as Qualcomm had acquired Nuvia to boost its custom computing core designs and challenge competitors in the PC market.

title: ARM is suing Qualcomm for licensing and trademark violations
summary: ARM is suing Qualcomm for breach of contract and trademark infringement over Qualcomm's acquisition of chip startup Nuvia Inc. ARM claims Nuvia's licenses, which are critical for chip design, cannot be transferred to Qualcomm without permission and were terminated after negotiations failed. The lawsuit threatens Qualcomm's strategy to expand into the laptop and server processor markets, and highlights a growing conflict between two major players in the chip industry.

title: 10 Big Named Companies Near 52 Week Lows @Ycharts
summary: This article lists ten well-known companies that were trading near their 52-week low prices as of August 25, 2022. It provides the current price and the 52-week low price for each company, including Abbott Laboratories, Verizon, Comcast, and Intel. The piece also includes a chart visualizing the data provided by YCharts.

title: Intel, Brookfield to invest up to $30 bln in Arizona chip factories
summary: Intel and Brookfield Asset Management have agreed to jointly fund up to $30 billion for Intel's advanced chip factories in Arizona. This partnership allows Intel to expand its onshore chip production capacities without overburdening its balance sheet, with Brookfield's infrastructure affiliate taking a 49% stake in the project. The deal leverages private capital for a multi-year project, aligning with the recently signed CHIPS and Science Act and Intel's broader strategy to boost semiconductor manufacturing.

title: Intel Elects Lip-Bu Tan To Its Board
summary: Lip-Bu Tan, executive chairman of Cadence Design Systems and founding managing partner at Celesta Capital and Walden Catalyst Ventures, has been elected to Intel's board of directors, effective September 1, 2022. Tan brings extensive experience from the semiconductor industry, venture capital, and public company boards, and will join Intel's M&A Committee. This appointment is part of Intel's ongoing transformation under CEO Pat Gelsinger.

title: Thematic Times: Semiconductors Power Thematic Indexes
summary: The article discusses how semiconductor stocks are crucial to many thematic indexes, particularly after the CHIPS and Science Act. It highlights direct and indirect exposure of various thematic indexes to semiconductors and the long-term benefits of the CHIPS Act for the industry and end users. The growth of the semiconductor market is primarily driven by the automotive sector, data storage, and wireless communications.

title: Intel Elects Lip-Bu Tan to Its Board of Directors
summary: Intel Corporation announced the election of Lip-Bu Tan to its board of directors, effective September 1, 2022. Tan, executive chairman of Cadence Design Systems Inc., brings extensive experience in semiconductors, software, and venture capital, and will join Intel's M&A Committee. This appointment is expected to provide valuable perspective to Intel's ongoing transformation.

title: Chipmakers tumble on fears of worst downturn in 10 years
authors: Jeran Wittenstein and Ian King and Bloomberg
summary: Semiconductor stocks experienced a significant downturn following Micron Technology Inc.'s warning of slowing demand, raising concerns about the industry heading into a prolonged slump. Analysts believe the sector is entering its worst downturn in a decade, affecting every company and end market. Despite recent shortages and investments, the rapid evaporation of demand has taken experts by surprise, with some companies like Micron already cutting future spending.

title: Nvidia warns of lower second-quarter revenue on gaming weakness
summary: Nvidia Corp warned of a 19% drop in second-quarter revenue from the prior quarter due to weakness in its gaming business, sending its shares down by about 8%. This follows similar warnings from other chipmakers and is attributed to consumers weighing purchases of discretionary items amidst economic concerns, as well as continued supply chain issues. The company expects to report overall Q2 revenue of approximately $6.70 billion, significantly below analyst estimates.

title: Nvidia is hit by another ‘crypto hangover,’ and that isn’t the only problem
summary: Nvidia is facing a "crypto hangover" and other issues as the pandemic-era booms in PC sales, videogames, and cryptocurrency decline. The company warned of a $1.4 billion revenue shortfall due to weak gaming equipment sales and excess inventory. Nvidia's stock fell 6.3% on the news, reflecting broader concerns about multiple challenges impacting its core business.

title: Russian weapons in Ukraine powered by hundreds of Western parts: Defense think tank
summary: A new report by the Royal United Services Institute (RUSI) defense think tank reveals that more than 450 foreign-made components, primarily from Western companies, have been found in Russian weapons recovered in Ukraine. These components, despite export controls for some, were acquired by Moscow over years before the invasion. The findings highlight Russia's military reliance on foreign microchips and suggest that stricter export controls and enforcement could hinder Russia's ability to replenish its arsenal.

title: China’s top memory chip maker could be targeted by US equipment export ban
summary: China’s top memory chip maker, YMTC, is facing increased pressure as the US is reportedly considering a ban on exporting chipmaking equipment to Chinese factories producing advanced NAND chips. This potential move is part of Washington's escalating efforts to curb the advancement of China’s semiconductor industry, following calls from US senators to add YMTC to a trade blacklist. The restrictions could also affect other Chinese chip makers like SMIC by targeting equipment for advanced chip production.

title: Apple buys HP’s 67-acre San Diego campus as it expands footprint and works on custom modem
summary: Apple has purchased HP's former 67-acre campus in San Diego for $445 million, marking a significant investment in its engineering efforts in Southern California. The acquisition is intended to support Apple's expanding work on an in-house modem and other wireless technologies, with plans to increase local job creation from 1,200 to 5,000 by 2026. This move reinforces Apple's commitment to bringing more hardware components in-house, despite potential delays in its own modem deployment.

title: U.S. Congress passage of subsidies prompts chip makers to move on projects
summary: Major semiconductor manufacturers are accelerating plans for new chip factories and expansions in the U.S. following the passage of the "Chips and Science Act." This legislation authorizes approximately $52 billion in government subsidies and a $24 billion investment tax credit for domestic semiconductor production and research. Companies like SkyWater Technology, GlobalFoundries, Intel, and NXP Semiconductors have indicated they will proceed with or expand their U.S. investments, with some projects previously stalled awaiting this funding.

title: Intel Signs Up Taiwan-Based MediaTek In Win For Foundry Plans
summary: Intel has secured a significant deal with Taiwanese chip designer MediaTek to build new chips through Intel Foundry Services (IFS), marking a major win for Intel's growing foundry business. This partnership aims to provide MediaTek with a more resilient supply chain by utilizing IFS capacity in the U.S. and Europe. Despite the positive outlook from Intel, some industry figures express concern that focusing on manufacturing for other companies could exacerbate existing supply chain issues.

title: Intel Spends Record Sum on Lobbying Amid Global Chip Shortage
summary: Intel (INTC) spent a record $1.75 million on federal lobbying in the last three months, a 65% increase year-over-year, as the semiconductor industry sought billions in government grants and subsidies. This surge in lobbying occurred amidst a global chip shortage. The company's spending surpassed its previous high set in the first quarter of the same year.

title: Rambus Spins DDR5 DIMM Interface ICs for Data Center Servers
summary: Rambus has unveiled new SPD (serial presence detect) hub and temperature sensor ICs, completing its DDR5 DIMM interface chipset. These new chips, alongside their existing Registering Clock Driver (RCD), provide a comprehensive solution for DDR5 memory modules in PCs and data center servers. The article details the technical advantages of DDR5 over DDR4, emphasizing the role of these new components in optimizing performance, capacity, and thermal management for modern computing demands.

title: Chip parts supplier IQE files lawsuit against Tower Semiconductor
summary: Chip components supplier IQE has filed a lawsuit against Israeli chipmaker Tower Semiconductor, accusing it of misappropriating its intellectual property. The complaint was filed in the U.S. Federal Court in California. Tower Semiconductor, currently being acquired by Intel Corp, has not yet commented on the lawsuit.

title: Rambus Expands Portfolio of DDR5 Memory Interface Chips for Data Centers and PCs
summary: Rambus Inc. announced the expansion of its DDR5 memory interface chip portfolio with the addition of the Rambus SPD Hub and Temperature Sensor. These new components complement the existing Rambus Registering Clock Driver (RCD) and are designed to improve DDR5 DIMM system management and thermal control for servers, desktops, and laptops. This expansion aims to deliver higher performance within desired power envelopes and supports the increasing demands for bandwidth and capacity in advanced computing systems.

title: Santa Paula's hillside 'SP' monogram is fading. Here's what we know
summary: The iconic "SP" monogram etched on South Mountain above Santa Paula is fading due to overgrown shrubs and a lack of maintenance since the landowner's death. This landmark, nearly a century old and located on private property, has prompted calls for restoration efforts. City officials and community members are seeking permission from the current property representatives to organize new cleanup and potential solar lighting initiatives.

title: Taiwan edge AI company Gorilla Technology IPO surges 123% on first day of Nasdaq trading
summary: Taiwanese edge AI company Gorilla Technology Group saw its IPO surge 123% on its first day of Nasdaq trading, closing at US$33.43 under the ticker "GRRR." The company plans to use the proceeds from its business combination with Global SPAC Partners for working capital and international expansion, aiming to form a "Smart City Diverse Industry Alliance" to expand global markets for edge AI analytics solutions. Gorilla Technology has developed its edge AI technology over 20 years, holding 31 patents, and provides comprehensive video-centric and content management solutions across various sectors with key partnerships including Softbank, Intel, and Dell.

title: Intel To Hike Chip Prices As Semiconductor Giant Deals With Inflation
summary: Intel has announced price increases across its product lines, including chipsets and microprocessors, by as much as 20 percent, effective in Q4 2022. The company attributes these hikes to inflationary pressures, rising material costs, and increased production expenses. Other companies in the semiconductor industry, including TSMC and various material suppliers, are also implementing price increases, suggesting a broader trend of rising costs in the tech sector.

title: An Atlanta developer has big plans for former DEC property in Hudson
summary: Portman Industrial, an Atlanta-based real estate developer, plans to purchase Intel's 148-acre property in Hudson, Massachusetts, and replace the existing buildings with a massive distribution center, potentially exceeding 1 million square feet. The site, originally built for Digital Equipment Corp. (DEC) in 1979, was a key player in the "Massachusetts Miracle" of the 1980s and was later acquired by Intel. The redevelopment requires numerous permits and studies due to its scale and impact on the area.

title: Wyden: Congress must act on grants for domestic semiconductor makers
summary: U.S. Sen. Ron Wyden is advocating for swift congressional action to provide billions in grants to boost domestic semiconductor manufacturing and research. He emphasizes the importance of these grants for lowering costs for U.S. consumers, creating high-wage jobs, and addressing national security concerns related to chip production dependency. Executives from Intel, nLIGHT, and Microchip Technology Inc. joined Wyden, highlighting the critical need for immediate federal investment to prevent the U.S. from falling behind global competitors and to address current chip shortages.

title: Vodafone, Wind River, Intel, Keysight Technologies and Radisys test ‘green’ Open RAN network
summary: Vodafone, in collaboration with Wind River, Intel, Keysight Technologies, and Radisys, successfully tested a "green" Open RAN network, demonstrating energy efficiency during an industry event. This initiative aims to make future Open RANs more sustainable, with tests showing a 9% to 12% reduction in power consumption under varying traffic loads. The companies plan to integrate these energy-saving techniques into Vodafone's goal of having 30% of its EU mobile sites on Open RAN by 2030, emphasizing cross-industry collaboration for environmental sustainability.

title: Micron Announces Availability of DDR5 DRAM For Next-Gen Intel & AMD Server and Workstation Platforms
summary: Micron has announced the commercial and industrial availability of its DDR5 DRAM specifically designed for next-generation Intel and AMD server and workstation platforms. This new DDR5 memory is expected to dramatically increase system performance by up to 85% over DDR4, catering to demanding AI, HPC, and data-intensive applications. Micron has been a key player in the development of DDR5 specifications and offers support through its Technology Enablement Program.

title: VIAVI Provides Benchmarking and Validation for Global O-RAN PlugFest, Demonstrating Technology Maturity, Performance and Security
summary: Viavi Solutions Inc. (VIAV) participated in the O-RAN PlugFest, validating and benchmarking O-RAN technologies to demonstrate their maturity, performance, and security across global locations. The company showcased interoperability in multi-vendor environments and highlighted advancements in security and AI/ML-driven network optimization. VIAVI's comprehensive test suite supported extensive testing for all O-RAN network components, solidifying its role in the ecosystem's development.

title: Direxion SOXL ETF: How To Trade This Leveraged Play On Semis (NYSEARCA:SOXL)
summary: This article discusses the Direxion Daily Semiconductor Bull 3X Shares ETF (SOXL), a 3X leveraged ETF on the semiconductor index. Despite SOXL being down 85% this year, the author advises against buying it immediately. The recommendation is to wait for signs of a bottom in the broader semiconductor index (SOXX) before initiating a position in SOXL.

title: HPE Is The First Big OEM To Adopt Ampere Computing Arm Chips
summary: HPE has announced its adoption of Ampere Computing's "Mystique" Altra Max Arm server chip in its standard ProLiant rack-mounted server, marking Ampere's first major OEM server maker partnership. This move, showcased with the ProLiant RL300 server, signifies HPE's renewed commitment to Arm-based processors after previous cautious ventures. The decision is driven by the Altra chips' deterministic performance and competitive price/performance, particularly for cloud-native workloads, positioning HPE to compete aggressively against Intel Xeon and AMD Epyc processors.

title: Intel Labs Announces Integrated Photonics Research Advancement
summary: Intel Labs has announced a significant advancement in integrated photonics research with the demonstration of an eight-wavelength distributed feedback (DFB) laser array fully integrated on a silicon wafer. This breakthrough, which features excellent output power and wavelength spacing uniformity, is crucial for increasing communication bandwidth in data centers and across networks. The innovation paves the way for high-volume manufacturing of next-generation co-packaged optics and optical compute interconnects for AI and ML workloads, leveraging Intel's existing 300-millimeter silicon photonics manufacturing process.

title: Hesai heads up lidar ISO test method working group
summary: Hesai has been appointed as the group leader for the new ISO Working Group dedicated to establishing an international standard for automotive lidar test methods, ISO/PWI 13228. This initiative, with Valeo as deputy leader and including companies like Denso and Bosch, aims to standardize performance descriptions, test methods, and market management for automotive lidar. The new standard is expected to address the pressing need for common regulations as the market for OEM-installed automotive lidar is projected to reach US$16 billion by 2025.

title: Intel wins latest race in chip uses for the cloud, says KeyBanc Capital Markets
summary: KeyBanc Capital Markets' new research indicates that Intel Corp. is currently leading the growth in cloud technology, specifically in server processors used for "cloud instances." The research, released on Thursday, highlights Intel's performance with newer processor architectures such as Ice Lake, positioning the chip giant as the winner in the latest race for chip uses in the cloud.

title: Intel wins latest race in chip uses for the cloud, says KeyBanc Capital Markets
summary: KeyBanc Capital Markets research indicates that Intel Corp. is leading the growth in cloud technology, specifically in server processors for "cloud instances." Their latest monthly data tracking highlights Intel's victory in this area, focusing on newer processor architectures like Ice Lake.

title: Ohio preview: Intel offers a rare peek inside its Arizona production facility
summary: This article provides a glimpse into Intel's Arizona manufacturing facility, Fab 32, highlighting its 24/7 operations. It mentions Jim Evers moving to Ohio to lead Intel’s New Albany complex and includes links to related articles about Intel's impact in Ohio.

title: These software companies are unsung winners in the semiconductor industry
summary: This article highlights software companies like Synopsys Inc. (SNPS) and Cadence Design Systems Inc. (CDNS) as critical but often overlooked players in the semiconductor industry. These companies provide Electronic Design Automation (EDA) software, which is essential for chip design engineers. Despite the focus on chip giants, these software firms play a crucial role in enabling the broader semiconductor sector, especially amidst ongoing chip shortages.

title: $6.5B Texas Instruments Fab Could Be First of Four at Site Totaling $30B
summary: Texas Instruments plans to build up to four semiconductor chip fabrication plants in Sherman, Texas, with the first $6.5 billion fab already under construction and expected to begin production in 2025. The total investment for all four plants could reach nearly $30 billion, supported by significant local incentives. This development is part of a broader U.S. push to increase domestic semiconductor manufacturing amidst global shortages.

title: Amid domestic semiconductor wave, Texas Instruments begins $30B build
summary: Texas Instruments has broken ground on an estimated $30 billion semiconductor manufacturing facility in Sherman, Texas, which is the largest private sector investment in Texas history. Production is slated to begin in 2025, creating up to 3,000 direct jobs and contributing to a nationwide effort to increase domestic chip manufacturing. This project aligns with a broader industry trend of expanding semiconductor fabrication in the U.S., driven by rising demand and supply chain challenges.

title: Intel Names April Miller Boise Executive Vice President and Chief Legal Officer
summary: Intel Corporation announced the appointment of April Miller Boise as executive vice president and chief legal officer, effective July 6. Miller Boise will lead Intel’s global legal, trade, and government affairs team, succeeding Steven Rodgers. She brings over 25 years of experience and was previously executive vice president and chief legal officer at Eaton Corp.

title: Intel Demonstrates Commitment to Security at RSA Conference 2022
summary: At RSA Conference 2022, Intel reinforced its commitment to security, showcasing innovations and partnerships aimed at addressing complex cyber challenges like hybrid workforces and connected devices. The company highlighted new solutions such as the Intel® NetSec Accelerator Reference Design, the expansion of Project Circuit Breaker, and advancements in hardware-based security with the Intel vPro® platform and confidential computing initiatives like Project Amber. Intel emphasized its holistic approach to security, spanning products, research, and ecosystem collaboration.

title: 6 High-Quality, Undervalued Semiconductor Stocks
summary: Semiconductor stocks have seen significant declines in 2022, creating a strong buying opportunity for long-term investors. Morningstar analysts highlight several high-quality, undervalued semiconductor companies with strong competitive advantages, benefiting from attractive valuations and a long-term demand surge for chips across various industries. The article discusses when the chip shortage might end and the positive long-term outlook for the sector despite potential short-term slowdowns.

title: Wolfspeed Appoints Owen DeLeon as VP of Sales for the Americas and Promotes Rick Madormo to SVP of Global Sales and Marketing
summary: Wolfspeed, Inc. has announced two key leadership changes in its sales department. Rick Madormo has been promoted to Senior Vice President of Sales and Marketing, succeeding Thomas Wessel, who is retiring. Concurrently, Owen DeLeon has been appointed as the new Vice President of Sales for the Americas.

title: JPMorgan CEO Dimon calls for raising minimum wage, more education to address racial gaps
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon advocates for raising the minimum wage, expanding education, and making mortgages more affordable to address racial gaps that cost the Columbus economy $10 billion annually. He also discusses the current economic outlook, noting a strong economy despite "storm clouds" like inflation, and emphasizes the importance of local initiatives and returning semiconductor production to the U.S.

title: Best semiconductor ETFs in the UK 2023
summary: This article provides a comprehensive guide to semiconductor Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) available to UK investors, explaining what an ETF is, the history and importance of semiconductors, and how to evaluate investment opportunities in this sector. It highlights top-performing semiconductor ETFs, discusses the significance of UCITS, and addresses considerations for ESG-minded investors, particularly concerning ON Semiconductor.

title: CBL Properties Follows Bankruptcy With Strongest Performance in More Than 15 Years, CEO Says
summary: CBL Properties has experienced its strongest performance in over 15 years, following a bankruptcy filing and subsequent reorganization. CEO Stephen Lebovitz attributes this rebound to a healthy recovery in retail, with strong sales from tenants and increased physical store importance in an omnichannel strategy. The REIT is focused on redeveloping its malls with diverse uses and maintaining a stable portfolio after divesting underperforming properties.

title: Qualcomm maintains multiple sourcing strategy
summary: Qualcomm Inc. has stated it will maintain a multi-sourcing strategy for its chips, including advanced chips from two major suppliers, to ensure a stable supply amidst the pandemic and a slowing global economy. The company anticipates continued strong growth in 5G penetration and expects Wi-Fi 7 technology adoption to rapidly increase, with end products equipped with these chips by the end of this year.

title: Pinterest, Inc. Class A Common Stock (NYSE:PINS) Stock Quote
summary: This article provides a stock quote and financial details for Pinterest, Inc. Class A Common Stock (NYSE: PINS). It includes current price, volume, trading ranges, and a list of recent news headlines related to Pinterest and the broader tech market. The article also features a FAQ section answering common questions about Pinterest's public trading status and stock information.

title: A union of Intel employees?
summary: Intel engineer Matt West is publicly advocating for a union for lithography engineers at Intel's chip factories, citing grueling hours and exhaustion as primary motivators. While west aims to join CODE (Campaign to Organize Digital Employees) and seeks Intel's neutrality, current efforts face challenges as coworkers fear retaliation and are hesitant to publicly support the union drive.

title: Intel shareholders reject compensation packages for top executives
summary: Intel Corp shareholders have rejected compensation packages for top executives, including CEO Pat Gelsinger's potential $178.6 million payout. Although the vote is non-binding, Intel stated it takes investor feedback seriously and plans to address their concerns, acknowledging "clearly more work to do" despite linking pay to performance. This comes as Gelsinger's 2021 earnings were over 1,700 times that of a typical Intel employee, and the company recently forecasted lower-than-expected revenue and profit for Q2.

title: Corporate Responsibility Report Letter from Intel's CEO
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger outlines the company's progress and future commitments in its Corporate Responsibility Report. Key achievements include investments in conservation, accelerating diversity and inclusion efforts, evolving the Pandemic Response Technology Initiative into the Intel RISE Technology Initiative, and launching the AI Incubator Network. Looking ahead, Intel aims for net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2040 and a $100 million investment in semiconductor manufacturing education and research.

title: Intel engineer, running for Congress, mounts union drive at Oregon chip factory
summary: An Intel engineer and congressional candidate, Matt West, is leading a unionization effort for hundreds of his colleagues at Intel's Hillsboro semiconductor factories in Oregon. The drive aims to address issues like long hours, pay disparities, and job security, particularly for engineers working on temporary visas. This initiative comes amidst a broader resurgence of organized labor in the US and during Intel's push for increased domestic chip manufacturing.

title: Intel Introduces Project Amber for Cloud-to-Edge and On-Premises Trust Assurance
summary: Intel announced Project Amber, a new service designed to provide remote verification of trustworthiness in cloud, edge, and on-premises environments, addressing the growing need for enhanced security and confidential computing. The company also detailed its efforts in securing AI deployments through partnerships and outlined a strategy for quantum-resistant cryptography by 2030, beginning with its 3rd Generation Intel Xeon Scalable platform. These initiatives aim to build trust and security for current and future technology landscapes.

title: Intel Vision 2022: AI Gaudi2 Chip, Accenture Collaboration And More Products Unveiled
summary: Intel announced a range of new products and collaborations at its Intel Vision 2022 event, including the AI Gaudi2 chip, 4th generation Xeon Scalable processors, and a collaboration with Accenture on Project Apollo. The announcements also highlighted new IPU and GPU solutions, and the expansion of its 12th Gen Core HX processors for hybrid work laptops, emphasizing performance and flexibility for professional users. These introductions aim to accelerate digital transformations and enhance AI accessibility and infrastructure compute capabilities.

title: Intel launches new AI chips, challenging Nvidia's market
summary: Intel Corp launched new AI chips, Gaudi2 and Greco, to challenge Nvidia's dominance in the AI chip market. The company is focusing on developing its open-standard software platform to differentiate itself and aims to capture a significant share of the rapidly growing AI chip market, estimated to reach $50 billion in the next five years.

title: Intel Announces New Cloud-to-Edge Technologies to Solve Challenges of Today and Tomorrow
summary: At its inaugural Intel Vision event, Intel announced significant advancements across silicon, software, and services designed to address complex challenges and accelerate digital transformations for customers. Key announcements include new AI processors like Habana Gaudi2, 12th Gen Intel Core HX processors for hybrid work, and updates on 4th Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors, alongside initiatives like Project Apollo for enterprise AI, the IPU roadmap, and Project Endgame for on-demand computing. The company emphasized real-world applications in industries such as education, finance, manufacturing, and medicine, highlighting collaborations with partners to deliver impactful technological solutions.

title: Intel Expands Atlanta Presence Across Software Development Team
summary: Intel is significantly expanding its software development team in Atlanta, planning to add over 100 new local jobs with six-figure salaries as part of a larger goal to create 500 jobs by 2024. This move reinforces Atlanta's growing reputation as a tech hub, alongside other major companies like Cash App, Nike, and Microsoft also establishing or expanding their presence in the city. The new roles will focus on areas like AI, cloud, and security, utilizing Atlanta's diverse technology community and talent base.

title: Lockheed CEO Says Supply Chain Must ‘Crank Up’ to Build Javelins
summary: Lockheed Martin is working to nearly double its annual production of Javelin missiles to 4,000, a process that will require a significant increase in its supply chain's capacity and could take up to two years. CEO Jim Taiclet emphasized the importance of the Bipartisan Innovation Act to boost domestic microprocessor manufacturing, as each Javelin missile requires approximately 250 microprocessors. This production ramp-up is critical as the U.S. and its allies are depleting stockpiles due to the high demand for Javelins in Ukraine, where they have been highly effective against Russian armor.

title: Nvidia pays $5.5m SEC fine over crypto-mining disclosures
summary: Nvidia agreed to pay a $5.5 million fine to the SEC for failing to adequately disclose revenue from crypto mining during two quarters in 2018. The SEC stated that Nvidia omitted information about surging demand from crypto miners while discussing how digital assets impacted other business lines. This lack of disclosure made Nvidia's financial results less predictable for investors.

title: Bausch + Lomb valued at $6.5 billion after stock ticks up in NYSE debut
summary: Bausch + Lomb made its U.S. market debut with a valuation of $6.48 billion, as its shares opened nearly 3% above an offer price that was below its targeted range. The modest reception comes amidst a challenging year for U.S. capital markets, influenced by the Ukraine conflict and a hawkish Federal Reserve outlook. The eye-care company raised $630 million for its parent company, Bausch Health Companies Inc, but none of the proceeds went to Bausch + Lomb itself.

title: Pave the Way for Next Wireless Breakthroughs
summary: This article discusses the accelerating pace of wireless innovation, focusing on the design and test challenges posed by next-generation wireless communication systems like 5G and satellite communications. It highlights key technological components such as wider bandwidths, higher-order modulation schemes, and multi-antenna techniques, and emphasizes the need for scalable and accurate test solutions to overcome these challenges. The author, Eric Hsu of Keysight Technologies Inc., explains how these advancements impact device performance and require sophisticated testing methods.

title: Intel Nabs Former AMD Exec Matt Poirier To Lead M&A Quest
summary: Intel has appointed former AMD executive Matt Poirier as senior vice president of corporate development, effective May 30, to lead its mergers and acquisitions strategy. Poirier, who previously focused on M&A at AMD and Xilinx, will report directly to CEO Pat Gelsinger. This move comes as Intel actively pursues acquisitions, including recent deals for Tower Semiconductor and Siru Innovations, and highlights the growing importance of M&A for Intel's expansion in various technology sectors.

title: New HP Chromebooks and Thin Clients Power Cloud-First Computing for Hybrid Work
summary: HP is launching new Chromebooks and Thin Clients, alongside software and device management solutions, tailored for hybrid work environments and cloud-first computing strategies. The new products, including the HP Elite c645 G2 and c640 G3 Chromebook Enterprises, and HP Elite t655 Thin Client, offer enhanced security, performance, and collaboration features designed to support mission-critical workers and IT teams. HP is also introducing HP Cloud Endpoint Manager for real-time thin client management and HP ThinPro 8.0 OS, emphasizing sustainability in its PC portfolio.

title: Intel Corporation pledges to emit zero emissions by 2040
summary: Intel Corporation has announced a commitment to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions across its global operations by 2040. The company plans to reduce its carbon footprint through various initiatives, including using 100% renewable electricity, investing in energy conservation, and developing more energy-efficient products and platforms. Intel will also collaborate with customers and engage in cross-industry research for greener technologies.

title: Intel to add hundreds of jobs in Atlanta starting at six-figure salaries
summary: Intel plans to create over 100 high-paying jobs in Atlanta, with average salaries exceeding $100,000, for a new software innovation division. Midtown is a strong contender for the location of this new outpost. This move signifies Intel's expansion into the Atlanta tech scene.

title: Chipmaker Texas Instruments expects revenue hit as China lockdowns dent demand
summary: Texas Instruments (TXN.O) forecast second-quarter revenue below Wall Street estimates due to reduced demand caused by COVID-19 lockdowns in China, sending its shares down 7% in extended trading. The company noted that the impact was primarily due to disruptions at its customers' factories. Despite this, Texas Instruments reported a 14% revenue increase to $4.91 billion for the first quarter, exceeding analyst expectations.

title: Self-driving Cars, Rare Earth Metals, ESG Activism: New ETFs On Syfe
summary: Syfe has introduced three new ETFs to its platform: IDRV (iShares Self-Driving EV and Tech ETF), REMX (VanEck Rare Earth/Strategic Metals ETF), and VOTE (Engine No. 1 Transform 500 ETF). These ETFs offer investors exposure to rapidly growing sectors such as electric vehicles and autonomous driving, critical rare earth metals, and shareholder activism focused on ESG initiatives. The article details the holdings, market outlook, and expense ratios for each of these new investment options.

title: Latest Oracle Exadata servers ascend to the cloud
summary: Oracle has announced the availability of its latest Exadata Cloud Infrastructure X9M appliance in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure, marking the rollout of its newest generation of Exadata processors. This new service, based on AMD microprocessors, offers significant improvements in performance, throughput, and capacity without increased costs, allowing organizations to consolidate various database workloads. Oracle claims superior performance compared to AWS RDS and Azure SQL, with the service designed for scalable deployment both on-premises and across Oracle's expanding global cloud footprint.

title: Why dividend ETFs may not be worthwhile
summary: This article examines the viability of dividend ETFs, concluding that many are not worthwhile after accounting for taxes, fees, and capital distributions. The author discusses challenges like 30% dividend taxation for foreign investors in US ETFs, poor underlying stock performance in high-yield ETFs, and issues with capital distributions eroding value. Alternative options in Singapore, UK, and Hong Kong are also explored, but ultimately deemed insufficient, leading to the recommendation that investors build their own dividend portfolios.

title: The end of one-chip wonders: Why Nvidia, Intel and AMD’s valuations have experienced massive upheaval
summary: The article discusses the dramatic shift in valuations among semiconductor companies, specifically Nvidia, Intel, and AMD. Five years ago, Intel's market capitalization surpassed Nvidia and AMD combined, but now Nvidia alone is worth more than the other two combined, reflecting significant changes in the semiconductor industry. This upheaval is attributed to evolving technology consumption patterns and companies specializing in new areas.

title: The end of one-chip wonders: Why Nvidia, Intel and AMD’s valuations have experienced massive upheaval
summary: This article discusses the dramatic shift in market capitalization within the semiconductor industry over the past five years. Once dominant Intel has been surpassed by Nvidia, which is now valued as much as Intel and AMD combined, reflecting fundamental changes in how technology is used and specialized solutions. This upheaval highlights a significant transformation in the industry's landscape.

title: Chip Startup Ampere, Founded By Ex-Intel Exec, Files IPO
summary: Ampere, a chip startup founded by former Intel president Renée James, confidentially filed for an initial public offering (IPO). The company, which already has significant backing from Oracle and uses ARM designs, aims to grab more data center market share from Intel and AMD. Industry experts anticipate continued growth in specialized chip designs for data centers, particularly ARM processors.

title: DeFiChain Adds New dTokens Corresponding to Disney, Intel, MicroStrategy, and iShares MSCI China ETF
summary: DeFiChain has announced the addition of four new decentralized tokens, or dTokens, following a community vote. These new dTokens correspond to Walt Disney Co ($dDIS), iShares MSCI China ETF ($dMCHI), MicroStrategy Incorporated ($dMSTR), and Intel Corporation ($dINTC), allowing users to gain price exposure to these traditional assets without ownership. DeFiChain, a blockchain built on the Bitcoin network, aims to provide decentralized financial applications and services, expanding its dToken universe to offer an alternative to traditional financial brokers.

title: Which is the bigger company: AMD, Nvidia, or Intel?
summary: This article analyzes Intel, AMD, and Nvidia to determine which is the "bigger" company, looking beyond market capitalization to factors like employee count, revenue, product diversity, and market share. While Nvidia leads in market cap, sustained analysis reveals Intel to be the largest overall due to its revenue and employee numbers, despite AMD and Nvidia's significant recent growth. The article also touches on the unique advantage Intel holds with its chip manufacturing capabilities.

title: Leveraging Intel Technology as a Force for Good
summary: Intel's RISE Technology Initiative supported 63 projects in the past year, investing $9.5 million to leverage Intel technology, employee talent, and partnerships for global good. These projects address accessibility, economic recovery, education, health and life sciences, social equity and human rights, and sustainability and climate. The initiative demonstrates how technology can be a force for positive change across diverse communities worldwide.

title: Technology ETF
summary: VanEck offers a suite of Technology ETFs that allow investors to gain exposure to disruptive and transformative megatrends such as semiconductors, spatial technology, hydrogen, esports, and cryptocurrency. These ETFs provide diversified exposure, potential for future winners through rules-based selection, regular rebalancing, and lower fees compared to actively managed funds. The article also details various risks associated with investing in Technology ETFs, including industry concentration, market risk, and liquidity risks.

title: Internet of Things Market Size [2022-2029] Worth USD 2465.26 Billion | Exhibiting a CAGR of 26.4%
summary: The global Internet of Things (IoT) market is projected to reach USD 2,465.26 billion by 2029, growing at a CAGR of 26.4% from USD 384.70 billion in 2021. This growth is driven by the increasing penetration of smart cities, deployment of vehicle solutions, and strong demand from the healthcare sector. Key players like Amazon Web Services, Intel, and Microsoft are focusing on product rollouts and technological advancements.

title: Intel’s Discrete Mobile Graphics Family Arrives
summary: Intel officially launched its Intel Arc A-series graphics family for laptops on March 30, 2022, marking its entry into discrete GPUs with the Arc 3 series available first, followed by Arc 5 and Arc 7 in early summer. These new graphics processing units are designed to enhance gaming and content creation, featuring innovations like Xe High Performance Graphics microarchitecture, Xe Super Sampling (XeSS), AV1 hardware acceleration, and Intel Deep Link technologies. The company also announced plans to release desktop and workstation products later this year, with a focus on delivering a robust ecosystem through partnerships and community engagement.

title: Gladstone Commercial Corporation Executes 15-Year Lease Renewal at Office Property in New Albany, Ohio
summary: Gladstone Commercial Corporation announced a 15-year lease renewal with CVG Management Corp. for its 50,499 square foot office building in New Albany, Ohio. This renewal extends CVG's occupancy until March 31, 2037, and is expected to increase Gladstone Commercial's AFFO and FFO. The property is strategically located near Intel's upcoming $20+ billion chip manufacturing campus.

title: Park Jung-ho: Korea’s Mr M&A
summary: Park Jung-ho, a key executive in SK chaebol, has earned a reputation as "Korea's Mr. M&A" over his three-decade career. He is known for spearheading major acquisitions such as Hynix, Toshiba’s memory business, and a significant division of Intel, which are considered landmark corporate transactions. Park Jung-ho serves as vice chairman of SK Telecom and CEO and vice chairman of both SK Hynix and SK Square, overseeing the SK Group's ICT activities.

title: The Top 5: Biggest Automotive Semiconductor Manufacturers
summary: The automotive semiconductor market, valued at $43.6 billion in 2021, is projected to exceed $115 billion by 2030, driven by the growth of electric vehicles and autonomous technologies. This article identifies the top five automotive semiconductor manufacturers, excluding TSMC which dominates the foundry market, and details their market share, financial performance, and strategic investments. The leading companies are Infineon Technologies AG, NXP Semiconductors N.V., Renesas Electronics Corp., Texas Instruments, Inc., and STMicroelectronics N.V.

title: SoftBank preps Arm IPO, seeking a $60B valuation
summary: SoftBank is preparing for an Initial Public Offering (IPO) of Arm Ltd., aiming for a $60 billion valuation, following the collapse of its proposed sale to Nvidia Corp. The valuation is considered ambitious but potentially realistic due to Nvidia's appreciating stock price since the original acquisition agreement. Analysts suggest the success of the IPO at this valuation could indicate investor confidence in Arm's own growth potential beyond a merger.

title: Nvidia considers teaming up with Intel on chip manufacturing
summary: Nvidia is in discussions with Intel about potentially using Intel as a foundry for manufacturing its chips. This consideration comes amid a global semiconductor chip shortage and Intel's efforts to become a major U.S. foundry supplier, despite the challenges of aligning technologies and business models between the companies. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang expressed openness to the idea, noting existing close collaboration between the firms.

title: Tackling Global Supply Chain Disruption
summary: This article discusses how Microsoft has addressed global supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic, focusing on leveraging technology for agility and resilience. It highlights digitizing factories, using AI/machine learning for data and logistics, and integrating sustainability. The article also introduces Microsoft's Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Insights as a solution for organizations seeking to build resilient supply chains.

title: Is It Finally Time to Start Buying Intel Stock?
summary: Intel, a pioneer in micro-processing, has seen its stock underperform competitors for years, but an ambitious makeover and new leadership may signal an attractive entry point for long-term investors. CEO Pat Gelsinger's plans for a massive $20 billion semiconductor plant in Ohio and other investments aim to restore Intel's market leadership. Despite investor skepticism reflected in its depressed stock price, Morningstar analysts see an appealing opportunity with a 27% discount to its fair value estimate and a 3.11% dividend yield.

title: Intel announces $50 million investment in Ohio higher education
summary: Intel is investing $50 million in Ohio higher education institutions, complemented by an additional $50 million from the U.S. National Science Foundation, to develop a skilled workforce for its new semiconductor factories in Ohio. This $100 million initiative over the next decade aims to establish robust semiconductor manufacturing education partnerships, creating new curriculums, training programs, and research opportunities. The investment is part of Intel's larger $20 billion plan to build two chip factories in Ohio, expected to generate thousands of high-tech and construction jobs.

title: Dow jumps 417 as stocks rally, oil hits $102
authors: Ken Martin and The Associated Press
summary: U.S. stocks rallied following the Federal Reserve's first interest rate hike since 2018, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising over 400 points and crude prices rebounding above $100 per barrel. Key stock movers included Dollar General after boosting its dividend and Intel with a major investment announcement in Ohio, while economic data showed a mixed picture for housing and stable jobless claims.

title: What Intel's New Albany plans mean for a Dayton-area manufacturer
summary: A Dayton-area manufacturer specializing in silicon crystals and processing equipment, with plants in Springfield and western Ohio, is owned by one of Intel's suppliers that has already committed to expanding in the state. This article explores the implications of Intel's New Albany plans for this manufacturer.

title: Why Nvidia sees a future in software and services: Recurring revenue
summary: Nvidia is shifting its business model to focus on software and services to generate recurring revenue, moving beyond its traditional hardware sales. CFO Colette Kress highlighted opportunities in autonomous vehicles, where Nvidia's software will be monetized over the life of the car, and the metaverse, envisioning annual revenues of $1,000 per creative user and per digital twin bot. This strategic pivot aims to create more predictable income streams, leveraging existing hardware with new software offerings and expanding into new markets.

title: Oregon, passed over for Intel fabs, could get share of $10 billion chip research hub
summary: Oregon, despite missing out on recent Intel factory investments, is being considered for a portion of a $10 billion federal semiconductor research allocation. Both Intel and U.S. Sen. Ron Wyden believe the state, which hosts Intel's most advanced research, deserves a share of this funding. This initiative aims to bolster semiconductor research within the United States.

title: Maricopa Community Colleges and Intel to Launch New Semiconductor Manufacturing Workforce Development Initiative
summary: Maricopa Community Colleges and Intel are launching a new Semiconductor Manufacturing Quick Start program at Mesa Community College to address the growing employment needs of the semiconductor industry. This accelerated two-week program aims to train a diverse workforce, including women, veterans, and underrepresented minorities, for technician roles. Successful participants will receive certification, college credit, a tuition stipend, and interview opportunities with Intel for full-time positions.

title: Ultra Clean expands gobal footprint with new facility in Cavan, creating approximately 100 jobs
summary: Ultra Clean Holdings Inc. (Nasdaq: UCTT) is establishing an Advanced Technology Cleaning Centre (ATCC) in Cavan, Ireland, creating approximately 100 jobs. This expansion supports the growing semiconductor industry and will serve Intel Corporation and other European customers. The project, backed by IDA Ireland, highlights UCT's commitment to sustainability and regional investment.

title: Intel Boosting Chipmaking With $5.4B Tower Buy
summary: Intel Corp. is set to acquire Tower Semiconductor Ltd. for $5.4 billion to expand its foundry business and meet chip demand. The acquisition aims to leverage Tower's expertise in manufacturing analog chips for various industries and scale Intel's foundry services globally. The deal, pending regulatory approval, is expected to enhance Intel's capacity in the growing foundry market.

title: Texas Instruments Inc. stock outperforms market despite losses on the day
summary: Texas Instruments Inc. stock experienced a slight drop of 0.03% on a generally grim trading day for the market. Despite this loss, the company's shares outperformed major indices like the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average, which fell more significantly. Texas Instruments also performed better than several of its competitors, with a trading volume exceeding its 50-day average.

title: IBM exec referred to older workers as ‘dinobabies,’ suit says
summary: A lawsuit against IBM has revealed email communications where a high-level executive referred to older workers as "dinobabies" and expressed intent to usher them out to "accelerate change." The suit claims IBM had a "top-down plan to retain younger workers" to improve its demographic makeup. This incident highlights ongoing ageism concerns within IBM and the broader tech industry.

title: Intel Names Christoph Schell Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer
summary: Intel Corporation announced the appointment of Christoph Schell as executive vice president and chief commercial officer, effective March 14, 2022. Schell, formerly of HP Inc. and Philips, will lead the Sales, Marketing and Communications Group, succeeding Michelle Johnston Holthaus. He will report directly to CEO Pat Gelsinger and focus on driving customer and partner success and expanding Intel’s business opportunities worldwide.

title: Nvidia Posts Record Sales Amid Broad Chip Demand
summary: Nvidia Corp. reported record quarterly sales of $7.64 billion, a 53% increase from the previous year, and projected further growth. The graphics-chip maker also more than doubled its net income to $3 billion, surpassing Wall Street expectations for both profit and sales. This strong performance comes amidst broad chip demand, despite the company moving past its failed takeover bid for Arm Ltd.

title: ETFs to Gain on Intel's Buyout of Tower Semiconductor
summary: Intel's $5.4 billion acquisition of Tower Semiconductor is expected to boost several technology ETFs. These ETFs, including FTXL, SOXX, SOXQ, TDIV, and VLUE, have significant allocations to Intel and are positioned to benefit from the deal's impact on Intel's manufacturing capacity and market position. The acquisition aims to enhance Intel's foundry services and address the soaring demand for semiconductors.

title: Virgin Galactic, Tower Semiconductor, CrowdStrike, Bitcoin: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: This article highlights key market movers, including Intel's acquisition of Tower Semiconductor, Arista Networks exceeding earnings expectations, and the gains in cybersecurity stocks due to potential cyberattack concerns. It also notes Bitcoin's rise and Virgin Galactic's upcoming public ticket sales, alongside mixed results for other major tech and hospitality companies.

title: Leading Chip Designer to Buy Global Foundry Firm for $5.4B
summary: Intel Corp. announced its definitive agreement to acquire Tower Semiconductor Ltd. for $5.4 billion in cash ($53.00 per share), driving Tower Semiconductor's stock up 42%. This acquisition is set to advance Intel's IDM 2.0 strategy by expanding its manufacturing capacity and global footprint, broadening its offerings in specialty technologies, and meeting the high demand for semiconductors. The transaction, unanimously approved by both boards, is expected to close in about 12 months, pending shareholder and regulatory approvals.

title: Intel to Buy Israel’s Tower Semiconductor for $5.4 Billion
summary: Intel Corp. has agreed to acquire Israel’s Tower Semiconductor Ltd. for $5.4 billion as part of CEO Pat Gelsinger’s strategy to expand into the outsourced chip-manufacturing business. This acquisition aims to enhance Intel's expertise and customer base in the chip-foundry market, directly competing with industry leaders like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. The deal is expected to close in about 12 months and is a key part of Intel's broader investment cycle to modernize its factories and rebuild manufacturing capabilities.

title: Intel appoints interim general counsel
summary: Intel has appointed Susie Giordano, corporate vice president and corporate secretary, as its interim general counsel, effective immediately. This appointment follows the announced retirement of current general counsel Steven Rodgers, who plans to retire on May 31 after more than 22 years with the company. Giordano previously oversaw Intel's corporate legal group and provided legal support to Intel Capital.

title: Tower Semi deal won’t solve Intel’s margin issues, analysts say
summary: Intel's planned acquisition of Tower Semiconductor for $5.4 billion is unlikely to resolve its ongoing gross margin issues, according to analysts. While the deal aims to expand Intel's manufacturing capacity with new foundries, analysts suggest these additions focus on lower-margin production and will not help Intel become a leader in cutting-edge foundry technology. Wall Street has expressed dissatisfaction with Intel's declining gross margins, as CEO Pat Gelsinger invests in capacity building at the expense of immediate profitability.

title: After decades of uncertainty, Tower is reaping the benefits of the chaos in the chip market
summary: Tower Semiconductor, an Israeli chip company, is being sold to Intel for $5.4 billion after years of uncertainty regarding its viability. This acquisition benefits Intel by helping it split its production capabilities and reduce activity in the East, following a period of stagnant revenue due to logistical constraints and competition. Tower's specialization in analog chips, its location, and its profitability make it a strategic asset for Intel's new strategy under CEO Pat Gelsinger.

title: Intel to Acquire Tower Semiconductor for $5.4 Billion
summary: Intel announced a definitive agreement to acquire Tower Semiconductor for $5.4 billion ($53 per share in cash). This acquisition aims to accelerate Intel's global end-to-end foundry business and significantly advance its IDM 2.0 strategy by expanding manufacturing capacity, global footprint, and technology portfolio. The deal is expected to be immediately accretive to Intel’s non-GAAP EPS and will combine Intel's leading-edge nodes with Tower's specialty technologies to serve a growing semiconductor market.

title: Autonomous Movers Set for US Launch in 2024
summary: Benteler EV Systems, Beep Inc., and Mobileye, an Intel Company, have announced a strategic collaboration to develop and deploy automotive-grade, fully electric, autonomous movers across public and private communities in North America. These SAE Level 4 autonomous vehicles are aimed at first- and last-mile use cases in urban areas, with production deployments expected to begin in the United States in 2024. The initiative seeks to address micro-transit inequities, reduce road congestion, and provide safe, reliable mobility through scalable vehicle development, autonomous driving platforms, and turnkey mobility operations.

title: ETF of the month: VanEck Semiconductor UCITS ETF (SMGB)
summary: The VanEck Semiconductor UCITS ETF (SMGB) has been named ETF of the month, highlighting its impressive performance in 2021 by returning 44.4% and gathering $859m in assets since its December 2020 launch. The ETF has benefited from increased demand for semiconductor chips driven by global digitalization, the reopening of economies, and emerging technologies like electric vehicles and 5G. Despite some recent market concerns from hedge fund selling, the semiconductor industry is projected to see continued revenue growth in 2022.

title: SoftBank’s sale of Arm to Nvidia collapses, Arm to IPO
summary: The proposed sale of Arm Ltd by SoftBank Group Corp to U.S. chipmaker Nvidia Corp has collapsed due to regulatory hurdles and scrutiny from various international bodies. Instead of the sale, which was valued at up to $80 billion, Arm will now plan for an initial public offering (IPO). The deal faced opposition from U.S., British, EU, and Chinese regulators over concerns about competition, pricing, and innovation in vital chip markets.

title: Reference design offers wireless docking over Wi-Fi 6E for PCs
summary: Synaptics Incorporated has introduced Gemini, a reference design that offers wireless docking over Wi-Fi 6E for PCs, claiming it's the world's first true Wi-Fi 6/6E wireless docking experience for laptops. This technology enables full dual-4K display capability and ultra-low latency, comparable to wired connections, and integrates hardware and software components like the BCM43752 Wi-Fi 6/6E radio and DL-1950 video interface IC. While initially focused on PC docking, Gemini's applications extend to tablets, gaming, and VR, with analyst Patrick Moorhead highlighting its potential to revolutionize connectivity in hybrid work environments.

title: Intel stock hits lowest price in more than a year, and there is another shoe to drop
summary: Intel's stock dropped over 6% to its lowest point in more than a year after analysts warned of potential troubles beyond falling margins: an impending oversupply of PCs. This oversupply is expected to severely impact Intel's largest business segment. The stock's performance made it the worst performer on the Dow Jones Industrial Average Thursday.

title: Intel Corporation v Commission (Case T-286/09 RENV): General Court Quashes Intel's €1.06 Billion Fine
summary: The General Court has partially annulled the European Commission's €1.06 billion fine on Intel for abusing its dominant position through exclusivity rebates. The Court ruled that the Commission failed to establish to the requisite legal standard that the rebates were capable of having anticompetitive effects, rejecting the previous per se illegality stance. This decision involved a detailed review of the Commission's AEC test and its application of relevant criteria.

title: Intel stock punished again as slimmer profit margins ding earnings forecast, but CEO sticks to his plan
summary: Intel's stock was punished again after the company's earnings forecast was dinged by slimmer profit margins, despite CEO Gelsinger sticking to his long-term plan for building out manufacturing capacity. The chip maker expects profit margins to remain under pressure for an extended period, leading to a disappointing earnings guidance that fell below Wall Street expectations. Intel forecast GAAP gross margins of 49% and non-GAAP margins of 52% for the first quarter, with expected GAAP earnings of 70 cents a share and non-GAAP earnings of 80 cents a share.

title: How the ‘world's first’ AI-managed ETF stacks up, almost five years later
summary: This article reviews the performance and evolution of AIEQ, the "world's first" AI-managed ETF, nearly five years after its debut. Despite initially underperforming the S&P 500, AIEQ has grown in assets, team size, and model sophistication, though it has faced recent headwinds. The article details how the fund, run by EquBot, uses tens of thousands of proprietary AI models and IBM Watson to analyze structured and unstructured data, emphasizing its commitment to explainability and transparency.

title: Is chip giant Nvidia going to scrap its $40BN bid for Arm?
authors: Giles Turner and Peter Elstrom and Bloomberg
summary: Nvidia is reportedly preparing to abandon its $40 billion acquisition of Arm Ltd. due to fierce regulatory backlash and little progress in securing approvals. Regulators and customers, including the U.S. FTC, have expressed concerns that the deal would make Nvidia too powerful. SoftBank, Arm's current owner, is stepping up preparations for an Arm initial public offering as an alternative.

title: Land around Foxconn was finalist for Intel's $20 billion semiconductor production facility
summary: Land near the Foxconn Technology Group site in Mount Pleasant, Wisconsin, was a finalist for Intel Corporation's $20 billion semiconductor production facility. Despite strong competition from Wisconsin officials, Intel ultimately chose a 1,000-acre site in Licking County, Ohio. Wisconsin officials remain optimistic, stating that the qualities that attracted Intel will continue to draw other investors to the I-94 corridor.

title: Intel Vs. Micron Technology: Which Semiconductor Stock Is The Better Buy?
summary: This article compares Intel (INTC) and Micron Technology (MU), two major semiconductor stocks, to determine which is the better investment. It notes that Intel is larger and more diversified than Micron, and currently offers lower price-to-earnings and price-to-free cash flow ratios. The author, Bill Zettler, has a beneficial long position in Intel shares.

title: Governor DeWine Announces Monumental Investment by Intel to Bring Their Most Advanced Semiconductor Manufacturing Plants to Ohio
summary: Ohio Governor Mike DeWine announced a monumental investment by Intel Corporation to build two state-of-the-art semiconductor manufacturing facilities in Licking County, Ohio. This $20 billion project is the largest single private sector investment in Ohio's history, expected to create over 20,000 jobs and add $2.8 billion to Ohio’s annual gross state product. The initiative aims to rebalance global chipmaking capacity, boost U.S. semiconductor manufacturing leadership, and strengthen the domestic supply chain for critical technologies.

title: Intel investing $20 billion to bring chip manufacturing to Ohio amid global shortage
summary: Intel announced an investment of over $20 billion to build two new semiconductor chip factories in central Ohio. This project aims to address the global chip shortage and reduce the U.S.'s reliance on Asian manufacturing for semiconductors. The initiative is expected to create 3,000 Intel jobs and 7,000 construction jobs, with production slated to begin in 2025.
source: ABC News - Breaking News, Latest News and Videos
source_domain: ABC News - Breaking News, Latest News and Videos

title: Intel to invest at least $20 billion in Ohio chip-making facility
summary: Intel Corp. plans to invest at least $20 billion in a new chip-making facility near Columbus, Ohio, to bolster its semiconductor production in response to increased demand for digital products and a global chip shortage. This investment is part of Intel's broader strategy to expand its manufacturing capabilities and regain its position as a leading chip designer and manufacturer, including for other companies. The move is expected to create 3,000 permanent jobs in Ohio and comes at a time when governments are offering subsidies to attract semiconductor production plants to reduce supply-chain disruptions.

title: How to Invest in the Top 100 U.S. ESG Companies
summary: The article discusses the 2022 list of top 100 U.S. ESG companies compiled by Just Capital, highlighting major movements like Alphabet's rise and Meta's fall. It explains the methodology behind the rankings, which prioritize issues important to Americans, and introduces the Goldman Sachs JUST U.S. Large Cap Equity ETF (JUST) as a way to invest in companies demonstrating "just business behavior."

title: Chip giant Nvidia expands R&D operations in Israel
summary: Nvidia is expanding its R&D operations in Israel by establishing a new design and engineering group focused on next-generation CPUs for AI, robotics, and autonomous vehicles. The company, which acquired Israel's Mellanox Technologies in 2020, plans to hire additional engineers in Israel, further solidifying the country's role as Nvidia's largest R&D hub outside the US. This expansion intensifies competition for tech talent in Israel, where both Nvidia and Intel have significant R&D presence, and Google is also entering the chip-making sector.

title: These 3 ETFs let you play the hot semiconductor sector, where Nvidia, Micron, AMD and others are growing sales rapidly
summary: This article highlights three ETFs that offer investors exposure to the rapidly growing semiconductor sector, featuring companies like Nvidia, Micron, and AMD. The chip-focused exchange-traded funds have significantly outperformed the S&P 500 and Nasdaq over the past 15 years, indicating their strong performance potential despite market pressures. The article also mentions Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) reporting robust fourth-quarter sales and earnings, reinforcing the sector's positive outlook.

title: Intel Gains After Recruiting Micron’s David Zinsner as Its Next CFO
summary: Intel Corp. stock rallied after announcing the appointment of David Zinsner, previously CFO of Micron Technology Inc., as its new Chief Financial Officer. Zinsner will replace the retiring George Davis and will report to CEO Pat Gelsinger, tasked with overseeing the company’s finances as it aims to regain its prominence in the semiconductor industry. He is set to begin his new role on January 17th.

title: Intel Names David Zinsner Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
summary: Intel Corporation announced the appointment of David Zinsner as its new Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, effective January 17, 2022. Zinsner brings over 20 years of experience in semiconductors and manufacturing, having previously served as CFO at Micron Technology, Inc. He will report to CEO Pat Gelsinger and oversee Intel's global finance organization, succeeding George Davis, who will retire in May 2022.

title: Micron Technology searches for site for $40B factory. Is Boise among the contenders?
summary: Micron Technology is reportedly scouting locations for a new $40 billion manufacturing plant, with sites in Arizona, California, Texas, and North Carolina under consideration, though Boise is apparently not on the list. This search is part of Micron's larger plan to invest over $150 billion in chip production over 10 years to address a global chip shortage and meet growing demand driven by AI, 5G, and autonomous vehicles. The company is evaluating locations based on factors like site availability, talent pool, utility services, sustainability, and regulatory environment, with a focus on domestic production potentially spurred by the CHIPS Act.

title: Semiconductor giant Micron scouts Central Texas for major factory, sources say
summary: Micron Technology Inc. is considering Central Texas for a massive fabrication facility as part of its plan to invest over $150 billion in expanding its chipmaking capabilities over the next decade. While no final decision has been made, this investment could reportedly reach $40 billion in the region. Other states are also under consideration for the factory.

title: Intel appoints 10 Israeli executives to senior global positions
summary: Intel Corporation has appointed 10 Israeli executives to senior global positions, including Karin Eibschitz-Segal as a global corporate vice president, making her the second Israeli woman to hold such a role. The appointments highlight Intel's appreciation for its Israeli human capital and come amidst a global semiconductor shortage, underscoring Israel's growing importance in the tech industry. Intel is the largest private employer in Israel, with significant development centers and manufacturing plants.

title: Intel names 10 Israelis to senior global positions
summary: Intel Corporation has appointed 10 Israeli executives to senior global positions within the company's operations, including Corporate Vice Presidents and Intel Fellows. This move highlights Intel's confidence in the human capital in Intel Israel and their contributions to strategic global operations and engineering. Intel Israel's management expressed pride in the nominations, seeing them as a testament to the appreciation shown for their talent.

title: Intel apologizes after Xinjiang avoidance request
summary: Intel issued an apology after facing backlash in China for a letter requesting suppliers to avoid sourcing from the Xinjiang region due to U.S. regulations concerning forced labor. The company stated the request was to comply with U.S. law, not an expression of its own views, regretting the concern caused to its Chinese partners and public. This incident follows similar boycotts against other international brands by Chinese consumers and celebrities over human rights concerns in Xinjiang.

title: Intel apologizes over its statement on forced labor in Xinjiang. (Published 2021)
summary: Intel issued an apology after its statement regarding the avoidance of products and labor from Xinjiang sparked outrage in China. The company clarified that its original letter to suppliers was an effort to comply with U.S. sanctions against Xinjiang, rather than a political stance. This incident places Intel in a growing list of multinational firms caught between U.S. sanctions and Chinese nationalist sentiment.

title: Intel Apologizes for Asking Suppliers to Avoid Xinjiang
summary: Intel Corp. issued an apology after asking its suppliers to avoid sourcing goods from Xinjiang, a region where the Chinese government is accused of human rights abuses. This request, made to comply with U.S. regulations, drew sharp criticism from Chinese state media and prompted calls for boycotts of Intel products. The incident highlights the growing tensions between foreign companies and China over the Xinjiang issue.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Intel apologises in China over Xinjiang supplier statement
summary: U.S. chipmaker Intel apologized in China after facing backlash for a statement to suppliers warning against sourcing products or labor from Xinjiang, a region accused of human rights abuses by the U.S. government. Intel clarified that its commitment was a compliance with U.S. law rather than a stance on the issue, a move that still drew criticism from Chinese social media users and led to a brand ambassador ending his contract. Many viewed the apology as an attempt to protect sales in the massive Chinese market.

title: Desktop computers and All-in-One PCs
summary: HP offers a wide range of desktop computers and All-in-One PCs designed for various uses, including work, entertainment, gaming, and creative tasks. The article highlights new AI PC models like the HP OmniDesk and OmniStudio X, alongside established lines such as HP Pavilion, Envy, OMEN, and VICTUS, detailing their specifications and intended applications. Customers can filter choices by use case, series, operating system, product type, and screen size to find the perfect device.

title: Intel to invest $7 billion in new plant in Malaysia, creating 9,000 jobs
summary: Intel Chief Executive Pat Gelsinger announced a $7 billion investment to build a new chip-packaging and testing factory in Malaysia, creating over 4,000 Intel jobs and more than 5,000 construction jobs. This expansion aims to address the global semiconductor shortage, which Gelsinger expects to persist into 2023. The new advanced packaging facility is projected to begin production in 2024.

title: A little-known investor has outperformed Warren Buffett over the past 20 years — and grown his fund's assets from $34 million to $1.3 billion
summary: Wilmot Kidd, an 80-year-old investor set to retire, has grown his fund, Central Securities, from $34 million to $1.3 billion over 47 years by employing a Warren Buffett-style investment strategy. Kidd's approach involves long-term holding, concentrated portfolios, low costs, and private deals, leading to his fund outperforming Berkshire Hathaway and the S&P 500 over several decades. His notable successes include a $700,000 investment in Plymouth Rock in 1982, now valued at $293 million, and a current stake in Analog Devices worth $75 million from a $6 million investment in 1987.

title: Intel's CEO is pressing Congress to pass a bill that has $52B in subsidies for domestic chip production
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger is urging Congress to pass a bill that includes $52 billion in subsidies for domestic chip production. This push comes amidst a global semiconductor shortage and highlights the limited number of companies capable of producing cutting-edge chips.

title: TSMC and Intel Get Into a Rare Public Spat Over U.S. Chipmaking
summary: Chip giants Intel and TSMC are engaging in a rare public dispute regarding U.S. chipmaking endeavors. This spat highlights the growing tensions and competitive landscape within the semiconductor industry. The article describes the increasingly awkward relationship between the two key players.

title: Intel plans to take self-driving car unit Mobileye public
summary: Intel announced its plan to take its self-driving car unit, Mobileye, public in the United States by mid-2022. This deal could value Mobileye at over $50 billion, with Intel intending to retain majority ownership and Mobileye's executive team.
