The move aims to build on Mobileye's innovation track record and unlock value for shareholders, as Intel faces pressure from activist investors regarding its chip manufacturing operations.

title: Intel plans to take self-driving car unit public in the U.S. in mid-2022
summary: Intel announced its plan to take its self-driving car unit, Mobileye, public in the U.S. in mid-2022 through an IPO. Intel acquired Mobileye for $15.3 billion in 2017, and the IPO is expected to value Mobileye at over $50 billion, creating value for Intel shareholders who will remain majority owners. This move aims to give Mobileye more visibility and help fund Intel's expansion plans, including building new chip plants.

title: Intel Announces Intent to Take Mobileye Public
summary: Intel announced its intention to take Mobileye public in the United States in mid-2022 via an initial public offering (IPO) of newly issued Mobileye stock, with Intel maintaining majority ownership. This move aims to unlock value for Intel shareholders, building on Mobileye's significant revenue growth and innovation in driver-assistance and autonomous driving solutions since its acquisition by Intel in 2017. Mobileye's executive team, including CEO Prof. Amnon Shashua, will remain in place, and both companies will continue their strategic partnership in the automotive tech market.

title: Intel to acquire Israeli company Screenovate, maker of screen mirroring tech
summary: Intel announced its acquisition of Israeli company Screenovate, a developer of screen mirroring technology, for an estimated $150 million. This acquisition marks Intel's fifth purchase of an Israeli company in five years and aims to enhance user experience on personal computers, particularly for Intel's EVO laptops, by enabling seamless transitions between devices.

title: Regulators in US, UK, EU All Alarmed By Chip Maker Nvidia’s $40B Deal to Buy Chip Designer
summary: Regulators in the U.S., U.K., and E.U. are expressing alarm over Nvidia Corporation's $40 billion proposed acquisition of chip designer Arm Ltd. The U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has filed a lawsuit to block the deal, citing concerns that it would grant Nvidia too much power and stifle competition and innovation in the semiconductor industry. Nvidia, however, maintains that the merger would benefit the industry, promote competition, and preserve Arm's open licensing model.

title: U.S. sues to block Nvidia’s $40-billion chip takeover of Arm
summary: U.S. antitrust officials have sued to block Nvidia's proposed $40-billion acquisition of Arm Ltd., citing concerns that the deal would stifle innovation and undermine competition in the semiconductor industry. The Federal Trade Commission argues that the merger would grant Nvidia excessive control over chip designs widely used across various technologies. The acquisition, initially valued at $40 billion in September 2020, has faced regulatory hurdles globally due to Arm's critical role as a technology licensor to hundreds of companies including Nvidia's rivals.

title: Amazon's cloud unit launches new chips to take on Intel, Nvidia
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) has introduced two new custom computing chips, Graviton3 and Trainium, aimed at competing with offerings from Intel, AMD, and Nvidia. AWS claims its new chips offer better performance per dollar and lower costs for machine learning model training compared to its rivals. This move signals AWS's continued drive to develop its own hardware and intensify competition in the cloud computing and chip markets.

title: Investors are going wild over a Dutch chip firm. And you've probably never heard of it
summary: ASML, a Dutch chip firm, holds a critical monopoly in manufacturing the highly complex extreme ultraviolet lithography (EUV) machines essential for producing the most advanced chips. Despite its significant market value of $350 billion and being crucial to major chipmakers like TSMC, Samsung, and Intel, many investors may not be familiar with the company. Demand for ASML's machines is projected to lead to a significant sales boom over the next decade, with annual revenue expected to hit 24-30 billion euros by 2025.

title: Nvidia jumps after big data centre growth boosts outlook
summary: Nvidia's stock jumped after the company reported strong revenue forecasts, driven by significant growth in its data center segment. While gaming chip sales remain strong, and the company sees potential in the metaverse and cryptocurrency mining, its proposed acquisition of Arm Ltd. faces regulatory challenges. Nvidia's market capitalization has soared, placing it among the top S&P 500 companies.

title: Qualcomm, diversifying from mobile phones, to supply chips for BMW self-driving cars
summary: Qualcomm announced that it will supply chips for BMW's next generation of driver-assistance and self-driving systems, marking a significant diversification beyond its core mobile phone chip business. This move underscores Qualcomm's strategic expansion into the automotive sector, aiming to challenge competitors like Nvidia and Intel in the self-driving technology market. The new chips will be used in BMW's "Neue Klasse" series of cars, with production slated to begin in 2025.

title: Aeva and Luminar deals show lidar gaining traction
summary: Aeva and Luminar, two lidar companies that recently went public via SPACs, are gaining traction in the autonomous vehicle industry. Aeva has partnered with Fabrinet for mass production of its chip-scale lidar modules, while Luminar's lidar has been selected for Nvidia's DRIVE Hyperion platform. Another lidar startup, Ouster, also reported a significant increase in sales and plans to launch a new automotive lidar platform.

title: AMD lands Meta as customer and takes on Nvidia, sending shares up 11%
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) shares rose 11% after announcing Meta Platforms Inc. as a new data center chip customer, intensifying its competition with Intel. AMD also unveiled new chips, including the MI200 for AI and machine learning to challenge Nvidia, and the Bergamo processor for cloud computing to compete with Ampere Computing. These strategic moves bolster AMD's market position against larger rivals and secure its presence with major cloud providers.

title: AMD shares close up 10% after company wins Meta partnership, announces new chips
summary: AMD shares surged 10% after the company announced a partnership with Meta (formerly Facebook) as a chip customer and unveiled a new range of chips at its Accelerated Data Center Premiere event. This move strengthens AMD's position against competitors like Intel, as the company continues to gain market share with its data center chip sales experiencing significant growth. Additional details about the Meta partnership are expected to be revealed later in the week at the Open Compute Project summit.

title: Intel Loses Ground to AMD as Demand for Chromebook Chips Wanes
summary: Intel Corp. lost over 2 percentage points of market share to Advanced Micro Devices Inc. in the third quarter of 2021, a setback driven primarily by a sharp decline in demand for chips used in low-end notebooks like Chromebooks. AMD now accounts for 24.6% of personal-computer processor sales, up from 22.5% a year prior, as Intel's technology edge erodes.

title: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger’s “insane” plan to restore the company’s glory days
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger is implementing an "insane" and ambitious plan to regain the company's market leadership. This involves massive capital expenditures between $25 billion and $28 billion annually, along with $15 billion in R&D, to improve technology and capacity, especially in foundry business. The strategy aims for performance parity by 2024 and industry leadership by 2025, a bold move given Intel's recent struggles against competitors like Apple and ARM-based chips.

title: Chipmaker GlobalFoundries valued at $26 bln in lackluster Nasdaq debut
summary: GlobalFoundries Inc. made a lackluster Nasdaq debut, with shares opening flat and finishing slightly below its IPO price, valuing the chipmaker at approximately $26 billion. Despite raising $2.6 billion, the company faces lower gross margins compared to competitors, though it plans significant investments to boost capacity and future margins amid a global chip shortage. CEO Thomas Caulfield expects demand to remain high for years, with acute shortages potentially easing in 2023.

title: US tech company NetApp to open international headquarters in Cork
summary: US-based technology company NetApp is establishing its international headquarters in Cork, Ireland, aiming to create up to 500 jobs by 2025. This expansion is part of NetApp's strategy to grow its business and international presence, capitalizing on Ireland's strong ecosystem for tech companies and skilled graduates. The new office will support its global operations outside the US, aligning with the accelerated digital transformation trends observed during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Intel teams with Google Cloud to develop new class of data center chip
summary: Intel Corp and Google Cloud have collaborated to create "Mount Evans," a new class of chip called an "infrastructure processing unit" (IPU) aimed at optimizing cloud computing data centers. This chip separates and speeds up overhead tasks like setting up virtual machines, improving efficiency and security. Intel hopes to make this IPU an industry standard beyond Google, with both companies working on releasing free software tools.

title: Intel Unveils 12th Gen Intel Core, Launches World’s Best Gaming Processor, i9-12900K
summary: Intel has launched its 12th Gen Intel Core processor family, featuring six new unlocked desktop processors based on its performance hybrid architecture. Headlining this release is the Intel Core i9-12900K, touted as the world's best gaming processor. This new generation introduces DDR5 memory and PCIe 5.0 connectivity, aiming to significantly enhance gaming and content creation experiences.

title: AMD Grows Revenue In Sixth Straight Quarter Reveal Q3 2021 Results
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ:AMD) reported significant revenue growth for its third fiscal quarter of 2021, marking its sixth consecutive quarter of revenue increase, driven primarily by its Enterprise, Embedded and Semi-custom segment. The company recorded $4.3 billion in net sales, representing a 54% annual and 12% sequential growth, with strong contributions from data center and custom-design chips. Despite a sequential drop in cash flows due to investments in long-term supply chain capacity, AMD doubled its operating income and achieved a 78% annual net income growth, with projections for continued revenue and gross margin improvement in the current quarter.

title: AMD sales rise 54% on strong demand for chips for servers and game consoles
summary: AMD reported strong third-quarter earnings, beating analyst expectations for both revenue and EPS, driven by high demand for its chips in PCs, servers, and game consoles. The company also issued a robust forecast for the fourth quarter, expecting continued growth in server and semi-custom segments amidst ongoing chip shortages. AMD's strategic acquisition of Xilinx is proceeding, aiming to strengthen its position in the data center market.

title: Navitas Semiconductor Goes Public With $1.7B Valuation
summary: Navitas Semiconductor went public on October 20 under the symbol "NVTS" with a market value of roughly $2 billion, having completed a reverse merger with Live Oak Acquisition Corp. II. The company, which develops gallium nitride semiconductors, expects $27 million in revenue for 2021 and anticipates its revenue to more than double next year with an influx of $320 million from going public, allowing expansion into data centers, solar, and electric vehicles. Co-founders Gene Sheridan and Dan Kinzer celebrated the IPO seven years after starting the El Segundo-based company.

title: Intel CFO George Davis To Retire In May 2022
summary: Intel's CFO George Davis will retire in May 2022, marking him as the fourth highly compensated executive to leave the company since last year. Davis, who joined Intel in April 2019, previously served as CFO for Qualcomm and Applied Materials. His departure underscores significant leadership changes at the semiconductor giant.

title: Beelink SER3 Review – A good AMD Ryzen 7 mini PC… after tweaks
summary: This review examines the Beelink SER3 mini PC featuring an AMD Ryzen 7 3750H processor, highlighting that while its out-of-the-box performance is satisfactory, significant improvements can be achieved through BIOS tweaks, including memory overclocking and power scheme adjustments. The article details hardware specifications, performance benchmarks on Windows and Ubuntu, eGPU capabilities, power consumption, and gaming performance after optimization. It concludes that with a few specific changes, the SER3 offers impressive performance for its price, despite some initial limitations like single-channel memory.

title: What is MRAM (Magnetoresistive random access memory)?
summary: MRAM (magnetoresistive random access memory) is a non-volatile memory technology that stores data using magnetic states, offering advantages like high speed, high density, and low power consumption. Developed since the 1980s, MRAM aims to improve electronic products by potentially replacing DRAM and SRAM and outperforming NAND flash. While it has made inroads in specific industries and seen advancements from companies like Everspin, it remains an emerging technology with ongoing research focused on solutions like STT-MRAM for faster speeds and higher density.

title: Apple unveils game-changing MacBook Pro
summary: Apple has unveiled a completely reimagined MacBook Pro powered by the new M1 Pro and M1 Max chips, available in 14- and 16-inch models. These new laptops offer extraordinary performance, unprecedented battery life, and advanced features like a Liquid Retina XDR display, improved camera and audio systems, and extensive connectivity, marking a significant leap for professional users. The MacBooks are designed for various professionals, offer remarkable power efficiency, and feature an environmentally conscious design with recycled materials.

title: Synopsys Inc. stock rises Monday, still underperforms market
summary: Synopsys Inc. stock edged higher on Monday, rising 0.31% to $307.22, marking its fifth consecutive day of gains. Despite this, the stock underperformed the broader market, as the S&P 500 Index rose 0.34%. Synopsys Inc. also showed mixed performance compared to competitors like Intel Corp., Autodesk Inc., and Cadence Design Systems Inc.

title: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger hopes to win back Apple by outcompeting it
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger expressed his hope to regain Apple as a customer, acknowledging that Intel will need to outperform Apple to achieve this. Gelsinger stated that he doesn't blame Apple for choosing to produce its own chips over using Intel's. He emphasized the necessity of Intel's products being superior to Apple's.

title: ASML Holding: On Sentiment, Semiconductors & Sanity
summary: This article discusses ASML Holding N.V. (Nasdaq: ASML), a critical player in the semiconductor equipment market, highlighting its unique extreme ultraviolet (EUV) and deep ultraviolet (DUV) lithography technologies. Despite strong fundamental performance, including significant revenue growth and high gross margins, the stock recently experienced a 20% drop due to negative investor sentiment and inflation fears, rather than any issues with its business operations. The author argues that Wall Street's current focus on sentiment over fundamentals presents a buying opportunity for growth investors.

title: PAR Technology Introduces PAR Phase™
summary: ParTech, Inc. (PAR) has launched its new flagship POS hardware, PAR Phase™, built with 11th Gen Intel® Core™ vPro® and Intel® Celeron® processors. This next-generation terminal is designed to maximize ROI for restaurants by supporting future technological advancements like AI and fraud prevention, and offers various form factors to suit different aesthetics. The company highlights its reliability and adaptability to the evolving hospitality industry needs.

title: Highest Density SuperBlade® Server for HPC Applications
summary: Supermicro's SuperBlade® server solutions offer high density and efficiency for HPC, enterprise cloud, and other demanding applications. Available in 8U, 6U, and 4U enclosures, these systems support advanced processors from Intel and AMD, high-speed networking, and various storage options, alongside resource-saving architecture for optimal TCO. The article highlights successful deployments by companies like HEROZ and Korea Hydro and Nuclear Power, and provides extensive details on features and configurations.

title: Oregon’s chip industry, facing labor shortage, turns to TV and radio ads – and hiring people still in school
summary: Oregon's microelectronics industry is experiencing a severe labor shortage, prompting companies like Intel to launch aggressive recruitment campaigns including TV and radio ads and hiring students still in school. Despite high demand for chips and well-paying jobs, the industry struggles to attract workers due to misconceptions about the nature of the work. Educational institutions like Portland Community College are also seeing low enrollment in microelectronics programs, exacerbating the long-term staffing challenges for manufacturers.

title: Intel Advances Neuromorphic with Loihi 2, New Lava Software Framework and New Partners
summary: Intel introduced Loihi 2, its second-generation neuromorphic research chip, and Lava, an open-source software framework for developing neuro-inspired applications. Loihi 2 offers significant improvements in processing speed, resource density, and energy efficiency, and is fabricated with a pre-production version of the Intel 4 process. The Lava framework aims to foster collaboration and accelerate the path to commercialization within the neuromorphic research community.

title: Oracle revamps its Exadata hardware platforms, boosting performance for on-premises workloads
summary: Oracle has refreshed its Exadata X9M platforms, including Exadata Cloud@Customer X9M and Exadata Database Machine X9M, to significantly boost performance for on-premises database and analytics workloads. These new offerings incorporate advanced hardware and software optimizations, leading to improved speed, efficiency, and cost reductions for customers. Additionally, Oracle introduced the Zero Data Loss Recovery Appliance X9M with enhanced data protection and recovery capabilities.

title: Astera Labs Raises $50M in Series C Funding at a $950M Valuation
summary: Astera Labs, a Santa Clara, Calif.-based provider of connectivity solutions for intelligent systems, raised $50M in Series C funding, led by Fidelity Management and Research with participation from Atreides Management and Valor Equity Partners, and existing investors. The funding round values the company at $950M. The company plans to use the funds to expand its product portfolio and operations, including hiring in North America and Asia.

title: Astera Labs, a fabless chip startup, nabs $50M at a $950M valuation to remove bottlenecks in high-bandwidth cloud applications
summary: Astera Labs, a fabless semiconductor company, has raised $50 million in a Series C funding round, valuing the company at $950 million post-money. This funding, led by Fidelity Management and Research, will help the company scale operations and launch new product lines to address bottlenecks in high-bandwidth cloud applications, especially for AI and machine learning workloads. Intel, a strategic backer and customer, is collaborating with Astera Labs on developing PCI Express and CXL technology to enhance server and storage infrastructure.

title: Northern Trust Accused of Fiduciary Breaches Related to AutoZone 401(k)
summary: Northern Trust Corporation and Northern Trust, Inc. have been added as defendants in a lawsuit alleging fiduciary breaches related to AutoZone's 401(k) plan. The lawsuit accuses Northern Trust of failing to monitor fees and performance of plan investments and for allegedly giving bad advice that promoted high-fee proprietary products. The amended complaint suggests a conflict of interest, as Northern Trust received significant fees from managing AutoZone's pension plan.

title: Intel Breaks Ground on Two New Leading-Edge Chip Factories in Arizona
summary: Intel broke ground on two new leading-edge chip factories in Chandler, Arizona, representing a $20 billion investment that will increase its total Arizona investment to over $50 billion. This expansion aims to bolster U.S. semiconductor leadership, balance the global supply chain, and support surging demand for chips across various segments. The new facilities, Fab 52 and Fab 62, are expected to create thousands of jobs and manufacture Intel's most advanced process technologies by 2024.

title: Semiconductors: the skills shortage
summary: The semiconductor industry faces a severe global skills shortage, particularly for highly qualified engineers, despite significant government investments in various countries to boost chip production. This deficit threatens to hinder the growth of the digital revolution and supply chain security, exacerbated by geopolitical tensions and increasing demand. Addressing this requires not only massive STEM training but also competitive hiring practices, diversification of the workforce, and international cooperation that balances talent exchange with proprietary technology concerns.

title: The great chip shortage of 2021: Navitas Semiconductor weighs in
summary: The article discusses the global chip shortage of 2021, its impact on consumers and industries, and alternative solutions. Navitas Semiconductor CEO Gene Sheridan offers insights into price increases and highlights gallium nitride (GaN) as a viable alternative for power conversion chips, contrasting it with silicon's dominance in data processing. The piece emphasizes the continued investment in current silicon production despite GaN's advantages in sustainability and lead times.

title: Supermicro Introduces Rack Plug and Play Cloud Infrastructure with Free Remote Access Testing and Validation
summary: Supermicro has introduced a Rack Plug and Play Cloud Infrastructure, aiming to provide a turn-key solution for enterprises to repatriate cloud workloads with significant cost savings compared to hosted cloud offerings. The company is offering a free remote access testing and validation program called "JumpStart" for this new cloud infrastructure. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Red Hat and Intel, focuses on delivering efficient, scalable on-prem cloud solutions based on Red Hat OpenShift, utilizing Intel Xeon processors and Optane Persistent Memory.

title: Supermicro Expands Portfolio of High-Performance Single-Processor Systems
summary: Super Micro Computer, Inc. (SMCI) announced an expanded portfolio of single-processor systems based on new Intel Xeon E-2300 and 3rd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors. These systems are designed to support a wide range of applications from intelligent edge to data center-class systems, offering optimized performance and efficiency for various workloads. The new offerings feature PCI-E 4.0 I/O and Intel's SGX security features, available in multiple form factors.

title: Mobileye and SIXT Plan New Robotaxi Service
summary: Mobileye, an Intel subsidiary, and SIXT announced a collaboration to launch an autonomous robotaxi service in Munich, Germany, in 2022. Riders will be able to access the service via the Moovit and SIXT apps, leveraging Mobileye's self-driving technology and SIXT's mobility platform. This initiative marks the first commercial robotaxi service between a tech supplier and a mobility services provider, following Germany's new AV law.

title: John Donahoe
summary: John Donahoe is presented as the president and CEO of eBay Inc., overseeing a global e-commerce and payments leader with $14.1 billion in revenue in 2012. The article highlights his career trajectory, including his previous role as president of eBay Marketplaces and over 20 years at Bain & Company. It also mentions his educational background and Irish American heritage, with roots in County Tipperary.

title: Look for PCIe 5.0, NVMe 2.0 to boost storage performance
summary: Enterprises requiring high-performance storage for AI and ML workloads should anticipate new products utilizing PCIe 5.0 and NVMe 2.0 specifications. PCIe 5.0 doubles data rates, and NVMe 2.0 introduces command sets for key-value (KV) and Zoned Namespace (ZNS) technologies, though product availability will lag, with software changes needed to fully leverage NVMe 2.0's benefits.

title: Intel Appoints Bruce H. Andrews as Corporate Vice President and Chief Government Affairs Officer
summary: Intel Corporation announced the appointment of Bruce H. Andrews as corporate vice president and chief government affairs officer, effective Sept. 7, 2021. Andrews will lead Intel’s global government affairs group and oversee the company’s government affairs and public policy functions and strategies, reporting to Steven R. Rodgers, Intel’s executive vice president and general counsel. His extensive experience from roles at SoftBank Group, Rock Creek Global Advisors, the U.S. Department of Commerce, and Ford Motor Co. is expected to help Intel navigate the complex global political landscape and foster a constructive policy environment for the semiconductor industry.

title: Intel Lands Pentagon Deal to Support Domestic Chip Making
summary: Intel Corp. has secured a deal with the Pentagon to provide commercial foundry services as part of the Rapid Assured Microelectronics Prototypes - Commercial (RAMP-C) program. This initiative aims to bolster domestic design and production of advanced microchips, addressing a global chip shortage and supporting the U.S. government's long-term national security needs. Intel will join other companies like IBM and Synopsys in this effort, with plans to invest $20 billion in new factories in Arizona.
banner_image: Photo: Edwin Cheng for The Wall Street Journal

title: Intel Wins US Government Project to Develop Leading-Edge Foundry Ecosystem
summary: Intel Foundry Services (IFS) has been awarded an agreement by the U.S. Department of Defense to lead the first phase of the Rapid Assured Microelectronics Prototypes - Commercial (RAMP-C) program. This initiative aims to establish a domestic commercial foundry infrastructure for leading-edge custom and integrated circuits for critical defense systems. Intel will partner with industry leaders like IBM, Cadence, and Synopsys to develop and fabricate test chips, bolstering the U.S. semiconductor supply chain and leveraging Intel's significant investments in advanced process technologies.

title: Niche chip maker SkyWater plays key role in U.S. supply strategy
summary: SkyWater Technology Inc., a niche U.S. chip manufacturer, is playing a crucial role in the Biden administration's strategy to bolster domestic semiconductor supply chains and reduce reliance on foreign production, particularly from Taiwan. Despite its smaller size compared to industry giants, SkyWater's status as the only U.S. investor-owned fab and its advanced 3-D chip stacking technology, backed by significant military funding, position it as a key player in the intensifying U.S.-China competition for technological supremacy. The article highlights the global push by various nations, including the U.S., Europe, and Japan, to strengthen their domestic chip industries amidst supply chain disruptions and geopolitical concerns, though some experts question the efficacy of government interventions.

title: Intel CEO Calls Chip Maker ‘Willing Buyer’ as Semiconductor Industry Consolidates
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger has stated that the company is a "willing buyer" as the semiconductor industry consolidates. He plans to use mergers and acquisitions to support Intel's revival strategy. Gelsinger expects consolidation to continue in the industry and sees Intel as a key consolidator.

title: Rambus Outs HBM3 Details: 1.075 TBps of Bandwidth, 16 Channels, 16-Hi Stacks
summary: Rambus has unveiled new details about its HBM3-ready combined PHY and memory controller, revealing specifications that promise a significant leap in memory performance. The new HBM3 standard could achieve up to 8.4 Gbps-per-pin, 1.075 TB/s of throughput, and support for 16 channels and 16-Hi memory stacks, more than doubling the capacity and bandwidth of HBM2E. These advancements are expected to radically speed up future GPUs and SoCs, with the first chips leveraging this design anticipated in late 2022 or early 2023.

title: Edge Computing Market 2021-2025 Witnesses Emergence of Dominant Players Including Cisco Systems Inc., Dell Technologies Inc., and Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co.| Technavio
summary: The Edge Computing Market is projected to grow by USD 7.29 billion during 2021-2025, with a CAGR exceeding 26%. North America is expected to contribute 44% of this growth, while the industrial manufacturing segment will lead in end-user categories. Key players include Cisco Systems Inc., Dell Technologies Inc., and Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co., with the market facing challenges from competition with low-cost centralized computing.

title: Intel Says It’s ‘Winding Down’ RealSense Camera Business
summary: Intel is winding down its RealSense computer vision division, which produced high-tech cameras and sensors for applications like robotics and digital signage, to focus on its core businesses. The company will honor current customer commitments and plans to reallocate its computer vision talent and technology to support other core initiatives. While some RealSense product lines are ceasing, Intel will continue to sell select stereo products through existing distribution channels.

title: Nvidia earnings will be a data-center show, but don’t miss the software on the side stage
summary: Nvidia's upcoming second-quarter earnings report is expected to heavily feature data-center sales, with analysts predicting a significant rise in server-chip sales. However, the article highlights the increasing importance of Nvidia's software in its overall valuation, suggesting it should be compared more with software companies. While hardware is key, the software supporting Nvidia's graphics processing chips is a critical, often overlooked, aspect of its market position.

title: Board of Directors
summary: This article lists the members of the Joby Aviation Board of Directors, detailing their professional backgrounds and expertise. Each board member's biography highlights their relevant experience, particularly in technology, aviation, finance, and large-scale operations, which are valuable to Joby Aviation's mission. The board includes founders, seasoned executives from major tech and aviation companies, and finance professionals instrumental in the company's growth.

title: HP Delivers Ultimate Chrome OS Experiences for Life and Work in Today's Hybrid World
summary: HP Inc. has expanded its Chrome OS ecosystem with the introduction of the HP Chromebook x2 11 and the HP Chromebase 21.5 inch All-in-One Desktop, along with the HP M24fd USB-C Monitor. These new devices are designed to offer versatility and mobility for hybrid work and family use, featuring innovations like the first Chromebook detachable powered by Snapdragon 7c and the first Chromebase All-in-One with a rotating display. The company emphasizes sustainable design in its new lineup, reflecting a focus on environmental responsibility.

title: Is Vuzix Stock a Good Buy? Probably Not.
summary: This article evaluates Vuzix Corporation (VUZI) stock, concluding it is not a good buy due to weak revenues, a hardware-focused business model lacking recurring revenue, and an overvaluation despite recent growth. While augmented reality has enterprise potential, Vuzix's progress has been slow, and its stock price surge, attributed to the "ARK Effect," has led to rich valuations that are not supported by the company's current financial performance or business strategy. The author advises investors against buying, citing personal rules regarding market cap, valuation ratios, and consistent revenue growth.

title: ServiceNow Acquires Database Performance Software Company Swarm64 -
summary: ServiceNow has acquired Swarm64, a Berlin-based database performance software company, to enhance its ability to scale digital workflows and handle growing data volumes for customers. Swarm64, founded in 2013 and previously venture-backed by Intel Capital and Xilinx, specializes in combining analytics and transactional database functionality. This acquisition aligns with ServiceNow's broader strategy of evolving its offerings beyond IT service management and expanding its partner ecosystem.

title: SK Hynix to set up US NAND firm led by Intel’s senior vice president
summary: SK Hynix, after acquiring Intel's NAND memory chip business, plans to establish a new company in the United States. This new entity will be led by Robert Crooke, Intel's senior vice president, with the aim of retaining Intel's existing engineering talent. The move is part of the $9 billion acquisition which is currently under antitrust review globally, with China being the only major authority yet to approve.

title: NVIDIA maintains dominant position in 2020 market for AI processors for cloud and data center
summary: NVIDIA maintained its dominant position in the 2020 global market for AI processors used in cloud and data centers, holding an 80.6% share of global revenue. The company generated $3.2 billion in cloud and data center AI processor revenue, up from $1.8 billion in 2019, primarily due to its leadership in GPU-derived chips. Omdia predicts that alternative suppliers will gain significant market share in the coming years despite NVIDIA's current advantage.

title: Microchip Technology sees record sales as computer chip supply issues persist
summary: Microchip Technology (MCHP) reported record-setting sales at the beginning of its 2022 fiscal year, driven by the ongoing global demand for computer chips. CEO Ganesh Moorthy indicated that the entire semiconductor supply chain remains constrained, suggesting that chip shortages will extend into 2022. The company, based in Chandler, is experiencing strong demand amidst an industry-wide supply crunch.

title: AMD Trying To Increase Worldwide Semiconductor Availability
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) is making significant investments across its supply chain to increase worldwide semiconductor availability amidst a global chip shortage. The company is responding to the surge in demand for PCs, re-energized by remote work and learning during the pandemic, and is working to bridge the gap in semiconductor supply which is expected to last until at least 2023. AMD's Corporate Vice President, David McAfee, highlighted their efforts to source additional capacity and noted the challenge of the limited number of specialized chip fabrication facilities globally.

title: Intel Launches AI for Workforce Program for Students in 18 Community Colleges
summary: Intel announced a significant expansion of its AI for Workforce Program to 18 community colleges across 11 U.S. states, partnering with Dell Technologies. The program aims to equip students with critical AI skills to meet the growing demand in the workforce, offering certificates or associate degrees in artificial intelligence. This initiative seeks to democratize AI education and foster a diverse talent pool, with plans for further expansion in 2022.

title: Supermicro Adds 60- & 90-Bay 3rd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable Storage
summary: Super Micro Computer, Inc. has announced new 60-bay and 90-bay top-loading storage solutions powered by 3rd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors. These new systems leverage Supermicro's Simply Double storage systems and are designed to support PCIe Gen4 drives for maximum performance and offer flexible configurations including single-node, dual-node, and dual-node high availability. The solutions feature hot-swap SAS/SATA bays, M.2 slots, internal slim SATA SSD slots, and can support up to 1.6PB of HDD storage and 60TB of flash storage.

title: BlackRock, Others Invest $450 Million on PsiQuantum
summary: PsiQuantum has secured $450 million in Series D funding led by Blackrock, with participation from Baillie Gifford, Quantum1 Group, M12 – Microsoft's venture fund, Blackbird Ventures, and Temasek. The Palo Alto-based company, which leverages a photonic approach to quantum computing, plans to use the funds to expand its team and build a 1 million-quantum-bit machine. This latest funding round brings PsiQuantum's total raised since 2016 to $665 million and values the company at $3.15 billion, making it one of the largest independent Quantum Technology companies.

title: Hey Intel, AMD’s CEO is also ready to ‘fight for every socket,’ while producing strong growth
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su responded to Intel's promise to "fight for every socket" by stating AMD is also ready for the competition. This comes as AMD demonstrates strong growth, particularly with data-center sales exceeding 20% of its revenue, leading to an increase in its annual guidance. Su's comments highlight the escalating rivalry in the chip market, particularly in the crucial data-center segment.

title: Hey Intel, AMD’s CEO is also ready to ‘fight for every socket,’ while producing strong growth
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su echoed Intel's pledge to "fight for every socket" in the crucial data-center market, demonstrating confidence as AMD continues strong growth. AMD is outperforming Intel by increasing its annual guidance and seeing data-center sales top 20% of its revenue.

title: Intel to build Qualcomm chips, aims to catch foundry rivals by 2025
summary: Intel announced its factories will begin building chips for Qualcomm and Amazon, aiming to regain its leadership in chip manufacturing by 2025 against rivals like TSMC and Samsung. The company outlined a new roadmap with five chipmaking technologies and a revised naming scheme to reflect its competitive standing. This move signifies Intel's commitment to overcoming past delays and establishing itself as a leading foundry.

title: Intel Sets Plan to Again Become World’s Premier Chip Company
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger has announced a strategic plan to reclaim the company's position as the world's leading chip manufacturer within four years. The plan involves introducing a new central processing unit annually between 2021 and 2025, each featuring more advanced transistor technology to compete with Asian rivals amidst a global chip shortage.

title: Intel Accelerates Process and Packaging Innovations
summary: Intel Corporation unveiled its detailed process and packaging technology roadmap through 2025 and beyond, introducing breakthrough technologies like RibbonFET and PowerVia, and advanced 3D packaging innovations such as Foveros Omni and Direct. The company also announced a new node naming convention and strong momentum for Intel Foundry Services, aiming for process performance leadership by 2025.

title: GlobalFoundries' second fab sure to bring more jobs, tech prestige to Capital Region
summary: GlobalFoundries plans to build a second chip manufacturing facility, Fab 8.2, in Saratoga County, which is expected to cost over $10 billion and create 1,000 new jobs. This expansion is contingent on federal funding from the U.S. Innovation and Competition Act, which aims to boost U.S. semiconductor manufacturing amidst a global chip shortage. The project, along with an existing Fab 8 expansion, will significantly increase chip output and solidify the Capital Region's role in the global tech industry.

title: Intel CEO Says Chip Shortage Could Stretch Into 2023
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger believes the global semiconductor shortage could extend into 2023, joining a growing consensus that supply chain disruptions will persist. The shortage is impacting various industries, leading to rising prices and production delays for goods ranging from consumer gadgets to automobiles. While some easing is expected later this year, a full return to supply-and-demand balance in the semiconductor industry could take one to two years due to the time required to build manufacturing capacity.

title: How an executive’s hair dryer saved the memory chips — tales of Micron’s 40 years
summary: This article chronicles the 40-year history of Micron Technology Inc., from its humble beginnings in a dentist's basement in Boise to becoming a global semiconductor powerhouse. It details the company's founding by the Parkinson brothers, its challenges, growth, leadership changes, and its evolving relationship with Boise, transitioning from a manufacturing hub to a research and development center with significant local economic impact. The narrative highlights key figures like Steve Appleton and the unique story of how a hair dryer saved early Micron chip sales.

title: Nvidia Stock’s Surge Makes Chip Maker 10th-Biggest U.S. Listed Company
summary: Nvidia Corp. has become the 10th-largest U.S. public company due to a surge in its stock, driven by the post-pandemic boom in the semiconductor business. The company's shares have increased by nearly 80% over the past year, resulting in a market value of approximately $453 billion. This valuation exceeds the combined market capitalization of its rivals Intel Corp. and Broadcom Inc.

title: Zoom to Acquire Five9: Turns its Focus on the Contact Center
summary: Zoom Video Communications Inc. (ZM.O) announced its acquisition of cloud software provider Five9 Inc. (FIVN.O) in an all-stock transaction valued at approximately $14.7 billion. This strategic move aims to diversify Zoom's business beyond its core video conferencing services by expanding into the contact center market. The acquisition is seen as a logical horizontal expansion for Zoom, leveraging Five9's cloud-native offerings and significant growth.

title: Intel Elects Andrea Goldsmith to Board of Directors
summary: Intel Corporation announced the election of Andrea Goldsmith, dean of engineering and applied science at Princeton University, to its board of directors, effective September 1, 2021. Goldsmith brings extensive experience in wireless communications, having co-founded Plume WiFi and Quantenna Communications, and currently serves on the boards of Medtronic and Crown Castle International. Her appointment will increase Intel's board to 10 members, contributing to 40% women and 30% racially or ethnically diverse directors.

title: AEye’s LiDAR to be Available on The NVIDIA DRIVE Autonomous Vehicle Platform
summary: AEye, Inc. announced its adaptive, intelligent LiDAR solutions will be available on the NVIDIA DRIVE autonomous vehicle platform. This collaboration will provide ADAS and AV developers with advanced tools to enhance data quality for Level 2+ to Level 5 autonomous driving applications. Both companies emphasize that intelligence and AI-driven sensing are crucial for developing safer and high-performing autonomous systems.

title: The pros and cons of a rumored Intel-GlobalFoundries deal
summary: Analysts are weighing in on the rumored deal between Intel Corp and GlobalFoundries. While a potential acquisition could provide Intel with immediate foundry expertise and additional facilities, some believe it could also be a distraction during a critical period for the company. The article discusses the potential benefits and drawbacks of such a merger.

title: Intel in talks to buy GlobalFoundries for about $30 billion - WSJ
summary: Intel Corp is reportedly in talks to acquire semiconductor manufacturer GlobalFoundries Inc for approximately $30 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. This potential deal comes amid a global semiconductor shortage and could help Intel significantly ramp up chip production, although GlobalFoundries has denied direct discussions with Intel. The acquisition could also raise antitrust questions given GlobalFoundries' history with AMD.

title: Intel is in talks to buy GlobalFoundries for about $30 billion
summary: Intel is reportedly in discussions to acquire GlobalFoundries for approximately $30 billion, a move that would significantly boost Intel's strategy to become a major contract chip manufacturer. This potential acquisition aligns with Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger's push to expand chip-making capabilities for other companies, a market currently dominated by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. The deal, if it materializes, would be Intel's largest acquisition ever, although GlobalFoundries is also considering an initial public offering.

title: Intel exploring deal to buy US chipmaker GlobalFoundries for $30B
summary: Intel Corp. is reportedly in talks to acquire chipmaker GlobalFoundries Inc. for up to $30 billion, which would be Intel's largest acquisition to date. The potential deal aligns with Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger's strategy to bolster the company's chip production capabilities and compete with industry leaders like TSMC. Analysts note the acquisition could offer immediate benefits to Intel by providing access to more fabs, while GlobalFoundries' owners would secure a significant payday without the uncertainty of an IPO.

title: AT&T, Samsung, Qualcomm help launch 6G research center at University of Texas
summary: The University of Texas at Austin is launching a new 6G research center, 6G@UT, with significant backing from major wireless industry players including AT&T, Samsung, and Qualcomm. These companies, along with Nvidia, InterDigital, Crown Castle, Intel, Honda, Nextnav, Western Digital, and Yokogawa, will fund research projects for three years and collaborate on developing foundational 6G technologies. The center will focus on advanced sensing, machine learning, terahertz spectrum use, and aims to revolutionize wireless communication with unprecedented native intelligence.

title: Intel Corporation names Shlomit Weiss as co-General Manager of its Design Engineering Group
summary: Shlomit Weiss is returning to Intel as Senior Vice President and co-General Manager of its Design Engineering Group, where she will oversee chip development for client computers. Weiss, who previously spent 28 years at Intel and most recently served as Senior VP for Silicon Engineering at Nvidia, will work from Israel alongside Sunil Shenoy. She brings extensive experience, having been recognized for developing Intel's Dual-Core processor architecture and leading the Sky Lake processor development.

title: TSMC Wins Intel Order For Two 3nm CPUs To Regain Market Share Lost To AMD
summary: TSMC has secured an order from Intel to produce two 3nm CPUs, signaling Intel's strategy to regain market share lost to AMD, particularly in notebooks and data centers. This move marks a significant shift for Intel, which has historically relied on its own manufacturing facilities, and indicates a larger 3nm chip order for Intel than for Apple. Mass production for TSMC's 3nm process is expected to begin next year, with commercial output of Intel's chips following in 2023.

title: Focus: Qualcomm's new CEO eyes dominance in the laptop markets
summary: Qualcomm's new CEO, Cristiano Amon, plans to challenge Apple's dominance in the laptop market by developing energy-efficient chips with the help of former Apple chip architects. The company is also focusing on revenue growth from China for its smartphone chip business despite political tensions and aims to leverage its Nuvia acquisition to push 5G connectivity into laptops, providing custom-designed chips to compete with Apple. Amon also faces the challenge of potentially losing Apple as a modem chip customer and improving Qualcomm's brand recognition among consumers.

title: Qualcomm's new CEO eyes dominance in laptop markets
summary: Qualcomm's new CEO, Cristiano Amon, aims to dominate the laptop chip market by next year, challenging Apple's energy-efficient chips with custom-designed processors. The company plans to leverage its acquisition of Nuvia and a team of ex-Apple chip architects to create leading performance for battery-powered devices. Amon also anticipates significant revenue growth from China, despite political tensions, and is open to licensing Nuvia's designs for cloud computing data centers.

title: Intel restructures data center group, announces new execs and one exit
summary: Intel's CEO Pat Gelsinger is continuing to reorganize the company, announcing several executive changes and a restructuring of its important data center business unit. The company also created a new GPU unit as part of these changes.

title: GE Healthcare, Wayra Choose 5 AI-Led Startups for Edison Accelerator
summary: GE Healthcare and Wayra UK have selected five AI-led health tech startups for their first Edison Accelerator cohort in EMEA. These startups will focus on leveraging AI to enhance medical imaging, improve oncology care, and optimize patient experiences, with the goal of improving diagnosis, care pathways, and patient support. The program provides mentorship, co-development opportunities, and access to GE Healthcare's global network to help these businesses scale their solutions.

title: Intel Restructuring: Navin Shenoy Out; New Software, GPU Units
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger has announced a major restructuring of the company, leading to the departure of top data center executive Navin Shenoy. The Data Platform Group is being split into two new business units, and two new divisions, the Software and Advanced Technology Group and the Accelerated Computing Systems and Graphics Group, are being formed. These changes aim to accelerate Intel's pace in regaining technology leadership, with new leaders appointed to head the reorganized groups.

title: Longtime Intel exec Navin Shenoy leaves as chipmaker restructures data center business
summary: Longtime Intel executive Navin Shenoy is departing the company as CEO Pat Gelsinger implements a major restructuring of its critical data center business, creating two new units. The Data Platform Group is being split into a Datacenter and AI group led by Sandra Rivera, and a Network and Edge Group led by Nick McKeown. Additionally, Intel is forming a Software and Advanced Technology Group and an Accelerated Computing Systems and Graphics Group, led by Greg Lavender and Raja Koduri respectively, to better compete with rivals like Nvidia, Arm Ltd., Qualcomm Corp., and Advanced Micro Devices Inc.

title: Intel to work with India’s Reliance Jio on 5G network technology
summary: Intel Corp announced a partnership with India's Reliance Jio to co-develop 5G networking technology. This collaboration stems from Intel's venture capital unit's $250 million investment in Jio Platforms last year. The companies will focus on "co-innovations" for Reliance Jio's 5G radio-access network.

title: Chipmaker SiFive Is Said to Draw Intel Takeover Interest
summary: Chipmaker SiFive Inc. has reportedly attracted takeover interest from Intel Corp., with Intel offering more than $2 billion for the semiconductor design startup. The talks are said to be in early stages, and SiFive retains the option to remain an independent company.

title: Dell announces new AMD-based Integrated Systems for Azure Stack HCI
summary: Dell Technologies Inc. has launched new AMD-based configurations for its Dell EMC Integrated Systems for Microsoft Azure Stack HCI, designed to handle more complex workloads and offer enhanced performance. These systems feature AMD EPYC 2nd generation CPUs and incorporate advanced security features from both AMD and Dell. Additionally, software updates aim to simplify provisioning and delivery tasks for IT engineers by pre-installing the Azure Stack HCI operating system and integrating OpenManage software with Microsoft Windows Admin Center.

title: Qualcomm supplying new Snapdragon chips locally
summary: Qualcomm Inc. is expanding its presence in the computer market by supplying new Snapdragon processors for 5G-enabled laptops, partnering with local companies like Acer Inc. The company aims to challenge Intel Corp. and transfer mobile applications to laptops, targeting various tiers of notebooks. Qualcomm also revealed its acquisition of Nuvia Inc. for about US$1.4 billion, enhancing its CPU and technology design capabilities.

title: How Nvidia plans to own the data center with AI
summary: Nvidia aims to revolutionize enterprise computing by making data centers run 10 times faster at one-tenth the cost, leveraging its strong position in AI architectures. The company plans to disrupt Intel's x86 dominance through Arm-based architectures, integrated chip designs, and a compelling software consumption model. The article highlights Nvidia's strategic moves, financial standing, and the potential impact of its proposed acquisition of Arm Ltd. on the data center market.

title: Intel vs. AMD — should you buy either stock now?
summary: This article contrasts Intel and AMD, two dominant players in the processor market, from an investment perspective. While AMD has shown significant outperformance under CEO Lisa Su, Intel remains the largest provider of core processors for PCs and servers, boasting a substantial R&D budget and strong cash flow. The piece questions which stock is a better buy for investors, acknowledging Intel's new CEO Pat Gelsinger's efforts to diversify and fend off AMD's market share gains.

title: Intel vs. AMD — should you buy either stock now?
summary: This article analyzes the long-standing rivalry between Intel and AMD in the core processor market. While AMD has shown significant market-share growth and superior stock performance, Intel remains a dominant force with a large R&D budget and strong cash flow. The piece explores the investment merits of each company for those considering buying either stock.

title: Oracle launches Arm-based cloud computing service using Ampere chips
summary: Oracle Corp has launched a new cloud computing service that utilizes Arm-based data center chips from Ampere Computing, becoming the second major cloud provider after Amazon Web Services to offer such a service. This move aims to provide customers with more value and choice, challenging the long-standing dominance of Intel and AMD in the cloud chip market. Oracle is also promoting initiatives to expand software compatibility with Arm chips.

title: Flex manufactures everything from hair dryers to the Mac Pro — what’s next?
summary: This article features an interview with Flex CEO Revathi Advaithi, discussing the company's diverse manufacturing operations from consumer electronics to autonomous driving systems, and the complex interplay of politics, automation, and global supply chains. Advaithi also addresses the ongoing chip shortage, the future of manufacturing in the US, and Flex's commitment to sustainability. She highlights the company's shift towards investing in healthcare and automotive sectors due to technological changes.

title: SOXX Versus SOXL Semiconductor ETF Forecast: Which Is a Better Buy?
summary: This article compares two semiconductor ETFs, SOXX and SOXL, to determine which might be a better investment. SOXL is a leveraged ETF offering 3x daily returns, leading to higher performance during bull markets but also higher risk. SOXX is a plain ETF for risk-averse, long-term investors, with both ETFs holding similar top companies and having a positive medium-term outlook despite the cyclical nature of the industry.

title: Marius A. Haas, Owner
summary: Marius A. Haas is a Founding Partner of BayPine Capital and an owner of Austin FC. His career includes leadership roles at Dell Technologies, KKR, Hewlett-Packard, Compaq, and Intel Corporation, with a focus on commercial operations and M&A. Haas also serves on the board of Westlake Chemical and is a strategic advisor to ASU Thunderbird.

title: AMD CEO predicts supply of TSMC-built chips to improve
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su addressed current chip shortages, stating they are cyclical and not a "disaster," despite the semiconductor firm's increasingly tough path. Under Su's leadership, AMD has seen significant growth, with its market value surging to over US$90 billion, leading to a recent US$4 billion stock-repurchase plan. She emphasized the competitive nature of the market and AMD's ambitions amidst accelerated demand for computing resources due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Implications of US-China Tech War for Taiwan’s Semiconductors Industry
summary: Taiwan's semiconductor industry, particularly TSMC, has gained significant global attention amidst worsening US-China relations, highlighting its critical role in advanced technology and global industrial activity. However, both US and Chinese ambitions for self-sufficiency in semiconductor production threaten Taiwan's business model and could eventually create friction for its firms. Taiwan's government must strategize to position its tech dominance as a partnership rather than a risk to ensure its continued viability.

title: Global Magneto Resistive Random-Access Memory (MRAM) Market
summary: The global Magneto Resistive Random-Access Memory (MRAM) market is projected to grow from USD 1.02 billion in 2019 to USD 25.82 billion by 2027, exhibiting a CAGR of 49.60%. A new report from Fior Markets provides a comprehensive analysis of the market, including growth drivers, restraints, opportunities, and key players such as Intel, Honeywell, Toshiba, and Samsung. The study segments the market by type (Spin-Transfer Torque, Toggle) and application (Automotive, Consumer Electronics, Enterprise Storage, Aerospace, Robotics).

title: Intel’s 2020-2021 Corporate Responsibility Report: A Letter from Intel’s CEO
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger introduces the company's 2020-2021 Corporate Responsibility Report, highlighting progress toward its 2030 RISE goals. The report emphasizes advancements in renewable energy, water conservation, diversity and inclusion efforts, and leveraging technology for global impact through initiatives like the Pandemic Response Technology Initiative. Gelsinger reinforces Intel's commitment to creating world-changing technology while addressing critical societal challenges.

title: Cisco to buy Israeli startup Sedona for reported $100 million
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. announced its intention to acquire Israeli communication technologies startup Sedona Systems. While financial details were not officially disclosed, the deal is estimated to be worth $100 million. Sedona Systems, founded in 2014, specializes in network automation platforms to optimize network infrastructure.

title: Intel Launches New 11th Gen Core for Mobile
summary: Intel Corporation (INTC) announced the global launch of its 11th Generation Intel Core H-series mobile processors, code-named "Tiger Lake-H," on May 11, 2021. The flagship Intel Core i9-11980HK, based on 10nm SuperFin process technology, delivers speeds up to 5.0GHz, offering industry-leading mobile performance for gaming, content creation, and business professionals with up to eight cores and 16 threads, and PCIe Gen 4 support. The release also includes new Intel vPro H-series and Intel Xeon W-11000 series mobile processors, powering over 80 enthusiast laptop designs this year.

title: Samsung to jump into laptop processor market with Exynos chip in H2
summary: Samsung Electronics is set to enter the laptop processor market in the second half of this year with a premium Exynos chip, targeting the rapidly growing global laptop market. The new Exynos chip will feature a GPU developed with AMD, focusing on improved computing power and battery efficiency with 5-nanometer processing technology. Samsung's move follows other tech giants like Apple and Qualcomm, who have also developed laptop-grade chipsets, as the company seeks to compete with market leader Intel.

title: IBM unveils 2-nanometer chip technology for faster computing
summary: IBM has introduced what it claims is the world's first 2-nanometer chipmaking technology, a significant advancement promising up to 45% faster performance and 75% more power efficiency compared to current 7-nanometer chips. This breakthrough demonstrates that silicon chips still have generational improvements to offer, despite slowing progress in transistor miniaturization. While the technology will take several years to reach the market, it represents a crucial step in computing power and efficiency.

title: Overview: Micron Technology business segments
summary: This article provides an overview of Micron Technology's business segments and its position in the semiconductor market. It details Micron's product offerings, including RAM, NAND, and NOR, and how they are organized into CNBU, SBU, MBU, and EBU segments. The article also mentions key competitors like Intel, Samsung, Qualcomm, and SK Hynix.

title: Intel to Invest $3.5 Billion to Expand New Mexico Manufacturing Operations
summary: Intel Corporation announced a $3.5 billion investment to equip its New Mexico operations for advanced semiconductor packaging technologies, including Foveros. This multiyear investment is expected to create at least 700 high-tech jobs and 1,000 construction jobs, supporting an additional 3,500 jobs in the state. The expansion is a key part of Intel's IDM 2.0 strategy, reinforcing its leadership in advanced packaging and expanding manufacturing capacity.

title: Apple’s new M1 chip creates a competitive advantage
summary: Apple has introduced new iMacs and iPad Pros featuring its M1 chip, allowing the company to control its entire technology stack and gain a competitive advantage. This strategy insulates Apple from the global chip shortage affecting other manufacturers reliant on third-party semiconductors. Experts like Richard Barnett highlight that Apple's approach contrasts sharply with the challenges faced by automotive, consumer electronics, and medical device industries.

title: Intel Exploring Sale of its Sports Technology Arm, True View Platform
summary: Intel Corp. is considering selling its sports division, which specializes in immersive video technology, particularly its True View platform. The company has retained PJT Partners to assist with the potential sale, and possible buyers could include tech companies, media platforms, or sports technology SPACs. Intel's sports group was formed in 2016 from acquisitions and its True View technology is used in numerous NFL and NBA stadiums, as well as European soccer clubs, offering 360-degree video replays.

title: Intel vs Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)
summary: This article analyzes the long-standing rivalry between Intel and AMD, comparing their historical market dominance, recent performance, financial health, and future outlook. It highlights AMD's recent surge due to TSMC's advanced chip manufacturing, challenging Intel's traditional leadership. The author concludes by positioning AMD as a growth play and Intel as a value play, considering potential comebacks and ongoing industry challenges like chip shortages.

title: Arm details new data center chips, says Oracle, Alibaba will use them
summary: Arm Ltd revealed new details about its next-generation data center technology, with its "N2" Neoverse computing cores expected to be about 40% faster and "V1" cores 50% faster than previous methods for AI tasks. Oracle Corp and Alibaba Group Holding are set to use these new Arm-based chips, signaling a growing push into the data center processor market long dominated by Intel and AMD. This move is seen as crucial for Nvidia Corp's $40 billion acquisition of Arm, which is currently under national security review.

title: Intel Collaborates with Microsoft against Cryptojacking
summary: Intel and Microsoft are expanding their collaboration against cryptojacking, with Microsoft Defender for Endpoint now utilizing Intel Threat Detection Technology (Intel TDT) for CPU-based cryptomining machine learning detection. This integration enhances endpoint detection and response by providing full-stack visibility and hardware-accelerated threat detection, offering robust protection without compromising PC performance. The move addresses the growing threat of cryptojacking as cryptocurrency values rise, leveraging Intel TDT's unique CPU-based malware monitoring capabilities.

title: 4 “Picks and Shovels”-Type Semiconductor Companies: Lam Research (LRCX), ASML Holding NV (ASML), Micro-Mechanics (5DD), UMS Holdings (558)
summary: This article identifies four "picks and shovels" type semiconductor companies that are poised to benefit from the current global semiconductor shortage and increased spending in the sector. These companies provide essential tools, equipment, and services for semiconductor manufacturing, rather than producing the chips themselves. The article highlights Lam Research, ASML Holding NV, Micro-Mechanics, and UMS Holdings, detailing their unique contributions to the industry and financial performance indicators.

title: Semiconductor maker Skyworks to acquire Silicon Laboratories' infrastructure and automotive business for $2.75bn
summary: Skyworks Solutions plans to acquire Silicon Laboratories' infrastructure and automotive business for $2.75 billion to expand into new markets like industrial, 5G wireless infrastructure, and data centers. This acquisition will help Skyworks diversify its revenue and leverage its global sales channels while Silicon Labs' team brings decades of innovation. The move also positions Skyworks in the automotive market amid a global semiconductor shortage impacting car manufacturers.

title: Intel breaks silence on effects of Micron's 3D XPoint exit
summary: Intel's director of technology initiatives expressed surprise at Micron's decision to exit the 3D XPoint business and confirmed Intel's plans to integrate Optane with the emerging CXL interface. Micron, however, believes there are better alternatives for CXL-enabled memory solutions than 3D XPoint, viewing 3D XPoint as an expensive investment without a broad, big market in the near future. Despite Micron's exit, Intel remains confident in its ability to supply Optane products, anticipating a persistent memory market exceeding $36 billion by 2030.

title: Semiconductor giant Intel wins patent infringement trial
summary: A federal jury in Texas has cleared Intel of claims it was infringing two patents formerly owned by Dutch chip maker NXP Semiconductors, dodging a potential US$1 billion-plus blow. This win comes after a different jury in the same courthouse ordered Intel to pay VLSI Technology US$2.18 billion over other patents last month. VLSI was seeking US$3 billion in damages in this latest trial, arguing the inventions were critical to Intel's chip development.

title: Apple Launches Powerful New iPad, ‘Air Tags’ to Track Lost Items
summary: Apple announced new products including a powerful iPad Pro with the M1 chip, new iMac computers, and AirTags for tracking lost personal items. The new iPad Pro aims to meet increased demand for work-from-home solutions, while AirTags offer a secure way to locate misplaced objects using the "Find My" network. Apple also unveiled a new podcast subscription service.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: How Intel contributes $10B to Oregon's GDP
summary: Intel's latest report highlights its significant economic impact on Oregon, contributing $10 billion to the state's GDP based on 2019 figures. This comes as new CEO Pat Gelsinger advocates for boosting American semiconductor manufacturing, underscoring the importance of Intel's operations in the U.S. The article emphasizes Intel's role in the regional economy.

title: Ford details new production cuts due to global chip shortage
summary: Ford Motor Co. announced additional plant shutdowns affecting five U.S. facilities and one in Turkey due to the ongoing global semiconductor shortage. The company had previously estimated the shortage could cost between $1 billion and $2.5 billion, and other automakers like Nissan, Honda, and Volkswagen are also experiencing production cuts. The semiconductor shortage, exacerbated by a fire at a Japanese chip factory and winter storms in Texas, continues to severely impact the automotive industry.

title: Dell announces long-awaited spinoff of VMware in $9B deal
summary: Dell Technologies Inc. announced the long-expected spinoff of VMware Inc., its majority-owned computing virtualization company, in a deal set to create two standalone companies. The move, aimed at simplifying capital structures and unlocking shareholder value, will see VMware distribute a cash dividend of $11.5 billion to $12 billion, with $9.3 billion to $9.7 billion going to Dell to help pay down debt. While the two companies will remain commercially linked, analysts believe the separation will boost stock prices and allow both entities to pursue independent growth opportunities.

title: Data processing units accelerate infrastructure performance
summary: Data processing units (DPUs) are emerging as a critical technology in data centers, offloading networking and communication tasks from CPUs to enhance infrastructure performance. This article explains how DPUs work, highlights key vendors like Fungible, Nvidia, AWS, and Nebulon, and discusses their role in software-defined infrastructure and future enterprise adoption.

title: NVIDIA Announces CPU for Giant AI and High Performance Computing Workloads
summary: NVIDIA has announced its first data center CPU, Grace, an Arm-based processor designed to deliver 10x the performance of today’s fastest servers for complex AI and high-performance computing workloads. This specialized processor targets advanced applications with enormous datasets and massive memory requirements, making NVIDIA a "three-chip company" alongside its GPUs and DPUs. The Swiss National Supercomputing Centre and Los Alamos National Laboratory are among the first to plan Grace-powered supercomputers, expected online in 2023.

title: Nvidia to directly challenge Intel with Arm-based 'Grace' server chip
summary: Nvidia Corp announced its plan to develop an Arm-based server processor chip called "Grace," directly challenging Intel in the data center market. This move intensifies competition with Intel and adds complexity to the antitrust review of Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm. The new server chip, expected in 2023, is designed for artificial intelligence algorithms, further solidifying Nvidia's focus on AI computing.

title: Nvidia steps up competition with Intel and AMD with first data-center CPU, based on Arm
summary: Nvidia introduced its first data-center CPU, named Grace, which is based on Arm technology, intensifying its competition with Intel and AMD in the artificial intelligence and data-center market. This move comes as Nvidia awaits approval for its $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings PLC, showcasing its strategy to leverage licensed technology for future AI business. The new CPU, announced at Nvidia's annual GTC developers conference, aims to challenge the dominance of Intel and AMD in the server CPU space.

title: Nvidia steps up competition with Intel and AMD with first data-center CPU, based on Arm
summary: Nvidia introduced its first data-center CPU, named Grace, which is based on Arm technology, intensifying its competition with Intel and AMD in the artificial-intelligence market. This move comes as Nvidia awaits approval for its $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings PLC, demonstrating its strategy for future AI business. The new CPU bundle for servers enters a market traditionally dominated by Intel and AMD.

title: Nvidia steps up competition with Intel and AMD with first data-center CPU, based on Arm
summary: Nvidia introduced its first data-center CPU, named Grace, based on Arm technology, aiming to intensify its competition with Intel and AMD in the artificial-intelligence market. This move signals Nvidia's commitment to the chip-making sector, leveraging technology from its acquisition target, Arm Holdings PLC, to tap into the growing AI business. The announcement was made during Nvidia’s annual GTC developers conference by CEO Jensen Huang.

title: Nvidia debuts Grace, its first data center CPU for advanced AI workloads
summary: Nvidia has launched Grace, its first Arm-based data center CPU, specifically designed to handle the demanding requirements of advanced AI workloads like natural language processing and drug discovery. Grace is intended to work in conjunction with Nvidia's GPUs to deliver significantly higher performance than current systems, and will power future supercomputers like the Alps project at the Swiss National Computing Center. The company also announced other AI initiatives, including the cloud-native DGX SuperPOD and the Jarvis conversational AI framework.

title: GM cutting overtime shifts at two U.S. truck plants due to chip shortage
summary: General Motors is reducing overtime production shifts at two U.S. assembly plants that manufacture its full-size pickups due to the ongoing semiconductor chip shortage. This marks the first time GM has cut production shifts for its highly profitable pickups because of the chip shortage, which it expects to reduce its operating profit by $1.5 billion to $2 billion this year. The company is prioritizing chip allocation for pickups and full-size SUVs and is canceling traditional summer shutdown periods at most U.S. plants to compensate for lost production.

title: Intel unveils highest performing data-center processors, made with Israel team
summary: Intel has launched its new Ice Lake Server processors, which are optimized for cloud and high-end computing and promise 46% higher performance than the previous generation. These processors, developed in Haifa and produced in Kiryat Gat, Israel, include built-in AI capabilities, encryption, and cybersecurity features. All major cloud service providers, including Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and Dell, plan to offer services powered by these new Intel processors in 2021.

title: Cisco, Dell and Lenovo debut new servers based on Intel's 3rd Gen Xeon Scalable processors
summary: Cisco, Dell, and Lenovo have all announced new server lineups featuring Intel's new 3rd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors. These new servers offer improved performance, enhanced security, and greater efficiency for various data center workloads, targeting hybrid cloud environments, AI, machine learning, and business-critical operations. The companies are also introducing new features like integration with hybrid cloud platforms, advanced cooling technologies, and flexible consumption models.

title: Intel Launches Its Most Advanced Performance Data Center Platform
summary: Intel has launched its 3rd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors (code-named “Ice Lake”), marking its most advanced performance data center platform. These processors offer an average 46% increase in performance for popular data center workloads, alongside built-in AI acceleration and advanced security features. The platform is optimized for a broad range of applications across cloud, network, and intelligent edge environments, with significant industry adoption already underway.

title: Insight Public Sector Named as Principal Technology Partner for Cyber Bytes
summary: Insight Public Sector has partnered with the Cyber Bytes Foundation to launch the Advanced Technology Labs at the Quantico Cyber Hub in Stafford, Virginia. This initiative will bring together technology experts, equipment, and training from 15 leading global solutions providers to serve various government agencies, nonprofits, businesses, colleges, and universities. The Quantico Cyber Hub aims to accelerate the adoption of advanced cyber technologies and enhance the cyber workforce.

title: Oracle's Andy Mendelsohn makes the case for a converged database, multitenant architecture and autonomous tech
summary: Andy Mendelsohn, Executive Vice President of database server technologies at Oracle, discusses the company's strategy for database solutions in a video exclusive with SiliconANGLE. Oracle is pushing a "converged approach" for databases, multitenant architecture, and autonomous technology, aiming to provide self-service experiences for data scientists and developers. Mendelsohn highlights Oracle's Exadata technology and cloud-native instant elasticity as key differentiators, supporting their autonomous data warehouse and updated database offerings like 21c with persistent memory and blockchain tables.

title: Arm’s v9 Architecture Explains Why Nvidia Needs To Buy It
summary: This article explores why Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings, initially questioned, makes strategic sense following Arm's v9 architecture announcement. The v9 architecture's focus on integrating vector math, matrix math, and digital signal processing into CPUs, alongside new security features and a "Realms" memory partitioning system, suggests a future where specialized, highly integrated compute on-device is paramount. Nvidia's move to acquire Arm is positioned as a bet on this evolving compute landscape, where a single, malleable architecture can support a vast array of devices from IoT to datacenters, potentially limiting the expansion of hybrid CPU-GPU models for certain workloads.

title: The China challenge: Why Intel is too strategic to fail
summary: This article analyzes Intel's strategic shift to IDM 2.0 under CEO Pat Gelsinger, focusing on the company's plan to leverage internal manufacturing, external foundries, and a new Intel Foundry Services division. It examines the market changes impacting Intel, the critical threat from China's semiconductor ambitions, and the need for significant partnerships, including with IBM and the U.S. government, for Intel to regain its leadership and combat the China challenge. The authors argue that despite positive steps, Intel needs even more substantial changes, possibly a joint venture with a volume leader like Samsung, to succeed.

title: Why is Nvidia a better investment than Intel in a virus-hit market?
summary: This article compares Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA) and Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) as investments in a market heavily impacted by supply chain issues and increased demand for digital services. It highlights Nvidia's stronger profitability and revenue growth in the past year, driven by its GPU portfolio and expansion into data centers, making it a stronger buy recommendation despite higher relative valuation. In contrast, Intel, while still a dominant player, faces weaker guidance and an uncertain short-term outlook, with its stock viewed as a riskier investment at present.

title: Intel says it will invest $20 billion in domestic chip manufacturing
summary: Intel Corp. announced a significant investment of $20 billion to build new semiconductor chip fabrication plants within the United States. The initial phase of this plan will involve the development of two new facilities in Arizona, expanding on Intel's existing campus there. This move aims to bolster domestic chip manufacturing capabilities.

title: In $20bn push, Intel hopes to make US chip-making great again
summary: Intel announced a significant expansion of its advanced chip manufacturing capacity with a $20bn investment to build two factories in Arizona, aiming to regain its market leadership and challenge rivals TSMC and Samsung.
