CEO Pat Gelsinger's strategy includes opening Intel's plants to outside customers in a "foundry" business model and focusing on cutting-edge computing chip manufacturing. This move is also a response to US and European concerns about the concentration of chipmaking in Asia and seeks to boost domestic production.

title: Intel AI-Powered Backpack Helps Visually Impaired Navigate World
summary: Intel, in collaboration with AI developer Jagadish K. Mahendran and Luxonis, has unveiled an AI-powered, voice-activated backpack designed to help visually impaired individuals navigate and perceive their surroundings. This innovative system detects obstacles, traffic signs, and changing elevations using a Luxonis OAK-D spatial AI camera, powered by Intel Movidius VPU and OpenVINO toolkit. The backpack provides real-time verbal information to the user through a Bluetooth earphone, significantly enhancing independent navigation for the visually impaired.

title: Intel to spend $20 billion on U.S. chip plants as CEO challenges Asia dominance
summary: Intel announced plans to invest $20 billion in two new chip manufacturing plants in Arizona, aiming to expand its advanced chip production and open its factories to outside customers. This move by CEO Pat Gelsinger directly challenges the dominance of TSMC and Samsung in the advanced chip market and seeks to shift the technological balance of power back to the U.S. and Europe. The company expects $72 billion in revenue and adjusted earnings per share of $4.55 for 2021, and the new strategy is intended to restore Intel's reputation and create 3,000 permanent jobs.

title: Intel to invest $20B in Arizona expansion, add 3,000 jobs
summary: Intel announced a $20 billion investment to expand its campus in Chandler, Arizona, which is already considered the most advanced semiconductor factory globally. This expansion is expected to generate over 3,000 permanent high-tech jobs and an additional 3,000 construction jobs. The move signifies a major commitment by Intel to bolster its manufacturing capabilities in the U.S.

title: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger Announces ‘IDM 2.0’ Strategy for Manufacturing, Innovation and Product Leadership
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger unveiled "IDM 2.0," a new strategy for manufacturing, innovation, and product leadership, emphasizing Intel's internal factory network, expanded use of third-party foundries, and the establishment of Intel Foundry Services (IFS). The strategy includes a $20 billion investment to build two new fabs in Arizona and a new research collaboration with IBM to accelerate semiconductor manufacturing innovation. Gelsinger also announced the return of the Intel Developer Forum spirit with the new Intel Innovation event series.

title: Bull trend intact: S&P 500 retests the breakdown point
summary: The article discusses that the U.S. benchmarks' broader technical outlook remains bullish despite uneven price action in March. The S&P 500 and Dow industrials are consolidating recent record highs, while the Nasdaq Composite continues to underperform and remains range-bound. The piece also briefly mentions a home construction ETF and Intel amid March volatility.

title: One executive’s journey from an Arab Village in the Galilee to Silicon Valley
summary: Ziyad Hanna, Corporate VP at Cadence, defied expectations by rising from a construction worker and high school teacher in an Arab village in the Galilee to a leadership role in Silicon Valley. His journey involved overcoming discrimination, pursuing multiple degrees including a PhD from Oxford, and making significant contributions to companies like Intel and Jasper Design Automation. Hanna is committed to promoting diversity in the tech sector and empowering the Arab community in Israel's high-tech industry.

title: ON Semi Brings LiDAR To Automotive Sensor Portfolio With New SiPM Array
summary: ON Semiconductor has introduced a new SiPM array, the ArrayRDM-0112A20-QFN, specifically designed for automotive LiDAR systems. This product is touted as the first linear array of silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs) to hit the commercial market and the first automotive-qualified SiPM, promising enhanced detection and low noise for advanced driver-assistance systems (ADAS). The innovation is expected to significantly increase the adoption of LiDAR in autonomous vehicles, contributing to safer and more intelligent transportation.

title: An Oregon utility's unique model for supporting clean energy goals
summary: Portland General Electric (PGE) has developed a unique Green Future Impact (GFI) program in Oregon, acting as a model for how utilities can help large companies and cities access renewable energy. The program streamlines the procurement of clean energy through aggregated power purchase agreements and customer-identified projects, accelerating the deployment of renewable resources in the state. By handling regulatory and legal hurdles, PGE makes it easier for customers like Intel to meet their clean energy goals, demonstrating a successful model for other utilities to adopt.

title: Laptop Bench Test: Dell Latitude 5410 – An upgrade in mediocrity?
summary: This article reviews the Dell Latitude 5410 laptop, evaluating if it offers significant upgrades over its predecessor or remains a mediocre device. The review details specifications, performance benchmarks (Cinebench, GeekBench), and its suitability for corporate use, concluding it's a solid "fleet laptop" for business tasks rather than a high-performance personal device.

title: Applied Materials brings AI and big data into semiconductor inspection machines
summary: Applied Materials has introduced new optical semiconductor wafer inspection machines that integrate big data and AI to enhance defect detection and accelerate chip manufacturing. These systems, including Enlight and ExtractAI technology, aim to address the increasing complexity and cost of chip production by improving inspection efficiency and reducing yield loss. The AI-driven approach helps chipmakers identify critical defects faster and adapt to changing manufacturing processes, ultimately boosting profitability.

title: Qualcomm Completes Acquisition of NUVIA
summary: Qualcomm Incorporated announced the completion of its acquisition of NUVIA for $1.4 billion. This acquisition aims to enhance Qualcomm's CPU roadmap, integrating next-generation CPUs across various products including smartphones, laptops, and automotive systems. The first Qualcomm Snapdragon platforms featuring these new internally designed CPUs are expected to sample in the second half of 2022.

title: How Google’s New Career Certificates Could Disrupt the College Degree (Exclusive)
summary: Google is launching new career certificate programs on Coursera in project management, data analytics, and user experience design, aimed at bridging skills gaps and providing high-paying job qualifications without requiring a college degree. These programs are designed to be completed in six months or less and are supported by need-based scholarships and partnerships with over 130 employers committed to hiring graduates. Google is also enhancing its search engine to help job seekers find opportunities based on education and experience levels, including "no degree" options, contributing to economic recovery and addressing unemployment exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: AMD and Xilinx Set to Merge Before the End of 2021, Looks Promising
summary: Rival chipmakers Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Xilinx are proceeding with a $35 billion all-stock merger, expected to finalize by the end of 2021. The deal will see AMD shareholders owning 74% of the new entity and Xilinx shareholders 26%, with Xilinx stockholders receiving 1.734 shares of AMD for each of their shares. This merger aims to diversify AMD's product portfolio and strengthen its position in computer processors, particularly in data centers and wireless networks.

title: Changing Of The Guard For HPC And Big Iron At HPE
summary: Pete Ungaro, the long-time head of Cray and then HPE's High Performance Computing & Mission Critical Solutions group, is stepping down, with Justin Hotard taking over. This leadership change occurs as HPE continues to navigate a challenging market, focusing on profitability and leveraging the Cray acquisition to scale its HPC business. The company is making strategic bets on services and utility-style pricing for on-premises systems, with recent financial results indicating these efforts are beginning to pay off despite overall revenue and profit declines in some segments.

title: Gemini-1 Spreads Millions of Processors Into RAM
summary: GSI Technology introduces Gemini-1, a processor-in-memory chip that accelerates specific mathematical functions by up to 100x compared to traditional processors. Designed as an "associative processing unit" (APU), Gemini-1 integrates about 2 million simple processing elements directly within SRAM cells, making it highly specialized for parallel search and cryptography algorithms. While not a general-purpose CPU, it excels at tasks like Hamming distance and Tanimoto similarity calculations by eliminating the data transfer bottleneck between CPU and RAM.

title: NUBURU establishes advisory board
summary: NUBURU Inc., a developer and manufacturer of high-power industrial blue lasers, has formed an advisory board to enhance its market position and customer understanding. The board comprises global experts from various industries, including battery and e-mobility, consumer electronics, and defense. NUBURU's CEO, Dr. Guy Gilliland, believes the board's insights into market trends and customer perspectives will be crucial for the company's strategic direction.

title: Why the automotive supply chain is in a semiconductor jam
summary: The automotive industry is facing a severe semiconductor shortage, shutting down production lines globally and raising questions about lean operations. This shortage of microcontroller units (MCUs) is expected to last for several months, severely impacting major automakers like GM and Ford. The article also discusses how this crisis is prompting automakers to rethink their just-in-time inventory management strategies.

title: 'SOXL': The Fight for Semiconductors Is Getting Chippy
summary: The article discusses how a global semiconductor shortage could provide tailwinds for semiconductor ETFs like the Direxion Daily Semiconductor Bull 3X ETF (SOXL). President Joe Biden's pledge to address the shortage and develop a long-term strategy, along with increased demand for consumer electronics due to the pandemic, are cited as contributing factors to the sector's bullish momentum. The shortage impacts various industries beyond traditional technology, including automotive, highlighting the broad significance of semiconductor supply.

title: Years later, Bloomberg doubles down on disputed Supermicro supply chain hack story
summary: Bloomberg has published a new article, years after its initial disputed report, to double down on its claims that the Chinese state infiltrated Supermicro to plant secret chips on its motherboards. While Supermicro and other companies involved continue to deny these allegations, the new report offers additional context and quotes, alleging wider historical tampering and government investigations. Despite the ongoing denials and lack of official government confirmation, Bloomberg stands by its investigative journalism.

title: Microchip Announces the World’s First PCI Express® 5.0 Switches
summary: Microchip Technology Inc. announced the world's first PCI Express (PCIe) 5.0 switch solutions, the Switchtec PFX PCIe 5.0 family, to meet the increasing demand for high-performance computing in applications like data analytics and autonomous driving. These switches double interconnect performance and, combined with XpressConnect retimers, make Microchip the sole provider of both PCIe Gen 5 switches and retimer products, offering a complete infrastructure solution. The Switchtec PFX family supports high-density, high-reliability applications and includes advanced debug and diagnostic features to accelerate time-to-market.

title: U.S. Stock ETFs Stumble as Jobless Claims Reveal Weakness
summary: U.S. stock ETFs sawawed between gains and losses as elevated jobless claims signaled weakness in the labor market despite positive earnings reports. The persistent high unemployment figures, coupled with the resurgence of COVID-19 cases, fueled concerns about further job losses. Investors, meanwhile, are shifting back to growth names, particularly technology, anticipating continued strong earnings in that sector.

title: Western Digital to pay $7.75M to settle claims it paid women less than men
summary: Western Digital has agreed to a $7.75 million settlement to resolve claims that it paid and promoted women less than men. In addition to the financial settlement, the company will implement measures to ensure equitable evaluation, promotion, and compensation for women, including statistical analyses and leadership development initiatives. This settlement highlights ongoing issues of pay inequality in the tech industry, with other companies like Dell EMC, Google, and Intel also facing similar accusations or proactively addressing disparities.

title: Intel CEO Bob Swan to Be Replaced by VMware Chief
summary: Intel Corp. Chief Executive Officer Bob Swan will be replaced by VMware Inc. CEO Pat Gelsinger, who is returning to Intel more than a decade after leaving. This leadership change comes as Intel faces manufacturing delays, increased competition, and customers designing their own chips. Gelsinger's appointment is seen as a move to bring back technical and home-grown leadership to address the company's challenges.

title: Qualcomm eyes challenge to Apple, Intel with $1.4 billion deal for chip startup
summary: Qualcomm Inc. announced its acquisition of Nuvia Inc., a chip startup founded by former Apple Inc. executives, for $1.4 billion. This strategic move aims to integrate Nuvia's technology into Qualcomm's smartphone, laptop, and automotive processors, challenging Apple and Intel in chip performance. The deal also represents Qualcomm's effort to lessen its reliance on Arm Ltd. and enhance its custom core designs for various applications.

title: Qualcomm eyes challenge to Apple, Intel with $1.4 billion deal for chip startup
summary: Qualcomm Inc announced its acquisition of Nuvia Inc, a chip startup founded by former Apple executives, for $1.4 billion. This move aims to enhance Qualcomm's chip performance in smartphones, laptops, and automotive processors, challenging rivals like Apple and Intel. The deal also helps Qualcomm reduce its reliance on Arm Ltd's licensed technology by incorporating Nuvia's custom core designs.

title: Intel graphics chip will tap new version of TSMC 7-nanometer process - sources
summary: Intel Corp plans to outsource the manufacturing of its "DG2" discrete graphics chip for personal computers to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC). This chip will use an enhanced version of TSMC's 7-nanometer process and is aimed at competing with Nvidia and AMD in the booming PC gaming market. The move highlights Intel's increasing reliance on TSMC as it debates outsourcing some of its flagship CPU chips.

title: Rock star chip designer Jim Keller joins Tenstorrent
summary: Legendary computer chip designer Jim Keller has joined Toronto startup Tenstorrent Inc. as its new president and chief technology officer. Keller, known for his work at AMD, Apple, and Tesla, will guide Tenstorrent in its mission to create a machine learning training chip that utilizes software to optimize computing power and increase efficiency, challenging established players like Intel, AMD, and Nvidia.

title: Intel Lands Pentagon Deal to Support Domestic Chip Making
summary: Intel Corp. has secured a deal with the Pentagon to provide commercial foundry services as part of the Rapid Assured Microelectronics Prototypes - Commercial (RAMP-C) program. This initiative aims to bolster the domestic design and production of advanced microchips in the United States, addressing the ongoing global chip shortage. Intel's foundry services unit will collaborate with companies such as IBM, Synopsys, and Cadence Design Systems in this effort.

title: Exclusive: Hedge fund Third Point urges Intel to explore deal options
summary: Activist hedge fund Third Point LLC, which has amassed a nearly $1 billion stake in Intel Corp, is urging the U.S. chipmaker to explore strategic alternatives, including whether it should keep chip design and production under one roof. Third Point CEO Daniel Loeb sent a letter to Intel Chairman Omar Ishrak, calling for immediate action to boost the company's position, address "human capital management issue," and consider divesting failed acquisitions. This push comes as Intel has lost market share to competitors like TSMC, Samsung, and AMD, and its stock has underperformed the Nasdaq Composite Index.

title: Third Point Calls on Intel to Explore Strategic Alternatives
summary: Activist hedge fund Third Point LLC has urged Intel Corp. to consider sweeping strategic changes, including potentially selling acquisitions and splitting its design and manufacturing operations, following a year of product delays and a loss of market valuation. Third Point CEO Daniel Loeb stated that Intel's challenges threaten the U.S. tech industry and called for these changes to preserve America's leadership in the semiconductor sector.

title: Intel shares rise after Third Point urges chipmaker to explore strategic alternatives as market share deteriorates
summary: Hedge fund Third Point, which recently acquired a significant stake in Intel, is urging the chipmaker's board to explore strategic alternatives due to deteriorating market share against rivals like TSMC, Samsung, and AMD. Third Point highlighted concerns about Intel's loss of manufacturing leadership and its impact on U.S. national security. Intel has stated it welcomes input from investors to enhance shareholder value.

title: Check Point Software Technologies Appoints Ms. Rupal Hollenbeck to Its Board of Directors
summary: Check Point Software Technologies announced the appointment of Ms. Rupal Hollenbeck to its board of directors, effective January 1, 2021. Ms. Hollenbeck brings extensive experience from Oracle and Intel Corporation. She replaces Irwin Federman, who is retiring after 25 years of service.

title: Dogwood Therapeutics Inc Stock Price Today | NASDAQ: DWTX Live
summary: This article provides live stock price data for Dogwood Therapeutics Inc. (NASDAQ: DWTX), including its current price ($2.980), daily range, 52-week range, and key financial statistics. It also highlights analyst ratings, company health assessments, and recent news related to the company's drug development and financial activities. The company, formerly Virios Therapeutics, Inc., focuses on developing medicines for pain and fatigue-related disorders.

title: Element AI sold for $230-million as founders saw value mostly wiped out, document reveals
summary: Montreal startup Element AI Inc. was sold to ServiceNow Inc. for US$230-million, a deal that saw the value of common shares held by founders and many employees largely wiped out due to the company's financial struggles and inability to meet product development goals. While institutional shareholders are expected to recoup investments, the sale highlights the challenges faced by the highly hyped AI firm despite significant venture capital and government funding. The transaction involves ServiceNow retaining Element AI's research scientists and patents, effectively abandoning its business.

title: Microsoft Designing Its Own Chips for Servers, Surface PCs
summary: Microsoft (MSFT) is reportedly designing its own in-house processors for its cloud servers and potentially its Surface PCs, aiming to reduce its reliance on Intel (INTC) technology. This move mirrors efforts by other cloud-computing rivals like Amazon.com Inc. to develop custom silicon for cost and performance advantages. Following this news, Intel's stock experienced a significant drop.

title: STMicroelectronics to be Carbon Neutral by 2027
summary: STMicroelectronics has announced an ambitious goal to achieve carbon neutrality by 2027, making it one of the first semiconductor companies globally to set such a target. The roadmap includes an intermediate milestone to reduce direct and indirect emissions by 50% from 2018 levels by 2025, aligning with the Paris COP21's 1.5°C scenario, and a commitment to source 100% renewable energy by 2027. This initiative emphasizes the company's long-standing dedication to sustainability and innovation in eco-friendly technologies.

title: Intel, Nvidia probed over tech allegedly used against Uighurs
summary: Two US legislators, Senator Marco Rubio and Representative Jim McGovern, have sent letters to Intel Corp and Nvidia Corp, probing the sale of advanced computer chips allegedly used by China for mass surveillance on Uighurs in the Xinjiang region. The letters sought information on the companies' exports to China and whether they ensured their technology was not used for human rights abuses. Both companies have responded, with Intel stating it does not tolerate human rights violations and Nvidia declining to comment.

title: Global Automotive Advanced Driver Assistance System (ADAS) Market- Featuring Aptiv Plc, Continental AG, and DENSO Corp. Among Others
summary: The global automotive advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) market is projected to grow by USD 57.51 billion between 2020 and 2024, at a CAGR of almost 21%. This growth is primarily driven by the integration of map content in ADAS and the increasing development of AI-enabled ADAS solutions. Key companies mentioned in the report include Aptiv Plc, Continental AG, DENSO Corp., and others.

title: Update on Intel’s Neuromorphic Ecosystem Growth and Progress
summary: Intel provides an update on the rapid growth of its Neuromorphic Research Community (INRC), which now includes over 100 members with recent additions like Lenovo, Logitech, Mercedes-Benz, and Prophesee. The company highlights significant research results from INRC members using its Loihi neuromorphic research test chip, demonstrating orders of magnitude gains in computing efficiency and speed for various real-world edge use cases such as voice command recognition, gesture recognition, image retrieval, optimization problems, and robotics. Intel plans to continue investing in this ecosystem and integrate learnings into the development of its next-generation neuromorphic research chip.

title: Intel Debuts 2nd-Gen Horse Ridge Cryogenic Quantum Control Chip
summary: Intel unveils Horse Ridge II, its second-generation cryogenic control chip, designed to address quantum computing scalability challenges. This new chip enhances integration for quantum systems, enabling qubit manipulation and readout, and multigate pulsing. Horse Ridge II operates closer to qubits within a cryogenic refrigerator, simplifying control wiring and aiming for increased fidelity and decreased power output.

title: Intel's 3D XPoint dominance will face challenge from Micron
summary: Intel's initial dominance in the 3D XPoint market with its Optane products is expected to face significant competition, primarily from Micron Technology, starting around 2022. The article discusses the potential for other vendors like Samsung and SK Hynix to enter the market and highlights the role of new technologies like Computer Express Link (CXL) in accelerating 3D XPoint adoption across different processor architectures. Market analysts predict substantial growth in 3D XPoint revenue, with DIMMs becoming a major revenue driver, and Micron is preparing to release competitive products, including DIMMs, leveraging these new interface standards.

title: AWS Leverages Habana Gaudi AI Processors
summary: AWS announced new EC2 instances that will utilize Habana Gaudi AI processors, developed by an Intel company. These instances are projected to offer up to 40% better price performance for machine learning workloads compared to current GPU-based EC2 instances, supporting common frameworks like TensorFlow and PyTorch. This move strengthens Intel's AI strategy by providing a competitive solution for training deep learning models at scale in the cloud.

title: Smart City Platform Market May See a Big Move | Cisco Systems, Intel, NEC
summary: The Global Smart City Platform Market was valued at approximately USD 124.7 billion in 2019 and is projected to grow at over 11.2% annually from 2020 to 2027. Key drivers include rising urban populations, the increasing adoption of IoT technology, and digital transformations. Major players like Cisco Systems, IBM, Siemens, Hitachi, Microsoft, Schneider Electric, Huawei, Intel, NEC, and Amazon Web Services are profiled in a new HTF MI report.

title: Why Teradyne’s offerings provide value to end-user markets
summary: This article examines Teradyne's (TER) diverse product line and how it delivers value to its customer base across various end-user markets. It details Teradyne's semiconductor test platforms like FLEX, J750, and Magnum, and how they cater to industries such as mobile, automotive, and data storage. The article also highlights Teradyne's key customers and its presence in semiconductor-focused ETFs.

title: NVIDIA Unlikely to Compete with AMD on 7-nm Node
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) is developing ray tracing technology for its future GPUs, with plans to launch 7-nm gaming GPUs ahead of NVIDIA. NVIDIA, however, is not rushing to adopt 7-nm technology, focusing instead on affordable and power-efficient 12-nm FinFET processes for its current Turing GPUs. The article suggests NVIDIA might skip 7-nm and directly move to 7-nm+ or 5-nm nodes in the future.

title: Applied Materials’s position in the semiconductor space
summary: Applied Materials (AMAT) generates significant revenue from leading semiconductor companies like Samsung, Intel, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. The company's revenue growth is driven by orders from smaller customers and its diverse product lines, though it faces geographical risk due to a substantial portion of its revenue coming from Taiwan. The article highlights AMAT's ability to increase revenue and backlog despite chip capital expenditure forecasts remaining constant.

title: AMD’s Ryzen 3000 Series Beats Intel CPUs in Price and Performance
summary: AMD's new Ryzen 3000 series CPUs, including the Ryzen 9 3900X and Ryzen 7 3700X, are challenging Intel's dominance by offering superior performance and competitive pricing. The Ryzen 9 3900X competes directly with Intel's Core i9 9920X, while the Ryzen 7 3700X provides better multi-threaded performance and power efficiency than Intel's Core i7-9700K at a lower cost.

title: Intel keeps up Moore’s Law with 14nm
summary: This article discusses how Intel continues to uphold Moore's Law with its 14nm technology, highlighting the historical significance of Moore's Law in the semiconductor industry and Intel's role in its application. It details Intel's Broadwell chip, the first to use 14nm technology, and addresses the challenges Intel faces in meeting expectations for production and profitability due to development costs. The article also touches upon investment opportunities in semiconductor ETFs.

title: Intel sells Enpirion power management and controller product line to Richtek for $85M
summary: Intel Corp. has sold its Enpirion power management and controller product line to Richtek Technology Corp., a subsidiary of MediaTek Inc., for $85 million. This divestiture allows Intel to focus on its core FPGA business and invest in high-growth opportunities such as 5G, edge computing, AI, and cloud technologies. The acquisition provides Richtek with high-frequency and high-efficiency power solutions as it expands into enterprise-level system applications.

title: Who’s a Very Good Pandemic Business? Chewy Is. Oh, Yes It Is
summary: Chewy (CHWY) has experienced phenomenal growth in 2020, becoming a top pandemic business as pet care surged. CEO Sumit Singh's 2019 compensation of $108.2 million placed him among the highest-paid executives, despite the company not yet achieving profitability in its nine years of existence. This success highlights the booming online pet supply market.

title: CEO Lip-Bu Tan Molds Troubled Cadence Into Long-Term Leader
summary: Cadence CEO Lip-Bu Tan transformed the company from a troubled state into a long-term leader by embracing brutal honesty from customers and employees, fostering a collaborative culture, and demonstrating humility. Under his nearly 12-year leadership, Cadence's stock soared over 2,700%, revenue significantly increased, and the company joined the S&P 500. Tan's approach emphasizes seeking out problems early, learning from mentors, and inspiring teamwork, leading to substantial financial and cultural improvements.

title: How Apple built its own chip empire and gave Intel the boot
summary: Apple is transitioning its MacBooks from Intel chips to in-house silicon, marking a major milestone for the company's hardware and software integration. This move stems from a long-term strategy that began with the acquisition of P.A. Semi in 2008, enabling Apple to develop its own A-series chips for mobile devices. The decision was driven by improved performance of Apple's chips, better chip economics by outsourcing production, and greater control over hardware-software integration.

title: Apple unleashes M1
summary: Apple announced the M1 chip, its first chip designed specifically for the Mac, delivering industry-leading performance, powerful features, and incredible efficiency. The M1 chip integrates numerous technologies into a single SoC, featuring an 8-core CPU, the world's fastest integrated graphics, and a 16-core Neural Engine for accelerated machine learning. This launch marks the beginning of a two-year transition for the Mac to Apple silicon, with macOS Big Sur optimized to leverage the M1's capabilities.

title: Apple’s New MacBooks (and Mac Mini) Are Powered By iPhone DNA
summary: Apple announced new Mac desktop and laptop computers powered by its homemade M1 chip, an ARM-based design similar to those found in iPhones and iPads. This marks a significant shift from Intel processors, promising benefits like improved battery life, graphics, and machine learning capabilities, along with compatibility for iOS and iPadOS apps. The initial models include new MacBook Air ($999), MacBook Pro ($1,299), and Mac Mini ($699) offerings.

title: Apple unveils M1, the 1st in-house chip for Mac computers
summary: Apple unveiled its first in-house "Apple Silicon" chip, dubbed the M1, at its final event of 2020, powering new MacBook Air, MacBook Pro, and Mac Mini models. This new chip aims to significantly improve performance, speed, and battery life for Macs, marking a major step for Apple to gain more control over its hardware development. The company plans to transition its entire computer lineup to Apple Silicon chips within a few years.

title: Apple's new Macs could revive the PC chip wars, benefit Qualcomm: Analysts
summary: Apple is expected to unveil new Mac computers using its own in-house Arm-based processor chips, a move that could disrupt the PC chip market currently dominated by Intel and AMD. This shift could benefit companies like Qualcomm, which has been developing Arm-based processors for Windows PCs. Analysts suggest that Apple's entry into this market could accelerate the adoption of Arm-based PCs, despite challenges related to software compatibility.

title: Apple's new Macs could revive the PC chip wars, analysts say
summary: Apple's expected unveiling of new Mac computers with in-house processor chips based on Arm Ltd. technology could re-ignite competition in the PC chip market, currently dominated by Intel and Advanced Micro Devices. This shift marks a departure from Apple's nearly 15-year relationship with Intel and could benefit companies like Qualcomm, which has been adapting Arm-based processors for Windows PCs. Analysts believe Apple's entry will accelerate the adoption of Arm-based PCs, although challenges remain for software compatibility.

title: Top Analyst Upgrades and Downgrades: AbbVie, Alibaba, ADM, Best Buy, Intel, Lemonade, Nikola, Peloton, SAP, Under Armour, Wynn and More
summary: This article details top analyst upgrades, downgrades, and initiations for various companies on Monday, November 2, 2020. Key companies include AbbVie, Alibaba, Best Buy, Intel, Lemonade, Nikola, Peloton, SAP, Under Armour, and Wynn, along with their new ratings, price targets, and recent stock performance. The report provides a snapshot of analyst sentiment ahead of market challenges heading into 2021.

title: Intel Puts Its Indirect-Materials Spend on the Road to Digitization
summary: Intel has digitized its indirect-materials spend to manage its complex supply chain more efficiently. Facing challenges with 15,000 "legacy" contracts and 650 suppliers, the company developed an in-house solution utilizing machine learning and natural language processing to audit contracts, significantly reducing assessment time and improving contract quality, with projected savings of $19 million annually. This initiative has allowed Intel to perform 100% audits of all contracts daily and is seen as a key step towards an "autonomous digital supply chain."

title: AMD’s Lisa Su challenges Intel with record Xilinx deal
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su has announced a US$35 billion all-stock acquisition of Xilinx Inc, marking one of the largest chip deals ever and a direct challenge to Intel's dominance. This strategic move aims to expand AMD into new markets like automotive and communications networking, bolstering its offerings in cloud data centers. The acquisition will significantly increase AMD's research and development budget, positioning the company for future technical leadership, building on Su's successful turnaround of AMD since 2014.

title: AMD Agrees to Buy Xilinx for $35 Billion in Stock (Published 2020)
summary: Advanced Micro Devices has agreed to acquire Xilinx for $35 billion in an all-stock deal, aiming to expand its chip business into new markets like 5G communications and automotive electronics. This acquisition is part of a broader trend of consolidation in the chip industry and would position AMD to compete more fiercely with rivals like Nvidia and Intel. The deal is expected to help AMD grow its presence in data centers and enhance its profitability.

title: AMD to buy chip peer Xilinx for $35 billion in data center push
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) announced an all-stock deal to acquire Xilinx for $35 billion, intensifying its competition with Intel in the data center chip market. The acquisition is expected to close by the end of 2021 and aims to leverage the strengths of both companies in the growing data center and AI sectors, benefiting from their shared reliance on TSMC for manufacturing.

title: AMD Agrees to Buy Chipmaker Xilinx (XLNX) in $35 Billion All-Stock Deal
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) has agreed to acquire Xilinx Inc. for $35 billion in an all-stock deal, marking AMD's largest acquisition to date. This move is expected to bolster AMD's product offerings and intensify its competition with Intel Corp. Xilinx investors will receive 1.7234 AMD shares for each Xilinx stock, valuing Xilinx at approximately $143 per share, a 25% premium over its closing price before the announcement.

title: Supermicro 2U Ultra-E Short-Depth Server -- Now with NEBS Level 3-Certification -- Delivers Data Center Computational Power to the Telecom Edge
summary: Supermicro has announced that its 2U Ultra-E short-depth server is now NEBS Level 3-certified, making it suitable for deployment in telecom and other edge applications. This server expands Supermicro's portfolio for telecom customers, offering intensive workload processing, NEBS compliance, free-air cooling, and AC/DC power options. The system, powered by dual 2nd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors, provides enhanced features like GPU and FPGA support, optimized for 5G and telecommunications with lower power requirements.

title: McAfee goes public…again
summary: Cybersecurity company McAfee returned to Wall Street with an IPO priced at $20 a share, raising $740 million, although its stock dropped 6.5% on its first day of trading. The company, previously acquired by Intel and later majority-owned by TPG, faces strong demand for cybersecurity software but also significant debt and competition. Intel and other major stakeholders still hold shares, while controversial founder John McAfee is no longer affiliated with the firm.

title: Nvidia’s A100 GPU sets new performance records in MLPerf benchmarks
summary: Nvidia's A100 GPU has set new performance records in the latest MLPerf benchmarks, dominating tests across six application areas for data center and edge computing systems. The A100 GPU significantly outperformed CPUs in image classification and recommender tests, demonstrating extreme cost efficiency benefits for AI inference. Nvidia's systems are also making an impact in various industries, including medical imaging, automotive, and financial services, and are integrated into powerful supercomputers.

title: South Korea's SK Hynix to buy Intel's NAND business for $9 bln
summary: SK Hynix is set to acquire Intel's NAND memory chip business for $9 billion in an all-cash deal, positioning the South Korean company as the world's second-largest NAND memory producer. This move allows Intel to divest its non-core businesses and focus on its more lucrative Optane memory technology, while SK Hynix aims to boost its NAND capacity and market share. The deal is expected to consolidate the memory chip industry, despite initial negative reaction from SK Hynix shareholders regarding the price.

title: Opinion: How did Intel lose its Silicon Valley crown?
summary: This article discusses Intel's decline as the leading chip manufacturer in Silicon Valley, examining whether the challenges stem from technological limits or leadership decisions. The chip giant announced a delay in its 7-nanometer manufacturing process and considered outsourcing some production for a key next-generation chip, shocking investors and analysts. This move is seen as a significant setback for the company once considered the standard-bearer of Moore's Law.

title: AMD launches new Ryzen 5000 series CPUs, based on Zen 3 architecture
summary: AMD has officially launched its new Ryzen 5000 series desktop processors, built on the Zen 3 architecture, promising significant generational leaps in performance and power efficiency. These new CPUs, including the Ryzen 9 5900X and 5950X, are set to offer substantial improvements in single-threaded and gaming performance compared to their predecessors. The Ryzen 5000 series goes on sale November 5, with prices ranging from $300 to $800.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | AMD Is in Advanced Talks to Buy Xilinx
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) is reportedly in advanced talks to acquire rival chip maker Xilinx Inc. The potential deal could be valued at over $30 billion, marking a significant consolidation in the semiconductor industry. This acquisition would enhance AMD's competitive position against Intel and expand its presence in telecommunications and defense markets.

title: Semiconductor Market to reach USD 90.80 billion by 2024, Broadcom Inc. and Infineon Technologies AG emerge as Key Contributors to growth | Technavio
summary: The semiconductor market is projected to grow by USD 90.80 billion during 2020-2024, progressing at a CAGR of over 4%. This growth is significantly driven by the rising adoption of semiconductor ICs in automobiles and emerging semiconductor packaging technologies. Broadcom Inc. and Infineon Technologies AG, along with other major players, are identified as key contributors to this market expansion, with the APAC region expected to contribute 76% of the market growth.

title: Intel Wins US Government Advanced Packaging Project
summary: The U.S. Department of Defense has awarded Intel Federal LLC the second phase of its State-of-the-Art Heterogeneous Integration Prototype (SHIP) program. This program grants the U.S. government access to Intel's advanced semiconductor packaging capabilities in Arizona and Oregon, leveraging Intel's significant R&D and manufacturing investments. The SHIP program aims to develop multichip package prototypes, accelerate interface standards, and integrate special-purpose government chips with Intel’s commercial silicon products to modernize critical systems and strengthen the domestic defense industrial base.

title: Intel's $7B expansion in Chandler finally operational, making it the chipmaker's largest U.S. factory
summary: Intel's long-awaited $7 billion expansion project, Fab 42 in Chandler, is now operational. This facility is recognized as the most advanced semiconductor factory globally and has become Intel's largest U.S. factory. The project has been years in the making, establishing Intel as a significant player in the advanced chip manufacturing sector.

title: Intel Spins Out Omni-Path Interconnect Business Into Stand-Alone Company
summary: Intel has spun out its Omni-Path Architecture high-speed interconnect technology into a new stand-alone company called Cornelis Networks, which has raised $20 million in Series A funding. This move provides an alternative to Nvidia's Mellanox InfiniBand and allows former Intel architects to continue developing and supporting the Omni-Path product line, which Intel had previously de-emphasized. Cornelis Networks aims to support existing customers, sell current products, and develop next-generation interconnect solutions for high-performance computing and AI workloads.

title: Dutch chipmaker NXP opens gallium-nitride 5G chip plant in Arizona
summary: NXP Semiconductors NV has opened a new factory in Chandler, Arizona, to produce gallium-nitride radio chips for 5G telecommunications equipment. This move aligns with U.S. efforts to bring more chip manufacturing domestically and highlights gallium nitride's importance for 5G networks due to its efficiency. The facility will also house an R&D center, with full production capacity expected by year-end.

title: Taiwan-born AMD boss Lisa Su to receive top prize
summary: Lisa Su, the Taiwan-born president and CEO of AMD, is set to receive the prestigious Robert N. Noyce Award from the Semiconductor Industry Association for her contributions to the semiconductor industry. Su, who emigrated to the US at age 3, is recognized for advancing leading-edge semiconductor and high-performance computing technologies and inspiring others in tech. She is the second ethnic Chinese awardee for this honor.

title: Intel Introduces IoT-Enhanced Processors to Increase Performance, AI, Security
summary: Intel announced new IoT-enhanced processors, including the 11th Gen Intel Core, Intel Atom x6000E series, and Intel Pentium and Celeron N and J series, designed to bring advanced AI, security, and real-time capabilities to edge computing. These processors aim to address challenges in edge complexity and total cost of ownership across various sectors like industrial, retail, healthcare, and smart cities. The new offerings are expected to significantly boost performance for essential IoT applications, supporting the growing $65 billion edge silicon market opportunity by 2024.

title: Intel Appoints Saf Yeboah-Amankwah as Senior Vice President and Chief Strategy Officer
summary: Intel Corporation announced the appointment of Safroadu (Saf) Yeboah-Amankwah as senior vice president and chief strategy officer, effective November 1. He will lead the global strategy office, including Intel Capital, and collaborate with the executive team on growth strategies. Yeboah-Amankwah joins Intel from McKinsey & Company, where he was a senior partner and global head of the Transformation Practice for the Telecom, Media and Technology practice.

title: A brewing U.S.-China tech cold war rattles the semiconductor industry
summary: The U.S. semiconductor industry is concerned about a brewing tech cold war with China, fearing disruptions to the global supply chain as trade tensions escalate. Companies are developing strategies like hoarding supplies or relocating production, while the U.S. government is pushing for domestic manufacturing incentives through legislation like the CHIPS for America Act and the American Foundries Act. This push aims to strengthen U.S. leadership in advanced technologies and reduce reliance on foreign chip production.

title: Intel R&D Expenses by Quarter: FY Q1 1993 – Q2 2020
summary: The article provides a quarterly breakdown of Intel's R&D expenses from Q1 1993 to Q2 2020, highlighting key financial milestones and strategic shifts. Intel spent nearly 17% of its total revenue on R&D in Q2 2020, amounting to $3,354 million, despite a 2.4% YoY decline primarily due to the ramp down of its 5G smartphone modem business. The report also details historical R&D spending trends, significant increases, and insights into Intel Corporation's background and strategic acquisitions.

title: Intel Net Income by Quarter: FY Q1 1993 – Q2 2020
summary: This article provides an overview of Intel Corporation's quarterly net income from Q1 1993 to Q2 2020, highlighting significant financial milestones and fluctuations. It notes a 22.2% year-over-year growth in Q2 2020 net profit, reaching $5.105 billion, and identifies Q4 2019 as the most profitable quarter in Intel's history. The article also includes a brief company profile, detailing its founding, IPO, key customers, market ranking, and acquisition history.

title: Why Nvidia is spending $40 billion on Arm
summary: Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm, if completed, would be the largest semiconductor deal ever and is primarily aimed at boosting Nvidia's data center business by integrating Arm's CPU technology with Nvidia's GPUs. The deal raises questions about Nvidia's ability to neutrally license Arm's technology to competitors like Apple and Samsung, but Nvidia plans to operate Arm as an independent, customer-neutral subsidiary. Investors reacted positively to the news, and Nvidia sees significant potential in infusing its AI and graphics chips into Arm's vast ecosystem.

title: ARM: UK-based chip designer sold to US firm Nvidia
summary: UK-based computer chip designer ARM Holdings has been sold to US firm Nvidia for $40bn (£31.2bn), four years after its acquisition by Softbank. Nvidia has pledged to maintain ARM's UK presence, increase staff, and retain its brand, aiming to create a premier AI computing company. However, the deal faces scrutiny and opposition from ARM's co-founders and others due to concerns about potential conflicts of interest, US export control regulations, and its impact on the UK technology sector.

title: ARM: Can 'crown jewel' of UK technology be protected?
summary: The UK government is considering options to protect Cambridge-based ARM Holdings after its acquisition by Nvidia, a move that contrasts with their earlier stance during Softbank's purchase in 2016. ARM's co-founder has criticized the deal, fearing Nvidia will disrupt ARM's business model. While Nvidia promises UK investment, blocking the deal poses challenges given current laws and potential impacts on foreign investment.

title: -Nvidia's Arm deal sparks quick backlash in chip industry
summary: Nvidia's proposed $40 billion acquisition of Arm Ltd is encountering strong opposition from chip industry rivals in South Korea and China, raising concerns about Arm's neutrality and potential competition with Nvidia. Analysts suggest the deal could be detrimental to Arm's ecosystem and may drive customers toward alternative technologies like RISC-V. Despite Nvidia's assurances of maintaining Arm's open licensing model, competitors fear increased licensing fees and intensified competition in emerging markets like self-driving cars.

title: -Nvidia to buy chip designer Arm for $40 bln as SoftBank exits
summary: Nvidia announced its acquisition of UK-based chip designer Arm from SoftBank Group for $40 billion, a deal set to significantly impact the global semiconductor sector. The acquisition poses questions regarding Arm's maintained neutrality under U.S. ownership and faces regulatory scrutiny, particularly in China. Nvidia plans to expand Arm's licensing model and integrate its own IP, while SoftBank exits Arm to raise cash.

title: Nvidia jumps on $40 billion chip deal; analysts expect tough scrutiny
summary: Nvidia's shares surged after announcing a $40 billion deal to acquire UK-based chip designer Arm from SoftBank, marking a potential shift in the chip industry landscape. Analysts anticipate significant regulatory challenges for the acquisition, particularly from China, due to its scale and implications for competition. The deal is seen as a major move for Nvidia, positioning it among top chip suppliers, but also raising concerns among rivals and regulators.

title: Nvidia reaches $40B deal to buy SoftBank's Arm Holdings
summary: Nvidia has agreed to acquire Arm Holdings from SoftBank Group and SoftBank Vision Fund for $40 billion in stock and cash. This deal, which includes $21.5 billion in Nvidia stock and $12 billion cash, aims to position Nvidia strongly in the age of AI, leveraging Arm's processor designs to compete in the data center chip market. SoftBank will retain a less than 10% stake in Arm after the acquisition.

title: Duration: 3 minutes, 1 second.
summary: UK tech giant Arm Holdings is being sold to US company Nvidia for $40bn (£31bn) in a deal that faces regulatory approval and opposition from rivals and politicians. Arm co-founder Hermann Hauser heavily criticized the takeover, calling it an "absolute disaster" that would lead to job losses and destroy the company's business model. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has pledged to keep Arm headquartered in Cambridge and invest in a new AI research facility there, but the deal raises concerns about Arm's neutrality and its position in the US-China tech rivalry.

title: Intel Corp. names Israeli to second in command for global manufacturing
summary: Intel Corp. has appointed Daniel Benatar, the current manager of its Kiryat Gat plant in Israel, as the assistant general manager of Intel’s manufacturing global group, making him the highest-ranking Israeli in the firm's manufacturing arm. He will retain his role at the Israeli facility, which has undergone significant upgrades and employs 4,900 people. This appointment comes as Intel considers outsourcing its chip manufacturing.

title: What Intel Is Planning for The Future of Quantum Computing: Hot Qubits, Cold Control Chips, and Rapid Testing
summary: Jim Clarke, Intel's director of quantum hardware, outlines the company's strategy for achieving "quantum practicality" through silicon-based quantum computers. Key focuses include developing "hot" silicon spin qubits, cold control chips like Horse Ridge, and rapid testing methods using cryoprobers to overcome scaling and wiring challenges. The company aims to make quantum computing useful by addressing issues like coherence time, error correction, and efficient interconnects.

title: Dell EMC PowerEdge C6525 Review 2U4N AMD EPYC Kilo-thread Server
summary: The Dell EMC PowerEdge C6525 is a 2U 4-node server designed for high-density computing, utilizing AMD EPYC 7002 "Rome" processors to provide up to 512 cores and 1024 threads per chassis. The review examines the chassis design, node features, and performance aspects, highlighting its benefits in compute density and thermal management. It also touches upon the controversial CPU locking mechanisms implemented by Dell.

title: Intel rolls out $10B stock buyback, CEO says stock is cheap
summary: Intel announced a new $10 billion stock buyback program through accelerated share repurchase agreements, with the CEO stating the stock is trading below its intrinsic valuation. This move is part of a larger $20 billion buyback plan initiated in October, which was suspended in March. The company will fund these repurchases using existing cash resources.

title: Intel plans big stock buyback after shares plummet, boosting prices in after-hours trading
summary: Intel announced a plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock by the end of the year, following a nearly 19% drop in its shares over the past month. This decision resulted in a nearly 4% gain in after-hours trading. The company views these repurchases as prudent given that its shares are trading below intrinsic valuation, amidst struggles with new chip engineering and increased competition from rivals like AMD and Nvidia.

title: IBM rolls out newest processor chip, taps Samsung for manufacturing
summary: IBM has announced its new Power10 processor chip for data centers, designed to handle three times the workload of its predecessor and perform AI tasks up to 20 times faster. Samsung Electronics Co Ltd will manufacture the chip using its 7-nanometer process. This move allows IBM to compete against Intel, especially given Intel's manufacturing delays.

title: IBM rolls out newest processor chip
summary: International Business Machines Corp (IBM) announced a new Power10 processor chip designed for data centers, capable of handling three times the workload of its predecessor and up to 20 times faster for artificial intelligence computing tasks. The chip, manufactured by Samsung Electronics Co Ltd (005930.KS) using 7-nanometer technology, positions IBM to compete more effectively with Intel Corp, especially given Intel's noted manufacturing delays. This move highlights IBM's continued focus on high-performance computing systems.

title: Nvidia hurdles $300 billion market cap, which Intel hasn’t topped since the dot-com bust
summary: Nvidia Corp. has achieved a market capitalization exceeding $300 billion for the first time, establishing itself as the largest U.S. chip company. This milestone comes as Nvidia's stock has surged over 100% this year, contrasting sharply with Intel's recent struggles. Nvidia is poised to report its second-quarter earnings soon, with strong market performance leading into the announcement.

title: Nvidia hurdles $300 billion market cap, which Intel hasn’t topped since the dot-com bust
summary: Nvidia Corp. has surpassed a $300 billion market capitalization for the first time, establishing itself as the largest U.S. chip company. This milestone comes as Nvidia's stock has risen over 100% this year, while Intel's has declined by nearly 20%. Nvidia is set to report its second-quarter earnings soon after achieving this record valuation.

title: IBM rolls out Power10 chip for data centres; taps Samsung for manufacturing
summary: IBM has announced its new Power10 processor chip for data centers, designed to handle three times the workload of its predecessor. The Power10 chip will be manufactured by Samsung Electronics Co Ltd using its 7-nanometer chip manufacturing process. This move strengthens IBM's focus on high-performance computing systems.

title: Intel’s manufacturing crisis puts company at a crossroads
summary: Intel is facing a significant manufacturing crisis due to delays and setbacks in its 10-nanometer and forthcoming 7-nanometer chips, leading to a $42 billion loss in market value and a shake-up in its manufacturing leadership. The company, once a leader in chip production, now trails rivals like TSMC and is contemplating outsourcing production, raising questions about its future strategy and leadership in advanced manufacturing, despite strong current sales. This crisis highlights internal organizational problems and potentially marks the end of the "golden age" of Moore's Law for Intel.

title: Investing in Nasdaq 100 in 2000
summary: This article analyzes the long-term performance of investing in the Nasdaq 100 in 2000, a period of extremely high valuations. The author conducts an in-depth study showing that while the index as a whole tripled in value by 2020, this was driven by a small number of winning companies, particularly Apple and Amazon, and required significant patience through a prolonged drawdown. The study extracts key lessons for investors, including the importance of diversification, patience, holding onto winners, and understanding that valuation ultimately matters.

title: Beelink GT-R Review – An AMD Ryzen 5 Mini PC Tested with Windows 10 and Ubuntu 20.04
summary: This article reviews the Beelink GT-R mini PC, an AMD Ryzen 5-based device tested with both Windows 10 and Ubuntu 20.04. It covers hardware specifications, performance benchmarks across both operating systems, gaming capabilities, thermal management, power consumption, and BIOS settings. The review highlights its strong performance compared to lower-powered Intel mini PCs, the quality of its port selection, and discusses the noise level of its fans under load.

title: Gigabytes of ‘sensitive’ internal Intel documents dumped online
summary: Intel is investigating a leak of approximately 20 GB of internal documents, some marked "confidential," which appeared on messaging platforms and data hosting sites. The company believes an individual with access to its Resource and Design Center downloaded and shared the data, which includes training manuals and technical documents for software and firmware development kits. The leaked files, current as of March 2020, did not contain personally identifiable information on Intel employees or customers.

title: Lisa Su’s AMD Is Flying High as Rival Chip Maker Intel Stumbles
summary: Lisa Su's AMD is experiencing a surge in demand and market share, outperforming rival Intel Corp. The company's chips are in high demand due to remote work, personal computers, and gaming consoles, leading to a raised full-year sales outlook. This success is attributed to strategic decisions made by CEO Lisa Su over the past six years.

title: Consider this ETF as AMD Closes in on $100 Billion Market Cap
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) is nearing a $100 billion market capitalization, driven by strong earnings and market share gains from Intel. This article suggests the VanEck Vectors Semiconductor ETF (SMH) as a way to invest in semiconductors, highlighting its focus on highly liquid and leading companies in the industry. It also presents iShares PHLX Semiconductor ETF (SOXX) and SPDR S&P Semiconductor ETF (XSD) as alternative investment options.

title: AMD closes just shy of $100-billion market cap, as more analysts see it taking market share from Intel
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc.'s stock reached fresh records on Tuesday, closing with a market cap of $99.84 billion, just shy of $100 billion. This surge followed an analyst's price target hike and strong earnings reports, indicating an accelerating market share gain from Intel Corp. The company briefly surpassed a $100 billion market cap intraday.

title: AMD closes just shy of $100-billion market cap, as more analysts see it taking market share from Intel
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) stock reached a market capitalization just shy of $100 billion after another analyst raised their price target. AMD shares closed up 9.5% at $85.04, setting a new closing record and a market cap of $99.84 billion. This surge follows strong earnings and continued signs that AMD is gaining market share from Intel Corp.

title: Intel Beats Estimates, but Stock Crashes on Weak Outlook
summary: Intel Corporation (INTC) beat EPS estimates but saw its stock crash due to weak guidance, gapping significantly lower despite a history of beating quarterly results. The stock entered bear market territory, down 30.3% from its January high, and is showing a negative technical outlook with a looming "death cross." Investors are advised to buy on weakness to the 200-week SMA and reduce holdings at risky levels.

title: Clorox names Linda Rendle CEO
summary: Linda Rendle, a 17-year veteran of The Clorox Co., has been promoted to chief executive officer, effective Sept. 14. This announcement comes as the company posted sales up 22%.

title: AMD CEO Lisa Su: Roadmap Execution Is Key To Fighting Intel
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su emphasizes that consistent roadmap execution is crucial for competing with Intel, especially after Intel's 7nm product delay. AMD's revenue for EPYC processors more than doubled in Q2, contributing to a strong overall performance and an increased full-year revenue growth forecast. The company is on track with its next-generation processors and GPUs, including plans for Zen 3 and Zen 4 architectures, demonstrating a persistent focus on product delivery and customer engagement.

title: Intel Is Now Ordering Chips From TSMC Following Delays
summary: Intel (INTC) has reportedly placed orders with TSMC (TSM) for 6-nanometer chips, a move considered unprecedented for the prominent chip manufacturer. This decision follows Intel's announcement of significant delays for its 7-nanometer chip until 2022 and confirms its "contingency plans." The news negatively impacted Intel's stock and led analysts to reassess its competitive position against TSMC and AMD.

title: Climate Corp. Adds Accomplished Tech Leader as Chief Product Officer
summary: Climate Corp. has appointed Ranjeeta Singh as its new Chief Product Officer, bringing over two decades of tech industry experience from Intel and Teradata. Singh will be responsible for driving product strategy and roadmap plans for Climate FieldView, leveraging her expertise in AI, data science, and IoT solutions to benefit farmer-customers. Mike Stern, CEO of The Climate Corporation, expressed enthusiasm for Singh's leadership and her potential to enhance the company's capabilities.

title: Intel engineering leader Murthy Renduchintala will leave as the company mulls manufacturing shift
summary: Venkata "Murthy" Renduchintala, Intel's chief engineering officer, is resigning on August 3 amidst the company's manufacturing difficulties, particularly with its 7-nanometer architecture. His departure comes as Intel evaluates potentially using outside foundries for chip production, following a significant drop in its stock after Q2 earnings. Renduchintala's group will be split into five, with Ann Kelleher leading the 7-nanometer chip development.

title: Shares of Taiwan’s TSMC soar after Intel’s apparent retreat in chip manufacturing
summary: Shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) rallied significantly after Intel signaled a potential shift away from manufacturing its own chip components, possibly outsourcing to TSMC. This surge made TSMC the 12th most valuable stock globally, briefly surpassing Walmart, and added over US$30 billion to its market capitalization. The event underscores TSMC's growing influence in the global semiconductor industry and its impact on Taiwan's stock market.

title: Intel’s chief engineer out amid manufacturing crisis
summary: Intel's chief engineering officer, Venkata “Murthy” Renduchintala, is leaving the company amidst delays in its next-generation computer chips. This departure is part of several changes Intel is implementing as it struggles with manufacturing issues, including a 12-month delay for its 7nm chips. The news led to a significant drop in Intel's stock value and has prompted the company to explore outsourcing chip production.

title: Intel's 7nm is Broken, Company Announces Delay Until 2022, 2023
summary: Intel announced a significant delay in the rollout of its 7nm CPUs, pushing their debut to late 2022 or early 2023. This delay is attributed to a "defect mode" causing yield degradation, putting Intel approximately twelve months behind its internal targets for 7nm process. The company is now exploring contingency plans, including the use of third-party foundries for some components and entire chip designs, and plans to increase shipments of 10nm chips by 20%.

title: Intel has weathered coronavirus because of data center and PC sales, but only one of those is expected to grow
summary: Intel is projected to experience strong sales growth in its data center business throughout the remainder of the year due to companies' continued migration to the cloud. However, the demand for PC sales is expected to reach a saturation point. The company is set to report its quarterly earnings after market close on Thursday.

title: Climate Corp. Adds Accomplished Tech Leader as Chief Product Officer
summary: Ranjeeta Singh has been appointed as the new Chief Product Officer of Climate Corp. She brings over two decades of experience in AI and data science from Intel and Teradata, and will lead the product strategy for Climate FieldView. Singh aims to leverage her expertise to solve customer pain points and optimize agricultural inputs for farmers.

title: Analog Devices Acquires Maxim in an Underwhelming $21 Billion Bet
summary: Analog Devices (ADI) is acquiring Maxim Integrated Products in a $21 billion all-stock deal, aiming to strengthen its position in analog semiconductors and diversify its portfolio. While ADI anticipates increased scale and market presence, the analyst expresses concerns about the competitive landscape in network infrastructure and data center semiconductors, as well as challenges related to supply chain integration. The article suggests that ADI may struggle to fully realize the acquisition's benefits in certain competitive segments and faces integration hurdles.

title: COVID-19 Impact & Recovery Analysis - Global Automotive ADAS Aftermarket 2020-2024 | Growing Emphasis on Automotive Safety to Boost Growth | Technavio
summary: The global automotive ADAS aftermarket is projected to grow by USD 2.04 billion between 2020 and 2024, with a CAGR of 9%, driven by increasing emphasis on automotive safety. Technavio's report, which considers the impact of COVID-19, highlights key vendors like Continental AG and Intel Corp. and identifies growing online purchases of aftermarket ADAS as a primary growth driver. The market is segmented by technology (e.g., Passive Car Assists, FCWS, LDWS) and geographic regions, offering detailed analysis of market size, trends, and vendor landscapes.

title: Nvidia market value closes in on Intel
summary: Nvidia is nearing Intel in market capitalization for the first time, fueled by a 70% stock surge this year due to the accelerated shift to cloud-based digital services. Nvidia's market cap has reached approximately $245 billion, just shy of Intel's $249 billion. This milestone would position Nvidia as the third-largest chipmaker globally by market cap, trailing only Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and Samsung Electronics Co.

title: Nvidia surpasses Intel as largest U.S. chip maker by market cap
summary: Nvidia Corp. has surpassed Intel Corp. to become the largest U.S. chip maker by market capitalization for the first time. This milestone was achieved on Wednesday, July 8, 2020, with Nvidia's market cap reaching $251.31 billion compared to Intel's $248.16 billion. While other companies like Texas Instruments and Qualcomm have previously and temporarily held the top spot over Intel, this marks a significant achievement for Nvidia.

title: Nvidia surpasses Intel as largest U.S. chip maker by market cap
summary: Nvidia Corp. has surpassed Intel Corp. as the largest U.S. chip maker by market capitalization for the first time, with Nvidia's market cap reaching $251.31 billion compared to Intel's $248.16 billion. This milestone marks Nvidia's shares gaining 74% for the year, while Intel shares have slipped 2%. While other chipmakers like Texas Instruments and Qualcomm have temporarily surpassed Intel in the past, this is a first for Nvidia.

title: Nvidia Valuation Soars Past Intel on Graphics Chip Boom
summary: Nvidia's market valuation has surpassed Intel's for the first time, driven by high demand for its graphics chips in data centers and other growing tech sectors. Nvidia (NVDA) gained 2.4% on Wednesday, reaching a market value exceeding $248 billion, with its shares up 72% this year, while Intel (INTC) shares have fallen 2%. This surge reflects investor confidence that the pandemic is accelerating a shift to cloud-based digital services utilizing Nvidia's technology.

title: Chicago Quantum Exchange announces seven new partnerships to advance research, training
summary: The Chicago Quantum Exchange (CQE), a research hub based at the University of Chicago, has announced seven new corporate partnerships to advance quantum technology research and development. These new partners include Intel, JPMorgan Chase, Microsoft, Quantum Design, Qubitekk, Rigetti Computing, and Zurich Instruments, expanding CQE's collaborations to a total of 13 companies. The partnerships aim to accelerate discovery, develop quantum applications, and prepare a skilled quantum workforce by leveraging expertise from universities, national laboratories, and industry leaders.

title: Nvidia on Cusp of Topping Intel in Market Cap After 70% Gain
summary: Nvidia (NVDA) is nearing Intel (INTC) in market capitalization for the first time, buoyed by a more than 70% stock gain in 2020. This surge is attributed to investor confidence that the COVID-19 pandemic is accelerating the shift towards cloud-based digital services, for which Nvidia's technology is crucial. The graphics chipmaker's rapid growth positions it to potentially overtake the long-standing chip giant.

title: Motion to add willful infringement charge based entirely on post-suit activity is granted…because it is Unopposed
summary: The U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware granted VLSI’s motion to add claims for willful infringement against Intel based on post-suit activity, but denied pre-suit allegations due to a lack of plausible evidence that Intel knew of or was willfully blind to its infringement. The post-suit claims were granted because Intel did not oppose them, even though the court initially appeared poised to deny them. This decision highlights the importance for defendants to oppose all aspects of motions to amend to add willfulness claims.

title: New PCIe 4.0 SSDs, 24 Gbps SAS SSDs supply bandwidth boost
summary: Major drive manufacturers are rolling out new enterprise SSDs supporting PCIe Gen 4 and 24 Gbps SAS to significantly increase bandwidth for data centers. Companies like Kioxia, Intel, and Western Digital are introducing these faster options, though adoption of PCIe Gen 4 is currently limited by processor compatibility and customer demand. The article also highlights continued strong demand for SAS SSDs, particularly in storage array markets.

title: Teardown: Velar infotainment master controller
summary: This article provides a teardown analysis of the Velar infotainment master controller, designed for Jaguar Land Rover vehicles. It details the various electronic components from companies like Intel, Microchip, and Broadcom, highlighting the continuous increase in automotive electronics. The analysis includes a list of key components found on the main PCB, embedded compute module, Ethernet switch PCB, and BT/WLAN module.

title: Apple to Drop Intel and Use its own Chips in Mac Computers
summary: Apple announced its decision to transition from using Intel-based chips to its own Apple Silicon chips for its Mac computers, with the first Macs featuring these new chips expected by late 2020. This move aims to enhance Mac performance, efficiency, and establish a common architecture across all Apple products, allowing Mac computers to run apps previously exclusive to iPhones and iPads. The new Apple chips are based on technology from Arm Holdings, whose technology also powers the world's fastest supercomputer, Fugaku.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: After 15 Years, Apple Prepares to Break Up With Intel (Published 2020)
summary: Apple is preparing to end its 15-year partnership with Intel, with plans to replace Intel processors in Macs with self-designed chips. This move, expected to be announced soon, signifies Apple's growing independence and determination to control its product manufacturing, a trend seen among other major tech companies like Facebook, Amazon, and Google. The new Mac chips are anticipated to arrive next year and will likely be manufactured by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

title: Intel stock slips as new lines of AI chips released
summary: Intel stock experienced a decline after the company launched new artificial intelligence and data analytics chips. The company's shares fell by 1.2%, underperforming the broader market. This occurred despite new product introductions aimed at supporting AI and data analytics.

title: Intel Elects Dion J. Weisler to Board of Directors
summary: Intel Corporation announced the election of Dion J. Weisler, former president and CEO of HP Inc., to its board of directors. Weisler will serve as an independent director and a member of the compensation and finance committees, bringing extensive global executive and technical industry experience. His appointment increases Intel's board to 10 members, continuing the company's focus on adding diverse and skilled independent directors.

title: Apple, ARM, and Intel
summary: This article discusses Apple's anticipated transition of its Mac computers from Intel processors to its own ARM-based chips, highlighting the historical context of this decision, Intel's manufacturing struggles, and the potential implications for performance and the broader server market. It also critically examines Intel's past strategic missteps, particularly its decision regarding iPhone chip production.

title: Electronic Products Market 2020 Analysis by Global
summary: This article provides an analysis of the global electronic products market in 2020, identifying key manufacturers such as Samsung Electronics, Intel, and Micron Technology. It highlights Asia Pacific as the largest market region and discusses factors driving growth, including the rising demand for smart TVs. The report also addresses the impact of COVID-19 and offers insights into market size, growth rates, and regional segmentation until 2030.

title: Insight Partners to acquire senior Israeli venture fund Gemini V for $500 million
summary: Insight Partners is set to acquire the fifth fund of Israeli venture firm Gemini Israel Ventures for approximately $500 million. Gemini V's portfolio includes successful companies like WalkMe Inc., JFrog Ltd., Monday.com Labs Ltd., and Moovit App Global Ltd., which was recently acquired by Intel for $1 billion. This acquisition is part of a series of investments and deals made by Insight Partners in Israeli tech companies.

title: Intel Loses a Chip Wizard at the Worst Possible Time
summary: Intel's top chip architect, Jim Keller, resigned effective immediately for personal reasons after only two years with the company. This departure is seen as a significant blow to Intel, which is already ceding ground to rivals in a competitive market, and comes at a challenging time for the chip giant. Keller's extensive experience from companies like Apple and AMD highlights the severity of his exit for Intel.

title: Former Apple executive Jim Keller resigns from top chip design role at Intel
summary: Jim Keller, a prominent chip designer known for his work at Apple, Tesla, and AMD, has resigned from his role at Intel for personal reasons. His departure raises concerns among analysts about Intel's processor roadmap and vulnerability to competition, especially with Apple reportedly planning to use its own chips in Macs. Keller will serve as a consultant for Intel for six months during the transition.

title: Intel loses ‘rock star’ chip designer Jim Keller
summary: Intel Corp. has announced the departure of its celebrated chip designer, Jim Keller, who is leaving for "personal reasons" after two years with the company. Keller, known for his work at AMD, Apple, and Tesla, was instrumental in Intel's efforts to expand beyond traditional PC and server chips into new markets like AI and cloud computing. Despite his departure, Intel has already reorganized its engineering leadership and Keller will serve as a consultant for six months to ensure a smooth transition.

title: US Cloud Data Firm NetApp To Acquire Israel’s Spot.io
summary: US cloud data services company NetApp is set to acquire the US-Israeli company Spot.io for an estimated $450 million. Spot.io helps businesses manage cloud workloads and slash computing costs for clients like Moovit, Ticketmaster, and Wix. This acquisition aims to establish NetApp's leadership in cloud management and infrastructure tools, promising significant cost savings for customers by combining their technologies into an Application Driven Infrastructure.

title: AMD CEO Lisa Su Tops Earnings as Highest Paid CEO in The S&P 500
summary: AMD CEO Lisa Su has become the highest-paid CEO in the S&P 500, with a pay package valued at $58.5 million. This compensation is attributed to AMD's impressive performance over the past five years, driven by the success of EPYC, Ryzen, and Radeon products. Lisa Su is also the first woman to hold this distinction, being one of only 20 women on the list compared to 309 men.

title: San Jose-based Cisco promises $5M for charities fighting racism, discrimination
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. announced it would donate $5 million to charities combating racism and discrimination, following widespread protests over racial injustice. Other tech companies like Facebook, Intel, and Apple have also pledged similar contributions. This decision led Cisco to postpone its annual Cisco Live event, with CEO Chuck Robbins emphasizing the need for space and healing amid current societal turmoil.

title: AMD’s Lisa Su Takes The No. 1 Position As S&P 500’s Highest Paid CEO
summary: Dr. Lisa Su, CEO of AMD, has been identified as the highest-paid chief executive in the S&P 500 for 2019, with total compensation of $58.5 million, a 338% year-over-year growth. Her compensation was largely comprised of stock awards, reflecting AMD's significant stock market gains and market share growth under her leadership. The article details AMD's recent performance, including strong notebook sales and GPU market share increases, and touches upon upcoming product plans.

title: What Is a DPU?
summary: This article explains what a Data Processing Unit (DPU) is and how it differs from CPUs and GPUs, positioning it as the third pillar of computing. It details the key components of a DPU, including a multi-core CPU, high-performance network interface, and acceleration engines, emphasizing its role in modern data centers and SmartNICs. The article also outlines ten critical capabilities for network data path acceleration engines within a DPU.

title: Intel Acquires Rivet Networks To Beef Up Wi-Fi Portfolio
summary: Intel Corporation announced its acquisition of Rivet Networks, a Texas-based networking company known for its "Killer" brand products, to enhance its Wi-Fi portfolio. Rivet Networks' team will join Intel's Wireless Solutions Group, integrating their hardware, software, and cloud-based technologies to improve PC Wi-Fi performance. This marks Intel's second acquisition this month, following the purchase of Moovit for $900 million.

title: Why Intel is betting its chips on microprocessor mastermind Jim Keller
summary: This article profiles Jim Keller, a legendary microprocessor designer who has worked for Apple, Tesla, and AMD, and is now tasked with revitalizing Intel's chip-design enterprise.
