It explores his unconventional career path, his philosophy of simplification and learning, and the significant impact his designs have had on the tech industry, including the Ryzen chips for AMD and the Autopilot chip for Tesla. The piece details how Intel is relying on Keller to overcome its recent struggles and regain its market leadership.

title: Qualcomm: a history
summary: This article provides a brief history of Qualcomm, detailing its growth from its founding in 1985 to becoming a major chip-maker and patent licensing business. It covers key milestones including product development, acquisitions, and strategic shifts that shaped the company's trajectory and market position. The article also touches on Qualcomm's current discussions to potentially acquire NXP Semiconductors for $30 billion.

title: TSMC Announces Intention to Build and Operate an Advanced Semiconductor Fab in the United States
summary: TSMC announced its plan to build and operate an advanced semiconductor fab in the U.S. state of Arizona. This facility will use 5nm technology, have a capacity of 20,000 wafers per month, create over 1,600 high-tech jobs directly, and involves a total investment of approximately US$12 billion from 2021 to 2029. The project is strategically important for the U.S. semiconductor ecosystem and relies on continued U.S. federal government and Arizona state support.

title: TSMC, maker of iPhone chips, to build $12bn chip factory in US
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), a major supplier to Apple Inc., announced plans to build a $12 billion chip factory in Arizona, in partnership with the US government. This move aligns with the Trump administration's efforts to increase foreign manufacturing in the US and will create up to 1,600 jobs, producing advanced 5-nanometer chips. The investment highlights the strategic importance of semiconductor production within the US amidst growing US-China trade tensions.

title: TSMC’s Announcement Of A New U.S. Semiconductor Fab Is Big News
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) announced plans to build a new semiconductor fabrication facility (fab) in Arizona, a move deemed significant despite its initial limited scale. This investment, estimated at $12 billion for a 5 nm technology fab, highlights the challenges and costs of advanced semiconductor manufacturing. While a welcome development for the U.S. supply chain, it represents only a small step towards securing domestic semiconductor production, as the U.S. will still rely heavily on Asian facilities for capacity and specialized processes like packaging.

title: Nvidia confirms Ampere will power next-gen GeForce graphics cards
summary: Nvidia has confirmed that its new Ampere GPU architecture will power next-gen GeForce graphics cards, unifying its entire GPU range from gaming to data centers. CEO Jen-Hsun Huang announced that Ampere will replace both Turing and Volta chips, with the architecture also being used in supercomputers to aid in COVID-19 research. While a specific release date for gaming cards wasn't given, an August/September announcement is anticipated.

title: Intel Launches First Global Challenges, Marks a New Era of Shared Corporate Responsibility
summary: Intel has launched its first Global Challenges, marking a new era of shared corporate responsibility, as outlined in its annual Corporate Responsibility Report. The company commits to industry-wide collaborations in health and safety, pandemic preparedness, tech inclusion, and carbon-neutral computing to address global issues. This initiative expands Intel's commitment beyond its operations to tackle challenges that require collaboration across major organizations and industries.

title: Nvidia Unveils New Data Center Chips to Speed Pace of AI
summary: Nvidia Corp. announced new Ampere graphics chips and computers for AI processing in data centers, claiming a 20x performance increase over predecessors. These new chips are designed to handle both AI training and inference tasks, a capability that will bolster Nvidia's leadership in the growing AI market. The company is selling Ampere-based computers called DGX for $199,000 each, touting their superior performance compared to traditional Intel-based server arrays.

title: COVID-19 Impact and Recovery Analysis | Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) Market 2020-2024 | Demand for High Memory GPU to Boost Growth | Technavio
summary: Technavio projects the Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) market to grow by USD 38.28 billion between 2020 and 2024, with a CAGR exceeding 29%. This growth is primarily driven by the increasing demand for high-memory GPUs, coupled with the expansion of the PC gaming and gaming console markets. The report provides an in-depth analysis of market trends, vendor landscapes, and the impact of COVID-19, segmenting the market by device type and geography.

title: Intel Capital Invests $132 Million in 11 Disruptive Technology Startups
summary: Intel Capital announced new investments totaling $132 million in 11 technology startups focusing on AI, autonomous computing, and chip design. These companies, including Anodot, Astera Labs, and KFBIO, aim to bring breakthrough innovations to market. Intel Capital continues its commitment to investing in disruptive startups and promoting diversity within its portfolio.

title: Intel, Health Institutions to Use Emerging AI Technique to Improve Tumor Detection
summary: Intel and 30 health-care organizations, led by Penn Medicine, are collaborating to develop an AI system that improves brain tumor detection. They are utilizing federated learning, an emerging AI technique, to train machine-learning algorithms on medical images without sharing sensitive patient data. This initiative aims to assist radiologists in more easily identifying brain tumor boundaries.

title: Nvidia shares heading for first record close since coronavirus pandemic
summary: Nvidia shares are on track for a record close, recovering from a COVID-19 related drop, after an analyst boosted the price target ahead of earnings. The analyst cited Nvidia's acquisition of Mellanox Technologies and increased demand for gaming chips and data-center spending as reasons for the upgrade. The company's stock has risen significantly year-to-date, outperforming semiconductor and S&P 500 indexes.

title: HP’s Innovative Cloud-Based Devices Enable Productivity Anytime, Anywhere
summary: HP announced new cloud-based devices, including Chromebooks and thin client solutions, designed to empower remote workers and address the security challenges of the "work from home" era. The new portfolio emphasizes sustainability, security, and performance, featuring products like the HP Elite c1030 Chromebook Enterprise with an integrated privacy screen and ocean-bound plastics. These innovations aim to provide businesses with secure, scalable, and easy-to-deploy tools for a cloud-centric workforce.

title: Intel buys Moovit transit app for $900 million to help develop robotaxis
summary: Intel Corp has acquired Israeli public transit app Moovit for approximately $900 million to advance its self-driving "robotaxis" initiative, aiming for deployment by early 2022. Moovit's technology and user data from over 800 million users will be integrated into Intel's Mobileye unit, which projects the robotaxi market to reach $160 billion by 2030. The acquisition, negotiated during the coronavirus pandemic, is seen by Intel as an opportunity to fill critical gaps in its future mobility plans.

title: Intel Acquires Israel’s Moovit In $900M Move To Accelerate Autonomous Transportation With Mobileye
summary: Intel has acquired Israeli mobility-as-a-service company Moovit for approximately $900 million to accelerate Mobileye's autonomous transportation initiatives. This acquisition aims to leverage Moovit's extensive transportation dataset and user base to enhance Mobileye's robotaxi services and overall mobility-as-a-service strategy. Moovit will continue to operate under its own brand within Mobileye, contributing to the development of self-driving technology and improved urban mobility.

title: Intel Acquires Moovit to Accelerate Mobileye’s Mobility-as-a-Service Offering
summary: Intel Corporation announced its acquisition of Moovit, a mobility-as-a-service (MaaS) solutions company, for approximately $900 million. This acquisition is intended to accelerate Mobileye’s plan to become a complete mobility provider, including robotaxi services, leveraging Moovit's expansive user base and transportation data. The move positions Intel and Mobileye to capitalize on the growing ADAS, data, and MaaS markets, projected to exceed $230 billion by 2030.

title: Intel Delivers World’s Fastest Gaming Processor
summary: Intel announced its new 10th Gen Intel Core S-series desktop processors, including the flagship Core i9-10900K, touted as the world's fastest gaming processor. These new processors offer speeds up to 5.3 GHz with Intel Thermal Velocity Boost, promising enhanced gaming, faster multitasking, and improved video editing capabilities. The processors are expected to be available globally starting in May 2020.

title: Intel and MIC Announce Scale to Serve Program to Rapidly Expand Remote ICUs to 100 US Hospitals
summary: Intel and Medical Informatics Corp. (MIC) launched the Scale to Serve Program, a $50 million initiative by Intel, to help 100 US hospitals rapidly implement MIC’s Sickbay platform. This platform expands ICU bed capacity, enhances patient care efficiency, and reduces COVID-19 exposure risk for healthcare providers by enabling remote patient monitoring. Intel will fund implementation fees, and MIC will waive initial software subscription fees to support hospitals during the pandemic.

title: AMD (NASDAQ:AMD) Reports 41% Year-Over-Year Revenue Growth, Record Notebook Sales
summary: AMD reported Q1 FY2020 earnings with $1.79 billion in revenue, marking a 41% year-over-year growth, despite missing Wall Street analyst expectations and its own previous guidance. The company saw strong performance in Ryzen and EPYC processors and record notebook sales, although overall sequential revenue dropped. AMD remains optimistic about Q2 FY2020, forecasting 21% year-over-year revenue growth.

title: Product Review: The Zebra ET56 Offers Portability, Power
summary: The Zebra ET56 enterprise tablet is reviewed as an ideal device for clinical settings due to its trifecta of portability, power, and military-grade durability. It features a powerful Intel Atom E3940 processor, a high-resolution display, and robust wireless connectivity, making it suitable for demanding healthcare environments. The tablet's rugged design, MIL-STD-810G rating, and advanced camera capabilities ensure reliability and support for telemedicine and triage.

title: Exclusive: Amazon deploys thermal cameras at warehouses to scan for fevers faster
summary: Amazon.com Inc has begun using thermal cameras at its warehouses to more quickly screen workers for fevers, a key symptom of the coronavirus. This represents an effort to maintain operations and contain the virus' spread without fully closing warehouses, a move that comes amid reports of infections at over 50 U.S. facilities and calls from unions to close buildings. The camera systems, which are faster and require less contact than forehead thermometers, are being deployed in warehouses near Los Angeles and Seattle, and at Whole Foods stores.

title: Indian American Billionaire Aneel Bhusri Donates $1 Million towards COVID19 Relief
summary: Indian American billionaire Aneel Bhusri, CEO of Workday, has donated $1 million to the Give2SF fund to help small businesses in San Francisco affected by COVID-19. Bhusri, with a net worth of $2.2 billion in 2019, has also joined The Giving Pledge, committing to donate over half his wealth to noble causes, following the example of other Indian American philanthropists. He is recognized for his employee-centric approach, advocacy for pay parity, and mentoring young professionals.

title: Wilson Sonsini Advises MaxLinear in Acquisition of Intel Division
summary: Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati is advising MaxLinear, Inc. in its acquisition of Intel Corporation's Home Gateway Platform Division assets for $150 million. This all-cash transaction, announced on April 6, 2020, will integrate Intel's Wi-Fi Access Points, Ethernet, and Home Gateway SoC products into MaxLinear's portfolio. The acquisition aims to enhance MaxLinear's connectivity and access solutions and is expected to close in Q3 2020, pending regulatory approvals.

title: Enovix Raises $45 Million To Launch 3D Silicon Lithium-ion Battery
summary: Enovix Corporation has secured $45 million in new funding to produce and commercialize its "3D Silicon Lithium-ion Battery." The company plans to launch production at its Fremont, California facility by the end of 2020, aiming for a run-rate of 8 million units per year by 2021-2022, primarily for portable electronics with future expansion into the EV market within five years. This investment, which includes strategic funding and customer contracts, highlights the company's progress in developing high energy-density silicon-anode batteries and its proprietary production process.

title: Paula Cooney Joins Flir as Chief HR Officer
summary: Paula Cooney, a former human resource executive at Intel, has been appointed as the chief HR officer and senior vice president at Flir Systems. In her new role, she will be responsible for overseeing strategic HR efforts, including talent management, culture development, and organizational aspects. Cooney brings extensive experience from her 13-year tenure at Intel and her recent position leading global HR for H.B. Fuller.

title: Intel To Sell Home Gateway Assets For $150 Million
summary: Intel is selling the majority of its Home Gateway Platform Division assets, including SoC products for home gateways, Wi-Fi access points, and Ethernet, to MaxLinear for $150 million in cash. This sale reflects Intel's ongoing strategy under CEO Bob Swan to consolidate connectivity solutions that are not part of its core business, while still prioritizing other connectivity initiatives like Wi-Fi 6 and 5G. MaxLinear will integrate Intel's employees and technology to expand its offerings in the connected home market.

title: GlobalFoundries Has Quietly Become A Player In Silicon Photonics Manufacturing
summary: GlobalFoundries has quietly established itself as a significant player in silicon photonics manufacturing, now holding at least 10% of the foundry market share. This position was achieved through strategic acquisitions, such as IBM's Microelectronics business in 2015, and key partnerships with companies like Ayar Labs and MACOM Technology Solutions Inc. The article highlights GF's roadmap, including its 90nm and future 45CLO platforms, aimed at addressing the growing demand for higher bandwidth in data centers and 5G networks.

title: This Supreme Court Case Shows Exactly Why Every Employer Needs to Understand ERISA Requirements
summary: A recent Supreme Court ruling against Intel Corp. highlights the critical importance of ERISA compliance for employers, emphasizing the need for clear communication and adherence to fiduciary duties. The case extended the statute of limitations for a lawsuit against Intel, underscoring that simply making disclosures available online may not be sufficient. Employers must understand ERISA requirements, including the types of plans covered and potential penalties, and consider measures like wrap documents and professional consulting to minimize compliance risks.

title: Storage class memory makes its way into the enterprise
summary: Storage class memory (SCM) is emerging as a critical technology for enterprise workloads, offering a non-volatile memory solution that bridges the gap between DRAM and SSDs. The article highlights the growing number of SCM products and use cases, with Intel's Optane brand and offerings from Micron Technology, Kioxia, and Samsung leading the market. SCM is particularly beneficial for latency-sensitive applications like AI, analytics, and high-performance computing, enabling improved application performance and more efficient data processing.

title: Intel Scales Neuromorphic Research System to 100 Million Neurons
summary: Intel announced its new neuromorphic research system, Pohoiki Springs, which boasts the computational capacity of 100 million neurons and will be accessible to members of the Intel Neuromorphic Research Community (INRC). This cloud-based system integrates 768 Loihi neuromorphic research chips and is designed to accelerate workloads that are inefficient on conventional architectures. Pohoiki Springs is a significant step towards more sophisticated neuromorphic workloads, with Intel envisioning its use for real-time processing, problem-solving, and adaptation, without replacing traditional computing systems.

title: Intel, Micron update phase-change memory agreement ...
summary: Intel and Micron have updated their phase-change memory agreement, terminating their previous Product Supply Agreement from 2012 and entering into a new 3D XPoint wafer supply agreement with revised pricing and forecast terms. This comes after both companies faced profitability challenges related to 3D XPoint production, with Micron continuing to report significant under-utilization charges for its Lehi, Utah fab.

title: AMD's Ryzen Mobile 4000 H-series arrives to give gamers a real choice again
summary: AMD's new Ryzen Mobile 4000 H-series processors are launched, aiming to compete directly with Intel in the gaming laptop market. These 45W chips, first revealed at CES 2020, promise significant performance gains over Intel's 9th Gen chips, including the Core i7-9750H and i9-9880H. The H-series, featuring Ryzen 5 and Ryzen 7 options with up to 8 cores and 16 threads, are designed for gaming laptops and professional creator machines.

title: Everspin Technologies and GLOBALFOUNDRIES Extend MRAM Joint Development Agreement to 12nm
summary: Everspin Technologies and GLOBALFOUNDRIES have extended their Spin-transfer Torque (STT-MRAM) joint development agreement to include a future project on an advanced 12 nm FinFET MRAM solution. This partnership previously covered 40 nm, 28 nm, and 22 nm STT-MRAM processes. The extension aims to further solidify their mutual technology leadership and advance STT-MRAM as a future memory technology, particularly eyeing its use in microcontroller and IoT applications.

title: Supermicro getting its edge systems off the ground and in the field
summary: Super Micro Computer Inc. is rolling out new IP65 enclosed outdoor edge systems designed for harsh conditions, including 5G radio-access networking and AI inferencing. These configurable servers run Intel Corp.'s Xeon D or 2nd Gen Xeon scalable microprocessors and offer flexibility for FPGA and GPU acceleration. The company sees significant growth potential in these edge computing markets, particularly for 5G, Embedded, and IoT solutions.

title: Everything You Should Know before Investing in Nokia Stock
summary: This article examines Nokia's performance in 2019 and its prospects for a rebound in 2020, focusing on its 5G strategy. It highlights executive changes, new partnerships with Marvell and Intel, and cost-cutting measures, alongside the company's Q4 2019 earnings. The article also touches on speculation about asset sales and the company's financial position.

title: Major Tech Company Using Facial Recognition to ID Workers
summary: Intel is implementing facial recognition technology at its Oregon offices and other U.S. sites to identify employees, suppliers, and contractors, aiming to enhance workplace security and identify "high risk individuals." This move, potentially the largest workplace facial recognition deployment in the country, faces scrutiny from technology watchdogs and privacy advocates due to the lack of an opt-out option and concerns over data breaches and potential misuse. Despite these concerns, Intel asserts worker safety is its priority, while experts acknowledge potential benefits alongside unforeseen consequences and biases in the technology.

title: Are There Better Ways to Stack DRAM?
summary: Xperi Corporation, through its Invensas DBI Ultra 3D interconnect technology, is proposing a new method for stacking DRAM that aims to reduce costs and enable higher layer counts of 8, 12, or even 16 layers. This technology uses low-temperature, low-profile die-to-wafer and die-to-die hybrid bonding, eliminating the need for copper pillars and underfill, potentially making it more cost-effective than current HBM stacking methods. While stacking isn't new, the success of Xperi's approach will depend on its ability to lower costs enough for wider adoption in various applications, including cost-sensitive ones like cellphones.

title: Cognizant Names Archana Deskus to Board of Directors
summary: Cognizant announced the appointment of Archana Deskus to its board of directors as a new independent director, effective March 5, 2020. Ms. Deskus, who is currently Senior Vice President, Chief Information Officer for Intel Corporation, brings extensive experience in leading technology strategies for large global corporations. Her expertise in business transformation and innovation is expected to be a valuable asset to Cognizant's board.

title: Opinion: AMD shows that it’s not resting on its laurels with ambitious road map
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. demonstrated at its annual analyst meeting that it is not complacent after being the top performer in the S&P 500 last year. The company presented an ambitious road map with new chip architectures and aggressive goals, making a strong case for investors to continue trusting CEO Lisa Su. AMD aims for continued strong growth despite fierce competition from Intel Corp.

title: Cisco exec named CEO of Western Digital as Cisco tells employees about its 'next phase of strategy'
summary: Cisco executive David Goeckeler has been named the new CEO of Western Digital. This move comes as Cisco announces internal organizational changes aimed at accelerating growth, innovation, and digital transformation. The article also mentions Cisco's related activities, including offering free video conferencing and planning layoffs.

title: Intel Announces 2019 Supplier Continuous Quality Improvement Awards
summary: Intel recognized 37 suppliers with its 2019 Supplier Continuous Quality Improvement (SCQI) Awards for their exceptional quality and performance. These awards, part of Intel’s SCQI program, acknowledge suppliers who demonstrate best-in-class excellence and continuous improvement, contributing significantly to Intel's ability to deliver products and advance technology. The program includes three levels of recognition: SCQI, Preferred Quality Supplier (PQS), and Supplier Achievement Award (SAA), highlighting achievements in areas like diversity, cost, quality, and innovation.

title: Intel hires VMLY&R as global creative agency
summary: Intel has appointed VMLY&R as its new global creative agency, marking a significant change in its advertising strategy. This move positions VMLY&R to handle Intel's creative campaigns worldwide. The announcement was made by Lindsay Rittenhouse for Ad Age.

title: Intel’s Culture Needed Fixing. Its C.E.O. Is Shaking Things Up. (Published 2020)
summary: Intel CEO Robert Swan is leading a significant cultural overhaul at the company, encouraging its 110,000 employees to address internal problems more openly through initiatives like the "One Intel" tagline. This shift aims to move Intel away from its historical near-monopoly mindset and foster greater collaboration with customers to succeed in new markets, reflecting the biggest attitude adjustment in decades for the Silicon Valley giant. The changes are influenced by the precepts of former CEO Andrew S. Grove.

title: Intel receives $600M bond approval for Chandler manufacturing plants
summary: Intel has received approval for a $600 million bond to support its manufacturing expansion in Chandler, Arizona. This bond will aid the ongoing $7 billion investment in Fab 42, which is projected to create 3,000 new Intel jobs and over 10,000 long-term jobs in Arizona. Fab 42, upon completion, is expected to be the most advanced semiconductor factory globally.

title: Pure Storage Upgrades FlashArray//X, Plans Unified File/Block Storage Capabilities
summary: Pure Storage has upgraded its FlashArray//X with new Intel Xeon Scalable processors, boosting performance by up to 25 percent and potentially 50 percent for specific applications. The company also announced plans for Purity 6, an upcoming operating system refresh that will introduce unified block and file data capabilities to the FlashArray//X line. Customers enrolled in the Evergreen Storage service program will receive free upgrades to these third-generation FlashArray//X systems every three years.

title: Supreme Court rejects appeal in Apple’s $1-billion dispute over FaceTime patents
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court has rejected Apple's appeal in its decadelong patent dispute with VirnetX Holding Corp. over FaceTime technology. This decision means Apple may have to pay up to $1 billion in damages to VirnetX for using its secure communications technology without permission. VirnetX, a Nevada company with modest revenue, saw its stock jump significantly on the news.

title: Intel Announces Unmatched Portfolio for 5G Network Infrastructure
summary: Intel announced a comprehensive portfolio of hardware and software solutions designed to transform 5G network infrastructure from core to edge. Key announcements include the Intel Atom P5900, a 10nm SoC for wireless base stations, new 2nd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors, and the Diamond Mesa structured ASIC for 5G network acceleration, positioning Intel as a leading silicon provider in the rapidly expanding 5G market. The company also introduced the 5G network-optimized Intel Ethernet 700 Series Network Adapter and expanded its OpenNESS toolkit for edge computing.

title: Electrical tape on sign tricked a Tesla into speeding in a test
summary: Researchers from McAfee Inc. were able to trick a Tesla vehicle into accelerating by placing a strip of electrical tape over a speed limit sign, causing the car's cruise control to read 35 mph as 85 mph. This incident highlights potential vulnerabilities in machine learning systems used in automated driving, though McAfee states the immediate real-world risk is low given the current development stage of autonomous vehicles. The findings contribute to the field of adversarial machine learning, demonstrating how physical alterations can confuse computer vision systems in self-driving cars.

title: Israeli VC Firm Grove Ventures Closes $120M Fund For Deep Tech Startups
summary: Israeli VC firm Grove Ventures announced the closure of its Grove Ventures II Fund (Grove II), raising $120 million to invest in early-stage, deep tech startups in Israel targeting European and US markets. The fund, which was oversubscribed, focuses on companies developing "hard-to-replicate solutions" across various sectors, led by serial entrepreneur Dov Moran. Grove Ventures aims to empower deep tech entrepreneurs to build international companies and address significant industry challenges with innovative technology.

title: Verus brings on former Intel exec Stuart Odell
summary: Consultants Verus has announced the addition of Stuart Odell, a former Intel executive, to its team. The article, published on February 18, 2020, highlights this significant hire.

title: HP Inc. PC President Alex Cho: ‘Get Ready For The Return Of The PC’
summary: HP Inc. PC President Alex Cho discusses the resurgence of the PC, particularly among Gen Z, debunking earlier predictions of its decline due to tablets. He highlights how HP is leaning into this trend by focusing on design, security, connectivity, and sustainability to meet the evolving needs of users who primarily use PCs for creation, consumption, and collaboration. The article anticipates future developments from HP, moving towards more empathetic computing experiences beyond traditional speeds and feeds.

title: Top 2019 enterprise storage arrays win Products of the Year
summary: The 2019 Products of the Year awards for enterprise storage arrays highlight a significant industry shift from disk to flash storage, driven by the need for ultrafast solutions for AI workloads. Vast Data took the gold for its Universal Storage V2.0, NGD Systems won silver for its 32 TB Newport U.2 NVMe computational storage drive, and DataDirect Networks secured bronze with its DDN AI400, demonstrating innovation across flash, computational storage, and high-performance computing. The awards emphasize the growing importance of flash-based systems and the emergence of new technologies like computational storage.

title: Nvidia forecast tops expectations on cloud sales despite coronavirus hit
summary: Nvidia Corp exceeded Wall Street's first-quarter revenue expectations, driven by strong sales of its chips to cloud computing vendors, despite projecting a $100 million hit due to the coronavirus outbreak. This forecast signals a rebound in chip demand, particularly in the data center business, which helped offset a slight miss in gaming revenue and increased Nvidia's shares. The company expects current-quarter revenue of $3 billion, plus or minus 2%.

title: How analog in-memory computing can solve power challenges of edge AI inference
summary: This article explores how analog in-memory computing can address the significant power consumption and latency issues of edge AI inference, which are prevalent with cloud-based AI solutions. It highlights the memory bottleneck in traditional digital computing and introduces a multi-level memory architecture, like Microchip Technology's memBrain, that integrates computation directly into memory, dramatically reducing power usage. The technology utilizes SuperFlash memory cells to perform Multiply-Accumulate operations efficiently at the edge, offering extreme low power, smaller footprint, and lower development costs for AI applications.

title: Intel dumps its Nervana neural network processors for Habana’s AI chips
summary: Intel Corp. has decided to discontinue development of its Nervana neural network processors, opting instead to focus on the AI chip technology acquired with Habana Labs Ltd. for $2 billion. This decision comes as Habana's chips, such as the Gaudi and Goya, have demonstrated superior performance compared to Nervana's NNP-T and NNP-I processors. The move could have implications for Intel's AI Platforms Group, led by a Nervana co-founder, raising questions about potential mergers with Habana.

title: Tim Boyle named Chairman of the Board at Columbia Sportswear
summary: Columbia Sportswear Company's Board of Directors has appointed CEO and President Tim Boyle as Chairman of the Board. Additionally, Andy Bryant has been appointed as the Lead Independent Director. Bryant, who previously chaired Intel Corporation's Board, has been a Columbia board member since 2005.

title: AMD chief Lisa Su joins Cisco board as networking giant touts 5G, silicon products
summary: Lisa Su, CEO of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), has joined the board of Cisco Systems. This appointment comes as Cisco is launching new software, silicon, and router products, while AMD has recently achieved record revenues and an all-time high stock price under Su's leadership.

title: Corsair One i164 SFF PC Review
summary: This review examines the Corsair One i164, a small form factor (SFF) PC featuring an Intel 9900K and NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Ti. The article details its design, I/O, cooling system, and internal specifications, highlighting its quiet operation and powerful components. It assesses whether this new iteration lives up to the high recommendations of its predecessor.

title: Quantum Computing Under Hype Cycle and Market Clock Scrutiny
summary: This article discusses quantum computing's position within Gartner's Hype Cycle and Market Clock theories, examining how new technologies often face unrealistic expectations. It explores the differing views on quantum computing's potential, from its current limitations as highlighted by industry experts to the optimistic long-term visions of advocates like Mikhail Lukin. The piece also touches on investment trends and the ethical implications of technological advancement.

title: Voting Gets Lazy; Cash-Craving Comcast; Broadcom Bites the Apple
summary: This article discusses several market topics, starting with the potential for smartphone voting and its implications for democracy. It then analyzes Comcast's strategy to offset video subscriber losses with price hikes and new streaming services, Intel's strong quarterly performance, and Broadcom's significant supply deal with Apple. Finally, it questions the market's enthusiastic reaction to American Express's latest earnings report and offers advice on navigating uncertain market conditions.

title: Teardown: Apple iPhone 11 Pro Max
summary: This article provides a detailed teardown analysis of the Apple iPhone 11 Pro Max, highlighting its key specifications, manufacturing cost, and major internal components. It also touches upon Apple's strategy regarding 5G modems, including its settlement with Qualcomm and acquisition of Intel's modem business for future product development. The teardown provides insights into the device's camera modules, RF components, and main PC board.

title: Medtronic CEO Omar Ishrak Named Chairman of Intel
summary: Omar Ishrak, CEO of Medtronic, has been elected as the new chairman of Intel Corp.'s board, succeeding Andy Bryant. Ishrak expressed honor at the appointment and previously announced plans to step down as Medtronic's CEO. During his tenure at Medtronic, he oversaw the significant acquisition of Covidien.

title: Mercury Systems Unveils Multicore Processor Module for Helicopters, UAM Vehicles
summary: Mercury Systems has introduced its CIOE-1390 multi-core processor module designed for helicopters and urban air mobility vehicles, featuring Intel Atom multi-core processors and BuiltSAFE technology for flight safety certification. The company anticipates high demand for these processors in UAM and military markets due to the increasing need for advanced onboard processing and the limitations of traditional single-core processors. This development aims to provide powerful, flight safety-certifiable processing solutions for next-generation platforms.

title: Intel Board of Directors Elects New Chairman and New Director
summary: Intel Corporation announced that Andy D. Bryant stepped down as chairman of the board, and Dr. Omar Ishrak was elected to succeed him as independent chairman, effective immediately. Additionally, Alyssa Henry was elected to Intel’s board, marking the seventh new independent director added since 2016. Bryant will remain on the board until the 2020 annual stockholders’ meeting to facilitate a smooth transition.

title: Intel Names Omar Ishrak As Its New Board Chairman
summary: Intel Corp. has appointed Omar Ishrak, CEO of Medtronic, as the new chairman of its board of directors, succeeding Andy Bryant who is stepping down. Ishrak has been on Intel's board since 2017 and takes the helm amidst ongoing CPU shortages affecting Intel's PC and data center lines. Additionally, Alyssa Henry of Square Inc. was elected as a new independent director.

title: Intel Board of Directors Elects New Chairman and New Director
summary: Intel Corporation announced that its board of directors elected Dr. Omar Ishrak as the new independent chairman, succeeding Andy D. Bryant, effective immediately. The company also announced the election of Alyssa Henry to its board, marking the seventh new independent director since early 2016. Andy Bryant will remain on the board until the 2020 annual stockholders' meeting and expressed confidence in Dr. Ishrak's leadership and the strengthening of the board with Henry's expertise.

title: Intel’s pending layoffs will hit multiple business groups, Oregon workers
summary: Intel is preparing for layoffs impacting multiple business groups, including software, and Oregon workers. These cuts are expected to be in the hundreds and announced after their quarterly financial results, though not as extensive as the 2016 job reductions. The company is reportedly repositioning resources towards new hardware technologies and data center solutions.

title: How Connected Retail Market Segments Growth Boosting New 'Income Cycle’?
summary: This article announces a new study on the India Connected Retail Market from HTF Market Intelligence Consulting Pvt. Ltd., covering the market from 2019-2025. The report details market predictions, key driving forces, future trends, and profiles major players. It also breaks down the market by types, applications, and regions, providing guidance for stakeholders and an in-depth analysis of the industry.

title: Air Taxi Startup Joby Aviation Lands $590M From Toyota-Led Series C
summary: Joby Aviation, a California-based air taxi startup, secured $590 million in a Series C funding round led by Toyota, bringing its total funding to $720 million. Toyota's investment signifies its push into air transportation, aiming to leverage its manufacturing expertise to help Joby develop and produce electric aircraft. Joby Aviation's planes are designed for quiet, fast travel, with the goal of eventually making per-trip passenger pricing comparable to ground transportation.

title: AMD Hires Top Intel Exec Dan McNamara To Grow EPYC Business
summary: AMD has appointed former top Intel executive Dan McNamara as senior vice president and general manager of its Server Business Unit to further develop the EPYC server processor business. This strategic hire, announced alongside four other senior executive promotions, aims to strengthen AMD's leadership team and build on its recent momentum. McNamara will report to Forrest Norrod and is taking over from Scott Aylor, who is departing later this year.

title: Supermicro Expands Oracle Relationship with Best in Class Server Solutions
summary: Supermicro, a Gold-level member of Oracle PartnerNetwork, has expanded its collaboration with Oracle by testing and certifying a wide range of its servers with Oracle Linux and Oracle VM Server for x86. This expansion aims to enhance performance and TCO value for customers running Oracle workloads in cloud, virtualization, and enterprise database applications. The certified systems leverage Supermicro's system designs and 2nd Generation Intel Xeon Scalable processors, supporting larger datasets and higher availability with Intel Optane DC persistent memory.

title: 6 Things To Know About Intel's New CIO Archana Deskus
summary: Intel has appointed Archana "Archie" Deskus as its new CIO and senior vice president, a role critical for demonstrating how Intel's technologies can transform IT organizations. Deskus brings extensive experience from five previous CIO roles, including a significant IT restructuring at Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Her responsibilities at Intel will include leading a 5,000-person IT organization and integrating AI more deeply into Intel's IT strategy and products.

title: Joby Aviation Raises $590 Million In Series C Financing To Launch Air Taxi Service
summary: Joby Aviation announced it raised $590 million in Series C funding, led by Toyota Motor Corporation with a $394 million investment, to help launch its electric air taxi service. This funding brings Joby's total to $720 million, and Toyota will contribute manufacturing and quality expertise to accelerate the certification and deployment of Joby's VTOL aircraft. The partnership aims to revolutionize transportation by introducing an affordable, zero-emissions air mobility system.

title: Investing in Quantum Computing - The Quantum Daily Guide
summary: This article discusses the challenges of investing directly in quantum computing given its nascent stage of development. It highlights that most companies are private and that publicly listed companies offer limited, indirect exposure. The article also touches upon ETFs as a diversification option but emphasizes that targeted pure-play investments are difficult to achieve currently.

title: Chipmaker Sckipio Agrees to Transfer Employees to Sequans Communications
summary: Israel-based chip company Sckipio Corp. has agreed to transfer 25 of its local software developers to New York-listed Sequans Communications SA. Sckipio, which develops chips for modems and broadband applications, faced difficulties after major clients like AT&T Inc. halted their orders. A small team, including management, will remain with Sckipio to continue technology development.

title: Trump administration pressed Dutch hard to cancel China chip-equipment sale - sources
summary: The Trump administration engaged in a high-level campaign to pressure the Dutch government into canceling the sale of advanced chip manufacturing technology from ASML to a Chinese customer. This effort, involving Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and a classified intelligence briefing for the Dutch Prime Minister, aimed to prevent China from acquiring technology essential for advanced microprocessors. The pressure appears to have been successful, as the Dutch government did not renew ASML's export license for the machine.

title: Highflying Nvidia’s Deal for Arm Signals Loftier Chip Ambition
summary: Nvidia's $40 billion acquisition of Arm Holdings from SoftBank Group Corp. is poised to significantly impact the global semiconductor industry. The deal involves a mix of cash and stock, with potential additional payments based on Arm's financial performance. This transaction further elevates Nvidia's position and represents another major move for SoftBank.

title: Investors Love Thematic ETFs and Mutual Funds, but They Aren’t Always Loved Back - WSJ
authors: Tyler Comrie By Michael A. Pollock
summary: Thematic ETFs and mutual funds are popular among investors, allowing them to invest in specific trends like AI, clean energy, or space. However, these funds can often disappoint despite investor enthusiasm. The article suggests strategies for investors to better manage their thematic fund investments.

title: Intel expands paid leave benefits
summary: Intel is significantly enhancing its paid leave benefits, expanding leave for new parents to 12 weeks, providing up to eight weeks for family care, and increasing bereavement leave to two weeks. The company is also introducing a new parent reintegration program allowing part-time work with full-time pay for up to four weeks, alongside a breast milk shipping benefit for traveling mothers. These changes aim to support employee well-being and aid in talent attraction and retention.

title: Apple has secret team working on satellites to beam data to devices
summary: Apple has a secret team of engineers working on satellite technology that could be used to beam internet services directly to devices, bypassing traditional wireless networks. The project is still in its early stages and could potentially mitigate dependence on wireless carriers or enhance location tracking for Apple devices. While the clear direction and use for satellites haven't been finalized, CEO Tim Cook's interest indicates it's a company priority.

title: Intel Expands Leave Benefits for Family Care, Bereavement (1)
summary: Intel Corp. is expanding its U.S. paid leave benefits starting January 1, 2020, to include eight weeks for family care and two weeks for bereavement. Additionally, parental bonding leave will increase to 12 weeks, and short-term disability coverage approximating regular pay for up to 52 weeks will be provided at no cost during maternity leave. These changes represent a significant increase from previous benefits, such as one week of bereavement leave.

title: Intel shells out $2 billion to buy Israel’s Habana Labs
summary: Intel has acquired Israeli artificial intelligence (AI) chipmaker Habana Labs for $2 billion. This acquisition is part of Intel's strategy to expand its AI capabilities and better compete in the rapidly growing AI chip market. Habana Labs will operate as an independent business unit within Intel's Data Platform Group.

title: Intel Buys Israeli AI Chipmaker Habana Labs for $2 Billion
summary: Intel Corp. acquired Israeli AI chipmaker Habana Labs for approximately $2 billion to strengthen its position in the rapidly expanding artificial intelligence silicon market. This acquisition is part of Intel's strategy to make its offerings essential to major silicon buyers and compete against companies like Alphabet's Google and Amazon's AWS, which are increasingly designing their own chips for data centers. Habana Labs is expected to operate independently for the time being.

title: Intel scoops up Israeli artificial intelligence startup for $2B
summary: Intel has acquired Israeli artificial intelligence startup Habana Labs Ltd. for $2 billion. Habana Labs, founded three years ago, had raised approximately $120 million from investors including Intel Capital, Bessemer Ventures, and Battery Ventures. Habana Labs investor and chairman Avigdor Willenz will become a senior adviser at Intel following the acquisition.

title: Intel buys Israeli AI start-up for $2 billion
summary: Intel has acquired Israeli artificial intelligence firm Habana Labs for approximately $2 billion. Habana Labs, which develops dedicated AI processors called Goya, will operate as an independent business unit reporting to Intel’s data platforms group. This acquisition marks one of the largest private exits in Israel and is particularly significant given Habana Labs had only raised $120 million prior to the deal.

title: Intel Deepens AI Push With $2 Billion Purchase of Habana Labs
summary: Intel is expanding its presence in the artificial intelligence market by acquiring Habana Labs, an Israel-based AI chip-making startup, for approximately $2 billion. This acquisition is strategically aimed at strengthening Intel's offerings of AI chips specifically designed for data centers. The deal seeks to attract more data-center customers by enhancing Intel's capabilities in handling the increasingly complex AI algorithms used for data analysis.

title: Intel hires former GlobalFoundries, IBM chip executive
summary: Intel Corp has hired Gary Patton, former chief technology officer at GlobalFoundries and a veteran of IBM's chip unit, as corporate vice president and general manager of design enablement. This move continues Intel's strategy of bringing in high-profile executives from competitors, following previous hires from Advanced Micro Devices and Qualcomm. Patton is recognized for his skill in transitioning research and development into practical chip factory applications.

title: Which groups earn the most at Intel? Company offers peek at pay data other tech firms won’t show
summary: Intel released compensation data for its U.S. employees from 2017 and 2018, revealing that white and Asian males were the highest earners in most occupation categories. The company, which is transparent about its diversity efforts, aims to encourage other tech firms to share similar data. This disclosure comes as the EEOC for the first time required companies to include pay data.

title: NortonLifeLock approached by Intel’s McAfee and private-equity firms
summary: NortonLifeLock, the $16 billion consumer-software company, has attracted acquisition interest from several entities, including rival McAfee LLC. Private-equity firms TPG and Thoma Bravo LLC have also approached NortonLifeLock. One of the options under consideration is a potential combination with McAfee's consumer business, which is owned by Intel Corp. and the aforementioned private-equity firms.

title: Intel says this breakthrough will make quantum computing more practical
summary: Intel is pursuing quantum computing through miniaturization, a strategy it hopes will differentiate it from rivals like Google and IBM. The company announced a new controller chip the size of a hand that replaces much larger external units, aiming to make quantum computers more practical. This miniaturization approach focuses on packing qubits more densely and simplifying the bulky machinery currently required for quantum computation.

title: Applied Materials Appoints CEO
summary: Applied Materials Inc. has announced that Gary Dickerson, president of the company, will become CEO effective September 1st. He will succeed Michael Splinter, who will transition to executive chairman after serving as CEO since 2003. Dickerson previously served as CEO of Varian Semiconductor Equipment Associates and held various roles at KLA-Tencor Corp.

title: HKSTP and UMEC Organise First AI Chips Summit
summary: The Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation (HKSTP) and United Microelectronics Centre (UMEC) jointly organized the first AI Chips Summit to promote the development of an Artificial Intelligence hardware ecosystem. The summit brought together global technology experts, industry players, academics, and Park company representatives to discuss advanced machine learning-based design methodologies and tools for AI chips and accelerators. HKSTP emphasized its ongoing efforts to support AI and innovative technology development through initiatives like iDM 2 Micro-Electronics Node and AI Plug@HKSTP.
source: Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation (HKSTP)
source_domain: Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation (HKSTP)

title: Intel may buy another AI chip developer, Habana Labs
summary: Intel is reportedly in advanced talks to acquire Israeli AI chip developer Habana Labs for up to $2 billion, following its 2017 Mobileye acquisition. Habana Labs, founded in 2016, develops processor platforms for deep neural network training and inference deployment, and recently launched its Gaudi AI Training processor. This potential acquisition would place Habana in competition with Nervana, another AI chip startup Intel acquired in 2016.

title: AMD share price up 120% in 2019; Strong outlook for 2020
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) shares surged 120% in 2019, reaching their highest level since 2006, fueled by strong Q3 results, positive developments in the US-China trade deal, and the successful launch of new Ryzen processors. The company's high price-earnings ratio of 219.44x indicates investor confidence in future growth, with CEO Lisa Su expressing optimism for 2020 and beyond due to a strong product portfolio and market momentum.

title: 3 networking startups rearchitect routing
summary: Three networking startups, Arrcus, DriveNets, and Volta Networks, are redefining routing by decoupling software from hardware, enabling it to run on commodity products. This disaggregation reduces operational expenses and adds flexibility, mirroring a trend previously seen in network switching. Industry analysts anticipate these companies could become M&A targets as service providers increasingly look towards white box routing for 5G deployments.

title: Intel in talks to buy Israeli AI chip co Habana Labs
summary: Intel is reportedly in advanced talks to acquire Israeli AI chip startup Habana Labs for an estimated $1 billion. Habana Labs, founded in 2016, previously raised $120 million, with Intel Capital leading its latest financing round in November 2018. If the acquisition proceeds, it would significantly strengthen Intel's position in the AI chip market, where Habana Labs has developed specialized AI Training and Inference Processors.

title: Supermicro Launches Server Class Edge Systems for Open 5G Radio Access Network (RAN) Solutions
summary: Supermicro has launched new server-class edge systems designed for Open 5G Radio Access Network (RAN) solutions. These SuperServers leverage 2nd Gen Intel Xeon Scalable processors, support O-RAN compliant partner software, and are built to operate in harsh environments, accelerating the transition to open-source software and disaggregated hardware for 5G deployments. The company introduced models like the E403-9P-FN2T and 1U 1019P-FHN2T, along with plans for IP65-rated protective enclosures, to provide flexible and cost-effective 5G infrastructure.

title: JD.com’s StarLink IoT Platform is the Future of Retail
summary: The JD.com StarLink IoT platform is revolutionizing retail by integrating over 1,000 technologies to create seamless interactive shopping experiences in offline stores. It enhances traditional brick-and-mortar models with features like facial recognition, AR fitting, and real-time digital price tags, as demonstrated in the JD E-SPACE store. Beyond retail, JD's IoT solutions are transforming smart housing and the energy sector, leveraging partnerships with industry leaders to bring advanced technology to homes and infrastructure across China.

title: AMD Ryzen 9 3900X review: Amazing multi-core CPU performance at an unbelievable price
summary: This article reviews the AMD Ryzen 9 3900X, highlighting its exceptional multi-core performance and competitive pricing which allows it to challenge Intel's high-end offerings. The review emphasizes the CPU's 12 cores, 24 threads, PCIe 4.0 support, and AM4 compatibility, positioning it as a strong contender for demanding tasks like video editing and gaming. It concludes that the Ryzen 9 3900X offers incredible value and performance, making the desktop CPU market more competitive and beneficial for consumers.

title: Inside HPE’s massive S/4HANA consolidation
summary: HPE is undertaking a massive ERP consolidation to SAP S/4HANA, aiming to complete the project in under three years. HPE Senior Vice President and CIO Archana Deskus emphasizes the critical role of top-level executive support and strategic compromises for such rapid transformation. The initiative, part of HPE Next, seeks to simplify and standardize business processes globally, automate operations, improve user experience, and leverage data as a strategic asset, resulting in significant cost savings and application retirement.

title: Accenture, Airbus, GE and Hitachi Join Intel Neuromorphic Research Community
summary: Intel announced that Accenture, Airbus, GE, and Hitachi have joined its Neuromorphic Research Community (INRC), tripling its size to over 75 organizations. This expansion signifies growing commercial interest and the advancing maturity of neuromorphic computing for AI problems difficult for conventional deep learning. The new corporate members will collaborate with Intel to research and develop real-world applications for neuromorphic technology using Intel's Loihi processor.

title: Supermicro Collaborates with Intel to Deliver Large Scale Distributed Training AI Systems
summary: Supermicro is collaborating with Intel on AI solutions validated on the Intel Nervana Neural Network Processor for Training (NNP-T), a purpose-built AI training ASIC. These Supermicro systems, featuring NNP-T ASICs, are designed to train large AI models with near-linear scaling efficiency, addressing memory constraints and enabling easier scaling for complex deep learning models. The solution aims to accelerate AI model training for applications like image and speech processing, medical analytics, and autonomous driving.

title: Kulicke & Soffa Appoints Jeff Richardson to Its Board of Directors
summary: Kulicke & Soffa Industries, Inc. announced the appointment of David Jeffrey Richardson to its Board of Directors. Mr. Richardson brings over 32 years of semiconductor industry experience, previously serving as Chairman of Lattice Semiconductor Corporation and a Director of Ambarella, as well as holding key roles at LSI Corporation and Intel Corporation. The company believes his extensive management and technical background will be invaluable as K&S diversifies and grows.

title: AMD Radeon™ Pro 5000M Series Mobile GPUs Bring High-Performance AMD RDNA Architecture to Apple’s New 16-inch MacBook Pro
summary: AMD announced that its new Radeon Pro 5500M and 5300M mobile GPUs, based on the 7nm AMD RDNA architecture, will power Apple's new 16-inch MacBook Pro. These are the first 7nm discrete mobile GPUs for professional users, offering up to 4.0 TFLOPS of performance and up to 8GB of GDDR6 memory to enhance video editing, 3D content creation, and macOS game development. The GPUs aim to provide creative professionals with powerful visual fidelity for demanding applications.

title: Intel Speeds AI Development, Deployment and Performance with New Class of AI Hardware from Cloud to Edge
summary: Intel announced new AI hardware, including the Intel Nervana Neural Network Processors (NNP-T1000 and NNP-I1000) for training and inference, and its next-generation Intel Movidius Myriad Vision Processing Unit (VPU). These products are designed to accelerate AI development and deployment from cloud to edge, further strengthening Intel's AI solutions portfolio, which is expected to generate over $3.5 billion in revenue in 2019. The company also introduced the Intel DevCloud for the Edge to help developers prototype AI solutions on Intel processors.

title: Nio Could Be In For More Pain As Industry Association Issues Bleak EV Sales Forecast
summary: Nio (NIO) shares dropped after the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM) reported a significant year-over-year decline in electric vehicle sales for the fourth consecutive month in October. This bleak forecast, attributed to weaker consumer demand and reduced subsidies, suggests continued pressure on the NEV market in China, despite Nio's recent individual sales rebound.

title: Nio, Mobileye to bring autonomous vehicles to China, other major markets
summary: Nio, the Chinese electric car maker, has partnered with Intel's Mobileye to develop and mass-produce a Level 4 autonomous driving system for China and other major markets. The system, targeted for release from 2022, will be integrated into Nio's electric cars and used by Mobileye for its driverless ride-hailing services. This collaboration aims to enhance road safety and help Nio as it faces financial challenges.

title: McDonald’s Chief Forced Out after Relationship with Employee
authors: VOA - Voice of America English News
summary: McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook was forced out of the company due to a consensual relationship with an employee, which violated company policy. The board of directors voted on his employment after an investigation, and Chris Kempczinski was named as the new CEO. This decision is seen by some as a reflection of progress in addressing workplace issues in the era of the #MeToo movement.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: McFired: McDonald’s CEO removed over relationship with employee
summary: McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook was dismissed over a consensual relationship with an employee, which violated company policy. Chris Kempczinski, president of McDonald’s USA, was named the new CEO. The departure highlights increased scrutiny of executive behavior amid the #MeToo movement, while the company faces challenges with declining customer visits and fierce competition.

title: What's driving the Automotive Electronics Market trends? 2024
summary: The automotive electronics market is projected to exceed USD 400 billion by 2024, driven by increasing demand for advanced safety, comfort features, and the development of intelligent vehicle technologies. Stringent regulations, rising electric vehicle sales, and growth in ADAS systems are key factors fueling this expansion. Major players like Lear Corporation, Panasonic, and Continental are investing in R&D to develop advanced electronic systems.

title: Intel hits 10nm goals and signals a shift away from traditional CPUs
summary: Intel announced that its 10nm manufacturing process is now exceeding expectations and will expand production to a new facility in Arizona. More significantly, the company is intensifying its pivot away from being solely a CPU company, focusing instead on data-centric products like storage, software, networking, and AI, which it sees as a much larger and more profitable market than traditional PC and server CPUs. This strategic shift aims to move beyond a "protect and defend" CPU stance towards growth in these emerging segments.

title: Opinion: Intel suggests the chip recovery is here, even as rivals are still waiting
summary: Intel Corp. is showing signs of a semiconductor market recovery, even as some of its competitors are still waiting. The company reported record revenue and raised its full-year outlook by $1.2 billion. This recovery was partly driven by a bump in data-center business from government and service-provider customers.

title: Intel Introduces Tremont Microarchitecture
summary: Intel Corporation introduced its Tremont microarchitecture in October 2019, designed to advance instruction set architecture, microarchitecture, security, and power management. This new x86 CPU architecture offers significant performance boosts for compact, low-power packages, enabling innovative form factors for client devices, IoT applications, and data center products. Tremont also features a unique 6-wide out-of-order decoder for enhanced performance.

title: Infosys loses $6.6 billion in market cap after whistleblower complaints
summary: Infosys Ltd. shares fell 16%, wiping out $6.6 billion in market capitalization, after whistleblower complaints alleged unethical practices by top executives to boost short-term revenue and profit. The complaints claim CEO Salil Parekh bypassed approvals for large deals and CFO Nilanjan Roy prevented employees from highlighting issues, leading to an independent investigation by law firm Shardul Amarchand Mangaldas.

title: U.S. Department of Labor Reaches $5 Million Settlement With Intel Corp. To Resolve Pay Discrimination Allegations
summary: The U.S. Department of Labor's Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs (OFCCP) reached a $5 million settlement with Intel Corp. to resolve allegations of systemic pay discrimination against female, African American, and Hispanic American employees. The settlement includes $3.5 million in back pay and interest, plus an allocation of at least $1.5 million for pay-equity adjustments over five years for U.S. engineering positions. Intel Corp. also agreed to proactive steps to enhance compliance with Executive Order 11246, making it one of the first technology companies to take multiple proactive steps to ensure pay equity.

title: Semiconductor stocks are poised to benefit as industry sales growth resumes in 2020
summary: Analysts are predicting a rebound in the semiconductor industry in 2020, with sales growth resuming after a "reset" year in 2019. Despite the volatility and impact from the U.S.-China trade conflict, semiconductor stocks are seen as good long-term investments. For example, Nvidia's sales are expected to decline 6% in 2019 but grow 17% in 2020.

title: Intel Appoints Sharon L. Heck as Corporate Treasurer
summary: Intel Corporation announced the appointment of Sharon L. Heck as corporate vice president, treasurer, and chief tax officer, reporting to CFO George Davis. Heck replaces Ravi Jacob, who is retiring after 35 years with the company. She joined Intel in 2018 and previously held leadership roles at PwC and Berkshire Hathaway Inc.

title: Karen Walker Joins Intel as Senior Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer
summary: Karen Walker is appointed as Intel's new Senior Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer, effective October 23, 2019. With over 20 years of experience in global technology marketing, including a previous CMO role at Cisco, Walker will be responsible for strengthening Intel's brand and driving growth strategies worldwide. Her appointment is expected to help Intel in its transformation and expansion into new market opportunities.

title: Workday CEO resigns from Intel board
summary: Aneel Bhusri, CEO of Workday, resigned from Intel's board of directors after serving since 2014. Intel clarified that Bhusri's decision was not due to any dispute or disagreement with the company.

title: Apple says Mac Pro manufacturing will remain in Austin
summary: Apple announced on Monday that it will continue manufacturing its Mac Pro computers in Austin, Texas, reversing earlier reports of a potential move to China. This decision comes after the company secured tariff exemptions from the U.S. government for key imported parts, allowing it to avoid additional costs. Apple (AAPL) emphasized its commitment to U.S. manufacturing and its significant investment in the American economy, including its operations and planned expansion in Austin.

title: Pure Storage Goes Wide On Flash: Intros Optane-Based Modules For Performance, QLC For Capacity
summary: Pure Storage expanded its all-flash storage array line with two key innovations: DirectMemory Modules for high-performance applications using Intel Optane and QLC-based FlashArray//C for capacity-optimized, more economical all-flash storage. These introductions aim to broaden Pure Storage's market reach by addressing both extreme performance needs and the demand for cost-effective, high-capacity flash solutions, making the all-flash data center more economically viable. The new offerings are designed to provide significant performance boosts and consolidate large-scale tier-two data, respectively.

title: Pure Storage introduces flash-based Tier 2 appliance
summary: Pure Storage has launched FlashArray//C, the industry's first all-flash appliance designed specifically for Tier 2 storage, aiming to make flash storage more affordable for less-critical data. This new product utilizes quad-layer cell (QLC) NAND technology to significantly reduce cost per GB compared to traditional flash or even HDD-based systems for appropriate workloads. Alongside this, Pure also introduced new DirectMemory modules powered by Intel Optane to boost performance for Tier 1 applications in existing FlashArray//X models.

title: Intel promotes two Oregon execs to EVP roles
summary: Intel has promoted two Oregon-based executives to EVP roles, enhancing their influence within the company. This move signals the added weight attributed to these leaders and their contributions to the organization. The promotions highlight Intel's recognition of talent within its Oregon operations.

title: Intel 5G Exec Cormac Conroy Departs Company
summary: Cormac Conroy, an Intel executive who led the company's 5G modem efforts, resigned from Intel just before the company announced the sale of most of its smartphone modem business to Apple. Despite this departure and the sale, Intel states that LTE and 5G connectivity remain important for its PC business and Project Athena innovation program. Conroy's resignation follows Intel's decision earlier in the year to exit the 5G smartphone modem business, a move that aligns with Apple's reported efforts to recruit talent from Intel's 5G team.

title: Ushio’s Breakthrough In The Niche Extreme Ultraviolet Lithography market
summary: Ushio (TYO:6925) has achieved a breakthrough in the Extreme Ultraviolet (EUV) lithography market by perfecting a light source for testing patterned EUV masks, a critical component for enabling next-generation semiconductor manufacturing at nodes lower than 7nm. This innovation fills a crucial gap in the industry, positioning Ushio as a sole supplier for this niche and vital technology. The CEO, Koji Naito, highlighted that testing equipment was a bottleneck for EUV and their solution will boost production efficiency and yields, with the technology expected to turn profitable in the next fiscal year.

title: Dell Latitude 5300 Laptop Review: A small business laptop with LTE
summary: The Dell Latitude 5300 is reviewed as a compact and lightweight business laptop offering optional LTE and a matte touchscreen. It features an Intel Core i5-8365U CPU, UHD Graphics 620, and up to 32 GB RAM. While praised for its security features, connectivity, and performance for office tasks, it receives criticism for heat management under load and a shorter-than-expected battery life despite its large capacity.

title: Competition Commission of India orders probe against Intel for abuse of dominant position to protect parallel importers from its discriminatory warranty policy
summary: The Competition Commission of India (CCI) has ordered an investigation against Intel Corporation for alleged abuse of its dominant market position. This probe stems from a complaint by Matrix Info Systems Pvt. Ltd. regarding Intel's discriminatory country-specific warranty policy, which allegedly restricts parallel importers and limits consumer choice in the Indian market for Boxed Micro-processors. The CCI formed a prima facie opinion that Intel's revised warranty policy, implemented in 2016, violates Sections 3 and 4 of the Indian Competition Act, 2002.

title: AMD stock rebounds from earnings disappointment with new server chip
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) shares are rising following optimism over its new second-generation Epyc 2 server chip, codenamed Rome. AMD announced that Rome offers nearly double the performance of Intel Corp.'s Xeon processor at approximately half the cost. This news comes after the company's recent earnings disappointment and could potentially impact Intel's stock.

title: Qualcomm disappointed Wall Street. It says Huawei is partly to blame
summary: Qualcomm reported disappointing financial results for its fiscal third quarter, missing revenue and guidance expectations, partially blaming Chinese tech giant Huawei. CEO Steve Mollenkopf cited Huawei's increased smartphone market share in China, spurred by the U.S. export ban, as a key factor hurting Qualcomm's product and licensing revenue. Qualcomm is also in a royalty dispute with Huawei, which contributed to the missed guidance for the upcoming quarter.

title: Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) Market In 2019
summary: This article discusses the Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) market in 2019, highlighting its healthy CAGR of 9.70% from 2019 to 2026. Key drivers include the rising demand for smartphones, technological advancements, affordability, and energy efficiency. The report also details market segmentation, key competitors like Intel and Texas Instruments, and recent developments such as acquisitions by Cyient and Intel.

title: Apple pays $1 billion for Intel unit in push for chip independence
summary: Apple Inc. has acquired the majority of Intel Corp.'s modem business for $1 billion, a strategic move to internalize smartphone chip production. This deal includes the transfer of 2,200 Intel employees and intellectual property, significantly boosting Apple's wireless technology patent portfolio to 17,000. It positions Apple to reduce reliance on external suppliers like Qualcomm and strengthen its leverage in future 5G patent licensing negotiations.

title: Apple to Buy Intel Modem Unit to Jumpstart In-House 5G Plans
summary: Apple Inc. is acquiring Intel Corp.'s cellular modem business for $1 billion to enhance its in-house 5G development capabilities. This acquisition will bring 2,200 Intel employees and 17,000 wireless patents into Apple, reducing Apple's reliance on Qualcomm for modem technology. Intel decided to sell the unit due to the high cost of supporting a single customer, Apple.

title: Apple was always going to build its own modem, and the Intel deal helps
summary: Apple has confirmed its acquisition of Intel's modem business for $1 billion, gaining 2,200 employees, patents, leases, and equipment. This move enables Apple to develop its own modems, a long-term goal given its preference for in-house chip design and its past disputes with Qualcomm. By owning its modem technology, Apple aims to optimize its future products and reduce dependence on external suppliers for critical intellectual property.

title: Intel (INTC) Q2 2019 earnings preview
summary: Intel is expected to report a decline in Q2 2019 earnings and revenue, with analysts forecasting a 13% drop in EPS and a 7.5% drop in revenue. Investors will be keenly watching the company's guidance for the third quarter and the second half of 2019 after a weaker-than-expected 2019 outlook previously hit the stock. Recent reports indicate an easing of Intel CPU shortages, which alongside new product plans for AI, 5G, and autonomous driving, and long-term revenue targets, will also be of interest.

title: Applied Materials showcases ‘new memory’ PVD equipment
summary: Applied Materials has unveiled new Physical Vapor Deposition (PVD) equipment, the Endura Clover MRAM PVD and Endura Impulse PVD, specifically designed for next-generation memory production. The company aims to sell $100 million worth of the equipment this year, believing it will enable mass production of MRAM, ReRAM, and PRAM. These PVD systems are crucial for creating the specialized thin films needed for advanced memory chips, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix among the clients involved in their development.
source: THE ELEC, Korea Electronics Industry Media
source_domain: THE ELEC, Korea Electronics Industry Media

title: Is AMD Ryzen 9 3900X good for gaming?
summary: The article confirms that the AMD Ryzen 9 3900X is excellent for gaming, especially when paired with a capable GPU, as it matches Intel's Core i9-9900K in single-core performance. It highlights the processor's 12 cores and 24 threads, making it suitable for both gaming and intensive workloads like video editing and streaming, with recommendations for GPU pairings for various display resolutions.

title: Supermicro Brings Unprecedented Performance and Configurability to the Intelligent Edge for New Security, 5G, and AI Solutions
summary: Supermicro announces new intelligent edge platforms designed for network security, 5G, and AI solutions, offering unprecedented performance and configurability. These solutions support advanced networking software, GPU acceleration, and are powered by Intel Xeon D-2100 series processors, addressing the needs of micro data centers and intelligent edge computing.

title: Can you game on the AMD Athlon 200GE?
summary: The AMD Athlon 200GE, priced under $60, offers surprisingly good integrated graphics (Vega 3) capable of playing older and lighter games at up to 60 FPS without a dedicated graphics card. While not a high-end gaming chip, it provides a solid entry point for budget PC builds, with benchmarks showing playable frame rates in titles like Dirt Rally, Tomb Raider, and Bioshock Infinite at 720p on low settings. For those seeking more power, the slightly more expensive Ryzen 3 2200G with Vega 8 graphics is suggested as an alternative.

title: Applied Materials buys Japan’s Kokusai for $2.2B to boost memory-chip presence
summary: Applied Materials Inc. has announced its acquisition of Japan's Kokusai Electric Corp. for approximately $2.2 billion to bolster its presence in the memory-chip market, particularly in Asia. This acquisition is seen as a strategic move to boost Applied Materials' revenue and market share, despite a reported downturn in demand for semiconductor equipment due to a memory chip glut. The deal faces approval from Chinese authorities, which could be a hurdle given current trade relations.

title: Intel Buys Santa Clara Based Barefoot Networks
summary: Intel Corporation has announced its purchase of Santa Clara-based Barefoot Networks to strengthen its data center and cloud offerings. Barefoot Networks, known for its programmable switches, will complement Intel's existing Ethernet products and enhance its Xeon datacenter CPUs. The acquisition aims to add deep expertise in cloud network architectures and integrate Barefoot Networks' talented team into Intel.

title: Super Micro storage server refresh homes in on NVMe flash
summary: Super Micro Computer Inc. has refreshed its storage server lineup, introducing a new BigTwin SuperServer model optimized for EDSFF NVMe flash storage and launching a 1U Petascale Systems line for high ingest rates. These new servers utilize second-generation Intel Xeon Scalable processors and support Intel Optane DC Persistent Memory, addressing the increasing demand for high-performance, dense storage at competitive prices, particularly for AI computing at the edge. The company emphasized that NVMe flash is becoming mainstream, offering significant performance advantages over older SAS and SATA technologies.

title: Microsoft, Sony, Nintendo Express Concern Over Trump Tariffs
summary: Microsoft, Sony, and Nintendo have jointly expressed concern over proposed U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods, stating that these would significantly harm the U.S. video game industry, its employees, and consumers. The companies warned that such tariffs would disrupt businesses, increase costs, depress sales, injure stakeholders, and put thousands of U.S. jobs at risk, given that over 96% of consoles imported in 2018 were made in China. They noted that a 25% price increase would make new consoles unaffordable for many families and lead to consumers paying an additional $840 million.

title: Hewlett-Packard and Fort Collins grew up together, but they've also grown apart
summary: This article details the evolving relationship between Hewlett-Packard (HP) and Fort Collins, Colorado, over four decades. While HP was once the city's largest employer and a significant community partner, its presence has diminished since the 2015 split into HP Inc. and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, leading to a reduced workforce and a less visible community role. Despite these changes, both companies continue to contribute to the city through philanthropy and job creation, and their legacy has fostered an entrepreneurial spirit in Fort Collins.

title: Flying cars, sound bubbles greet execs at Tel Aviv smart mobility confab
summary: The EcoMotion conference in Tel Aviv showcased Israel's growing leadership in smart mobility technologies, despite not being a car manufacturer. The event featured innovations such as a flying car for personal use by New Future Transportation (NFT) and sound-isolating "sound bubbles" for car interiors by Silentium Ltd., attracting major global automotive industry players. Other notable technologies included ContinUse Biometrics' accident prevention system for seniors, SoftWheel's autonomous electric platform, StoreDot's five-minute fast-charging batteries, and Aurora Labs' software for detecting and fixing car glitches.

title: Intel Announces New Chief People Officer Sandra Rivera
summary: Intel announced that Sandra Rivera is appointed as the company's new chief people officer and executive vice president, reporting to CEO Bob Swan. In this role, Rivera will lead the human resources organization and guide Intel's culture evolution as it transitions into a data-centric company. She replaces Matt Smith, who is retiring, and her previous role overseeing network infrastructure will merge with programmable solutions under Dan McNamara.

title: Intel Editorial: Intel to Acquire Barefoot Networks, Accelerating Delivery of Ethernet-Based Fabrics
summary: Intel has announced an agreement to acquire Barefoot Networks, a leader in Ethernet switch silicon and software for data centers. This acquisition will bolster Intel's focus on end-to-end cloud networking and infrastructure, integrating Barefoot Networks' expertise in programmable high-speed data paths and switch silicon development. The acquisition is expected to close in the third quarter of 2019 and aims to help Intel's Data Center Group meet the evolving needs of hyperscale cloud customers.
