title: Nova LTD : Quotes, Address, Contact
summary: Nova LTD is a leading innovator and provider of dimensional and materials metrology solutions used in semiconductor manufacturing. The company offers a comprehensive range of metrology solutions, combining high-precision hardware with advanced software modeling. Headquartered in Rehovot, Israel, Nova also has customer operations and service centers globally.

title: AMD stock jumps 10% after detailing new PC push at trade show
summary: AMD's stock surged nearly 10% after the chip maker detailed new product launches at a trade show in Taiwan. An analyst noted that AMD's new CPU represents the first time the company has taken the process-technology and performance lead from Intel in desktop CPUs. This strong performance comes as AMD begins to deliver on its promise of new products in the second half of the year.

title: DEEP FOCUS: Understanding Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) stock
summary: This article provides a deep dive into Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) stock, analyzing its market position, competition, product segments, financial trends, and cash flow situation. It highlights AMD's stock performance, its rivalry with Intel, and the anticipated impact of new product launches on its future growth and market share amidst the US-China trade war concerns.

title: Google to ARM: List of companies that severed ties with Huawei after US ban
summary: Following the US government's ban on Huawei due to national security concerns, a number of major technology companies have severed or suspended ties with the Chinese firm. This article lists companies including Google, ARM Holdings, Microsoft, Lumentum Holdings, Panasonic, Intel, Qualcomm, Xilinx, and Broadcom, as well as organizations like the Wi-Fi Alliance and SD Association, highlighting the significant impact of the ban on Huawei's global operations. The ban initially included a 90-day reprieve for existing products, but future uncertainty remains for Huawei's software and hardware capabilities.

title: Intel was losing employees. So it created an anonymous hotline to help unhappy workers
summary: Intel launched an anonymous employee hotline called "WarmLine" in 2016 to address a high employee turnover rate, particularly among women and minorities. The hotline has an 82% "save rate" and has handled over 20,000 cases, helping Intel improve retention and meet its diversity goals ahead of schedule. It also provides valuable data used to create training programs and improve leadership within the company.

title: We learn more about Huawei's Google ban from memes than recent news reports
summary: Google is withdrawing the licensing of the Android Operating System to Huawei's devices, prompting panic amongst Huawei users despite a temporary reprieve. Huawei states it is prepared with stockpiled components, while the internet has reacted with an array of memes humorously theorizing about the implications of the ban. These memes reflect the market situation, the company's difficult period, and the timeline of events leading up to the blacklisting.

title: Google, Qualcomm, Intel, and Broadcom all cut ties with Huawei
summary: Google revoked Huawei’s Android license, and American chipmakers like Intel, Qualcomm, and Broadcom announced they would stop selling components to the Chinese smartphone giant following a U.S. executive order banning American companies from supplying Huawei. This move is a major escalation in the U.S.-China trade war, potentially crippling Huawei's smartphone sales and delaying China's 5G network build. Analysts warn of potential retaliation from China against American tech companies operating within the country.

title: HPE-Cray deal brings supercomputers to enterprises for AI
summary: HPE acquired supercomputing pioneer Cray Inc. for $1.3 billion, aiming to strengthen its position in the HPC market, especially for AI workloads and lucrative government contracts. This deal is expected to increase HPE's federal business and academia footprint, as well as broaden the availability of supercomputing capabilities to corporate IT shops. The acquisition also positions the combined entity as a major player in the rapidly growing exascale computing market, despite potential antitrust questions regarding market concentration.

title: With Cray Deal, HPE Finally Enters The HPC Big Leagues
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is acquiring supercomputer maker Cray for $1.3 billion, net of Cray's cash, strategically positioning HPE in the high-performance computing (HPC) sector. This acquisition allows HPE to leverage Cray's exascale system wins and Slingshot interconnect technology, while providing Cray with the financial heft and market reach of a larger company. The deal is expected to solidify HPE's competitive standing against rivals like Dell and IBM in the HPC market.

title: After Meltdown and Spectre, meet a new set of Intel chip flaws
summary: Intel and cybersecurity researchers have unveiled four new potential chip attacks that exploit the speculative execution process, similar to Meltdown and Spectre. These flaws could allow attackers to steal sensitive data from a CPU, with examples like the ZombieLoad attack exposing browsing history. Intel states that vulnerabilities have been addressed in recent processors or can be mended via microcode and operating system updates.

title: Lenovo Unveils Preview of the World’s First Foldable PC in ThinkPad X1 Family
summary: Lenovo has unveiled a preview of the world's first foldable PC, joining the premium ThinkPad X1 family. This innovative device, powered by Intel with Windows and featuring an LG Display® OLED 2K screen, offers unprecedented portability without compromising productivity. The foldable PC is designed for highly mobile professionals, transforming from a compact, book-like form to a full-screen laptop or tablet, with full product details and availability expected in 2020.

title: Release! CORSAIR ONE i140/i160, small size of 12L
summary: Lynx International Inc. has launched the CORSAIR ONE i140 and CORSAIR ONE i160 compact gaming desktop PCs in Japan. These computers feature a small 12L body while packing high-spec components like Intel Core processors and NVIDIA GeForce RTX GPUs, alongside advanced cooling solutions for stable operation. The CORSAIR ONE i140 is priced at 399,800 JPY and the i160 at 479,800 JPY, both released on May 11, 2019.

title: Opinion: AMD and Cray seek to develop fastest supercomputer in the world
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and Cray Inc. have secured a $600 million contract from the U.S. Department of Energy to develop Frontier, which is expected to be the world's fastest supercomputer. This deal marks an ambitious revival of their partnership, potentially boosting AMD's influence in high-performance computing and data-center chips. Cray previously used AMD CPUs but switched to Intel, only to renew ties after AMD's Epyc data-center processors launched last year.

title: Investors Sue to Block Mellanox-Nvidia Deal, Report Says
summary: A shareholder of Mellanox Technologies Ltd. has filed a class-action lawsuit to block the company's acquisition by Nvidia Corp. for $6.9 billion. The suit alleges that Mellanox failed to provide sufficient information to the SEC regarding Nvidia's bid and criticized JP Morgan's analysis of the deal. The transaction, announced in March, is expected to be completed later this year.

title: AMD's 50th Anniversary Reminds Us Why The Company Matters
summary: This article reflects on AMD's 50th anniversary, highlighting its resilience, innovation, and historical milestones under various leaders, currently Lisa Su. The author, a long-time observer of AMD, discusses the company's evolution from its founding in 1969 to its current focus on high-performance computing, emphasizing its commitment to execution and a people-centric culture. The piece celebrates AMD's ability to consistently bounce back from challenges and its vision for future technological innovation.

title: AMD Ryzen 7 2700X Gold Edition: Should you buy the new CPU?
summary: The AMD Ryzen 7 2700X Gold Edition is a special release to celebrate AMD's 50th anniversary. It is identical in hardware to the regular Ryzen 7 2700X but includes keepsakes like Dr. Lisa Su's signature on the CPU lid, a commemorative t-shirt, and an autographed sticker. The article suggests that while the price is the same as the regular version, it's primarily for dedicated AMD fans who value the commemorative items, as there's no performance benefit.

title: Western Digital Stock Turns Bearish Ahead of Possible Golden Cross
summary: Western Digital's stock fell over 2% after reporting worse-than-expected Q3 earnings, with revenue falling 27% and EPS at 17 cents. Baird analysts downgraded the stock due to deteriorating NAND fundamentals, a sentiment supported by Intel's weak earnings report suggesting continued double-digit NAND price declines. Technical indicators also suggest further downside risk for WDC shares, despite a competitor, Seagate, beating earnings estimates.

title: Ahead of Apple Earnings, Investors Rush Into Tech ETFs
summary: Ahead of a significant week for technology earnings, investors are increasingly pouring money into tech-focused ETFs like XLK, QQQ, and VGT. Data from Bank of America Merrill Lynch, citing EPFR Global, indicates that tech stocks saw $1.3 billion in inflows last week, contrasting with overall U.S. equities experiencing net outflows. This surge in interest is partly attributed to anticipated reports from major tech companies, including Apple Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL), a top component in these funds.

title: Intel CEO Bob Swan on the company's disappointing Q1 earnings
summary: Intel CEO Bob Swan discussed the company's disappointing Q1 earnings and a projected drop in revenue during an appearance on "Squawk on the Street." He also addressed pressure from China affecting the company's performance. The discussion provides insight into the challenges Intel was facing at the time.

title: The Information Technology Industry: Comparing the cultures of Adobe, Dell, HP, IBM and Intel
summary: This article compares the company cultures of Adobe, Dell, HP, IBM, and Intel across various aspects, including overall culture, CEO and leadership, compensation, perks and benefits, and diversity, based on anonymous employee feedback. Adobe consistently emerges as the top-rated company in nearly all categories. The analysis highlights employee perceptions of strengths and weaknesses within each organization.

title: Intel roadmaps leak showing company's plans through 2021 - CPU - News
summary: Purported Intel mobile and desktop processor roadmaps have leaked, reportedly from a Dell presentation, detailing plans through Q4 2021. The roadmaps show the introduction of Comet Lake H series processors (14nm) and Ice Lake U (10nm) for mobile, and similar 14nm Comet Lake H and speculative 10nm Rocket Lake processors for desktops, indicating a slower transition to 10nm than previously anticipated by some.

title: How to Prepare For a Possible Decline in Chip ETFs
summary: This article discusses the semiconductor market, noting its significant year-to-date rally but also highlighting warnings from some analysts about overbought conditions. It suggests that investors could capitalize on a potential downturn using the Direxion Daily Semiconductor Bear 3X ETF (SOXS). The piece also explores diverging opinions on the sector's future, considering factors like 5G technology and upcoming earnings reports.

title: Why Apple was so upset with Qualcomm — and why it finally had to give in
summary: Apple and Qualcomm settled a bitter legal battle over royalties and licensing fees, leading Apple to once again buy Qualcomm chips. The dispute centered on Qualcomm's patent licensing model, which Apple viewed as abusive due to its "no license, no chips" policy and pricing based on the total device cost. Despite Apple's strong objections and Qualcomm's history of antitrust issues, Apple ultimately settled because Qualcomm remains the leader in wireless technology, especially with the rollout of 5G networks, leaving Apple with few alternatives after Intel's exit from the 5G chip market.

title: Qualcomm aims to take on Nvidia, Intel with new AI chips
summary: Qualcomm is entering the artificial intelligence chip market with its new Cloud AI 100 chip, aiming to compete with Nvidia and Intel. The company plans to target smaller, simpler data centers with power-efficient chips designed for "inference" tasks, leveraging its expertise from mobile phone chip development. Testing with partners like Microsoft is expected to begin later this year, with mass production in 2020.

title: Qualcomm Announces New AI Chip for Cloud Data Center Servers
summary: Qualcomm Inc., a leader in smartphone technology, is entering the crowded market for AI chips used in cloud data centers. The company plans to leverage its mobile expertise and advanced manufacturing to deliver power-efficient products, aiming for a share of a market projected to reach $17 billion by 2025. This move positions Qualcomm to compete with established players like Intel, Nvidia, and cloud providers already developing AI components.

title: Intel and Google Cloud Announce Strategic Partnership to Accelerate Hybrid Cloud
summary: Intel and Google Cloud announced a strategic partnership to accelerate hybrid cloud adoption for enterprise customers. They will collaborate on Anthos, a new reference design based on the 2nd-Generation Intel Xeon Scalable processor and an optimized Kubernetes software stack, to simplify application deployment across on-premise and cloud environments. This initiative aims to provide customers with increased workload portability and optimized solutions for their data-centric needs.

title: Decoding the Latest Generation of Intel CPUs
summary: This article explains the naming scheme for Intel's 2nd-Gen Xeon CPUs, code-named "Cascade Lake," which were released on April 2, 2019. It details how to decode the processor level (Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum), generation, SKU, and special features based on the CPU's alphanumeric code. The article also highlights key characteristics and target markets for each CPU series, including support for Optane DC Persistent Memory in Gold and Platinum models.

title: Intel hires new CFO from mobile chip rival Qualcomm
summary: Intel has hired George Davis, former CFO at Qualcomm and Applied Materials, as its new chief financial officer. This appointment fills a position that had been vacant since January at the U.S.'s largest chipmaker.

title: Intel to cut more than 100 jobs from headquarters
summary: Intel is carrying out its latest round of layoffs, affecting over 100 jobs at its Santa Clara headquarters. The cuts will specifically impact IT departments across four Silicon Valley campuses. This follows previous job reductions by Intel and other tech companies in the Bay Area.

title: Intel Capital expands Israel team, announces new $117m global investments
summary: Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of Intel Corp., is expanding its Israel team and announced $117 million in new global investments, including into Israeli startup ProteanTecs. This expansion follows Intel Capital's $120 million investment in 14 Israeli ventures in 2018. The move underscores Intel's commitment to Israeli innovation and its transition to a data-centric company.

title: Intel Driving Data-Centric World with New 10nm Intel Agilex FPGA Family
summary: Intel announced its new Intel® Agilex™ FPGA family, built on 10nm process technology, to address evolving data-centric business challenges across embedded, network, and data center markets. These FPGAs offer customized solutions with significant improvements in performance and power efficiency for diverse workloads from the edge to the cloud. Key innovations include support for Compute Express Link, 2nd-Generation HyperFlex Architecture, hardened BFLOAT16, PCIe Gen 5, and advanced memory support.

title: Houston company bringing AI to health care raises $11.9M from Intel, other VC funds
summary: Medical Informatics Corp., a Houston-based company specializing in AI for healthcare, has raised $11.9 million in Series A venture capital funding, with contributions from Intel Capital and TMC Ventures. The funding will accelerate the company's ability to expand into more hospitals and develop new clinical applications for its FDA-cleared product, Sickbay. Sickbay addresses challenges in collecting and utilizing patient data to detect symptoms faster, as demonstrated by its use at Texas Children's Hospital to predict heart issues in infants.

title: NVIDIA Is A Data Center Company Now
summary: NVIDIA's acquisition of Mellanox for $6.9 billion signifies its strategic shift from primarily a GPU company to a full-fledged data center company. This move leverages NVIDIA's success in High-Performance Compute (HPC) and AI with GPUs, integrating Mellanox's data center networking expertise to address the growing demands of data science and hyperscale workloads. The article highlights how NVIDIA is expanding its ecosystem to support diverse data center needs, from specialized accelerators to broader infrastructure solutions.

title: How a Dutch company's technology is likely driving Intel's expansion
summary: ASML's Extreme Ultraviolet lithography technology is ready for high-volume production, which is not only driving ASML's own local office expansion but also Intel's. This technology is critical for manufacturing smaller computer chips and is considered key for Intel's chip generations following 10-nanometer. The article indirectly connects ASML's technological advancements to Intel's expansion strategies.

title: Mellanox to stay independent within Nvidia with Waldman at its head, CEO says
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang announced that Mellanox Technologies Ltd., following its $6.9 billion acquisition by Nvidia, will operate as an independent unit and retain all employees, with plans to grow the workforce in Israel. Mellanox founder and CEO Eyal Waldman will continue to lead the unit. This acquisition marks Nvidia's largest to date, aimed at expanding its reach into data centers crucial for AI and machine learning.

title: Apple rolls out first update to iMac desktop in almost two years
summary: Apple Inc. has introduced the first update to its iMac all-in-one desktop computer since mid-2017, ahead of a major event on March 25. The new iMacs feature speedier Intel processors and AMD graphics engines, with the 4K 21.5-inch models being up to 60 percent faster and the 5K 27-inch versions up to 2.4 times faster. This update follows the recent launch of new iPad Air and iPad mini models, as Apple continues its hardware refreshments.

title: Micron Introduces Client 2200 NVMe SSDs
summary: Micron Technology, Inc. has announced the expansion of its client NVMe SSD lineup with the introduction of the Micron 2200 PCIe NVMe SSD. This new SSD targets OEMs seeking NVMe storage solutions, leveraging 3D TLC NAND and an internally designed ASIC drive controller and firmware in an M.2 form factor. The Micron 2200 offers capacities up to 1TB and boasts read speeds of up to 3GB/s and 240K IOPS, providing improved performance, lower latency, and reduced power consumption compared to traditional spinning disks and SATA SSDs.

title: Nearly Half of Israel's Largest Exporters Are Foreign-Owned
summary: Nearly half of Israel's 20 largest exporters, each with over $1 billion in annual sales, are foreign-owned, according to Calcalist data. Five are U.S.-owned, two European-owned, and one each by Chinese and Mexican companies. This trend was underscored by Nvidia's $6.9 billion acquisition of Israeli chipmaker Mellanox Technologies Ltd.

title: Nvidia outbids Intel to buy Israel's Mellanox in data centre push
summary: Nvidia Corp has agreed to acquire Israeli chip designer Mellanox Technologies Ltd for $6.8 billion, outbidding rival Intel. This acquisition aims to boost Nvidia's data center and artificial intelligence business, helping it integrate servers into larger computing systems and increasing its market share in the growing data center segment. The deal will bolster Nvidia against Intel and may face regulatory hurdles in China.

title: Nvidia to buy Mellanox for $6.9 billion as it pushes into data centers
summary: Nvidia has agreed to acquire chipmaker Mellanox Technologies Ltd. for $6.9 billion, a move aimed at bolstering its presence in the expanding data center market. The acquisition is Nvidia's largest ever and seeks to accelerate its successful initiatives in providing graphics chips for artificial intelligence work in data centers. The deal signals a potential resumption of consolidation within the semiconductor industry, despite concerns about regulatory approvals amid the U.S.-China trade war.

title: US gaming firm Nvidia to buy Israeli chip maker Mellanox for $6.9 billion
summary: US gaming and computer graphics giant Nvidia Corp. is set to acquire Israeli chip maker Mellanox Technologies Ltd. for $6.9 billion in cash. This deal marks the second-largest tech acquisition in Israel's history and will enhance Nvidia's capabilities in high-speed data center solutions. Mellanox, founded in 1999, specializes in servers and storage switching solutions and has seen significant demand for its products.

title: Nvidia to make largest acquisition in its history with $6.9 billion deal for Mellanox
Nvidia acquires Mellanox against growing AI, data competition
summary: Nvidia has acquired Mellanox Technologies Ltd. for $6.9 billion to strengthen its position in the rapidly growing and competitive market for AI and data-intensive computing platforms. This merger aims to bolster their combined capabilities against new rivals like Amazon and Cray, as both companies already have a significant presence in high-performance computing (HPC) with their integrated technologies. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to address increasing competitive challenges in the HPC market.

title: STMicroelectronics Launches Multicore MPU Series
summary: STMicroelectronics has launched the STM32MP1, a new multicore microprocessor series that combines Arm Cortex-A and Cortex-M cores with a GPU for compute and graphics support and power-efficient real-time control. This MPU is designed for developers migrating from microcontrollers to microprocessors, targeting industrial, consumer, smart home, and health applications. ST's OpenSTLinux distribution and enhanced STM32Cube tools aim to accelerate development, with the chips priced from $4.84 in 10,000-unit orders.

title: Cyber Security Market to cross USD 300 billion by 2024
summary: The global Cyber Security Market is projected to exceed $300 billion by 2024, growing from over $120 billion, driven by the increasing need to mitigate security risks as enterprises adopt cloud platforms and mobile devices. Organizations reported a significant rise in cybersecurity spending and an increase in cyber-attacks on mobile devices, fueling demand for security solutions. The market will see strong growth across various sectors including large enterprises, SMEs, transportation, and IT & telecom, with specific growth predicted for IAAM and infrastructure protection segments.

title: ARM Goes To War In The Datacenter With “Ares” Designs
summary: ARM is launching its "Ares" Neoverse designs (N1) for datacenters, promising significant performance gains, exceeding their initial 30% annual improvement target. These new designs feature a mesh topology, enhanced power efficiency, and a deep, reconfigurable pipeline, aiming to challenge Intel Xeon and other architectures in the server market. ARM anticipates these cores will scale from edge devices to high-end datacenters, offering competitive power consumption and performance metrics.

title: Machine learning is the biggest disruptive tech: AMD CTO Mark Papermaster
summary: AMD CTO Mark Papermaster discusses the significance of the company's new 7nm chips in meeting the insatiable demand for computational power, especially in data centers and mobile devices. He highlights machine learning as the biggest disruptive technology, noting its potential to leverage data and predict results, while also addressing concerns about AI and robotics replacing human jobs. Papermaster also touches on GPU usage in the crypto space, indicating AMD's focus on broader GPU markets in gaming, servers, and blockchain.

title: Intel Corp takes over Hyderabad-based Ineda Systems
summary: US-based Intel Corporation has acquired Hyderabad-based startup Ineda Systems, a fabless semi-conductor company. The acquisition primarily aims to secure Ineda's 100 engineers for their expertise in graphics. Ineda Systems, founded by Dasaradha Gude, specializes in AI, autonomous driving, and IoT, having designed Dhanush chips and raised $60 million.

title: Walmart and DreamWorks Animation Invite Fans to Step Into the Hidden World of How to Train Your Dragon Through New Virtual Reality Experience
summary: Walmart and DreamWorks Animation are launching an exclusive, first-of-its-kind immersive virtual reality experience tied to the upcoming film "How to Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World." This V-commerce activation, powered by HP, Intel, and Positron, will tour select Walmart parking lots, offering fans an interactive journey into the movie's world and access to exclusive merchandise. The initiative, led by Walmart's Spatial& startup, aims to transform merchandising and retail through cutting-edge technology and storytelling.

title: Intel expansion may result in nearly 1750 new jobs in Hillsboro
summary: Intel's proposed expansion at Ronler Acres in Hillsboro could lead to nearly 1,750 new jobs. While the company has not released full details, its permit application to the city of Hillsboro provided more insight into the project. This expansion continues Intel's growth in the region, following previous announcements of fab expansions in Oregon and globally.

title: Aehr launches FOX-CP wafer-level test & reliability screening system
summary: Aehr Test Systems has launched the FOX-CP, a new low-cost single-wafer test and reliability verification system designed for logic, memory, and photonic devices. This system, part of the FOX-P product family, is optimized for shorter test times, multiple touchdowns, and includes features like 2048 Universal Channels, making it suitable for silicon photonics and VCSEL arrays. The FOX-CP helps reduce test costs by identifying failing die before packaging and is available for order and shipment.

title: Global Smart Learning Systems Market 2019-2025 Enhancement
summary: The Global Smart Learning Systems Market is projected to grow between 2019 and 2025, driven by technological enhancements, recent trends, and opportunities. Key market players include Adobe Systems Inc., Smart Technologies, Cisco Systems, and Intel Corporation. The report highlights growth factors such as increased demand for collaborative learning, innovative schools, and e-learning importance, with the Asia Pacific region anticipated to experience the fastest growth.

title: Intel Drone Light Show and Intel True View Technology Enhance Pepsi Super Bowl LIII Halftime Show and Super Bowl LIII Viewing Experience
summary: Intel Corporation partnered with the NFL for Super Bowl LIII, showcasing a live drone light show during the Halftime Show with 150 enhanced Intel Shooting Star drones. Additionally, Intel True View technology, installed in 13 NFL stadiums, provided immersive 3D replays of game highlights for fans. These technologies aimed to enhance the viewing experience both at the stadium and for those watching at home by offering unique perspectives and entertainment.

title: Intel Now Has 20 Israeli Vice Presidents
summary: Intel has appointed seven new Israeli vice presidents, bringing the total to 20 out of 150 globally. This highlights Israel's significant role in Intel's R&D and operations, with 12% of all Intel patents from 2015-2018 originating in the country. Intel's extensive investments and acquisitions in Israel, totaling $35 billion, further underscore its commitment to the region.

title: Opinion: With Intel CEO choice, the bean counters are in charge of Silicon Valley’s most storied tech company
summary: Intel Corp.'s decision to appoint former CFO Bob Swan as permanent CEO is met with skepticism from Wall Street and Silicon Valley. Swan, who lacks engineering credentials unlike many past leaders, has been serving as interim chief executive since June. His appointment, alongside Chairman Andy Bryant, who is also a former CFO, signifies a shift towards financial leadership at the deeply technical company.

title: Intel's new CEO is facing the same old challenges
summary: Robert "Bob" Swan has been appointed as Intel's CEO at a critical time, inheriting significant challenges in manufacturing, innovation, and navigating a potentially declining PC market and slowing data center growth. Despite strong financial results in 2018, Intel faces intense competition from rivals like Samsung, TSMC, AMD, and ARM licensees, alongside the technical hurdle of pushing past the limits of Moore's Law. Swan, with a finance background, will need to demonstrate his ability to adapt Intel's strategy to these evolving industry dynamics.

title: Intel confirms Bob Swan is company’s new permanent CEO
summary: Intel has officially appointed Robert ‘Bob’ Swan as its permanent CEO after he served several months in an interim capacity following the resignation of Brian Krzanich. Swan, previously Intel's CFO, will now lead the company through its transformation into new market opportunities such as data centers, AI, and autonomous driving. Intel reported strong 2018 financial results with $70.8bn in revenues and a $21.1bn profit, and is forecasting another record year under Swan's leadership.

title: AI is here to stay. These women want to make sure Intel does it right.
summary: This article highlights four women at Intel, including Anna Bethke, Huma Abidi, Yinyin Liu, and Jennifer Myers, who are working to shape Intel's growing AI business. Their goal is to find real-world applications for artificial intelligence as Intel aims to increase its AI business revenue from $1 billion to $10 billion by 2022. The piece underscores the significance of their roles in the future of AI within the company.

title: Intel names permanent CEO, said to benefit firm’s Israel operations
summary: Intel has named Robert Swan as its permanent CEO. This appointment is expected to benefit the firm's operations in Israel due to Swan's familiarity with its activities there. Intel has significant investments and operations in Israel, including manufacturing and R&D centers, and recently announced an $11 billion investment for a new plant in Kiryat Gat.

title: Intel names Robert Swan as permanent CEO
summary: Intel has named Robert Swan as its permanent CEO, ending a seven-month search following the ouster of Brian Krzanich. Swan, who was previously interim CEO and CFO, initially expressed disinterest in the role but accepted after internal developments. His appointment signals Intel's continued focus on diversifying its portfolio beyond PC-centric revenue towards data-centric opportunities.

title: Intel Names Robert Swan CEO
summary: Intel Corporation has named Robert (Bob) Swan as its chief executive officer, effective January 31, 2019. Swan, who served as interim CEO for seven months and CFO since 2016, is the seventh CEO in Intel's history and has also been elected to the company's board of directors. Todd Underwood will assume the role of interim chief financial officer as Intel searches for a permanent CFO.

title: Robert Swan named Intel CEO
summary: Robert Swan, who had been serving as Intel's interim CEO for six months, has been appointed as the permanent CEO. Swan, the seventh CEO in Intel's history, was previously the company's CFO and will also join its board of directors. His appointment comes at a challenging time for Intel, as the company has faced struggles in adapting to a changing market and lost its top chipmaker title to Samsung.

title: Intel, Israel sign multi-billion dollar reciprocal purchase agreement
summary: Intel and the Israeli government have signed a multi-billion dollar reciprocal purchase agreement. As part of this deal, Intel will receive a grant of approximately $1 billion from the Israeli government to support its investment plan. This agreement highlights a significant economic partnership between the technology giant and the nation of Israel.

title: China weakness spreads far and wide, from Caterpillar to Nvidia
summary: Major US and European companies like Caterpillar, Nvidia, and Intel are reporting significant impacts from the slowing demand in China across various sectors, from industrial machinery and technology to automotive parts. While many industries are feeling the pinch, luxury goods and some consumer brands like Tiffany & Co. and Starbucks are, for now, experiencing continued growth, creating a mixed economic picture. The emerging trend suggests a broadening slowdown in China is affecting a diverse range of goods and services.

title: January 2019 Newsletter: 4 Charts Every Investor Should Know
summary: This January 2019 newsletter by Lyn Alden discusses major market drivers for 2019, highlighting high asset valuations and global leverage. It presents four key charts investors should know: corporate debt, central bank balance sheets, net worth to income, and the U.S. federal deficit and debt to GDP, to help balance risk and reward. The article also provides detailed portfolio updates and investment strategy recommendations focusing on dividends and defensive positioning.

title: Zero Latency partners with Microsoft, HP and Intel for next-gen free-roam VR
summary: Zero Latency, a pioneer in free-roam multiplayer virtual reality (VR) entertainment, has partnered with Microsoft, HP, and Intel to develop its next-generation VR platform. This collaboration involves the provision of software, hardware, and marketing assistance to enhance Zero Latency's global reach. The initiative aims to expand VR experiences through location-based entertainment, leveraging technology such as mixed reality headsets, cloud services, and Intel NUC VR platforms.

title: Intel misses on revenue and gives weak guidance — stock falls after hours
summary: Intel's stock fell sharply after the company reported lower-than-expected revenue for fiscal fourth-quarter 2018 and issued weak guidance for 2019. The company missed analyst estimates on Q4 revenue and Q1 2019 earnings and revenue forecasts. Investors are also keenly awaiting an update on Intel's search for a permanent CEO, seven months after Brian Krzanich's departure.

title: Intel showcases new 3D camera for robot, drone navigation sired by Haifa team
summary: Intel Corp. has launched the Intel RealSense Tracking Camera T265, a new 3D camera developed by its R&D team in Haifa. This camera enables robots and drones to navigate without external sensors or GPS, using an "inside-out tracking" system and a vision processing unit for on-board data processing. The T265, priced at $199, is designed for applications like robotics, drones, and augmented/virtual reality, offering a low-power solution for precise tracking in various environments.

title: Intel (INTC) Q4 2018 earnings report
summary: Intel reported mixed results for its fourth quarter of 2018, with earnings per share beating analyst estimates but revenue falling short. The stock dropped in after-hours trading, and the company issued a cautious outlook for 2019, citing intensifying trade concerns and other market dynamics. Despite the revenue miss, Intel's CFO highlighted record-breaking projections for the coming year driven by data growth.

title: Apple concedes that Qualcomm was the only 4G ready chip source
summary: Apple Inc. has conceded in court that Qualcomm Inc. was its sole viable supplier for 4G-ready chips during the mobile industry's transition, according to testimony by Apple's director of cellular systems architecture, Matthias Sauer. This admission is crucial for Qualcomm's defense against antitrust allegations by the US Federal Trade Commission, which accuses Qualcomm of using its market dominance to enforce inflated patent licensing fees. Apple's COO Jeff Williams also testified that Qualcomm cut off their chip supply, forcing Apple to move all business to Intel.

title: Intel Editorial: Intel Achieves Gender Pay Equity Globally
summary: Intel announced it has achieved global gender pay equity across its worldwide workforce, including stock-based compensation in its analysis. The company defines pay equity as closing the gap in average pay between employees of different genders or races/ethnicities in similar roles, after accounting for legitimate business factors. This milestone is part of Intel's broader commitment to diversity and inclusion, with ongoing efforts to maintain pay equity and improve representation for women and minorities.

title: C3.ai Expands Across Europe as Featured in L'Informaticien
summary: C3.ai CEO Thomas M. Siebel discussed the company's expansion across Europe and its focus on developing predictive analytics AI-based applications for industrial use cases in an interview with French computer science magazine L’Informaticien. The article highlights C3.ai's current customers and partners and its future plans to release a simplified software suite for smaller European organizations, making its applications accessible via a software store. Siebel also emphasized the need for governmental regulation of AI to prevent unintended negative consequences.

title: Israeli Johny Srouji reportedly in running for Intel CEO
summary: Johny Srouji, an Arab Israeli and senior VP of hardware technologies at Apple, is reportedly a candidate for the CEO position at Intel Corp. Srouji previously worked for Intel and was instrumental in establishing Apple's R&D center in Israel, overseeing the development of silicon and hardware technologies. This comes after Intel's former CEO, Brian Krzanich, resigned, and the company is reportedly considering a "non-traditional" candidate from outside.

title: NVIDIA Resets The Self-Driving Bar Again With AutoPilot Supporting 'Level 2+'
summary: NVIDIA announced its DRIVE AutoPilot system at CES 2019, which it describes as the "world's first commercially available Level 2+ automated driving system" that will enable supervised self-driving vehicles by 2020. The company also revealed that Mercedes-Benz has chosen NVIDIA as its AI partner for developing next-generation vehicles. Additionally, NVIDIA launched the new GeForce RTX 2060 GPU and announced over 40 new gaming laptops featuring GeForce RTX GPUs.

title: Apple’s COO Says Qualcomm Refused to Provide Chips for 2018 Phones
summary: Apple's COO Jeff Williams testified that Qualcomm refused to provide cellular modems for 2018 iPhones after Apple sued the chipmaker in 2017. This refusal forced Apple to exclusively use Intel-made modems in its latest iPhone models. Williams attempted to negotiate with Qualcomm, but the company declined to supply the chips.

title: Intel's Aicha Evans leaves for CEO role at Zoox
summary: Aicha Evans, Intel's chief strategy officer, has left the company to become the CEO of autonomous vehicle startup Zoox. This move follows her previous role in overseeing Intel's strategic direction.

title: Autonomous Vehicle Startup Zoox Names Intel Executive Aicha Evans as CEO
summary: Autonomous vehicle startup Zoox Inc. has appointed Intel executive Aicha Evans as its new CEO, replacing the ousted founder. Ms. Evans, previously chief strategy officer at Intel, brings 12 years of experience from various roles, including overseeing mobile phone chip sales and long-term strategy for autonomous vehicles. Her appointment aims to provide seasoned management as Zoox continues its mission to "reinvent the car."

title: Apple considered Samsung, MediaTek to supply 5G modems for 2019 iPhones
summary: Apple Inc. considered Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and MediaTek Inc, alongside current vendor Intel Corp, to supply 5G modem chips for 2019 iPhones, according to testimony from an Apple executive at a Qualcomm trial. This move highlights Apple's long-standing effort to diversify its modem chip suppliers and reduce its reliance on a single vendor like Qualcomm. The testimony also revealed Apple's "Project Antique" to secure a second modem supplier and the negative impact of Apple's lawsuit against Qualcomm on their business relationship.

title: Apple considered Samsung, MediaTek to supply 5G modems for 2019 iPhones
summary: Apple Inc. considered Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and MediaTek Inc, in addition to existing vendor Intel Corp, to supply 5G modem chips for its 2019 iPhones, according to testimony from an Apple executive. Historically, Apple sourced these chips from Qualcomm before splitting business between Intel and Qualcomm, and later moving solely to Intel for its newest phones in 2018. This consideration came out during the trial between Qualcomm Inc. and the U.S. Federal Trade Commission.

title: Ambarella's CV25 camera SoC with CVflow computer vision processing | Security News
summary: Ambarella has unveiled the CV25 camera System-on-Chip (SoC), part of its CVflow family, designed for next-generation intelligent solutions. This SoC integrates advanced image processing, high-resolution video encoding, and CVflow computer vision processing into a low-power design. The CV25 enables AI at the edge for applications like home monitoring, surveillance, and automotive solutions, supporting features such as facial recognition and driver monitoring.

title: Opinion: AMD’s Lisa Su takes center stage at CES, taking aim at Intel and Nvidia
summary: During her CES keynote, AMD CEO Lisa Su declared the company's intention to challenge and potentially surpass rivals Intel and Nvidia. She outlined AMD's 2019 strategies for computers, servers, and videogames, showcasing early performance of its 7-nanometer hardware. Su emphasized that the company's significant investments are now yielding results and are expected to continue doing so throughout 2019.

title: Intel's Mobileye is taking its ready-to-go self-driving technology to China to solve public-transit problems
summary: Intel's Mobileye is partnering with the Beijing Public Transport Corporation (BPTC) to bring autonomous mobility solutions to Beijing residents, with an initial deployment expected in 2022. Mobileye, known for providing a one-stop solution for autonomous technology including hardware, software, and safety protocols, emphasizes its flexible business model as an autonomy consultant. The partnership highlights Mobileye's "AV Kit" and "Responsibility Sensitive Safety" (RSS) model, aiming to establish new industry standards for public transportation.

title: Intel and Warner Bros. Immersive CES Experience Previews Entertainment’s Future in Autonomous Vehicles
summary: Intel and Warner Bros. unveiled a concept car at CES 2019 demonstrating immersive in-car entertainment for autonomous vehicles. The BMW X5, retrofitted with advanced technology, offers a virtual ride through Gotham City, moderated by Batman's butler Alfred. This collaboration aims to showcase the potential of the "Passenger Economy" by transforming commuting time into an entertainment experience while also integrating safety features like Intel's Responsibility-Sensitive Safety (RSS) framework.

title: Motherboard supports up to 300-watt Intel Core X-series processors
summary: Super Micro Computer, Inc. showcased its latest desktop, gaming, and workstation solutions at CES 2019. This includes the SuperO C9Z390-PGW, known for high overclocking performance, and the C9X299-PG300, which supports up to 300-watt Intel Core X-series processors. The company also presented the X11SPA-T workstation platform and several other motherboards for mainstream gamers.

title: Opinion: AMD’s Lisa Su takes center stage at CES, taking aim at Intel and Nvidia
German court rules Apple infringed Qualcomm patent| Gulf Times
summary: A German court ruled that Apple infringed a Qualcomm hardware patent, potentially banning sales of some iPhone models (7 through X) in Germany. Qualcomm must post a €668.4mn bond to enforce the order, which targets iPhones containing a specific Qorvo component that violates Qualcomm's envelope tracking patent. This ruling is part of a broader global legal battle between the two tech giants over patent infringement and alleged anti-competitive practices.

title: Huge Geodesic Dome is World’s Largest 360-Degree Movie Set
summary: Intel Studios has unveiled the world's largest immersive media hub, a 10,000-square-foot geodesic dome in Los Angeles equipped with 96 high-resolution 5K cameras. This technology enables "volumetric capture," allowing moviemakers to create 360-degree, 3D virtual environments and offering new forms of visual storytelling and interactive media experiences. The studio processes over 1 terabyte of data every 10 seconds and is working on two Hollywood virtual reality productions for release in early 2019.

title: How does NetApp’s MAX Data use Storage-Class Memory? Let’s find out
summary: This article delves into NetApp's MAX Data solution and its utilization of server-based Storage-Class Memory (SCM) to reduce data access latency. It explains how MAX Data integrates SCM with NetApp storage arrays, comparing SCM's performance to DRAM and flash memory. The article also covers MAX Data's architecture, data protection, server requirements, and filesystem, highlighting its benefits for IO-bound applications.

title: IonQ Quantum Computer Delivers More Processing Power Than Google's
summary: IonQ has announced a new trapped ion quantum computer with 79 processing qubits, claiming it will surpass Google's 72-qubit quantum computer in both qubit count and overall processing performance. The IonQ computer has already set a world record for a particular problem using the Bernstein-Vazirani Algorithm, achieving a 73% success rate, significantly higher than any other quantum computer. IonQ plans to make its trapped-ion quantum computers available to researchers in 2019 for various applications.

title: 10 Things You Didn’t Know about Micron Technology CEO Sanjay Mehrotra
summary: This article highlights 10 interesting facts about Sanjay Mehrotra, the President and CEO of Micron Technology. It covers his education, career trajectory including co-founding SanDisk, his patent holdings, and his leadership through market challenges like tariffs affecting Micron Technology.

title: Intel and ESL sign 3-year, $100 million deal, adding heft to booming esports market
summary: Intel and esports company ESL have extended their long-standing partnership with a three-year, $100 million deal aimed at boosting the global profile of electronic sports. Intel will provide advanced technology, including high-powered computer processors and 5G, for major esports events through 2021 and collaborate with ESL to create new events. This investment deepens Intel's involvement in the rapidly growing esports industry, which is projected to reach $1.4 billion by 2020.

title: These are the best tech companies to work for in India
summary: A new study by jobs site Indeed identifies the top tech companies to work for in India, revealing that multinational corporations are preferred over homegrown firms. Adobe, Nvidia, and Microsoft lead the list, emphasizing job seekers' desire for clear progression structures and positive workplace environments. The article details the top 15 companies, highlighting their employee ratings, key facts, and offices in India.

title: New Intel Architectures and Technologies Target Expanded Market Opportunities
summary: Intel unveiled new architectures and technologies at its Architecture Day, including the industry's first 3D logic chip packaging ("Foveros"), the "Sunny Cove" CPU microarchitecture, and Gen11 integrated graphics. These innovations are aimed at expanding market opportunities, particularly in data-intensive workloads for PCs, data centers, AI, and autonomous vehicles, with an estimated addressable market of over $300 billion by 2022. The company also introduced the "One API" software project and updates on memory/storage technologies, emphasizing a diverse computing era.

title: Adobe Named The Best Tech Company to Work For in India List
summary: Adobe has been named the top tech company to work for in India in a 2018 report by job search portal Indeed, followed by Nvidia and Microsoft. The report highlights that Indian job seekers prefer large international firms for career advancement and work exposure in the technology sector. Multinational corporations dominated the list, reinforcing the demand for such companies in India's job market.

title: China block of iPhone sales, memory outlook don’t hurt chip stocks
summary: Chip-related stocks saw a rebound despite news of China blocking sales of older iPhone models due to Qualcomm patent violations and ongoing tariff concerns. The PHLX Semiconductor Index outperformed broader market indexes, suggesting that investors are not significantly swayed by these developments regarding the chip sector's outlook. This performance indicates a recovery for chip stocks which had previously experienced selloffs throughout the year.

title: Taking aim at Intel, Qualcomm launches chip for business PCs
summary: Qualcomm has launched a new series of chips, the Snapdragon 8cx, specifically designed for business PCs to directly compete with Intel. These new chips will support Windows 10 Enterprise, addressing a limitation of previous Qualcomm chips that only supported consumer versions of Windows. This move intensifies Qualcomm's competition with Intel, which has historically dominated the PC chip market and is also being challenged in the data center business.

title: Lam Research CEO leaves amid misconduct inquiry, fourth chip boss this year to face such allegations
summary: Lam Research CEO Martin Anstice resigned Wednesday amid allegations of misconduct following an internal investigation. He will not receive severance benefits. This marks the fourth time this year a CEO of a major chip company has departed due to similar inquiries, following executives at Intel, Texas Instruments, and Rambus.

title: Lam Research CEO quits after 'misconduct' allegations
summary: Lam Research CEO Martin Anstice resigned due to allegations of "misconduct in the workplace and conduct inconsistent with the company's core values." He will receive no severance despite his $12.8 million compensation last year. Tim Archer, the company president, has been appointed as his successor.

title: To handle the data tsunami, Juniper’s founder turns to custom silicon
summary: Fungible Inc., founded by Juniper Networks Inc. founder Pradeep Sindhu, is developing custom silicon in the form of a data processing unit (DPU) to address the challenge of booming data volumes and the slowdown of Moore's Law. The company aims to optimize data movement and storage in data centers, focusing on data-centric computing and hardware/software integration to meet the demands of massively scalable data centers and edge computing. Despite initial venture capital skepticism, Fungible secured $32 million in funding, and its approach is validated by other tech giants also pursuing custom silicon solutions.

title: Lisa Lambert on why she left Intel Capital and the $250 million venture fund she runs for National Grid - Bizwomen
summary: Lisa Lambert, a veteran of Intel Capital, now heads National Grid Partners, a $250 million venture fund investing in cleantech startups. Lambert discusses her departure from Intel Capital and her strategic decision to focus on the cleantech sector, noting the quadrupling of deals in the energy sector since the 2008 bubble burst. National Grid Partners has already invested in several startups, including AutoGrid Systems Inc., Leapfrog Power Inc., and Sitetracker Inc.

title: Intel Unveils the Intel Neural Compute Stick 2 at Intel AI Devcon Beijing for Building Smarter AI Edge Devices
summary: Intel announced the Intel Neural Compute Stick 2 (Intel NCS 2) at its first AI developer conference in Beijing. This device, powered by the Intel Movidius Myriad X VPU, is designed to accelerate deep neural network inference applications and enable faster prototyping for AI and computer vision at the network edge. The Intel NCS 2 aims to empower developers to build smarter AI algorithms for various edge devices and facilitates the transition from prototyping to production leveraging the OpenVINO toolkit.

title: Longtime Intel Capital VC tells why she now runs a major utility's $250M fund
summary: Lisa Lambert, a veteran of Intel Capital, has launched a new startup investment, incubation, and business development unit for National Grid in Los Gatos. The venture fund, valued at $250 million, will focus on cleantech, a sector Lambert sees as promising despite a previous bubble burst a decade ago. This move marks her return to venture capital after leaving Intel several years prior.

title: Intel Accelerates Timing for Intel XMM 8160 5G Multimode Modem to Support Broad Global 5G Rollouts
summary: Intel announced the acceleration of its Intel XMM 8160 5G multimode modem, launching it more than half a year earlier than planned to meet demand for 5G deployments. This modem offers significantly faster speeds and supports multiple radio technologies in a single chipset, enabling smaller and more power-efficient devices for phone, PC, and broadband access gateways. Commercial devices leveraging this modem are expected to be available in the first half of 2020.

title: Video Company Kaltura Expands Operations With $5 Million Investment
summary: Kaltura Inc., a New York-headquartered video company, is investing $5 million to expand its operations by opening new offices in Paris, Munich, and Jerusalem. This expansion will also involve recruiting dozens of new employees. The move follows several large-scale deals and builds on their existing global presence and over $160 million in prior investments.

title: 50-years of Intel CEOs (infographic)
summary: This article from Portland Inno and Portland Business Journal provides an infographic looking back at the six individuals who have served as CEO of Intel over its 50-year history. It highlights the company's long-standing leadership. The piece also includes an image of Intel's chip production facilities in Hillsboro, emphasizing the manufacturing process.

title: Qualcomm asked by US federal judge to license its tech to competition such as Intel
summary: A US federal judge has ruled that chip seller Qualcomm Inc must license some of its modem chip technology to competitors, such as Intel Corp. This preliminary ruling emerged from an antitrust lawsuit filed by the US Federal Trade Commission against Qualcomm in early 2017. Qualcomm's shares dropped slightly following the news, as settlement talks between Qualcomm and the FTC continue.

title: HP Spectre Folio: One Of The Most Unique Devices I've Ever Reviewed
summary: The author reviews the HP Spectre Folio, highlighting its unique design as a leather-bound PC with three distinct usage modes. He praises its premium packaging, durable leather, and satisfying performance for productivity tasks, despite average battery life for its class. The article also details the device's connectivity, audio quality, and justifies its premium price point.

title: Supermicro Boosts Entry UP Server Line Enabling a Rich Set of New Workloads on Cost-Optimized, Entry-Class Systems
summary: Supermicro has launched a new line of UP servers optimized for the Intel Xeon E-2100 processors, delivering significant performance improvements, energy efficiency, and enhanced security compared to previous generations. These new servers cater to various applications including software-defined storage, small business, and IoT environments, offering a cost-effective solution for diverse entry-class workloads. The portfolio includes compact rackmount servers, mid-tower systems, and high-density MicroBlade and MicroCloud systems.

title: Apple’s first 5G iPhone will arrive in 2020
summary: Apple is planning to launch its first 5G iPhone in 2020, exclusively using Intel's 8161 5G modem chip despite challenges with heat dissipation and Apple's current dissatisfaction with Intel. While Intel is the primary provider, Apple has also conversed with MediaTek as a "Plan B," but is confident its issues with Intel can be resolved in time. This launch timeline makes sense given the 5G standard was only recently finalized and widespread 5G infrastructure will still be developing in 2019.

title: Intel says it met ‘full representation’ in its diversity goals, but what does that mean?
summary: Intel announced it reached "full representation" in its diversity goals two years early, defining this as its workforce mirroring the current talent pool (27% female, 9.2% Hispanic, under 5% African American). This definition, however, does not correlate with the overall U.S. population but is a step toward broader diversity, according to Intel. The article highlights the importance of inclusion alongside diversity and points out that many talent pipelines may not be built to encourage minority growth in tech.

title: Momentum Investing: It Works, But Why?
summary: Momentum investing, a strategy of buying recent stock winners and selling recent losers, has consistently generated above-average returns for decades, challenging the efficient market hypothesis. Despite its proven success, academics, including UCLA Anderson's Avanidhar Subrahmanyam, are still trying to definitively explain why it works. The article explores various behavioral theories, such as investor overreaction or underreaction to information, and calls for more focused research to narrow down the true driving factors.

title: Micron CEO on how the company plans to stay ahead of the semiconductor slump
summary: Micron CEO and President Sanjay Mehrotra discusses the company's strategy for navigating an industry-wide semiconductor slump and slower PC markets. He emphasizes the critical role of Silicon Valley in the company's future plans. The article also touches upon Micron's 40-year milestone.

title: Volkswagen, Mobileye and Champion Motors to Invest in Israel and Deploy First Autonomous EV Ride-Hailing Service
summary: Volkswagen Group, Intel's Mobileye, and Champion Motors announced a partnership to deploy Israel's first self-driving ride-hailing service, "New Mobility in Israel," starting in 2019 with full commercialization by 2022. Volkswagen will provide electric vehicles, Mobileye its level-4 AV Kit, and Champion Motors will manage fleet operations. The Israeli government supports this initiative, which will also serve as a global beta site for autonomous electric Mobility-as-a-Service.

title: Invesco Semiconductors ETF
summary: This page provides a detailed profile of the Invesco Semiconductors ETF (PSI), including its price, performance, holdings, expense ratio, and ESG scores. The ETF tracks an index of U.S. semiconductor firms, focusing on medium and small-cap companies for growth opportunities within the technology sector. It also offers insights into its volatility, dividend yield, and comparisons to other technology and semiconductor ETFs.

title: Micron to buy out Intel’s share of flash joint venture for $1.5 billion
summary: Micron Technology Inc. announced its intention to acquire Intel Corp.'s share of their IM Flash Technologies joint venture for $1.5 billion. This deal, expected to close within six to 12 months, will make Micron the sole owner of the world's only 3-D XPoint fab. Micron plans to finance the buyout using free cash flow while continuing its share buyback program.

title: Micron to buy out Intel’s share of flash joint venture for $1.5 billion
summary: Micron Technology Inc. announced its plan to acquire Intel Corp.'s share of their flash memory joint venture, IM Flash Technologies, for $1.5 billion. This deal will leave Micron with the world's only 3-D XPoint fab as a subsidiary. Micron expects to finance the buyout from free cash flow while continuing its share repurchase plan.

title: Intelsat, Satcom Direct Disrupt Business Aviation Connectivity
summary: Intelsat, Satcom Direct, and Astronics are partnering to launch FlexExec, a new Ku-band satellite internet service specifically for business aviation operators. This service, utilizing Intelsat's Epic high-throughput satellites and Astronics' tail-mounted antenna systems, offers dedicated high-speed connectivity up to 10 megabits-per-second, with plans to increase to 25. The collaboration also emphasizes robust cybersecurity and a "power by the hour" payment model.

title: C3.ai Announces Strategic OEM Partnership with Hewlett Packard Enterprise
summary: C3.ai and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) announced a strategic OEM partnership to globally scale the C3 AI Appliance powered by Intel. This collaboration aims to address the rapidly growing market for AI and IoT enterprise software applications by offering an integrated solution for on-premises, hybrid cloud, and edge computing deployments. The partnership will enable customers across various industries to more quickly operationalize AI, machine learning, and deep learning solutions while addressing governance, compliance, and security needs.

title: Intel Again Cuts Stake in ASML
summary: Intel has further reduced its stake in lithography vendor ASML to below 3%, following similar reductions by other major chipmakers like Samsung and TSMC. This move comes after an initial $4 billion investment in 2012 by Intel to accelerate extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography development. Despite the stake reduction, ASML's stock price has soared by approximately 350% since Intel's initial investment, with EUV technology now nearing production deployment.

title: 13 New Stocks in the Wide Moat Focus Index
summary: The Morningstar Wide Moat Focus Index recently underwent its quarterly reconstitution, adding 13 new stocks, including several semiconductor companies and asset managers, while removing 12. This re-evaluation ensures the index continues to feature competitively advantaged stocks trading at attractive price/fair value ratios. The article also details reasons for specific stock removals, such as CVS and GE, due to changes in their economic moat ratings.

title: Why AMD's Stock May Plunge 12% Further
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) stock is projected to fall an additional 12% from its current price, based on technical analysis, following a 20% drop from its 2018 intraday highs. The technical breakdown indicates that if the stock falls below a support level of $25.75, it could decline further to $24. Despite expectations for strong third-quarter earnings, high volatility and a larger volume of bearish put options suggest ongoing price pressure.

title: D-Wave takes quantum computers mainstream with ‘Leap’
summary: D-Wave Systems is launching "Leap," a web portal offering immediate, free, real-time access to its quantum computers for developers. This initiative aims to democratize quantum computing, moving it from large corporations and academic institutions to a broader user base. Leap provides not only access but also learning tools, open-source code, and a community forum to foster widespread adoption and application development for quantum technology.

title: Intel Manufacturing Facilities Run 365 Days a Year
summary: Intel Corporation highlights that its U.S. manufacturing and research and development facilities in Oregon, Arizona, and New Mexico operate 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. The company will celebrate Manufacturing Day with the National Association of Manufacturers on October 5, 2018, emphasizing that the majority of its advanced manufacturing and R&D are located within the United States. This commitment creates high-precision, IP-driven products crucial for global innovation.

title: Opinion: Why AMD believes it can challenge Intel in servers
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) is challenging Intel Corp.'s dominance in the server market with new chips, leveraging what it believes is superior technology. While AMD has had similar challenges in the past followed by setbacks, its recent rise suggests a potential turnaround might be more sustainable this time, reminiscent of its technological breakthrough in the early 2000s. The company sees significant opportunity for gains in data centers, a crucial sector in today's technology landscape.

title: AMD Stock Price Has Paused, Investors Should Pause As Well
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) experienced a significant stock surge but has since paused in the mid-$30s. While AMD's long-term outlook remains promising due to its technological advancements and competitive gains against Intel and Nvidia, its current valuation is considered high, suggesting investors should proceed with caution in the short term. The article advises waiting for a modest pullback or for financials to catch up before investing, highlighting strong long-term fundamentals despite the current overvaluation.

title: Barron's 400 ETF Boosts Exposure to These Sectors
summary: The Barron’s 400 ETF (BFOR) recently completed its semi-annual rebalance, increasing its exposure to the Consumer Discretionary, Energy, and Materials sectors. New additions to its underlying index include Visa and Intel, while Verizon and Boeing were among the deletions. Financial services and industrials continue to be the largest sector weights within the ETF.

title: ON Semiconductor Positioning Itself As A Leader In Self-Driving Car Technologies
summary: ON Semiconductor is establishing itself as a key player in self-driving car technologies by manufacturing all three primary sensor types: LiDAR, radar, and cameras. The company differentiates itself with a range of CMOS sensors for cameras and has strategically acquired SensL Technologies for LiDAR and an RF team for radar development. ON Semiconductor's technologies are integrated into major self-driving ecosystems like Intel Mobileye, NVIDIA Drive PX, and Baidu Apollo, positioning it as a comprehensive sensor solution provider for both self-driving and advanced assistive driving applications.

title: Micron Technology shares slip after CFO says Trump's tariffs will hit business and issues disappointing outlook
summary: Micron Technology shares fell after its CFO stated that new 10% tariffs on Chinese imports would impact gross margins and issued a disappointing outlook for fiscal first-quarter earnings and revenue, despite strong fourth-quarter results. The tariffs represent a significant challenge for Micron, which relies heavily on revenue from China. Analysts have also cooled on the stock due to anticipated price cuts and waning demand for memory chips.

title: New Tesla Rival Lucid Motors Says "Funding Secured"
summary: Lucid Motors, a luxury electric-vehicle startup, announced it has secured over $1 billion in funding from Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund. This investment is crucial for Lucid to bring its first model, the Air luxury sedan, into full production. The article highlights the innovative aspects of the Lucid Air and its potential to challenge Tesla's market leadership in the high-performance EV segment.

title: This chart shows AMD stock at historically overbought levels
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) shares have reached historically overbought levels, with its stock more than doubling its 200-day moving average and its Relative Strength Index (RSI) remaining above the overbought threshold. The stock soared 7.1% on a Friday, putting it on track for a 12-year high, and has more than tripled year-to-date (up 218%) driven by strong earnings and optimism for new chipsets. This contrasts with chief rival Intel Corp. whose shares have lost ground.

title: Glow: A community-driven approach to AI infrastructure
summary: Meta (Facebook) is expanding its hardware ecosystem for machine learning by announcing support for the Glow compiler from partners like Cadence, Esperanto, Intel, Marvell, and Qualcomm Technologies Inc. Glow, an open-source framework, enables rapid design and optimization of new silicon products for AI/ML by leveraging community-driven compiler software. This initiative aims to accelerate inference performance across various hardware platforms and extend hardware acceleration beyond data centers to mobile devices and other industries.

title: How this CEO avoided the glass cliff and turned around an "uninvestable" company
summary: Lisa Su, CEO of AMD, successfully turned around the struggling tech company after it faced significant losses and was deemed "uninvestable." Her strategy focused on three clear objectives: building great products, deepening customer relationships, and simplifying operations, while also fostering an open and learning-oriented company culture. Su's pragmatic leadership and communication style helped AMD achieve 25% revenue growth in 2017 and return to profitability.

title: Exclusive: Intel acquires San Jose-based chip startup in homecoming for founder
summary: Intel has acquired San Jose-based chip startup NetSpeed Systems, a move that will expand Intel's chip offerings to compete in emerging segments like automotive and artificial intelligence. This acquisition marks a return for NetSpeed founder and CEO Sundari Mitra to Intel, where she began her professional career. Mitra will also be reunited with her mentor Jim Keller at Intel.

title: Intel acquires system-on-chip startup NetSpeed Systems
summary: Intel Corp. has acquired NetSpeed Systems Inc., a startup specializing in system-on-chip development, to enhance its internal SoC initiatives and reduce costs. The acquisition brings NetSpeed's interconnect technology, including an AI-powered design tool called NocSudio, into Intel's Silicon Engineering Group. NetSpeed had previously raised $13.2 million from investors at a $60 million valuation.

title: Micron, KLA-Tencor warnings send chip-related stocks to worst day in more than two months
summary: Chip-related stocks experienced their worst day in over two months after Micron and KLA-Tencor issued market outlooks weaker than previously forecasted. The PHLX Semiconductor Index dropped 2.7% on Thursday, marking its largest one-day percentage decline since June 25. This downturn suggests that a rebound in the chip industry may be softer than anticipated, impacting chip-equipment companies the hardest.

title: ETFs Investors can Use to Capitalize on M&A Activity in Israel
summary: This article highlights how investors can capitalize on Israel's growing economy and M&A activity through ETFs. It specifically recommends the VanEck Vectors Israel ETF (ISRA) and BlueStar Israel Technology ETF (ITEQ), detailing their performance and asset allocations. The author notes that increased M&A in both tech and non-tech sectors, fueled by foreign investment, is driving Israel's GDP growth.

title: TSMC Benefits From Globalfoundries’ Decision to End 7nm Development
summary: Globalfoundries' decision to halt 7nm process development has significantly reordered the semiconductor manufacturing landscape, benefiting TSMC as AMD shifts its next-generation CPU and GPU production to the Taiwanese foundry. While Globalfoundries focuses on its 14nm and 12nm processes, analysts suggest that abandoning advanced node development could negatively impact Globalfoundries' long-term viability. This strategic move highlights the increasing challenges and costs associated with pushing Moore's Law, strengthening TSMC's position in the industry.

title: GlobalFoundries Halts 7nm Work
summary: GlobalFoundries has halted its 7nm process technology development, citing the high financial investment required and limited market demand compared to older nodes. This decision forces its primary customer, AMD, to rely entirely on TSMC for initial 7nm chips, potentially impacting AMD's supply and market share gains. GlobalFoundries will now focus on enhancing its 14/12nm node and FD-SOI technology, aiming for improved financial performance and positive cash flow.

title: Intel confirms three security flaws in its chips
summary: Intel Corp confirmed three severe security flaws in some of its microprocessors that could allow illegal data access from computer memory. These vulnerabilities, including "L1 Terminal Fault (L1TF)," were reported by researchers from multiple international institutions and could impact various microprocessors, operating systems, and virtualization software. Intel is working on fixes, with updates expected to roll out later this year to mitigate risks, and advises users to keep their systems updated.

title: Preparing for explosive growth, AMD execs tout need for more women in chip industry
summary: AMD executives are emphasizing the critical need to recruit diverse talent, particularly women, as the company prepares for significant growth that could surpass competitors like Intel. This call for diversity comes amidst AMD's rapid expansion in the chip industry. The article highlights the importance of increasing female representation to support the company's future development.

title: Dow drops about 200 points as financial crisis in Turkey spooks global markets
summary: U.S. stocks fell on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 196.09 points, as a financial crisis in Turkey, triggered by a plunging lira and increased U.S. tariffs, rattled global markets. The Turkish lira fell significantly after President Trump authorized higher metals tariffs, impacting European stocks and leading to a flight to quality in U.S. Treasurys. Bank and tech shares in the U.S. were particularly hit, though some analysts noted underlying strength in equities due to strong earnings.

title: GM contracting directly with Henry Ford Health System
summary: General Motors is partnering with Henry Ford Health System to launch GM ConnectedCare, a new direct-to-employer health insurance option aiming to save employees between $300 and $900 annually. This five-year contract requires participating GM employees in southeast Michigan to receive all care through Henry Ford Health System or pay out-of-network rates, marking a growing trend of employers directly contracting with providers to lower healthcare costs. The plan, available to nearly 24,000 non-unionized GM employees, demonstrates a shift towards shared risk and value-based care, with Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan handling claims processing.

title: Intel Corporation (INTC) Is Losing Its Market Share
summary: Intel Corporation is losing market share in PC and server microprocessors to competitors like Advanced Micro Devices. Barclays downgraded INTC stock due to Intel's lagging technology and uncertain CEO transition, while Bank of America noted AMD's significant share gains in Q2 2018. Despite healthy demand for semiconductors, analysts suggest AMD is currently a better investment than Intel.

title: GM inks direct contract with Henry Ford Health
summary: General Motors Co. and Henry Ford Health System have signed a "direct to employer" health care contract to provide a new health care option for GM employees in Southeast Michigan, aiming to cut costs by eliminating the insurance-company middleman. The ConnectedCare plan, open to 24,000 GM salaried employees and their families, offers access to over 3,000 providers and is expected to save employees $300 to $900 annually on premiums. This strategy reflects a shift towards value-based health care, holding providers accountable for employee health and cost performance.

title: Apple's first hires for its health clinics show how it's thinking differently about health care
summary: Apple's AC Wellness, a new subsidiary for employee health, has rapidly hired over 40 professionals, focusing on "well care" specialists like nutritionists and exercise coaches rather than just doctors. This approach emphasizes preventative health and patient experience over traditional fee-for-service primary care, aligning with a broader industry shift towards value-based care. The initiative highlights Apple's unique strategy in healthcare, with a significant number of hires from health-tech startups and a focus on holistic wellness.

title: Research Radar: Three managers worth watching
summary: This article highlights three portfolio managers—Tiffany Hsiao, Kearney Posner, and Burns McKinney—who have achieved notable Citywire ratings due to their strong performance in various investment sectors. Hsiao excelled in China Small Companies, Posner earned her first rating for a Floating Rate fund, and McKinney received an A rating for his Large-Cap Value fund despite a tough year for value investing. Each manager's success is attributed to specific investment strategies and successful stock selections.

title: AMD Stock Breaks Out but Approaches Overbought Levels
summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) stock rose 2.5% after Cowen & Co. reiterated an Outperform rating and raised its price target, citing opportunities in data centers and client markets, especially with upcoming 7nm products. This upgrade follows Intel's 10nm chip delay, which could allow AMD to gain market share. Despite breaking out to new highs, technical indicators suggest the stock is approaching overbought levels, potentially leading to consolidation before further gains.

title: Intel Corporation (INTC) Earnings Beat Overshadowed by Product Delays
summary: Intel Corporation reported stronger-than-expected second-quarter earnings and revenue but its stock dropped over 8% after announcing further delays for its 10-nanometer processors. Analysts believe these delays could lead to market share loss to competitors like Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and have prompted a downgrade of Intel's stock. The company's CEO, Bob Swan, indicated that the 10nm products are now expected by the holiday season in 2019, instead of an earlier 2019 launch.

title: Intel falls on delay of future chip technology
summary: Intel's stock fell despite beating Q2 2018 earnings and revenue expectations, largely due to concerns over delayed 10-nanometer chip technology and the sudden resignation of CEO Brian Krzanich. Interim CEO Bob Swan addressed challenges like gross margins and competitive pressures, while also providing a clearer timeline for the 10-nanometer product rollout in 2019. The company also raised its full-year outlook, and the search for a permanent CEO is ongoing.

title: Qualcomm ends $44 billion NXP bid after failing to win China approval
summary: Qualcomm Inc. has terminated its $44 billion bid to acquire NXP Semiconductors after failing to secure approval from Chinese regulators, a casualty of escalating Sino-U.S. trade tensions. The collapse of the deal, which would have been the largest semiconductor takeover globally, was publicly confirmed by both companies. Qualcomm will now proceed with a $30 billion share buyback and pay NXP a $2 billion termination fee.

title: Qualcomm plans huge stock buyback after ditching NXP bid: report
summary: Qualcomm Inc. is reportedly abandoning its bid to acquire NXP Semiconductors NV due to resistance from Chinese regulators. Instead, Qualcomm plans to propose a stock buyback plan, adding $10 billion to its existing program. This announcement is expected to coincide with Qualcomm's earnings release after the market close.

title: Qualcomm plans huge stock buyback after ditching NXP bid: report
