summary: Qualcomm Inc. is reportedly planning a significant stock buyback program after abandoning its bid to acquire NXP Semiconductors NV due to resistance from Chinese regulators. The company is expected to announce a $10 billion addition to its buyback program and confirm the NXP deal's abandonment during its earnings announcement. This development follows a period of extensions for regulatory approval and previous speculation involving Intel Corp.

title: Intel Promotes Three Corporate Officers
summary: Intel Corporation announced the promotion of three corporate officers: Michelle Johnston Holthaus, Daniel (Dan) McNamara, and Allon Stabinsky, all raised from corporate vice president to senior vice president roles. These promotions recognize their significant contributions and expanded responsibilities as Intel transforms from a PC-centric to a data-centric company. Each leader holds critical positions within Intel's Sales and Marketing, Programmable Solutions, and Legal departments, respectively.

title: Texas Instruments CEO Brian Crutcher loses job for personal misconduct
summary: Texas Instruments CEO Brian Crutcher was removed from his position due to personal misconduct, less than two months after taking the job. The company stated his behavior violated their code of conduct, though not related to operations or finances, and has reinstated his predecessor, Rich Templeton. This incident follows a similar CEO removal at rival chip maker Intel for code of conduct violations.

title: Texas Instruments CEO resigns on code of conduct violation
summary: Texas Instruments Inc announced the resignation of CEO Brian Crutcher just six weeks into his role due to a violation of the company's code of conduct regarding personal behavior. Chairman Rich Templeton will reassume the CEO and president roles, and the company confirmed the violation was unrelated to its strategy, operations, or financial reporting. The news caused Texas Instruments' shares to fall, despite the company reporting beating second-quarter earnings and sales estimates.

title: Texas Instruments' new CEO loses job for personal misconduct
summary: Texas Instruments CEO Brian Crutcher resigned due to personal misconduct, just six weeks after his promotion. The company states his violations were not related to strategy, operations, or financial reporting. Former CEO Rich Templeton will return to lead the company.

title: Texas Instruments Chief Executive Resigns; Conduct Violations Are Cited (Published 2018)
summary: Brian Crutcher, the newly appointed CEO of Texas Instruments, resigned due to violations of the company's code of conduct related to personal behavior. He is being replaced by his predecessor, Rich Templeton, who will return as president and CEO indefinitely. The company's stock saw a modest dip in after-hours trading, but analysts believe the return of Templeton will reassure investors.

title: SEMI announces re-election of board members
summary: SEMI announced the re-election of 10 current members to its international board of directors for two-year terms during SEMICON West. The executive committee confirmed Tetsuo Tsuneishi as chairman and Bertrand Loy as vice chairman. SEMI also honored Sean Larsen of Lam Research with the Technical Editor Award and Don Hadder of Intel with the Corporate Device Member Award for their contributions to industry standards.

title: Intel Editorial: Intel to Acquire eASIC – Adding to Its Programmable Solutions Talent and Capabilities
summary: Intel announced its plan to acquire eASIC, a structured ASICs provider, to expand its programmable solutions portfolio. This acquisition will allow Intel to better address high-performance and power-constrained applications in markets like wireless, networking, and IoT, and offer customers more choices, faster time-to-market, and lower development costs. The integration of eASIC's technology is expected to create new programmable chip solutions, potentially combining Intel FPGAs with structured ASICs using EMIB technology.

title: ETF investor says own chip stocks to ride the next technology boom
summary: Sean O’Hara, president of Pacer ETFs Distributors, argues that chipmaking companies, rather than traditional tech giants, are the future of the technology sector, driven by the expansion of the "internet of things" and advancements in AI and blockchain. Pacer ETFs Distributors is overweight on information technology, specifically semiconductors, which O'Hara considers the "spine or skeleton of technology." He highlights Micron Technology due to its cash flow generation and low trading multiples, noting its plan to buy back $10 billion in stock.

title: Intel Editorial: How Governments Can Help Advance Artificial Intelligence
summary: Naveen Rao of Intel Corporation outlines how governments can accelerate the advancement of artificial intelligence by focusing on education, research and development, and a thoughtful regulatory landscape. He emphasizes the need for collaboration between governments, industry, and academia to realize AI's full potential, advocating for curriculum reform, increased R&D funding, and responsible data liberation.

title: UTM triumphed in the Innovate Malaysia Design Competition 2018 winning 12 Prizes from 16 Categories
summary: Universiti Teknologi Malaysia (UTM) achieved remarkable success at the Innovate Malaysia Design Competition 2018, securing 12 prizes out of 16 categories, including the prestigious Innovate Malaysia Excellence Award. The competition, co-organized by eight technology leaders, serves as a crucial platform for grooming engineering talent and promoting industry platforms in universities. UTM's winning projects showcased innovative solutions across various fields, from workplace safety using deep learning to service robots for the elderly and IoT devices for fetal monitoring.

title: Intel co-founder Gordon Moore reflects on company’s 50-year history
summary: Intel co-founder Gordon Moore reflects on the company's 50-year history in an interview. He discusses the origin of Intel's name, its location in Santa Clara, and his mindset during his tenure as CEO. The article notes that Intel is celebrating its 50th anniversary on July 18, 2018.

title: Rambus CEO Ron Black Fired - "Conduct Issue"
summary: Rambus Inc. announced the immediate termination of CEO Dr. Ron Black due to a "conduct issue" unrelated to the company's financial performance. Luc Seraphin, Senior Vice President & General Manager of the Memory and Interfaces Division, has been appointed interim CEO while the board searches for a permanent replacement. Chuck Kissner has also been named Vice Chairman of the Board to support Seraphin during this transition.

title: Rambus fires CEO Ron Black for unspecified 'conduct' issue
summary: Rambus, a memory design and patent licensing company, terminated CEO Ron Black due to an unspecified "conduct" issue that board members determined fell short of company standards. Black's dismissal follows a week after Intel's CEO also resigned for a conduct-related issue. The company has a history of patent litigation, including a 2010 settlement where Samsung paid $900 million to Rambus.

title: This futuristic $4,000 'smart desk' can manage your entire work life — here’s what it can do
summary: The Cemtrex SmartDesk is a new "smart desk" priced at $4,000, designed to integrate various work functionalities into a single unit. It features three touch screens, a document scanner, wireless charging, and built-in wireless earbuds for calls. The desk runs on Windows PC with an Intel Core i7 processor and offers a unique Stark Gesture System for control.

title: Nomura Downgrades Intel After CEO Resignation
summary: Nomura Instinet downgraded shares of Intel Corp. (INTC) to neutral from buy and lowered its price target to $55 from $60 following the abrupt resignation of CEO Brian Krzanich. The downgrade reflects concerns over the lack of leadership and increasing uncertainty about Intel's long-term outlook, especially regarding the succession plan and ongoing struggles with chip manufacturing technology. Intel's stock was down 2.5% in early trading, despite a 14% year-to-date gain.

title: Intel CEO Krzanich steps down after company uncovers past relationship with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich has resigned from his position immediately after an internal investigation revealed he violated company policy. The violation stemmed from a past consensual relationship with an Intel employee, which contravened the company's non-fraternization policy applicable to all managers. An analyst commented that this leadership transition is "clearly not a positive" for the company.

title: Intel Ex-Chief’s Affair With Employee Began Before He Was CEO
summary: Intel's former CEO, Brian Krzanich, resigned after the company determined he had violated policy due to an affair with an employee. This relationship reportedly began about a decade ago, before he became CEO, and ended several years prior to his resignation. The woman involved still works at Intel but did not work closely with Krzanich.

title: Intel CEO resigns after probe of relationship with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigned after an investigation confirmed he had a consensual relationship with an employee in breach of company policy. CFO Robert Swan was named interim CEO while the board searches for a permanent replacement. This event comes as Intel navigates increasing competition and expands into new technology sectors.

title: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich quits over relationship with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich has resigned after the company discovered he had a consensual relationship with an Intel employee, violating the company's non-fraternization policy applicable to all managers. The resignation comes amid increased pressure on corporations to enforce workplace policies on gender equality and sexual harassment in the #MeToo era. Chief financial officer Robert Swan will serve as interim CEO while the company searches for a permanent replacement.

title: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich quits over relationship with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigned after the company discovered he had a past consensual relationship with an Intel employee, violating the company's non-fraternization policy. Chief financial officer Bob Swan was appointed interim CEO, and the company is seeking a long-term successor. This departure comes amidst increased scrutiny of workplace relationships and ongoing business upheaval for Intel, though the company also raised its quarterly sales forecast.

title: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigns over relationship with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigned after an internal investigation revealed a consensual relationship with an Intel employee that violated company policy. Robert Swan, the CFO, was named interim CEO as the company searches for a permanent replacement. This event highlights a growing trend of stricter corporate stances on executive conduct and office romances, with Intel maintaining its positive financial outlook despite the leadership change.

title: Intel CEO out after consensual relationship with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigned after the company discovered his consensual relationship with an employee, which violated Intel's non-fraternization policy. Chief Financial Officer Robert Swan has been appointed interim CEO while a search for a new CEO is underway. This departure occurs as corporate America faces increased scrutiny over workplace policies in the #MeToo era, and comes despite Intel announcing better-than-expected Q2 financial forecasts.

title: Intel's Brian Krzanich is forced out as CEO after 'consensual relationship' with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich was forced out of his position and resigned from the board due to a "consensual relationship with an Intel employee" which violated the company's non-fraternization policy. Chief financial officer Robert Swan has stepped in as interim CEO, and the search for a permanent replacement has begun. The company also raised its guidance for the second quarter, expecting $16.9 billion in revenue and 99 cents earnings per share.

title: Big Trouble At 3nm
summary: Developing chips at the 3nm node presents significant challenges, with design costs potentially reaching $1.5 billion and questions surrounding the real-world benefits of gate-all-around technologies like nanosheet and nanowire FETs. While some companies like Samsung and GlobalFoundries are pushing forward with nanosheet FETs, others like TSMC are still exploring options, and the industry faces hurdles in manufacturing, process control, and interconnects, suggesting a potentially long and costly transition. The article also highlights a shift where finFETs might struggle at 3nm, necessitating a move to new transistor architectures.

title: Dealing With Resistance In Chips
summary: Chipmakers are facing increasing challenges with contact and interconnect resistance as silicon scaling continues. New materials like cobalt are being introduced at advanced nodes (10nm/7nm) to reduce resistance, but their effectiveness is still under evaluation. The industry is also exploring other materials like ruthenium and advanced processes such as fully self-aligned vias and selective deposition/etch to overcome the limitations of traditional copper and tungsten.

title: Intel C.E.O. Brian Krzanich Resigns After Relationship With Employee (Published 2018)
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigned after an investigation by internal and external counsel found he had a "past consensual relationship" with an Intel employee, violating the company's non-fraternization policy for managers. Robert Swan, Intel's chief financial officer, has been appointed interim chief executive while the company searches for a permanent replacement. The company did not disclose details about the relationship or the employee involved.

title: Intel: CEO Brian Krzanich is out after "consensual relationship" with employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich has resigned after an internal investigation confirmed he had a consensual relationship with an Intel employee, violating the company's non-fraternization policy. CFO Robert Swan has been appointed Interim CEO while the board searches for a permanent replacement.

title: Intel CEO Krzanich Resigns Over Relationship With Employee
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich resigned after an internal and external investigation confirmed he violated company policy by having a consensual relationship with a co-worker. The chip maker's nonfraternization policy, implemented in 2011, applies to all managers. This incident marks one of the most high-profile CEO departures in an era of increased scrutiny over workplace behavior.

title: What’s Changed: Gartner’s 2018 Magic Quadrant for Access Management, Worldwide
summary: This article reviews Gartner's 2018 Magic Quadrant for Access Management, Worldwide, highlighting key changes since the previous year's report. It discusses Gartner's definition of Access Management, new and absent vendors, the empty Challengers Quadrant, and shifts among the Leaders, particularly CA Technologies' move to the Visionaries Quadrant. The report also emphasizes the growing importance of IDaaS and IoT in access management, while reiterating Gartner's stance against password vaulting.

title: Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGA) Market Globally by 2025 |
summary: A new research report details the global Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGA) market, projecting healthy growth from 2018 to 2025. The report highlights the increasing demand for programmable solutions due to the high costs and complexities associated with traditional Application Specific Integrated Circuits (ASICs). Key players in the FPGA market, product types, and geographical analysis are also covered, aiming to provide insights into market trends and future strategies.

title: Intel Editorial: The Dash to 5G Commercialization Begins
summary: Intel's Asha Keddy discusses the rapid commercialization of 5G following the finalization of the Standalone (SA) 5G New Radio (NR) standard. Intel has been instrumental in advancing 5G through technological inputs, global partnerships, and trials using their 5G Mobile Trial Platform, highlighting collaborations in China, the U.S., and with companies like Ericsson, Nokia, and Sprint. The article emphasizes 5G's potential to transform various industries and create new economic opportunities.

title: Goldman Sachs, Deepak Chopra, and Paul Tudor Jones Are Launching a New Investment Fund, but It’s Good
summary: Goldman Sachs and Paul Tudor Jones' nonprofit, Just Capital, have launched a new values-driven investment fund called the JUST U.S. Large Cap Equity ETF (ticker: JUST). This ETF offers investors a diversified basket of 500 large U.S. companies chosen based on crowdsourced American values, providing an ethical alternative to traditional indexes like the S&P 500. While not guaranteed to outperform, it allows investors to align their portfolios with companies that rank high on metrics like worker treatment, customer care, environmental impact, and tax payments.

title: Cisco puts AMD silicon into a new system for compute-intensive applications
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. has unveiled the UCS C4200, a new server system featuring AMD's Epyc processors, targeting compute-intensive applications. This move by Cisco further validates AMD's efforts to gain market share in the data center, having previously partnered with Microsoft and Baidu. Despite increased shipments, AMD still faces a challenge in significantly denting Intel's dominant position.

title: EEOC investigating Intel layoffs for age discrimination
summary: The EEOC is investigating Intel Corp. over allegations of age discrimination in its layoffs. The investigation focuses on whether the company's 10,000 global job cuts unlawfully targeted older workers, as indicated by a median age of 49 for affected employees in one 2016 layoff. Intel denies age or other demographics were factors, stating the layoffs were to support its strategic evolution.

title: Analog Devices wins prestigious technology award in Dublin
summary: Analog Devices Inc (ADI) received the "Hibernia" award at Ireland’s National Tech Excellence Awards for its significant contributions to the Irish technology sector, including job creation and ecosystem development. This prestigious award recognizes ADI's 40-year presence and ongoing innovation in Ireland, following previous winners like Microsoft and Intel. Brendan O’Dowd, General Manager of Industrial Automation at ADI, accepted the award, highlighting the company's impact on diverse applications.

title: Intel, Micron Jointly Announce QLC NAND FLASH, 96-Layer 3D Development
summary: Intel and Micron have jointly announced the development and production of 64-Layer 3D QLC NAND, achieving the industry's first 1 terabit (Tb) density per die at 4 bits/cell. They also provided an update on the progress of their 96-layer 3D NAND structure, which aims for even higher density and lower costs. These advancements are expected to lead to more cost-effective storage solutions for cloud workloads, consumer, and client computing applications.

title: Intel’s 3 Million Square Feet of Solar Panels Help Heat, Cool and Light
summary: Intel reports that it has installed 3 million square feet of solar arrays across nine nations, generating 33 million kilowatt-hours of green power annually. This energy helps heat, cool, and light its buildings, and produce electricity for on-campus use. The company notes that 100% of the energy used in its U.S. and Europe chip manufacturing comes from renewable sources.

title: At Germany's SAP, employee mindfulness leads to higher profits
summary: German software giant SAP is implementing a global mindfulness training program for its employees, aiming to boost engagement, health, and productivity. The company attributes a significant return on investment to this initiative, claiming a 200 percent return and a positive impact on operating profit due to increased employee engagement and reduced absenteeism. SAP is also advising other major firms like Siemens and Deutsche Telekom on developing similar mindfulness programs.

title: Extreme Networks CEO Meyercord On The Battle Plan For Taking On Cisco And HPE Aruba
summary: Extreme Networks CEO Ed Meyercord discusses the company's strategy for competing with larger rivals like Cisco and HPE Aruba, leveraging recent acquisitions of Avaya, Zebra Technologies, and Brocade assets. The company emphasizes its focus on intelligent edge technologies, automation, and cloud capabilities, alongside a partner-driven approach to cross-selling within its expanded product portfolio. Meyercord highlights significant cross-sell opportunities and the development of "validated designs" to simplify solutions for various verticals, aiming for a post-acquisition run rate exceeding $1 billion.

title: A Concentration of Flavors: IFF Acquires Frutarom in $7.1B Deal
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (IFF) has announced its acquisition of Frutarom Industries for $7.1 billion, a move that will make IFF the second-largest flavor company globally. This deal highlights the ongoing consolidation in the flavor industry, with both IFF and Frutarom having made numerous acquisitions themselves. The acquisition is expected to generate $5.3 billion in sales for the combined entity and $145 million in synergies by the third year.

title: Israel's Frutarom To Be Acquired For $7.1B By Global Flavoring Firm IFF
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances (IFF) is set to acquire Israeli company Frutarom for over $7 billion in cash and stocks. This deal marks the second-largest transaction for an Israeli firm this year and will see Frutarom shareholders receive $71.19 in cash and a portion of IFF common stock for each share. The acquisition aims to unite two industry leaders, expanding their reach in fast-growing markets and enhancing their focus on natural, health, and wellness products.

title: Israeli flavor and fragrance company Frutarom sells for $7.1 billion
summary: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. (IFF) is set to acquire Israeli flavor and fragrance company Frutarom Industries Ltd. for $7.1 billion in a cash and share deal. This acquisition marks the second-largest exit for an Israeli company. Frutarom shareholders will receive $71.19 in cash and 0.249 shares of IFF common stock per Frutarom share, valuing each share at $106.25.

title: Palo Alto Networks CEO Mark McLaughlin: Security “is a software fight”
summary: Palo Alto Networks CEO Mark McLaughlin discusses the evolving landscape of cybersecurity, emphasizing that security is a "software fight" requiring automation and an "application framework." He highlights the company's approach to making security easier and more cost-effective for businesses through an app store-like platform for third-party developers, and addresses the importance of logging all data for machine learning.

title: Dell Latitude 5290 (i5-8250U, HD) Laptop Review
summary: The Dell Latitude 5290 laptop is reviewed, highlighting its strengths as a business-oriented device with a robust case, good keyboard, and above-average CPU performance. However, the review critically points out the inclusion of an "abysmal HD TN display" as its major drawback, leading to a non-recommendation, especially given its price point. While appreciating its quiet operation, strong battery life, and expandable RAM, the display quality significantly detracts from its overall appeal, putting it at a disadvantage compared to competitors.

title: Jim Keller Joins Intel to Lead Silicon Engineering
summary: Intel announced that Jim Keller will join the company as a senior vice president to lead silicon engineering, including system-on-chip (SoC) development and integration. Keller brings over two decades of experience in x86 and ARM-based microarchitecture design from companies like Tesla, AMD, and Apple, where he contributed to the Zen architecture and early A-series processors. His appointment is expected to accelerate Intel's transformation in heterogeneous process and architectures for the data-centric computing era.

title: Global Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) Market
summary: A market study titled "Global Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) Market" examines the market's performance in 2018, providing an in-depth analysis of its state and competitive landscape. The report forecasts market potential from 2018 to 2022, covering revenue, share, industry volume, trends, and growth aspects. It also lists top manufacturers, market segmentation by application and type, and details on growth drivers and constraints.

title: GTC 2018: Nvidia’s bet on AI, machine learning paying off
summary: Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang discussed the company's successful pivot towards AI and machine learning, transforming it from a graphics card designer into a computing architecture and software company. This strategic shift has resulted in significant stock growth and revenue increases, cementing Nvidia's position as a leader in the GPU and AI markets, despite warnings from analysts about potential regulation and competition.

title: Under Construction: Intel’s Largest Water Recycling Plant
summary: Intel is constructing its largest water recycling plant in Hillsboro, Oregon, set to be completed in three years. This facility is a crucial step towards Intel's goal of returning 100 percent of its water to communities and watersheds by 2025, and upon completion, it will recycle approximately 1 billion gallons of water annually. The construction highlights Intel's ongoing efforts to reduce water usage in chip manufacturing and contribute to water conservation.

title: Opinion: Intel, beware: AMD is a different company than it was just two years ago
summary: The article highlights Advanced Micro Devices' resurgence, noting that the company, under CEO Lisa Su, is now a significant competitor to Intel. AMD is releasing a robust pipeline of new chips, including the Ryzen 2000-series PC processors, targeting critical consumer markets. This marks a period of consistent execution for AMD not seen in over a decade.

title: Qualcomm Starts Massive Layoff As Part of Cost Cutting Strategy
summary: Qualcomm has begun massive layoffs as part of its strategy to cut $1 billion in annual costs, affecting both temporary and full-time employees, who will receive severance packages. The headcount reduction comes amidst its ongoing legal dispute with Apple and follows a prior announcement to streamline operations to improve revenue and appease investors. The company expects to file Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) in California, indicating a significant number of job eliminations.

title: New Patterning Options Emerging
summary: Fab tool vendors are advancing self-aligned patterning technologies to address the scaling challenges of new devices at 10/7nm and beyond. These techniques, including multiple patterning and self-aligned contacts/vias, are crucial for achieving precise feature placement and overcoming edge placement errors as chip features shrink. New approaches like multi-color material schemes and selective deposition are being developed to improve accuracy and enable future transistor architectures.

title: HP's Executive Forum Gives Insights Into Business, Products, And Just As Important, Company Culture
summary: This article discusses key insights from HP's Executive Forum, highlighting new product announcements in gaming, personal systems, and printing, along with updates on their 3D printing initiatives. Beyond product reveals, the author emphasizes the strong company culture, particularly noting the heartfelt tribute to the late COO Jon Flaxman, which revealed the close-knit relationships within HP's leadership. The forum served to showcase HP’s strategic roadmap and its focus on both innovation and internal values.

title: Cadence CEO: “EDA’s a Systems Game”
summary: Cadence CEO Lip-Bu Tan discusses how EDA is becoming a "systems game" as more system companies are designing their own chips. He highlights the growth in AI accelerator investments, the importance of silicon photonics and high-speed SerDes, and China's strategic ambitions in semiconductor design and AI. Tan also touches on the continued strong design activity at advanced process nodes despite rising costs and complexity.

title: HP Intel 8th gen Pavilion gaming laptops and desktops launched - Systems - News
summary: HP has launched new Pavilion Gaming PC products, including two desktops, one laptop, and one desktop monitor, aiming to provide "Powerful PC Gaming Experiences to the Masses" for casual gamers. These products feature Intel 8th Gen Core processors (or AMD Ryzen for desktops), various GPU options from Nvidia and AMD, and flexible storage and display configurations. The new line sits below HP's premium Omen gaming series, offering a balance of performance and affordability.

title: SNSR – An Internet of Things ETF for IoT Investors
summary: This article evaluates the Global X Internet of Things ETF (SNSR) as an investment vehicle for gaining exposure to the Internet of Things (IoT) theme. It examines SNSR's performance against benchmarks like the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, details its top holdings—primarily semiconductor and sensor companies—and discusses whether it offers true "pure-play" IoT exposure. The author concludes that while SNSR is one of the few IoT-focused ETFs available, its performance hasn't consistently outperformed a general Nasdaq tracker ETF.

title: HP Revamps Pavilion PCs with Premium Features and Design
summary: HP Inc. introduced its next-generation Pavilion portfolio, featuring convertibles, notebooks, and desktops with premium features and expressive designs. The lineup includes thinner bezels, refined materials, stepped-up performance options, and will debut at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. HP also launched a new Pavilion Gaming portfolio to bring powerful PC gaming experiences to a broader audience.

title: HP Brings Powerful PC Gaming Experiences to the Masses
summary: HP Inc. introduced its new HP Pavilion Gaming lineup, offering notebooks, desktops, and displays tailored for mainstream gamers seeking powerful performance, bold design, and everyday versatility. This new portfolio aims to cater to the 62% of the growing gaming market who are more casual users, complementing HP's OMEN line built for enthusiasts. The lineup includes new laptops, desktops, and a 32-inch HDR display, providing a range of options for gaming and creative tasks, all at accessible price points.

title: How These Major Companies Are Getting Equal Pay Right
summary: This article examines how major corporations like Starbucks, Apple, Salesforce, Intel, and Adobe have achieved pay parity for women and underrepresented minorities in the U.S. It highlights the strategies these companies employ, including payroll audits and committed leadership, as well as the broader societal push for equal pay fueled by movements and evolving employee expectations. The piece emphasizes that while progress on wage equality has been slow, these companies are demonstrating that achieving pay parity is possible and crucial for future workforce attraction.

title: The AI compilation wars: Intel, Google, Microsoft, Nvidia, IBM and others arm for deep learning acceleration
summary: The article discusses the growing "AI compilation wars" as major tech companies like Intel, Google, Microsoft, Nvidia, and IBM develop cross-platform compilers for deep learning acceleration. These compilers aim to enable AI models built with various front-end tools to run optimally on diverse back-end hardware, fostering a future where AI developers can abstract their models and compile them for hybridized hardware environments. The trend highlights a move towards open-source, framework-agnostic AI development.

title: 4G vs. 5G Download/Upload Speeds For Smart Cities
summary: The article discusses the significant speed improvements offered by 5G networks compared to 4G LTE, highlighting their potential impact on smart city initiatives and IoT deployments. It elaborates on projected download and upload speeds for 5G and explores applications like autonomous vehicles, while also addressing infrastructure challenges such as zoning issues for new cellular towers.

title: Haifa team sires Intel’s ‘best processor ever’ for laptops
summary: Intel's Haifa-based development team led the creation of a new line of 8th generation Intel Core processors, including what the company calls its "best processor ever" for laptops. These new processors offer significant performance improvements over previous generations, catering to gamers and content creators. This is not the first time Intel's Haifa R&D team has been credited with major processor advancements.

title: Chips are down: Apple to stop using Intel processors in Macs, reports say
summary: Apple is reportedly planning to transition its Mac computers from Intel processors to in-house designed chips by 2020, mirroring its strategy for iPhones and iPads. This potential shift, which has been rumored for several years, led to a 6% drop in Intel's share price and aims to create a unified architecture across Apple's device ecosystem. The move would mark a significant change similar to Apple's transition from IBM's PowerPC to Intel processors in 2005.

title: Apple Plans to Use Its Own Chips in Macs From 2020, Replacing Intel
summary: Apple Inc. is reportedly planning to integrate its own processors into Mac computers starting as early as 2020, transitioning away from Intel Corp.'s chips. This strategic move, codenamed Kalamata, aims to create a more unified experience across Apple's device ecosystem, including Macs, iPhones, and iPads. The shift is anticipated to be a multi-step process and signifies a major change in Apple's hardware strategy.

title: GTC 2018: Autonomous vehicle development should continue, urges Nvidia boss
summary: Nvidia CEO Jen-Hsun Huang argues that autonomous vehicle development, particularly in safety, must continue and investments should increase despite a recent fatal accident involving an Uber self-driving car. He emphasizes that the technology is intended to save lives and calls for patience while investigations into the incident are ongoing. Nvidia itself temporarily halted its AV testing to assess new data but continues development using simulators.

title: Uber may have switched off safety system before fatal crash, Bloomberg reports
summary: A report indicates that Uber may have turned off the standard safety system in a self-driving Volvo SUV before it fatally struck a woman in Arizona. This revelation comes as Arizona's governor suspended Uber's autonomous vehicle testing privileges, citing concerns about public safety. Experts suggest the car's sensors should have detected the pedestrian, prompting questions about the safety measures in place during Uber's autonomous testing.

title: PacBio Sells Sequel System Sequencers to Annoroad
summary: Pacific Biosciences (PacBio) has sold ten Sequel System sequencers to Annoroad Gene Technology, a Beijing-based genomics services provider, to expand Annoroad's Single Molecule, Real-Time (SMRT) sequencing capacity. This transaction supports Annoroad's goal of building a leading genome center and enhancing its large-scale genomic service capabilities across various fields. The sequencers are expected to play a crucial role in Annoroad’s ATCG Database and its strategy to become a significant global player in genomics.

title: Intel shares jump; analyst boosts target; Microsoft search gets smarter
summary: Intel Corp. shares rose following several positive news developments, including an analyst boosting their price target. The article also mentions that Intel's Xeon Scalable processors are contributing to the company's 2018 growth.

title: Timeline: Broadcom-Qualcomm saga comes to an abrupt end
summary: Broadcom Ltd withdrew its $117 billion bid to acquire Qualcomm Inc after U.S. President Donald Trump blocked the attempt due to national security concerns. This timeline details the key developments in the Broadcom-Qualcomm saga, from Broadcom's initial offer to the eventual withdrawal of the bid and related political interventions. The article highlights the concerns raised by U.S. officials regarding the impact on America's lead in mobile technology and potential Chinese influence.

title: VWR, Part of Avantor, Receives Intel's Prestigious Supplier Continuous Quality Improvement Award
summary: VWR, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Avantor, has been honored with Intel's 2017 Supplier Continuous Quality Improvement (SCQI) award. This prestigious award recognizes VWR's elite performance in critical management systems across quality, cost, availability, technology, customer service, and sustainability. Companies receiving this award are considered industry role-models for their unparalleled supply chain support.

title: How Broadcom vs. Qualcomm went from hostile takeover bid to a Trump blockade
summary: The article details the escalating conflict between Broadcom and Qualcomm, which began as a hostile takeover bid and culminated in President Donald Trump blocking the record-breaking deal. The intervention by the U.S. government heightened the intensity of the battle, transforming a typical corporate fight into a political one. Key events leading up to the blockade included Broadcom's rush to move to the U.S., Qualcomm's executive chairman stepping down, and potential involvement from Intel.

title: Toshiba dynaEdge AR Smart Glasses, a wearable Windows PC announced
summary: Toshiba has introduced new dynaEdge AR Smart Glasses, a wearable Augmented Reality (AR) solution for enterprise customers. This solution combines the dynaEdge DE-100 Mobile Mini PC with Windows 10 Pro and the dynaEdge AR100 Head Mounted Display, offering capabilities like document viewing, live video calls, and barcode scanning. It will be available in Q2 2018 starting at $1,899.99.

title: Qualcomm’s chairman steps down, and Intel reportedly considers acquiring Broadcom
summary: Qualcomm's chairman, Paul Jacobs, has stepped down from his executive role and the board chairmanship, a move aimed at appeasing shareholders amidst a hostile takeover bid from Broadcom. Meanwhile, Intel is reportedly considering acquiring Broadcom to prevent a combined Broadcom-Qualcomm entity from dominating the chipmaking industry. This boardroom shuffle and potential acquisition highlight significant shifts in the competitive landscape of the semiconductor sector.

title: Corsair One ELITE Review (W/ i7-8700K and GTX 1080 Ti)
summary: This article reviews the Corsair One Elite, a compact gaming and productivity PC featuring an Intel Core i7-8700K processor and an Nvidia GeForce GTX 1080 Ti. It highlights the system's impressive performance, quiet operation, and clever design despite its higher price point. The review details specifications, benchmarks, and comparisons with rival systems, concluding that it's an excellent choice for users prioritizing small form factor and power over upgradeability.

title: Intel Corporation (INTC) Could Be a Huge Casualty of a China Trade War
summary: Intel Corporation (INTC) could be a major casualty of a U.S.-China trade war despite its recent stock gains, due to its deep ties and significant investments in China. The company's global semiconductor operations make it particularly vulnerable to tariffs and trade conflicts, which could exacerbate its existing challenges. The author argues that instead of being a good buy, INTC is a company in crisis, and a trade war would only worsen its situation.

title: Intel Expands Its 5G Ecosystem With Dell, HP, Lenovo PCs And Spreadtrum Alliance
summary: Intel is significantly expanding its 5G ecosystem, forging partnerships with Dell, HP Inc., and Lenovo to bring 5G connectivity to consumer PCs by late 2019. The company is also collaborating with Spreadtrum to deliver 5G phones and has completed the first public 5G NR interoperability test with Huawei, showcasing its end-to-end leadership in 5G. These strategic alliances highlight Intel's commitment to enabling 5G across various devices and infrastructure components.

title: AMD Ryzen CPUs with integrated Vega graphics are great for budget-friendly PC gaming
summary: AMD's Ryzen CPUs with integrated Vega graphics, specifically the Ryzen 3 2200G and Ryzen 5 2400G, offer a budget-friendly solution for PC gaming, especially for less demanding titles like League of Legends and Overwatch. These APUs leverage the AM4 socket, allowing for future upgrades, and represent a promising future for integrated graphics, enabling gamers to build affordable systems without needing expensive dedicated GPUs.

title: AMD vs. Intel: Two CPU giants are battling it out in 2018, but who will win?
summary: This article discusses the CPU battle between AMD and Intel in 2018, highlighting AMD's resurgence with its Ryzen processors and its push into the mobile computing market. It details Intel's struggles with production processes and AMD's strategic advancements with Ryzen Mobile and Zen architecture, predicting a significant shift in the CPU industry. The author evaluates which company is better positioned for success in the coming year, noting AMD's strong performance in desktop CPUs and its expansion into portable devices.

title: Intel Drone Light Show Breaks Guinness World Records Title at Olympic Winter Games PyeongChang 2018
summary: Intel's Drone Light Show team set a new Guinness World Records title at the Olympic Winter Games PyeongChang 2018 Opening Ceremony by flying 1,218 Intel Shooting Star drones simultaneously. This spectacular performance showcased Intel's advanced drone technology, designed for entertainment light shows with billions of color combinations, transforming the fan experience at the Olympic Games. Intel plans to enhance the Olympic Games through 2024 with its drone technology.

title: Qualcomm and Samsung announce strategic partnership as Apple looks to building its own chips
summary: Qualcomm Technologies and Samsung Electronics have announced a multi-year strategic partnership to transition the industry from 4G to 5G across various mobile devices. This comes as Apple is reportedly developing its own custom chips, potentially reducing its reliance on Qualcomm and Intel for modems. The collaboration aims to leverage both companies' strengths in mobile technology.

title: Former Intel executive Renee James launches Ampere, a new Arm-based server chip company
summary: Former Intel president Renee James has launched Ampere Computing, a new company focused on Arm-based server processors. Ampere has developed "Skylark," a 32-core Arm-based server processor, and aims to challenge Intel's dominance in the data center market at a time when Intel is facing security concerns. The company is backed by The Carlyle Group and plans to ship its chips later this year.

title: AMD earnings cap a stunning 2017, but there is still plenty to do
summary: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) completed its first profitable year since 2011, driven by a strong fourth quarter and a nearly 25% jump in sales in 2017. The company's turnaround gained significant momentum with new Ryzen and Radeon chips, especially in its compute and graphics business. While 2017 was a stunning year, the article suggests that 2018 will be even more critical for AMD to maintain its growth.

title: Cracks surface in the bull trend, S&P 500 pulls in from uncharted territory
summary: The article reports that cracks are beginning to appear in the bull market trend as the S&P 500 pulls back from uncharted territory. This comes at the end of an unusually strong month of January for U.S. stocks, which are now on the defensive. The report also highlights a 45-month high for the 10-year yield and retesting of major support by Apple, while Intel takes flight.

title: Xiaomi, Vivo, Oppo protest Broadcom’s $105 billion Qualcomm bid
summary: Three major Chinese smartphone manufacturers, Xiaomi, Oppo, and Vivo, have voiced their opposition to Broadcom's $105 billion bid to acquire Qualcomm. They argue that such a merger would create a monopoly in the smartphone chip market, stifle innovation, and negatively impact research and development in the wireless technology sector. The companies, heavy users of Qualcomm chips, emphasized their support for Qualcomm against Broadcom's unsolicited acquisition attempt.

title: Intel Corp. Is Now Sampling XMM 7560 LTE Modem
summary: Intel is currently sampling its XMM 7560 cellular modem to multiple customers, with products featuring the modem expected to be available later in 2018. This modem is significant as it supports the CDMA network, a key feature missing from previous Intel modems that limited their market share, particularly with Apple's iPhones. While Intel aims to expand the modem's use beyond smartphones to areas like always-connected PCs and autonomous driving, its primary success in the near future will likely depend on its adoption in upcoming Apple iPhone models due to Apple's large shipment volumes.

title: HP Enterprise launches Intel-powered Customer Experience Centre for IoT, smart cities
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) India, in collaboration with Intel, launched a Customer Experience Centre (CEC) in Gurugram to showcase IoT-based smart city solutions. This center aims to help governments and city administrations implement innovative and interactive services for citizens through IoT, with key solutions including eHealth, Public Wi-Fi, and Integrated Command and Control Centres. The CEC will enable partners and customers to experience cutting-edge technologies for smart city projects across India.

title: Intel’s Tiffany Sargent: The Next Evolution in Computing? It’s On the Edge
summary: Tiffany Sargent, Intel's chief IoT architect for the Americas public sector division, discusses the evolving landscape of computing, particularly focusing on the Internet of Things (IoT) and edge computing. She emphasizes the importance of connectivity, new communication technologies like LoRaWAN, and distributed computation for real-time data processing, especially for government applications. Sargent also highlights the critical need for industry collaboration and shared data frameworks to advance IoT ecosystems.

title: Computer Vision Company Announces Collaboration with Nvidia, Stock Rallies
summary: Foresight Autonomous Holdings Ltd. (Nasdaq-listed) announced that its affiliate, Rail Vision Ltd., is collaborating with Nvidia Corporation on system development, causing Foresight's stock to jump 18%. Foresight also increased its stake in Rail Vision to 32.62% and announced new pilot agreements with Chinese car manufacturers, while Nvidia expands its presence in the autonomous vehicle market, competing with Mobileye. Rail Vision, which develops an automated early warning system for locomotives, is pursuing European licensing and completed significant investment rounds in 2017.

title: Intel’s New Chip Aims For Quantum Supremacy
summary: Intel has announced a 49-qbit quantum computing chip, which brings the company close to achieving "quantum supremacy," a milestone where a quantum computer can solve problems beyond a classical supercomputer's capability. This development, following advances by IBM and Google, signifies a step closer to mainstream quantum computing, despite the current research-project status and error propensity of these early machines.

title: Intel Partners with BMW, Nissan, SAIC Motor, Volkswagen, Paramount Pictures, Ferrari North America to Showcase Power of Data at CES
summary: During his CES 2018 keynote, Intel CEO Brian Krzanich detailed how data is transforming various industries, from autonomous driving with partners like BMW, Nissan, and Volkswagen, to AI applications with Ferrari North America. He also introduced Intel Studios for immersive media and highlighted advancements in neuromorphic and quantum computing, emphasizing data's role in future innovations.

title: Intel Shares Fall as Investors Worry About Costs of Chip Flaw
summary: Intel's shares fell due to investor concerns about the financial and reputational fallout from recently disclosed security flaws in its microprocessors. The flaws could allow hackers to steal sensitive information, leading to potential lawsuits and demands for compensation from major customers. The incident is also expected to increase Intel's chip development spending on security and could lead cloud companies to seek lower chip prices.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Meltdown and Spectre are huge vulnerabilities for Intel and others: What you need to know
summary: Two serious security vulnerabilities named Meltdown and Spectre have been discovered in most computer chip designs, causing the tech industry to scramble for solutions. While software updates are being pushed for one issue, the other remains unfixed. Intel has acknowledged the major vulnerability impacting systems with its microprocessors designed over the last decade.

title: Intel admits vulnerability, but plays down effects; stock slides, AMD gains
summary: Intel Corp. acknowledged a vulnerability in its chips requiring software patches, while disputing reports that the flaw is unique to its products and would significantly impact performance. The company's stock experienced its worst day in eight months, though it pared earlier losses. Rival Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD) stated there was a "near zero" chance its chips would be affected.

title: Hacking fears: Security flaws put virtually all phones, computers at risk
summary: Security researchers have disclosed major flaws, Meltdown and Spectre, affecting chips from Intel, AMD, and ARM, which could allow hackers to steal sensitive information from nearly all modern computing devices. While Meltdown, specific to Intel, is more severe in the short term but patchable, Spectre affects a broader range of devices and is harder to fix, posing a long-term challenge. Companies like Intel, ARM, Google, Apple, and Microsoft are working on and releasing patches, though some suggest potential performance impacts on Intel chips.

title: Intel's CEO reportedly sold shares after the company already knew about massive security flaws
summary: Intel CEO Brian Krzanich sold a significant portion of his company shares after Intel was reportedly made aware of serious security flaws, reducing his stake to the bare minimum required for an Intel CEO. While the sales were part of a pre-planned trading strategy (10b5-1 plan), the timing raised questions as Intel and other chipmakers knew about the vulnerabilities months earlier. These flaws, known as Meltdown and Spectre, affect almost all computer processors and could allow data theft.

title: Intel Confirms Long-Standing Microprocessor Chip Hacking Vulnerability
summary: Intel confirmed a security vulnerability in its microprocessor chips, affecting devices dating back to 1995, which could allow hackers to obtain personal information. The flaw, also found in chips by Arm and AMD, exploits predictive processing algorithms. While Intel asserts the exploits cannot corrupt or delete data, the initial patch is expected to slow operating times, and the company is working with others to provide updates.
